Text: Deborah Orr's column in Saturday's Guardian highlights the counterproductive nature of demonizing the privileged, and rightfully so. However, she is incorrect in her assertion that abolishing private education is a futile cause. The systemic and unfair entrenchment of privilege through private education is morally wrong and distorts our society, often to a grotesque extent. This argument must continue to be made, without resorting to name-calling, until there is a consensus among both the disadvantaged 93% and the privileged 7% that we need to adopt a new approach.

"Take a closer look at the small C4 corner with a magnifying glass. The channel is facing unwarranted and unwanted privatization. Its outgoing chairman, Terry Burns, fought hard to stay on, but the government declined to extend his tenure. As a result, Charles Gurassa, the deputy chairman of easyJet and a seasoned executive, has been appointed to take his place. The C4 board may not have a leg to stand on, but what qualifications does Gurassa bring to the table? He boasts an impressive track record, having served as chairman, director, or non-executive director of 27 companies since 2003. Gurassa has a wealth of experience, but it's largely in the private sector. Prior to his current role, he was a director of leisure services at British Airways and has experience in the travel industry. However, he has no experience in television, apart from watching Richard Branson sell Virgin Mobile to NTL and overseeing the sale of LoveFilm to Amazon. In short, he's skilled at selling companies, not producing TV content. Ofcom and Downing Street have endorsed Gurassa's appointment, replacing a chairman who was a late convert to the Awkward Squad. It's possible that David Cameron will follow a similar precedent when selecting a new BBC chairman. Heaven help the ideals of independent public service. We can only hope that Mr. Gurassa will uphold these values, but it's hard to hold our breath."

It's tempting to think that the worst is behind us, at least for now. The recent rally in global stock markets, sparked by the Bank of Japan's decision to cut interest rates, has brought relief to many in the financial community. Oil prices, which plummeted to $27 (£19) a barrel just a fortnight ago, have risen to $34, up 40 cents on the day. However, the reality is quite the opposite. Investors are concerned that governments and central banks have yet to grasp the true extent of the global economic weakness, seven years after the financial crisis. The situation is precarious, with China's private debt levels reaching dangerous heights, Europe's banking system still reeling from bad debts, and consumers worldwide exhibiting nervous behavior. When a central bank acknowledges the importance of cheap money in driving investment and growth, investors rejoice. But when central bankers suggest that the world is recovering and ready for higher interest rates, investors panic. It's no wonder, given the recent reaction to the US Federal Reserve's smallest possible interest rate hike, which sent American consumers scrambling to stash their savings. New car sales declined in December, and consumer sentiment dipped in January, following a weak fourth quarter. The Fed noted that even a small rate hike would likely be ignored by US consumers, who are as resilient as Arnold Schwarzenegger's Terminator. The Bank of Japan's interest rate cut is another sign of global economic weakness. Tokyo aims to generate domestic growth after 25 years of stagnation and has introduced a negative interest rate, effectively charging deposits, to deter foreign funds and encourage domestic spending. The move has had the desired effect, with the yen falling against the dollar. We'll need to wait and see how this affects domestic demand. Meanwhile, the Bank of England has already put aside its hopes of following the Fed's lead. Governor Mark Carney previously hinted that a UK interest rate hike might be imminent, but those comments are now a thing of the past. His recent speeches suggest a more cautious tone. Given the Federal Reserve's potential struggles to increase interest rates by half a percentage point this year, largely due to concerns about the dollar's strength, it's unlikely that the UK would consider such a move. A rate hike would cause the pound to surge, making exports uncompetitive in foreign markets and leaving domestic businesses vulnerable to cheap imports. Carney is well aware that the recent closure of the Scunthorpe steel plant, a casualty of cheap Chinese steel imports, is just the beginning of the potential consequences.

Card Factory, a leading retailer of discounted greeting cards, has found a way to circumvent the UK government's 5p bag tax by removing the handles from thousands of its carrier bags. The 5p charge, which was introduced in October, applies to thin-gauge bags with handles from large retailers, with the revenue going to charity. However, Card Factory has confirmed that it is not charging for bags without handles, citing a clarification from the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. While the retailer still offers some bags with handles for the standard 5p fee, it has removed the handles from thousands of bags to provide customers with a free alternative. The bag tax was introduced in England to align with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, which already have similar levies in place. Since the tax was introduced, retailers like Tesco have reported significant reductions in single-use bag usage, with Asda noting a decline of over 90% in Northern Ireland, Wales, and Scotland. However, there have also been reports of thousands of bags being stolen by shoppers attempting to avoid the charge.

A primary school in Pontardawe has implemented a complete ban on chocolate due to a severe allergy affecting one of its pupils. The allergy is so severe that even being in the same room as someone eating chocolate poses a threat to the child's health. In a letter to parents, Alltwen primary school's headteacher, Owain Hyett, explained that the school will be completely chocolate-free, including the staff room and office, to ensure the pupil's safety. The school has also asked parents to remove all traces of chocolate from their children's bags and to avoid packing chocolate products in their lunches. The catering department is working to replace chocolate products on the school menu, and staff will be responsible for ensuring that all areas of the school remain chocolate-free. The decision has sparked controversy among some parents, who feel that they were not consulted and that the ban is too broad. One parent questioned the practicality of the ban, asking how staff would enforce it and whether they would have to inspect lunchboxes for chocolate. The ban is part of a growing trend of schools taking steps to accommodate children with severe allergies, including a recent ban on birthday cakes in a Lancashire school. Many primary schools and nurseries have already implemented bans on nuts, such as peanuts and almonds, due to the rising prevalence of nut intolerance among children. In England, national regulations have prompted many schools to prohibit crisps and chocolate from being brought into lunchboxes due to health concerns. Specifically, a primary school in Kent is one of the institutions that has taken this step, going so far as to ban fruit juice from being brought in due to its high sugar content.

Workers at the 246-year-old Shepton Mallet cider mill in Somerset, which is facing potential closure, will gather on Friday to discuss their future. The UK's largest union, Unite, is urging potential buyers to step forward and acquire the site to protect the 120-strong workforce and preserve a cider-making tradition that dates back to 1770. Unite emphasizes that the site is profitable and has been so for many years. The workers will meet at the Kilver Street cider mill at 11am to plan their campaign to save the site. Two weeks ago, the mill's Irish owner, C&C, announced plans to close the site, which produces well-known brands such as Gaymers, Blackthorn, and Ye Olde English. C&C, which also produces Bulmers and Magners cider in Ireland, attributed the decision to tough competition in the UK and Ireland over recent years. Although C&C plans to continue sourcing apples from Somerset farmers and processing them in Shepton Mallet before shipping them to Ireland for canning, bottling, and kegging, Unite hopes that a similar drinks manufacturer will take over the site to prevent its planned closure at the end of the summer.

The UK's first new nuclear power plants in decades are facing fresh delays due to reports that French energy giant EDF is uncertain about financing the £18 billion project. Directors were set to meet this week to approve a plan to build two nuclear reactors at Hinkley Point in Somerset, but a final decision has been pending since October. During a visit to the UK by Chinese Premier Xi Jinping, China's state nuclear firm CGN agreed to take a 33.5% stake in the project. However, EDF executives have delayed a final decision due to funding issues, according to French financial journal Les Echos. The company is reportedly seeking help from the French government to find new backers to join the project alongside CGN. Although directors are scheduled to discuss the issue at a board meeting on Wednesday, no decision is expected until the next meeting, which will take place before the release of final results on February 15. EDF has declined to comment on the matter. The opening of Hinkley Point C has been delayed twice, from 2017 to 2025, and the UK government has faced criticism for agreeing to pay EDF £92.50 per unit of electricity, more than double the market rate. A group of EDF employee-shareholders has also urged the company to abandon the Hinkley project, citing concerns that it could put the company's survival at risk. Green campaigners argue that any fresh delay highlights the flaws in a deal intended to kickstart a new generation of nuclear power in the UK. "The EDF board is clearly rattled by this crucial investment decision," said John Sauven, executive director of Greenpeace. "This delay could signal the end of Hinkley." Sauven added that EDF managers and employee representatives on the board are concerned that the project is too risky and too expensive. He also criticized former Chancellor George Osborne for defending the Hinkley project.

My father, Tony Buffery, passed away at the age of 76, leaving behind a legacy as a renowned neuropsychologist. Clive James once described him as having a "mind from outer space," a testament to his innovative thinking. Tony's early years were marked by his time at Cambridge University in the 1960s, where he was a member of the prestigious Footlights and Beyond the Fringe revues. He began his career as a writer and performer, showcasing his comedic talents alongside future Monty Python members John Cleese, Eric Idle, and Michael Palin.

Born in Birmingham, Tony was the younger son of Winifred, a typist, and George, a railway worker. He was a large baby, weighing 14 pounds at birth. Tony excelled academically and in sports, particularly the javelin, at Mosley grammar school. He went on to study at Hull University and later earned his PhD at Cambridge, where his thesis was titled "Baboons I Have Known." Comedy remained a passion of his, and he continued to write and perform with his contemporaries, including a two-man show with Clive James at the Edinburgh Festival in 1968.

However, Tony ultimately decided to pursue an academic career, leaving behind his comedic pursuits. He became a fellow of Corpus Christi, Cambridge, and later held positions at Oxford University, the University of London, and the University of Melbourne. His work as a neuropsychologist focused on developing computer programs to aid stroke and brain injury recovery, as well as studying the differences between male and female brains and their impact on cognition, emotions, and behavior.

Tony's papers were published under titles such as "Sex Differences in the Development of Spatial and Linguistic Skills." After a period of poor health, he met Maria Kowalska in New York and married her in 2006. "He spent 10 joyful years in Poland, where he taught English, honed his writing skills, and enjoyed watching movies and cricket. Tony leaves behind Maria, his partner; five children from his previous marriages - Ian, Abigail, Ariadne, Adam, and [your name]; and eight grandchildren, a legacy of his life."

Amazon is venturing into the grocery market after reaching a deal to sell Morrisons food. However, this is not the only initiative the company is pursuing: Amazon Fashion is in talks with Frances Russell, the former head of Marks & Spencer's womenswear, to join the company and is planning to launch its own clothing brand. The hire would be a significant coup for Amazon as it seeks to establish credibility in the clothing industry. Amazon Pay Monthly, a new service, quietly launched in the UK at the start of the year and has the potential to significantly boost sales. The service allows customers to pay for orders over £250 in monthly instalments for up to four years, with interest-free options available for purchases over £400 and £1,000. Otherwise, interest is charged at 16.9%. Amazon has opened its first physical bookshop in Seattle, its hometown, and is considering opening hundreds more. The shop stocks around 6,000 titles, curated based on reviews and sales data from Amazon.com. Amazon Prime Air is working to deliver orders via drones within 30 minutes, pending regulatory approval. The company is investing heavily in speeding up delivery times, with founder Jeff Bezos leading the effort. In the US, Amazon Fresh, the company's full grocery service, is available in several cities, including Seattle and New York, allowing customers to purchase items from local bakeries and butchers, as well as global brands. While Amazon Fresh has not launched in the UK, the company offers food delivery through Prime Now and Pantry, which allows households to regularly stock up on a range of products.

Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou, a major shareholder of Fastjet and founder of EasyJet, has called for the dismissal of the airline's directors, citing concerns over costs. In a letter to Fastjet's chairman, Haji-Ioannou, who owns a 12% stake in the company, demanded the immediate removal of CEO Ed Winter and another director, Krista Bates, from the main board. He claimed that the company has a high cost base, with Winter having burned through £80m in the past three years, and warned that the company will run out of cash by 2016 unless drastic action is taken. Haji-Ioannou has been critical of Fastjet's management, including its decision to establish a head office at London Gatwick, which he claims is a high-cost location that is far from the airline's main operations and customers in Tanzania. He also believes that Fastjet's revenue forecasts are unrealistic, particularly given its small fleet of six aircraft. Fastjet launched in 2012 with domestic flights in Tanzania and has since expanded to other African countries, but its shares have plummeted to a record low after a profit warning in December.

Capita's shares are continuing to decline as analysts downgrade their recommendations following the company's recent results and the announcement that its chairman is stepping down. The stock is currently down nearly 3% at £10.01. Berenberg has reduced its target price to £10.90 from £11.60, with a hold rating, while Panmure Gordon is maintaining its sell advice. According to Panmure analyst Michael Donnelly, the significant decline in the share price following Capita's preliminary results and the departure of its chairman, Martin Bolland, does not yet reflect the increased risk in the business. Donnelly believes that the company's free cash flow growth rate of 4% compound annual growth rate is not sufficient and advises investors to sell. He has reduced his target price to 900p (12.2 times PE) from 1000p due to higher net debt and lower free cash flow, and expresses concerns about goodwill, growth, cash, and the quality of earnings. Donnelly also expects further impairment charges, following Capita's announcement of £105m in impairment charges from two divisions. Berenberg, on the other hand, notes that Capita's 2015 results were largely in line with expectations, driven by 4% organic growth and a 20 basis point underlying margin expansion. However, the company faces significant challenges in 2016, with only one quarter of its growth visibility and declining returns and free cash flow generation. As a result, Berenberg is maintaining its hold recommendation.

Glencore, a multinational mining company, has launched a legal challenge against the Australian government to reduce port access fees. In a recent filing with the Australian Competition Tribunal, Glencore Coal argued that the increased fees to enter the newly privatized Newcastle port, which produces over 170 million tonnes of coal annually, will significantly impact the profit margins of coal producers. The company's appeal comes amid declining share prices and job cuts in its zinc production operations worldwide. The challenge follows the New South Wales government's decision to privatize the Newcastle port as part of a joint venture with Hastings Fund Management and China Merchants, which subsequently increased port fees by 40-60% for vessels accessing the shipping channel. The Australian Competition Tribunal will review a 2015 decision by the then-acting treasurer, Mathias Cormann, who declined to declare the port's fees as excessive. If Glencore's appeal is successful, it would allow the company to refer the access dispute to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission for arbitration, potentially leading to lower port fees. The tribunal battle will focus on technical issues related to competition laws, but it also touches on two critical policy areas: the privatization of state assets and concerns about price increases, as well as the long-term viability of coal mining ventures in Australia. In its tribunal documents, Glencore argues that the port's unconstrained pricing and monopoly over access to the port create uncertainty for coal producers and acquirers in the Hunter Valley. The company claims that the port's monopoly power will significantly impact the profit margins of coal producers operating in the Hunter Valley, particularly in the current operating environment where many mines are cash flow negative. The Australian government has yet to respond to Glencore's application. The case will also test the limited types of review available to the Australian Competition Tribunal in "access" cases, as established by new legislation in 2012. Glencore's financial struggles began shortly after its initial public offering (IPO) in 2011, when the company listed on the stock market. Initially, the share price was strong, but it has since plummeted due to the sharp decline in commodity prices.

McVitie's ginger nuts are set to return to store shelves after a three-month hiatus caused by flooding at a Carlisle factory. United Biscuits, the parent company of McVitie's, Carr's, and Jacob's, has informed its retail clients - including Tesco, Sainsbury's, Morrisons, and Asda - that ginger nut supplies will be available from mid-March. According to a company spokesperson, McVitie's ginger nuts will start appearing on shelves around March 11-12, although availability may vary depending on the retailer. Supermarkets have been out of stock of McVitie's ginger nuts and Carr's water biscuits since January, and were running low on custard creams and bourbons after the factory was inundated with 5ft of floodwater on December 5. The Carlisle-based factory, which is the second-largest biscuit factory in Europe, supplies the UK and other countries worldwide. The company resumed production of its McVitie's Gold bars in January, after a five-week cleaning and repair process. Currently, four of the factory's eight ovens are operational, with ginger nuts being the first main biscuit line to be produced. The factory is expected to produce 7 million ginger nuts daily to meet demand, with bourbons, custard creams, and boasters to follow a couple of weeks later. Carr's water biscuits, which require the factory's special brick ovens and local spring water, are expected to be the last biscuit line to return to production, likely by the end of March. United Biscuits' manufacturing director, Mark Taylor, expressed satisfaction with the progress made, stating that production had resumed more quickly than expected. "We're delighted with progress," Taylor said. "We started slowly to iron out any issues, and we're not yet at full speed." Around 400 staff, contractors, and suppliers are currently working at the factory, approximately half its usual workforce. In January, United Biscuits caused a commotion when it was compelled to acknowledge that it had been unable to locate alternative production facilities after the flood, resulting in a shortage of some popular biscuits. The company responded by placing a tongue-in-cheek advertisement in the newspaper, headlined "Flooding in water biscuit factory. Oh the irony." The ad acknowledged the significant damage sustained by the factory and the devastating impact of the heavy rain on the local community. Notably, this was not the first time the Carlisle factory had been affected by flooding; it had previously been hit in 2005, but was able to reopen thanks to a £1m government grant. According to Taylor, United Biscuits is currently exploring options with other manufacturers, including those in Thailand and Cockermouth, Cumbria, to enhance the Carlisle factory's flood defenses.

British Airways' parent company, International Airlines Group (IAG), reported a 64% increase in full-year profits for 2015, reaching €1.8 billion (£1.4 billion), largely due to decreasing fuel prices. The company, which includes Iberia, Vueling, Aer Lingus, and British Airways, expects to boost operating profits by approximately €1 billion in 2016. According to Chief Executive Willie Walsh, the results significantly surpass the targets set in 2011 when British Airways merged with Iberia. Walsh noted that while 2015 was a successful year, it was also marked by extreme volatility in currency and fuel markets. He attributed the benefits of lower fuel prices to being partially offset by the strengthening US dollar.

Walsh revealed that fuel unit costs, calculated by distance and seats flown, have decreased by 17%, thanks to hedging. When asked about the potential impact of the British EU referendum on IAG, Walsh stated that the company had conducted a risk analysis and did not foresee any material risks to its business. He emphasized that IAG is a global business with global ambitions, and the referendum's outcome would not alter its perspective.

While acknowledging that consumers have benefited from open aviation in the EU, Walsh expressed that IAG does not expect the referendum's outcome to affect fares. Unlike Ryanair, IAG will not take a stance on the vote, believing it is best left to the electorate. However, Walsh personally supports Europe but believes it needs reform. "I am pro-Europe from a personal perspective," he said, "and I see the benefits it has brought. However, I have significant experience dealing with the European Commission, and Europe needs to be reformed – the concept of being part of a trading area is positive, but it needs to change." "Simultaneously, Walsh cautioned the new Canadian owners of London City airport against increasing landing fees following their £2 billion acquisition from GIP. He emphasized that he would be concerned if they raised prices, and warned that if they did, IAG might reduce the number of flights from City airport. Walsh stressed that IAG is not a captive customer and that its customers have options elsewhere. The company also announced that Javier Sánchez-Prieto has taken over as chairman and CEO of Vueling, replacing Alex Cruz, who will become chairman and CEO of British Airways in April, succeeding Keith Williams."

Oprah Winfrey's partnership with Weight Watchers - is it a lifeline for the struggling weight-loss program or a desperate attempt to revive a dying brand? The company's latest earnings report suggests that the decline in membership has slowed, but it's still losing subscribers. Compared to the same period last year, the number of active subscribers decreased by 4.8%, a slight improvement from the 12.7% drop in the previous quarter. The number of people attending in-person meetings has dropped below the one million mark, with approximately 997,900 members attending meetings in the fourth quarter, down from 1.2 million in December 2013. Meanwhile, the online program has also seen a decline, with 1.39 million subscribers compared to 1.74 million in December 2013. Despite the declining numbers, Weight Watchers CEO Jim Chambers remains optimistic about the company's future, citing the success of its new program, Beyond the Scale, and the strong start to its partnership with Oprah Winfrey. Chambers credits Winfrey's "direct and emotional" announcement about joining the program, as well as her social media updates and anecdotes, with connecting with members and non-members. Winfrey has shared her own weight loss journey, revealing that she lost 26 pounds while still enjoying her favorite foods, including bread, every day. She also hosted a conference call with 4,000 subscribers, which was later replayed for an additional 8,000 listeners. "He emphasized that Winfrey has been a dedicated board member, contributing innovative ideas to the company. Chambers also noted that we're just beginning to see the full extent of Winfrey's involvement. During the investor call, Chambers highlighted a recent study by Indiana University School of Medicine researchers, which found that the Weight Watchers program with a prediabetes-specific component is more effective in helping adults with prediabetes lose weight and manage their blood sugar levels than attempting to do so on their own. According to Chambers, this'science-based evidence' could be a game-changer for Weight Watchers, allowing them to tap into the lucrative corporate wellness market."

The Brit Awards 2016 captivated a massive TV audience of nearly 6 million viewers, with performances by Adele, Rihanna, and a tribute to the late David Bowie generating a Twitter storm. According to ITV, the annual broadcast of the British Phonographic Industry's awards show averaged 5.8 million viewers, accounting for a 27.5% share of all TV viewing between 8pm and 10.20pm on Wednesday night. For the second year, Ant and Dec hosted the event, which matched the popularity of the previous year's ceremony, which was notable for Madonna's infamous tumble down a flight of stairs. A major Twitter promotion helped fuel an astonishing 7.5 million tweets about the show, with Adele's acceptance of the global success award sparking the peak rate of tweets at 55,000 per minute at 9.25pm. The most-talked-about individuals on Twitter were One Direction band members Louis Tomlinson and Liam Payne, with Adele coming in third. Just two years prior, the ceremony had generated more than 4 million posts on the social media site. Despite facing stiff competition from the final of BBC1's The Great Sport Relief Bake Off, which drew an average of 5.4 million TV viewers and a 24.7% share between 8pm and 9pm, the Brits managed to win their slot. In 2014, the Brits experienced a significant decline in viewers, with 4.6 million tuning in, matching the record low set in 2006. The event's biggest recent audience was 7.3 million in 2003, and 6.5 million viewers tuned in the following year in 2013.

Tinder has discovered a new way for men to boost their chances of success on the dating app: by becoming a licensed pilot after logging 1,500 hours of flight time. According to the company's research, pilots are the most popular profession among men on Tinder, followed by entrepreneurs, firefighters, doctors, and TV personalities. For women, the top professions are physical therapists, interior designers, entrepreneurs, PR/communications workers, and teachers. Interestingly, models rank eighth among men and tenth among women, with dental hygienists just one spot behind in the women's list - suggesting that a bright smile can be a major asset on Tinder. The study also found that students are a popular group on the app, with college students ranking tenth among men and sixth among women. Tinder's initial growth, like Facebook's, was driven by university students in the US. The study was based on US Tinder users and was conducted after the company added the option to include professions and education on profiles in November 2015. The company is encouraging users to fill out this information, promising that adding a profession will increase the chances of receiving a "right swipe". With pilots being the most right-swiped profession, it seems that looking convincing in a pilot's cap is a major bonus. Tinder has been working to change its reputation from a hookup app to a long-term matchmaking tool. According to CEO Sean Rad, a survey of over 300,000 users found that over 80% of users are looking for a long-term relationship.

I recently purchased a Burghley armchair from Lloyd Loom of Spalding, along with a seat pad, for £420 via bank transfer. The chair was delivered on December 4, but without the cushion. The company informed me that there had been a slight delay in obtaining the fabric, but assured me that it would arrive by early the following week and definitely by Christmas. Unfortunately, I did not receive the cushion. I have since discovered that Lloyd Loom has ceased trading at its Spalding premises and shipped its machinery and tools to Romania before Christmas. The cushion cost £72.50, a relatively small amount compared to the potential losses of former employees. I am wondering if I can get my money back. Unfortunately, it seems unlikely. If I had paid by credit card, I would have been able to claim from the card provider. Since I paid by bank transfer, I have no protection. It's worth noting that paying by bank transfer for goods to be delivered later can leave consumers vulnerable to this kind of situation. At least I have the chair.

Reddit users have rallied around a New Zealand student, Melody Madill, who had a severe epileptic seizure while home alone. Madill was Skyping her fiancée, Anna Messner, in the US, when she began to seize. Messner was helpless to assist, as she was thousands of miles away. "I was terrified," Messner said. "I had never seen her twitch and flail so violently, or her mouth foam and her lips turn blue." Desperate, Messner called the US emergency number 911, but was told they couldn't assist with overseas medical emergencies. Messner tried to rouse Madill, screaming and begging her to stay with her. When that didn't work, Messner turned to Reddit, posting a plea for help: "Mayday need someone to call 111." Within 10 minutes, Christchurch resident Jana Hayes responded, calling 111 and arranging for an ambulance to be sent to Madill's home. Hayes returned to Reddit to update the community on the situation, saying she was initially skeptical but glad she had helped. It took 45 minutes from the start of the seizure for the paramedics to arrive at Madill's house. Messner, still on Skype, heard the paramedics knock on the door and alerted them to Madill's location in her study. "My brother advised me to start shouting 'help' as that would grab their attention even more. Eventually, Madill got up and let the paramedics in," said Madill. She described the incident as "very confusing" because the last thing she remembered was talking to her fiancé, and then the paramedics were knocking on her window. Madill has been diagnosed with epilepsy since childhood, but hasn't had a seizure in 10 years. She praised Anna's quick thinking, saying, "I'm incredibly proud and grateful for what Anna did." Madill was relieved that Hayes, who had been in touch with her fiancé on Facebook, had the faith to lend a hand and didn't dismiss the Reddit post as a hoax. Online, Hayes is now being hailed as a "life saver."

The London property market is notoriously challenging to break into, but a recent auction sale took the concept of "digging deep" to a whole new level. A vacant front basement in New Eltham, south London, was put up for sale, marketed as a redevelopment opportunity for investors willing to take a risk on securing the necessary planning consents. Due to the lack of access, potential buyers were informed that there would be no internal viewings, as the space required excavation before it could be inspected. The leasehold for the basement, located beneath flats in New Eltham, was listed with Auction House at a guide price of £25,000 and eventually sold for £27,000. The property was sold by the freeholder, who is not the first to realize the potential value of the land beneath their buildings. In fact, another unexcavated basement in Croydon sold ahead of the auction, with planning permission already submitted. According to Andrew Binstock, an auctioneer, these types of properties are becoming increasingly common in his auction rooms. "It's like selling roof space above a property, except this is the gravel underneath," he said. The idea is that the buyer will apply for planning permission, knowing that the freeholder's consent is already given. Chris Coleman-Smith, an auctioneer at Savills, noted that some investors are willing to speculate on these kinds of properties, particularly in central London where development opportunities are scarce. "If they come off, great," he said. "It's probably a lot of aggravation to get to that point, but if you can pull it off, it's worth it." For context, two flats in a neighboring building in New Eltham sold for £180,000 and £215,000 in 2015, making this potential redevelopment a potentially lucrative opportunity if planning permits.

Trinity Mirror's new national title, the New Day, is set to launch on Monday, but Scots may struggle to find a copy, with only a limited number being made available in Edinburgh. The 25p weekday newspaper is expected to have a large print run of up to 2 million, but Scotland will receive only a fraction of that, with estimates ranging from 1,000 to 3,000 copies. The initial print run will be free on Monday, with 2,000 copies available in Edinburgh from Tuesday, and the price will rise to 50p two weeks after launch. Industry insiders believe the strategy is designed to protect Trinity Mirror's Daily Record, which sells 171,000 copies a day, making it the second best-selling newspaper in Scotland after the Sun. The small number of New Day copies being sent to Scotland are being transported from Oldham to Edinburgh, and a media source has described the move as "prioritising the Daily Record". The newspaper's spokeswoman explained that the limited launch in Scotland is due to the need to build up the title's Scottish content, and that there will be a phased roll-out of the New Day's distribution in Scotland as the brand expands. Despite the low number of copies heading to Scotland, Northern Ireland is expected to receive around 25,000 copies of the New Day. "Although this new publication is not a direct competitor to the i, it may be a strategic move by Johnston Press to establish a foothold in the market with readers and advertisers before launching its own cut-price i edition in Northern Ireland."

* The top story on MediaGuardian is about the Lords committee, which found no compelling reason to reduce the BBC's scope, and recommended that it continue to be a "universal broadcaster." The committee also criticized the deal to provide free TV licenses to over-75s.
* The most commented-on article on MediaGuardian is about the "hidden stories" that go unreported, which journalist Gary Younge explored in his James Cameron lecture.

Mashable, a digital media company, has secured approximately £10 million in a partnership deal with Turner, owner of CNN. As part of the agreement, Turner's TBS and TNT businesses will collaborate with Mashable to co-develop and distribute video content. The partnership will also grant Turner Entertainment access to Mashable's Velocity platform, an analytics tool that predicts social media trends. Additionally, Mashable will distribute some of Turner's shows and create opportunities for cross-promotion. Kevin Reilly, Chief Creative Officer of Turner Entertainment and President of TBS and TNT, will join Mashable's board of directors. Mashable plans to use the funding to expand its video services, including linear TV, and focus on growing its branded video division.

Mashable's CEO and founder, Pete Cashmore, expressed his excitement about the partnership, stating that technology is the current driving force behind creative pursuits and that Mashable's unique blend of tech credibility and cultural influence makes it an attractive partner for the future of media. Cashmore also highlighted the potential for innovative TV programming, citing Turner's reputation as a top-rated cable network as the perfect partner to bring fresh digital and cultural perspectives to television.

Mashable recently launched its own studios division, creating serialized video programming and branded entertainment for its website. The company has seen a significant increase in video production over the past year, with a doubling of output. In a separate deal, Mashable partnered with France 24, the international news and current affairs public service broadcaster, to launch a French-language version of its social media news site.

A pair of MPs has proposed transforming the BBC into a mutual organization, where its board is elected by licence fee payers. Labour's Gareth Thomas and Conservative MP Steve Baker argue that this would bring more direct ownership and accountability to the broadcaster, rather than the current system, which allows for excessive government interference. In a letter to the Times, Thomas and Baker wrote that the BBC is a "public service" broadcaster, but its ownership and accountability are unclear. They argued that the BBC Trust, which is responsible for governing the broadcaster, is accountable to no one, creating a vacuum that allows government interference to occur. A mutual organization is owned by its members, such as employees or customers, rather than outside investors. Thomas and Baker believe that the current proposals, which would give the government more control over the BBC, do not address the issues of ownership and accountability. Instead, they propose mutualizing the BBC, which would give licence fee payers a direct say in the organization's governance. "Becoming members and owners of the BBC would enable TV licence holders to address the ownership deficit. As members, they would elect representatives to hold the executive management accountable for their actions. Key issues like executive compensation and resource allocation would be decided at an Annual General Meeting (AGM) that would be open to all members, either in person or online. This would fill the accountability gap and provide a strong defense against political interference. Mutualising the BBC would not only lend credibility to the licence fee, but also foster a sense of unity between the BBC and its audience, which is essential for the BBC's success."

This week, the cost of a first-class stamp will increase to 64p, marking a 100% price hike over the past decade. The price of first-class stamps will rise by 1p, while second-class stamps will also increase by the same amount to 55p. The cost of stamps for large letters weighing up to 100g will rise by 1p to 96p for first-class postage. In April 2006, a first-class stamp cost 32p, while a second-class stamp has more than doubled in price to its current rate. If a first-class stamp had kept pace with RPI inflation, the cost would now be around 43p. Royal Mail has stated that it carefully considered the impact of price increases on customers and its own business before applying the "smallest possible increase". The company notes that the UK's first-class stamp price remains lower than the European average of 78p and less than the 64p average for second-class letters. However, Royal Mail argues that the price increases are necessary to fund the universal service obligation, which ensures mail delivery across the country six days a week at a flat rate. Nevertheless, the charity Citizens Advice has expressed disappointment that the price rise exceeds inflation, despite appearing modest.

Six major American technology companies - Facebook, Google, Microsoft, Twitter, Yahoo, and Apple - have come together to urge significant changes to the Investigatory Powers bill, also known as the "snooper's charter". The companies warn that the bill, as it stands, could set dangerous precedents that may be replicated elsewhere and have far-reaching consequences for all parties, both in the UK and internationally. In a joint submission to the public bill committee, the companies express concerns that the bill's attempts to establish extraterritorial jurisdiction could allow the UK to force companies to comply even if they are not based in the country. They argue that this approach is unnecessary, as international agreements could achieve the same goal. The companies also criticize the bill for its lack of clear guidelines on how to handle encrypted communications. Specifically, they argue that the bill should include an explicit threshold for when a service can be required to provide decrypted content, rather than leaving it to be determined on a case-by-case basis. For companies that offer end-to-end encryption, such as Apple's iMessage or Facebook's WhatsApp, this could require a complete overhaul of their services. Apple and its colleagues submitted a statement to the government, urging it to clarify that actions taken under authorization do not introduce new risks or vulnerabilities for users or businesses, and emphasizing that eliminating vulnerabilities is a shared goal with the UK government. Although all the firms had previously criticized the snoopers charter in December, with Apple submitting a separate brief from its competitors, there was little evidence that the government had addressed their concerns when the final version of the bill was introduced in early March. Eric King, director of the Don't Spy on Us coalition, described the changes as "cosmetic tweaks" and warned that the bill was being rushed through without sufficient time for proper scrutiny. The Web Foundation, founded by Tim Berners-Lee, inventor of the world wide web, condemned the final bill as "a slap in the face for British democracy".

A professor at Princeton University has taken an unconventional approach to sharing his career setbacks with the world. Johannes Haushofer, an assistant professor of psychology and public affairs, posted his CV listing his career failures on Twitter, in an effort to "balance the record" and encourage others to persevere in the face of disappointment.

The unusual CV, which Haushofer posted last week, features sections titled "Degree programs I did not get into," "Research funding I did not get," and "Paper rejections from academic journals." It also includes "Academic positions and fellowships I did not get" and "Awards and scholarships I did not get."

Haushofer created the document to "give some perspective" on the reality of academic failure. "Most of what I try fails, but these failures are often invisible, while the successes are visible," he wrote. "I have noticed that this sometimes gives others the impression that most things work out for me. As a result, they are more likely to attribute their own failures to themselves, rather than the fact that the world is stochastic, applications are crapshoots, and selection committees and referees have bad days."

Haushofer credited an article by Melanie Stefan, an academic at Edinburgh University, with inspiring his idea. The CV of failures quickly gained traction on Twitter, with many praising it as "inspiring," "brilliant," and "beautiful."

However, Haushofer's effort to share his failures with the world ultimately led to a "meta-failure." "This darn CV of Failures has received way more attention than my entire body of academic work," he joked.

Evian's "Baby Surfers" (starting at 00:04) is a quirky commercial that tells the story of a surfer who washes up on the shore, only to discover he's being cared for by babies. The ad, created by BETC and directed by James Rouse, is a humorous take on the brand's typical style.

The Natural Resources Defense Council's "The Extraordinary Life and Times of Strawberry" (starting at 01:42) is a captivating film that follows the life of a strawberry from seed to plate. With its fast-paced editing and engaging narrative, the ad effectively conveys the message about food waste. Sapient Nitro and director Martin Stirling collaborated on this project.

Com Hem's "Astronaut" (starting at 03:40) is a heartwarming commercial that celebrates childhood imagination. Set to Lou Reed's "Satellite of Love," the ad showcases a young girl's fantasy of becoming an astronaut, brought to life through impressive in-camera trickery and VFX. M & C Saatchi and director Tobias Granström worked together on this project.

Ikea's "Wonderful Life" (starting at 04:44) is a charming ad that suggests we're all on our own life adventure. The commercial, created by Mother and directed by Gary Freedman, features a young couple who imagine themselves as racing drivers and tennis players, highlighting the idea that our imagination can shape our reality.

Jason Stone is the editor of David Reviews.

Two New York Times employees are suing the newspaper, alleging that it fosters a discriminatory environment based on age, race, and gender. This development comes as Curt Schilling, a former ESPN commentator, accused the sports channel of racism, citing his own recent termination due to transphobic comments on Facebook. The prevalence of racism in the media is often linked to the lack of diversity within the industry. The notion that the workforce in US media does not represent the population is not a new one. In 1968, the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders found that the media reported and wrote from a predominantly white perspective, with fewer than 5% of editorial staff members being African American. This figure has barely changed over the years. According to statistics from the American Society of News Editors (ASNE), in 2015, only 4.7% of newsroom employees were African American, despite making up 13.2% of the US population. Similarly, Asian Americans were underrepresented, making up 5.4% of the adult population but only 2.8% of newsroom staff. Hispanic people comprised just 4% of employees in 2015, compared to 17.4% of the US population. According to an analysis by Alex T. Williams, published in the Columbia Journalism Review, the problem is not a lack of qualified minority candidates, but rather three obstacles that hinder their entry into the media industry: inexperience on campus newspapers, the prevalence of unpaid internships, and a lack of social capital to gain access to hiring networks. A new civil lawsuit against the New York Times this week draws on statistics related to representation. The lawsuit cites a 2014 study by the Women's Media Center, which found that New York Times reporters were 3.5 times more likely to cite men as sources than women. In 2015, the Women's Media Center released a report for the second consecutive year, revealing that the New York Times had the largest gender gap in bylines, with only 32% of articles written by women compared to 68% written by men. The report did not include the Guardian, but a recent analysis of comments found that articles written by men outnumbered those written by women, although this disparity varied significantly by subject. According to human resources data, six out of 10 staff members at Guardian US are women. The figures, which include both editorial and non-editorial staff, show that three quarters of employees are white, 11% are Asian, 6% are black, and 4% are Hispanic.

Australia is experiencing unusually warm weather, which is expected to continue throughout the coming month, according to climate scientists and meteorologists. This unseasonable warmth is a clear sign of the dangerous effects of climate change. The country has been setting temperature records left and right, with February being the most unusually warm month on record and March breaking that record just a short time later. In fact, March 2016 was the warmest March on record in Australia. The Bureau of Meteorology's seasonal outlook predicts that above-average temperatures will continue across the country at least through May.

According to David Karoly, a climate scientist at the University of Melbourne, climate change has increased the likelihood of March breaking temperature records in Australia by at least seven times. "The previous record had a one in 43-year chance of occurring naturally, but now it happens about once every six years due to human-caused climate change," Karoly said. "This is evidence that climate change is already happening and increasing the risks of extreme heat."

Blair Trewin from the Bureau of Meteorology notes that while April may not set a new record, it will still be much warmer than normal. Throughout May, there is an 80% chance that temperatures across most of the country will be warmer than the average from 1961 to 1990. By June and July, coastal regions will continue to experience unusually warm weather, but temperatures will return to normal in central and southern Australia.

The current warm spell is partly due to the monster El Niño event that occurred in 2015, which spread warm water across the Pacific Ocean. However, this is happening on top of the background of global warming, Trewin said. In an El Niño year, the world tends to experience extreme temperatures, while in other years, temperatures are merely above average. "La Niña events were typically followed by normal or slightly cool global temperatures."

Mexican journalist Francisco Pacheco Beltrán was brutally murdered in front of his home in Taxco, Guerrero state, on Monday, according to reports from local press and the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ). Pacheco, 55, was a correspondent for the daily Sol de Acapulco and editor of Foro de Taxco, a weekly magazine, and also contributed to Capital Máxima radio station. He was shot twice in the back of his head when he returned home in the early morning after dropping off one of his daughters at a bus terminal. His daughters, who were at home with their mother at the time of the attack, heard noises that sounded like firecrackers and found their father in a pool of blood. Unfortunately, police reported that there were no witnesses to the murder. Pacheco's work focused on local news and regional crime and violence, and some reports suggest that his reporting was critical of local authorities, particularly the mayor of Taxco. However, his family and colleagues stated that he had not received any threats. The Committee to Protect Journalists has called for a thorough investigation into Pacheco's murder, including any possible links to his work as a journalist. Mexico remains one of the most dangerous countries for journalists to work in, with the "endless cycle of violence" against them having a devastating impact on the local press.

A new coalition of automakers and tech companies, including Google, Uber, Lyft, Ford, and Volvo, is forming to influence US government regulations on self-driving vehicles. The Self-Driving Coalition for Safer Streets, led by former National Highway Traffic Administration administrator David Strickland, aims to bring autonomous vehicles to the road across the US. The coalition argues that self-driving cars will reduce the severity and frequency of crashes, as 94% of car crashes are caused by human error. However, experts warn that tech companies may become better protected under the law than car owners if a self-driving car crashes. This could pose a challenge for personal injury lawyers, who are already concerned about the technology. Accident lawyer Daniel Vega worries that the lobbying group may unfairly protect tech companies and app makers over human car owners, leaving drivers responsible for accidents. Statistician Susan Paddock notes that it's challenging to test self-driving cars to ensure their performance, and that consumers will need to become comfortable with uncertainty before the technology is widely adopted. "Even if autonomous vehicle fleets were to travel 10 million miles, it would still be impossible to draw statistically significant conclusions about their safety and reliability." "Uncertainty persists," she added, "and I'm unsure how the general public will react to this technology." 

In a statement issued on Tuesday, Strickland emphasized that the coalition's goal is to establish a single, national policy for self-driving cars, rather than navigating a patchwork of state regulations. "The widespread adoption of self-driving vehicle technology will undoubtedly lead to safer and less congested roadways in America," Strickland said. "To facilitate the deployment of this innovation, we believe that a clear, federal framework is essential, and the Coalition will work with policymakers to identify effective solutions that meet this goal."

Former Barclays CEO Bob Diamond is part of a consortium that is preparing to bid on the bank's African operations, according to a recent confirmation. The consortium has secured long-term investors and funding, with Diamond stating that there is support for the potential transaction. Diamond made this announcement to investors at Atlas Mara, a London-listed African bank he founded after being forced out of Barclays in 2012 following the Libor-rigging scandal. The involvement of Diamond and the private equity firm Carlyle in the consortium was revealed in a recent stock market announcement by Atlas Mara, which had been the subject of speculation in recent days. Barclays will face questions about its plans to reduce its 62.3% stake in Barclays Africa, which is listed on the Johannesburg stock exchange and operates banks across the African continent, when it releases its first-quarter results on Wednesday. Diamond did not disclose the size of the potential offer for Barclays Africa, but it is expected to require raising around $5 billion (£3.5 billion). Barclays' new CEO Jes Staley announced last month that he wants to reduce the stake in the African business to simplify operations and conserve capital. Atlas Mara, which operates in seven African countries, indicated that it expects to be acquired by the consortium if a deal is reached. If the consortium reaches a definitive agreement with Barclays, Atlas Mara expects to engage in discussions about a potential combination with the consortium. However, due to the complexity of the discussions, there is no guarantee that the proposed transactions, including the potential combination, will be completed. Diamond is working on the consortium with Ashish Thakkar, whose Mara conglomerate also backed the creation of Atlas Mara. Atlas Mara is currently worth a third of its value when it was first listed in December 2013.

Facebook is reportedly developing a standalone camera app, marking its fourth attempt to create such a platform. The app will allow users to seamlessly switch between taking still photos, recording videos, and live streaming, all presented in a camera-first view similar to Snapchat, according to a Wall Street Journal report. Although the app is still in its early stages and may not even launch, its intended purpose is to combat declining personal image and video sharing on the platform and encourage greater adoption of Facebook's Live Video feature. This new app follows three previous attempts by Facebook to create standalone camera apps, including Poke, Slingshot, and Camera. Poke and Slingshot were both inspired by Snapchat, while Camera was an attempt to compete with Instagram. However, Facebook ultimately acquired Instagram for $1 billion in 2012, just before Camera's launch, and subsequently shut it down. Later, Facebook released Poke, a transparent clone of Snapchat's ephemeral messaging feature, but it failed to gain traction. A year later, Facebook made a $3 billion bid to acquire Snapchat, but was rejected. In response, Facebook released Slingshot in 2014, which offered some unique features, such as the ability to request a response from the recipient. However, Slingshot also failed to gain widespread adoption.

Retail mogul Sir Philip Green is facing demands to relinquish his knighthood if he fails to repay dividends received from BHS during his ownership of the company. The call comes as the work and pensions select committee confirms it will investigate the BHS pension scheme's £571m deficit and its impact on the state-backed Pension Protection Scheme. Committee chairman Frank Field plans to summon Green to testify before MPs as part of the inquiry. The collapse of BHS into administration, which puts almost 11,000 jobs at risk, will see the PPF take on the company's pension scheme. The retail sector suffered another blow on Tuesday with the collapse of clothing retailer Austin Reed, threatening over 1,000 jobs. Green and Dominic Chappell, who purchased BHS from Green for £1 in 2015, are facing scrutiny over their management of the retailer. Calculations by The Guardian reveal that Green and his family collected £586m in dividends, rental payments, and interest on loans during their 15-year ownership of BHS. Meanwhile, BHS paid out £25m to Retail Acquisitions, led by Chappell, in the 13 months following the sale, for management fees, salaries, professional fees, and interest on loans. Labour MP John Mann has called on Green to repay £400m in dividends paid out of BHS or relinquish his knighthood. Mann stated: "Sir Philip Green and his family profited greatly from BHS and its hardworking staff. He inherited a company with a healthy pension fund, but upon selling BHS, a significant deficit had emerged. "Given that Green's family has taken £400m from the company, he must be held accountable for the actions taken during his tenure. "A simple and honourable solution to this crisis is for Green to repay the dividends, live up to the name of his new yacht, 'Lionheart', or surrender his knighthood." "The committee must examine the Pension Protection Fund and how the transfer of BHS's pension liabilities will affect the levy increases imposed on other eligible employers to fund the scheme. We will then assess whether the current legislation is robust enough to safeguard the contracts of future pensioners in occupational pension schemes."

Mortgage lending skyrocketed in March, reaching its highest levels since before the financial crisis, as buy-to-let investors and second-home buyers scrambled to beat the stamp duty deadline. According to the British Bankers Association, total lending reached £17.1 billion, a 64% increase from the same period last year and the highest figure since April 2008. In a rush to beat the April deadline, buyers hastily closed property deals, while remortgaging by existing homeowners also surged, driven by the expectation that interest rates will remain low for an extended period. The average mortgage loan size reached a record high of £184,200, surpassing the previous peak of £158,000 in April 2008. However, the lending figures reveal an increasingly imbalanced financial landscape, with borrowing by manufacturers for investment plummeting while buy-to-let speculation has soared. Lending to manufacturing companies, which had been growing at an annual rate of 12% in 2014, has come to a standstill, while construction lending is also declining. Meanwhile, personal borrowing on credit cards continues to rise, with British households making 223 million purchases in March, valued at £12.6 billion. Although the volume of purchases increased by 2%, the value fell by 1% compared to the same period last year. Mortgage brokers are bracing for a decline in lending in April, citing the rush of transactions in March. Adrian Anderson of Anderson Harris noted that while March was a bumper month, he expects April and May's lending figures to be more subdued, as many transactions were brought forward. He also cautioned that the mortgage market is not racing ahead, and that the surge in lending may not be sustained in the short term, as many borrowers still face affordability challenges. While some predict a decline in the housing market, others believe that the EU referendum could benefit first-time buyers. According to Jeremy Leaf, a former RICS chairman and north London estate agent, the withdrawal of investors from the market has created opportunities for first-time buyers. While prices are softening, they haven't dropped dramatically yet. Leaf suggests that prices may continue to soften due to the upcoming Mayoral election and Brexit, which could impact confidence. First-time buyers can take advantage of historically low loan rates, according to Moneyfacts, a data provider. The average two-year fixed mortgage rate has decreased from 2.97% to 2.55% over the past 12 months, and the average five-year fixed rate has dropped from 3.53% to 3.19% over the same period.

James Runcie, author of the Grantchester novels, has been appointed as the new commissioning editor for arts at BBC Radio 4. Runcie, who will join the team in May, replaces Tony Phillips, who left earlier this year to pursue new projects outside the BBC. Runcie expressed his excitement about the new role, saying, "I hope to bring enthusiasm, energy, and imagination to this thrilling opportunity at Radio 4. My goals include developing new ways of thinking, fostering the pleasure of discovery, and celebrating the human need to create and find meaning."

Runcie is best known for his Grantchester Mysteries series, a 1950s' detective drama set in a village near Cambridge, which has been adapted into two series by ITV. The series stars James Norton, who has appeared in shows such as Happy Valley and War and Peace. Prior to his appointment at Radio 4, Runcie was the head of literature and the spoken word at London's Southbank Centre, a role he held until January, and previously served as artistic director of the Bath Literature Festival for four years.

Gwyneth Williams, controller of Radio 4 and Radio 4 Extra, welcomed Runcie to the team, saying, "I look forward to working with him to inspire and invite the best in the world of the arts to come to Radio 4." Runcie is no stranger to the BBC, having worked as a documentary producer and director for BBC Television covering music and arts from 1988 to 2000.

A thinktank has warned that cities in northern England must become more productive if Chancellor George Osborne's vision of a "northern powerhouse" is to be realized. The Centre for Cities believes that the government's plan to bridge the economic gap between the south and north is too focused on intercity transport links and not enough on improving individual city performance. The proposed HS3 rail link, which aims to speed up east-west connections between major northern cities, is a key part of the government's plan to address the UK's economic imbalances. However, the thinktank argues that cities in the Rhine-Ruhr region of Germany and the Randstad region of the Netherlands, which the government cites as models for the northern powerhouse, are economically vibrant because individual cities are already strong, not because of better rail links between them. According to the Centre for Cities, the five most productive cities in these regions - Amsterdam, Bonn, Leverkusen, Haarlemmermeer, and Düsseldorf - are, on average, 40% more productive than their UK counterparts, Leeds, Warrington, Burnley, Liverpool, and Manchester. The thinktank notes that intercity commuter rail links in Rhine-Ruhr and Randstad are actually comparable to those in northern England. Alexandra Jones, the Centre for Cities' chief executive, emphasized that a successful northern powerhouse requires stronger, more productive cities. She said that the government's initiative has the potential to significantly impact the north-south divide, but only if it maintains its focus on boosting productivity in major northern cities like Manchester, Leeds, and Newcastle. These cities have the most potential for growth in the region, but are currently underperforming, especially compared to cities in more successful areas like Rhine-Ruhr and Randstad. To increase the chances of success, the Centre for Cities suggests that policymakers address the skills gap in northern cities, where fewer people are educated to degree level than in other areas of the UK. A think tank reported that nearly half of Reading's residents hold a degree, compared to just a quarter of those in Liverpool. To boost productivity, it would be more effective to enhance transportation within northern cities, allowing people to access job opportunities across their broader city region. Local policymakers should be granted more autonomy to tackle the unique skills and transportation challenges they face, rather than spreading limited resources and attention evenly across the entire region. According to Jones, "By focusing most resources on addressing the economic challenges faced by large northern cities and their surrounding regions, policymakers can maximize the benefits for the north as a whole."

Dominic Chappell, the former owner of BHS, has accused Sir Philip Green, the previous owner, of being responsible for the retail chain's collapse. Chappell claims that Green failed to honor his promise to secure credit insurance for the business and did not leave sufficient funds in the company. "Sir Philip Green never kept his word," Chappell told the Guardian. "We worked tirelessly, but it was Green's interference and broken promises that ultimately led to the demise of BHS." Chappell revealed that he was forced to pay out over £20 million in upfront guarantees to keep key suppliers on board, using a significant portion of the £60 million in cash left on the balance sheet by Green. He admitted that Green did not provide a written guarantee for credit insurance, but claimed it was verbally promised. Chappell stated that over £20 million was spent on VAT, wages, and rent, leaving the business with no choice but to borrow money from the Dellal family at high interest rates to stay afloat. The Dellals' Allied Commercial Exporters (Ace) provided Chappell with £35 million in cash to demonstrate to Green's Arcadia group that he was a credible buyer for BHS, and subsequently made millions from property deals and loan agreements with the retailer. Chappell, who is set to testify before a parliamentary inquiry into BHS's demise next week, distanced the Dellal family from the company's problems, instead blaming Green and the management team, led by Darren Topp, for the business's poor performance during the eight-week Christmas period. "We were unlucky, and Green's actions knocked us off course," Chappell said. Despite its efforts, Green's Arcadia group, led by finance director Paul Budge, claims to have provided BHS with more than £90m in cash and debt facilities, as well as over £100m in loan guarantees and £100m in property assets. According to Budge, the company gave Retail Acquisitions "more help or assistance or support than we could have possibly given to try to make this business work." He emphasized that the business's failure was not due to a lack of support from Green's Arcadia, citing "multiple reasons" that likely contributed to its downfall. In the month following the deal, BHS incurred expenses of less than £80m, but was expected to receive receipts of £55m, resulting in an outflow of approximately £25m. This outflow could have been financed using cash on hand and property receipts, Budge noted.

Home Retail Group CEO John Walden is set to receive a windfall of over £5 million in cash and shares if the company is sold to Sainsbury's. The fate of Walden's tenure is uncertain, but the company's annual report reveals that he will be able to cash in over 650,000 shares and options, regardless of whether he stays on or leaves. Under the terms of the proposed takeover, Walden would receive 0.321 Sainsbury's shares and 55p in cash for every Home Retail Group share, as well as a 25p windfall from the sale of Homebase and a 2.8p dividend, worth £1 million. Walden's total windfall could potentially exceed £6 million, considering his 785,000 shares and share options, worth £1.3 million, which are subject to performance criteria and vest over the next three years. He may also cash in up to 1.4 million more share options, worth up to £2.3 million, if he meets performance targets over the next two years. The remuneration committee has not yet decided what will happen to bonuses and share awards linked to performance targets beyond the date of the takeover. If Walden leaves the company, he would be entitled to a payout of at least £676,500, including his basic annual salary and benefits. In the year ending February 2016, Walden's total pay package was £1.5 million, down from £2.4 million the previous year, due to a decline in his annual bonus and long-term share bonuses. He also sold over 1.2 million shares, worth nearly £2 million, to pay his tax bill on exercised share options. After falling short of earnings per share and total shareholder return targets, Walden's bonus payments decreased. Sainsbury's is planning to finalize its acquisition of Home Retail Group this autumn, but the deal may be delayed due to the competition regulator's consideration of an investigation into the £1.4 billion takeover. The Competition and Markets Authority has set a deadline of June 13th for public comments on the potential impact of the deal on consumers, and will announce by July 25th whether to initiate a preliminary inquiry.

According to a report by the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA), ecstasy is making a comeback. After its peak in the 1990s rave and techno scenes, the drug is gaining popularity among both established users and a new generation due to "creative and aggressive marketing" and its higher purity. The report warns that the substance is now stronger than ever. This resurgence raises questions about current drug laws. The UK reported the second-highest level of ecstasy use among the 12 countries analyzed, with the Netherlands having the highest usage. Should we focus on lowering drug use rates or reevaluate our approach to criminalizing drugs? We invite drug counsellors to share their insights on the current state of drug attitudes in Britain. How can the law be improved? What common cases do you encounter? What trends are emerging? What concerns do you have for the new generation in light of the previous wave of ecstasy use?

Despite the failed takeover talks between Belgium's Bpost and Dutch postal group PostNL, the news has refocused attention on potential consolidation in the sector. Royal Mail, which was linked to PostNL in December, is up 7p at 539.5p in a down market. Analysts at Credit Suisse note that talk of mergers and acquisitions in the European postal sector is increasing, but they are cautious due to declining traditional mail volumes and limited opportunities for cost savings. They suggest that Royal Mail is more likely to drive consolidation than Deutsche Post DHL, but they do not see an obvious acquisition target. They also believe that Deutsche Post DHL will prioritize organic growth over acquisitions. However, Royal Mail may be more willing to consolidate the UK parcel market, which has overcapacity of 20%, or boost its GLS prospects in the European B2C express market once it resolves a labor dispute. With a strong financial position, Royal Mail's net debt is only 0.2 times adjusted EBITDA. Nevertheless, the analysts have previously expressed doubts about PostNL's ability to add value to Royal Mail, and they do not see any obvious acquisition candidates among Royal Mail's key parcel competitors, including DPD, Hermes, Yodel, and TNT Express.

Deloitte has achieved its highest-ever percentage of female partners in its annual promotions, with 30% of new partners being women. The accountancy firm's UK division has promoted 24 out of 80 new partners to be female, a significant increase from last year's 29% and 20% in 2014. Although the proportion of new female partners is rising, Deloitte still has a long way to go to reach gender parity, with only 16% of its 1,054 UK partners being female. The firm's new partner intake has also been criticized for being predominantly white, with just 10% of new partners not being white, compared to 13% of the UK population who identify as non-white. However, this is an improvement from the existing group of partners, which is only 4% non-white. Deloitte's chief executive, David Sproul, hailed the firm's progress on gender diversity, citing a second consecutive year of strong female representation among new partners. He acknowledged that the company still has work to do to close the gender gap, but pointed to initiatives such as its return-to-work program, which aims to recruit women who have been out of the workforce for two years or more. The program has been successful, with over half of participants from last year's scheme accepting a job with the company, and has been expanded to include 20 women this year. Deloitte has also introduced flexible working hours and mobile phone games to test job applicants' aptitude, which it claims helps remove unconscious bias from the recruitment process.

"I placed an order on the Argos website in January for a washing machine and TV, entering my debit card details. The website stated that delivery would take five days, but when I contacted customer services, a representative told me that Argos does not accept debit cards, contradicting the website's claim. To make matters worse, my bank statement showed that Argos had taken £286 from my account, but I still haven't received any goods. I'm struggling to get a resolution and would appreciate your help in retrieving my money.

This is just the latest in a series of complaints about Argos's poor customer service. A recent reader complaint, published in this column, described a similar issue with the delivery of a wrong mattress and a refund made to the wrong account. After our intervention, the company offered a £75 gift voucher as a goodwill gesture.

Regarding my complaint, I decided not to proceed with the purchase, and Argos has assured us that the matter has been resolved and a full refund issued. However, it's clear that the company needs to improve its customer service urgently to prevent losing more customers. As a leading retailer, Argos has been credited with transforming the digital retail landscape; it's crucial that its new owner, Sainsbury's, addresses these issues.

We welcome letters from readers and will consider publishing them. If you have a consumer complaint, please email us at consumer.champions@theguardian.com or write to Consumer Champions, Money, The Guardian, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Include a daytime phone number and a clear summary of your issue."

James Ball, the digital art director behind the "Guide to Computing" series, says that the old computers' "dials and buttons, knobs and switches" are charming. Ball, who works under the pseudonym Docubyte, developed a fascination with retro computers and began the project to celebrate them. He notes that it's rare to find machines that you can touch and interact with today, as most computers are now touch screens. Ball believes that pre-Apple era computers are often overlooked as design pieces, and his nostalgia for their "naive" aesthetic led him to seek out and photograph a range of machines from the latter half of the 20th century. He found the machines at the Science Museum in London, the Dresden Technical Collections, and the National Museum of Computing at Bletchley Park, and then painstakingly enhanced the images with his colleagues at INK studio to make them look new. "The retouching is crucial to the piece," Ball says, using the example of the Pilot ACE, an early 1950s computer designed by Alan Turing. Since there are no color photographs of the Pilot ACE when it was new, Ball and his team were effectively creating a new history by presenting the past in a new context. The series features eye-catching machines like the Harwell Dekatron, the world's oldest functioning computer, and the Control Data 6600, often called the first "supercomputer." Ball says that the machines "look nice," but he would also like to create a comprehensive book about computing history. With a touch of poignancy, he notes that each of his images, rendered as a jpeg, is about 5mb in size – larger than any file that the individual computers could sustain. "'In a humble, non-pretentious way,' he remarks, 'they're lovely in their outdatedness.'"

Or, if you'd like a slightly different tone:

"'With a touch of understatement,' he notes, 'those old things are charmingly out of date.'"

Or, if you prefer a more formal tone:

"'In a restrained and unpretentious manner,' he observes, 'they possess a certain beauty in their obsolescence.'"

A parliamentary inquiry is set to investigate the number of occupational pension schemes at risk of collapse, following recent high-profile cases such as the demise of BHS and the debate surrounding the future of the British Steel pension fund. The Commons work and pensions select committee, which is already examining the £571 million deficit at the BHS scheme, announced on Friday that it will launch a comprehensive inquiry into the issue, likely to begin in the autumn. The spotlight has recently fallen on workers' occupational pensions due to BHS's collapse and Tata Steel's potential sale of its UK business. Almost 13,000 current and former BHS employees who were under retirement age when the company went into administration in March may face a 10% cut to their pensions as a result of the collapse. The British Steel pension scheme, one of Britain's largest defined benefit plans with 130,000 members, is also facing cuts as the government works to put it on a stable footing to facilitate a sale. The latest figures show that the scheme has liabilities of almost £15 billion and a deficit of £700 million. The chair of the committee, Frank Field, stated that the British Steel pension scheme's troubles are further evidence of a broader threat to one of Britain's greatest savings successes in the last century - occupational pension schemes. The committee's in-depth case study on BHS is highlighting how such schemes are already struggling due to rising life expectancy and record-low returns on capital. "Pension law and regulation must urgently adapt to the issues of the future, rather than the problems of the past," Field said. "We should not be under any illusions that British Steel is a special case. The entire savings edifice is at risk." The Labour MP noted that 11 million workers have private defined benefit pensions, but more than 5,000 of the associated pension schemes are in deficit, with a total shortfall of £805 billion.
