"This will be a major inquiry that will consider radical solutions to one of the great problems of our time," he added. "Recently, the committee collaborated with the business, innovation, and skills committee to conduct a questioning session with the heads of the Pension Protection Fund and the Pensions Regulator regarding the BHS scandal. In the coming weeks, the committees will present a unique and free theatrical experience in London, featuring a June 8th interview with senior BHS executives and Dominic Chappell, the former bankrupt who acquired the department store chain for £1 from Sir Phillip Green. Sir Phillip Green himself will appear a week later."

Aldi is set to introduce 18 unique British craft beers to its stores, capitalizing on the upcoming bank holiday weekend. The discount supermarket chain is responding to heightened demand for specialty beers by stocking its shelves with brews such as Wet Your Whistle, White Witch, and A-Hop-alypse Now starting Sunday. The move aims to tap into the UK craft beer market, valued at £420 million and predicted to reach £1 billion by 2020. Over the past two years, Aldi has sourced the beers from 15 UK-based breweries, which will be sold in stores in England and Wales for £1.25 each. The retailer has carefully curated the selection to showcase the country's artisanal brewing traditions and exceptional beers. The chosen breweries include Wiltshire-based Wadworth, a family-run business that has been delivering ales in oak casks by shire horses for generations. Tony Baines, Aldi's joint managing director of corporate buying, describes the ales as an eclectic mix and promises they will be available at affordable prices. "We're thrilled to support the growth of some of the UK's most renowned regional breweries and microbreweries," he added.

The list of available UK craft beers includes:

* Wet Your Whistle (Box Steam brewery)
* Golden Bolt (Box Steam)
* Wadworth 6X (Wadworth)
* Two Tribes (Everards)
* Hop Bomb (Sadler's)
* Mellow Yellow (Sadler's)
* Wizard Amber (Robinsons)
* Maple Gold (Joseph Holt)
* White Witch (Moorhouses)
* Mid-Atlantic (Titanic)
* Velo Pale Ale (Black Sheep)
* Reverend James Rye (SA Brain)
* Surrey Nirvana (Hogsback)
* Castle (Arundel)
* Double Dragon (Felinfoel)
* A-Hop-alypse Now (Camerons)
* Strongarm (Camerons)
* Unicorn (Robinsons)

AstraZeneca has hit a roadblock after US regulators delayed approval of a key drug it acquired through its $2.7 billion purchase of ZS Pharma last year. The company has received a complete response letter from the US Food and Drug Administration regarding its ZS-9 treatment for high potassium levels, which outlines concerns that must be addressed before approval can be granted. The letter reportedly stems from a pre-approval manufacturing inspection and does not require the generation of new clinical data. AstraZeneca is currently evaluating the letter's content and will work closely with the FDA to determine the next steps for the new drug application. The news overshadowed positive results from a clinical trial of its Faslodex treatment for breast cancer, causing AstraZeneca's shares to dip 9.5p to £40.02. Some analysts believe the drug's launch could be delayed until 2017 due to a manufacturing issue. While AstraZeneca had expected peak annual sales of $1 billion for the drug, analysts at Shore Capital now forecast sales of $40 million in 2016, reaching $1.163 billion in 2023.

Axa, a French insurance giant, has sold its UK investment, pensions, and insurance businesses, including SunLife, to Phoenix, a UK-based insurer, in a deal worth £375 million. The acquisition will transfer £12.3 billion in assets under management and over 910,000 policies to Phoenix. The sale includes the pension and investment businesses Embassy and SunLife, which provide life insurance coverage to individuals over 50. SunLife, based in Bristol, has been part of Axa since 1996. Clive Bannister, CEO of Phoenix, described the acquisition as a significant step forward in the company's growth strategy. Phoenix specializes in acquiring life insurance businesses that are no longer open to new customers. Bannister stated that Phoenix will invest heavily to ensure a smooth transition of the businesses from Axa and is committed to providing exceptional service to both direct and independent financial adviser customers. Looking ahead, Phoenix believes there will be further consolidation in the UK life insurance industry and will continue to explore opportunities as they arise. The sale marks Axa's exit from the British life and savings market, following the sale of its Elevate business to Standard Life and an Isle of Man offshore bonds business to Life Company Consolidation Group. The disposals will result in a loss of €400 million for Axa, but will allow the company to focus on property and casualty, health, and asset management in the UK. Axa has also announced changes to its top management ahead of the arrival of new CEO Thomas Buberl in September. Buberl has led Axa's German business for four years and was appointed CEO in March, succeeding Henri de Castries, who is leaving the company earlier than expected. De Castries built Axa into one of the world's largest insurance companies through acquisitions in Europe and emerging markets, including China and Colombia. This week, Axa announced its decision to divest from tobacco investments, selling its €1.8 billion portfolio and calling on its rivals to follow suit. "Buberl emphasized the devastating human toll of tobacco use and the staggering economic burden it imposes."

The chairman of Barclays, John McFarlane, emphasized the importance of maintaining ties with Europe after Brexit while establishing a new international model for financial services. Speaking at TheCityUK's annual conference, McFarlane cautioned against losing sight of Europe as a market as businesses strive to build broader international connections. "The relationships with the EU will need to be repaired," he said, expressing hope that any outcome would benefit the UK's membership.

Ahead of a meeting with Prime Minister David Cameron and Business Secretary Sajid Javid, McFarlane's comments aimed to alleviate concerns that the political crisis would spill over into the economy and trigger a recession. Other business leaders, including easyJet CEO Carolyn McCall, have already warned that leaving the EU could lead to increased air fares and more expensive holidays.

During the meeting, Cameron reportedly urged businesses not to become "fixated" on the EU, but instead to focus on building relationships and generating sales in other markets. McFarlane acknowledged that the outcome of Brexit talks with the EU is uncertain, but emphasized that London remains the financial center for Europe. "Europe's capital markets are not in Frankfurt, Paris, or Dublin; they are in London," he said, adding that English will continue to be the language of business.

The UK is not expected to begin negotiations with Brussels until autumn at the earliest, and possibly not until next year, after a new prime minister is chosen. The talks to reach a deal on new trading terms are scheduled to take at least two years. Meanwhile, HSBC Chairman Douglas Flint advised bankers to be cautious in making demands in the wake of the Brexit vote, which he described as a rejection of the "expert class." The bank's CEO emphasized that its headquarters would remain in London and that there would be no return to the lax regulatory environment of the past. He noted that negotiations with the EU could potentially lead to adjustments to certain rules. Flint pointed out that the financial system's resilience was evident this week, as markets functioned smoothly despite a significant surge in trading volumes, which was a testament to the robust shape the system was in since the 2008 financial crisis. Following the recent Brexit vote, which sent British banking stocks plummeting, Harriett Baldwin, a junior finance minister, sought to reassure the City of London by highlighting that banks maintain substantial reserves and the Bank of England is prepared to take action if needed. Baldwin stated that financial markets are capable of withstanding challenges, adapting quickly, and finding new opportunities.

Evernote, a popular note-taking service, is facing a backlash from its users after limiting the features available to its free account holders. The company's Evernote Basic tier, which previously offered free access to the software, will now only allow syncing across two devices, which may not be sufficient for users with multiple computers or multiple mobile devices. While free users can still access the web version of Evernote, those who need to sync their data across more than two devices will be required to upgrade to a paid plan. Additionally, Evernote has increased the prices of its Plus and Premium tiers, which now cost $34.99 and $69.99 per year, respectively. Unlike some other services, Evernote charges based on the amount of data uploaded each month, rather than total storage capacity. The Plus tier allows for 1GB of data to be synced with the web each month, while the Premium tier allows for 10GB and also includes additional features such as business-card scanning and PDF annotation. In a statement, Evernote's CEO Chris O'Neill explained that the price increases were necessary to allow the company to continue investing in the software and delivering new features to users. "Our goal is to continue improving Evernote for the long term, investing in our core products to make them more powerful and intuitive," O'Neill said. "However, this requires a significant investment of energy, time, and money, and we're asking our most loyal users to help us make that investment in return for the benefits that will result." As a concession to Basic users, Evernote is also adding a passcode lock feature to the free tier. However, some users are still expressing dissatisfaction with the changes, with some commenting on Evernote's website that the app is "pricing itself out of the market" and that they're no longer sure if they love the service enough to continue using it. Evernote, one of the first popular services to enable online syncing of notes between apps and the web, is now facing growing competition from major players in Silicon Valley. Microsoft's OneNote, tightly integrated with its Office suite of productivity tools, offers free use (although storage exceeding 15GB requires a subscription). Moreover, OneNote has recently launched a total import service from Evernote, making it easy for users to switch. Apple Notes, the built-in service that comes pre-installed on iPhones, has been steadily improving since its launch in 2007 and is now a compelling, free alternative, according to die-hard Evernote fans.

"My mother, who suffers from dementia, has been plagued by issues with her BT landline. Living alone, she relies heavily on her phone to stay connected to the outside world. Despite our efforts, she is unable to adapt to a mobile phone, so the landline is her lifeline. My brother and sister-in-law live nearby, but I am 200 miles away, making our twice-daily calls a crucial part of her daily routine. Disruptions to these calls cause her significant distress. Unfortunately, her landline has been experiencing faults for several months, with the issue recurring every time it seems to be resolved. Engineers have visited the house, and I have been given direct access to BT's priority fault repair scheme. However, the fault persists, and I am at my wit's end. The recorded message announcing the fault is particularly distressing, as my mother believes it is someone speaking to her. It is clear that BT is not prioritizing its landline customers.

Only after media intervention did BT discover the fault, both with the network and the wiring in my mother's home. Despite its priority repair scheme, the company failed to resolve the issue promptly. However, after contacting the press office, a technician was sent and the problem was fixed within a day. As a goodwill gesture, my mother has been offered a year's free broadband and an unlimited call plan. If you're experiencing similar issues, please contact Anna Tims at your.problems@observer.co.uk or write to Your Problems, The Observer, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU, including your address and phone number."

Facebook has denied using location data to suggest potential friends, despite concerns about the feature's unsettling accuracy. The "people you may know" feature has been known to suggest users with no or few mutual friends, sparking questions about how it works. The feature's accuracy has been called into question, with some users reporting that it suggests people they have never met or have no connection to, beyond sharing the same physical space.

Fusion reported that Facebook was using location data from users' smartphones to inform its suggestions, calling it a "privacy disaster." However, Facebook responded by saying that location information is "only one of the factors" it uses to determine people who may know each other. The company's spokesperson claimed that location data is not currently being used, but did admit to running a small test in 2015 that used users' cities to rank existing suggested friends.

The test, which ran for four weeks at the end of 2015, was not widely known among Facebook staff, with some employees unaware that it had ended. On Wednesday, a Facebook spokesman confirmed that the company is not currently using location data, and that its suggestions are based on a variety of factors, including mutual friends, work and education information, networks, and imported contacts.

Facebook's help section also states that its suggestions are based on a range of factors, including mutual friends, work and education information, networks, and imported contacts. Despite the company's denials, some users remain concerned about the accuracy and privacy implications of the feature. Despite the unclear nature of these "other factors," Facebook's sometimes unsettling friend suggestions - which could be more accurately described as "people you know, but have no intention of befriending" - have been a topic of discussion since the feature was introduced in 2008. Last year, Vice's Motherboard investigated why users' online dating matches were appearing as suggested friends, but the results were inconclusive. Facebook denied using data from third-party apps like Tinder or OKCupid. The most logical explanation is that the platform's suggestions are based on its robust "link prediction" and modeling of its vast social network. A recent analysis of Facebook's friend graph found that just 3.57 degrees of separation exist between its 16 billion members, with an even smaller gap within the US. As Caitlin Dewey, the Washington Post's digital culture critic, noted last year, "Facebook's friend-recommendation system isn't magic or malice - just really good math." Users concerned about Facebook's use of their location settings can refuse access to this information in their phone's privacy settings. Additionally, they can check which contacts have been imported and request removal on their "invite history" page.

Shares in Carpetright have plummeted by almost 20% due to concerns that the uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit from the EU will negatively impact consumer spending on the high street. The company's chief executive, Wilf Walsh, has expressed caution about the potential impact of the referendum outcome on consumer confidence, citing challenging trading conditions in recent weeks. Despite reporting a 33% increase in underlying profits to £17.3 million for the year ending April 30, the company's shares dropped to a low of 216.88p before recovering to 225p by lunchtime. In the past, home furnishings retailers have been affected by slowdowns in housing transactions, which can trigger purchases. Carpetright's new financial year has gotten off to a rocky start, with like-for-like sales in the UK declining 7.6% in May before rebounding to a 6.3% increase in June. According to Walsh, the current atmosphere is unusual, with consumers not behaving in a predictable pattern. He noted that it's too early to gauge the full impact of the referendum on the company. Walsh, who joined Carpetright in 2014 to lead a turnaround, has been working to revamp the retailer, introducing a new store design and customer service improvements. While the brand is well-known, research has shown that only 50% of surveyed customers would consider shopping at Carpetright. This year, the company will invest £10 million in refurbishing 100 stores, replacing its outdated branding and introducing a new staff uniform. The retailer has also expanded its product range to include hard flooring, which has proven popular with customers. "Carpetright still has a long way to go in its transformation, but we're clear on our direction and confident that our plans to reposition the business will lead to positive outcomes," said Walsh. Shore Capital analyst George Mensah noted that the UK's decision to leave the EU will likely increase Carpetright's sourcing costs, as 75% of its materials come from mainland Europe. "The impact of the referendum will mainly be felt through the effects on imports and changes in consumer confidence and the housing market," he explained. "While we're aware of the short-term challenges that may affect consumer sentiment, we remain optimistic about the company's prospects, as we believe the changes it has implemented are already yielding better returns for shareholders."

The UK grocery market has experienced a decline for the first time this year, with all four major supermarkets suffering a decline in performance. Asda's sales plummeted by 5.9%, its worst performance on record and the largest decline in the market. In contrast, Tesco, the best-performing major chain, saw sales drop by 1.3%, according to analysis from Kantar Worldpanel. This decline is more pronounced than the 5.1% and 1% falls reported last month. Discounters Aldi and Lidl, however, continue to thrive, with sales increasing by 11.5% and 13.8%, respectively, and their combined market share reaching a new high of 10.5%. Aldi is now just a hair's breadth away from surpassing the Co-op to become the UK's fifth-largest supermarket. The latest figures do not include the period following the referendum, but Kantar's head of retail and consumer insight, Fraser McKevitt, believes that the decision to leave the EU will likely bolster the discounters further. He notes that 40% of the food we consume is sourced from overseas, and any long-term change in exchange rates may lead to higher prices, causing consumers to seek out cheaper alternatives. McKevitt also believes that the immediate economic uncertainty is unlikely to cause a significant drop in grocery volumes, citing the resilience of basic food, drinks, and household sales during the 2008 financial crisis. A rise in prices may even be beneficial for the major supermarkets, which have seen a 1.4% drop in grocery prices over the three-month period. The decline in sales at Tesco and Morrisons was also attributed to store closures, as the companies adjust to changing shopper habits. Nielsen's UK head of retailer and business insight, Mike Watkins, is more optimistic about a supermarket recovery later this year, citing the end of deflation and the impact of store closures soon to be behind us. According to Nielsen analysts, supermarket sales experienced a surge in the four weeks leading up to June 18, largely driven by a boost in sales of snacks, beverages, and gourmet items during the initial stages of the Euro 2016 football tournament. Beer, wine, and spirits sales jumped 6.2% year-over-year during this period, while crisp and snack sales rose 4.2%, marking the industry's first monthly sales increase in nearly a year. However, with England's early exit from the tournament following their loss to Iceland on Monday night, the brief Euro 2016 sales boost is likely to come to an end.

According to a recent industry survey, British retail sales slowed down in the months leading up to the EU referendum. The Confederation of British Industry's latest report shows that the balance of retailers reporting sales increases minus those reporting decreases fell to 4% in June, down from 7% in May. The survey, conducted between May 26 and June 14, took place before the UK's surprise decision to leave the EU. While some retailers, such as grocers, furniture and carpet shops, and hardware and DIY stores, reported an uptick in sales, others, including clothing retailers and department stores, experienced slower growth or even declines. Retailers anticipate a sales improvement in July, with the balance expected to shift to -10% from -5% in June, and orders expected to continue falling. The CBI noted that retail sales reported weak growth in the year to June, exceeding expectations of a modest decline and lifting sales slightly above average for the time of year. Orders placed with suppliers decreased in June, although at a slower pace than the previous month. Internet sales growth slowed in the year to June, falling below the long-run average, but is expected to rebound strongly in July. According to Howard Archer, chief European and UK economist at IHS Global Insight, the survey suggests that consumers were cautious in their spending in the run-up to the EU referendum, but did not completely abstain from spending. Archer noted that there was little evidence of a significant boost from the European football championships, which began on June 10, during the survey period. A major question now is how well or poorly retail sales will perform in July following the UK's vote to leave the EU. "After the Brexit vote, it's likely that consumer spending will be heavily impacted for a while due to increased uncertainty, potentially higher unemployment, and reduced purchasing power. It's probable that purchasing power will be squeezed as inflation rises significantly, driven by a sharp decline in the value of the pound. A separate report from Lloyds Bank found that consumer spending on essential items decreased again in May, although at a slower pace than in previous months. In fact, spending on essentials has been declining for 18 consecutive months, with a 0.4% year-over-year drop in May. Food and drink, which accounts for 40% of essential spending, actually saw a 0.1% increase in May, following a 0.7% drop in April. However, spending on fuel continued to decline, falling by 4.4% in May."

The top executives at the parent company of the Independent, which was preparing to cut jobs and shut down the newspaper titles, saw their take-home pay almost double last year. Despite the impending closure, the Independent and Independent on Sunday managed to reduce their pre-tax losses from £8.5m to £6.9m in the year ending September 27, 2015, according to the latest available accounts. On a "trading" level, excluding certain expenses, the newspapers lost just £3.74m last year, bringing them close to breaking even. However, the print titles were still shut down in March, as the company sold off the i and shifted its focus to digital-only publishing. Despite the impending closure, the directors of Lebedev Holdings, which controls the Independent, London Evening Standard, and London Live, enjoyed a lucrative year. The five directors, including Alexander Lebedev and Steve Auckland, saw their take-home pay triple from £589,000 to £1.48m. The highest-paid director, who remained anonymous, received £953,000, up from £529,000 in 2014. At the Independent, the highest-paid director's pay doubled from £200,000 to £416,000. The seven directors of the subsidiary company that runs the Independent saw their pay more than double from £387,000 to £831,000. The increase in director pay was largely due to the addition of new directors between 2014 and 2015. The financial filings for Evgeny Lebedev's media assets show that the Evening Standard enjoyed a significant profitability boost in 2015, with pre-tax profits rising from £1.09m to £3.38m. On a "trading" level, profits rose from £1.35m to £4.5m. Given the challenging ad market in the UK, which has seen many national newspaper publishers report significant print ad declines, the Evening Standard's revenue rose from £62.9m to £71m. Independent Digital News and Media, the separate company spun off from the Independent print titles, made a net profit before tax of £1.27m. ESTV, the parent company of London Live, reported a substantial decrease in losses, from £11.5m to £6.34m, over the course of the year ending September 30, 2015. Since acquiring a majority stake in the Evening Standard in 2009 and the Independent titles in 2010, Evgeny Lebedev and his father, Alexander, have invested over £135m in their UK media assets. According to the company's filings, the amount owed to Alexander Lebedev, Evgeny Lebedev, and their affiliated companies as of September 27, 2015, was £126.46m, plus £9.35m in interest. This represents a significant increase from the £111m total commitment reported in the previous year's filings. Additionally, Daily Mail & General Holdings, the owner of the Daily Mail and a 24.9% stakeholder in the Evening Standard, provided an interest-free loan of £12.48m.

ITV's stock market value has taken a significant hit since the Brexit vote, with almost £2.5 billion wiped off its value. The broadcaster's share price plummeted by over 20% on Friday and continued to fall by more than 5% in early trading on Monday. By midday on Monday, ITV's share price had dropped to 164p, a significant decline from its pre-Brexit price of 220p and its one-year high of 280p. Investors' concerns about the impact of Brexit on ITV's advertising revenue have driven the company's market capitalization from £9 billion to around £6.5 billion in the days following the EU referendum. City analysts are now speculating that ITV could become a takeover target due to its declining share price and the UK's currency crash, which has seen the pound fall 10% against the US dollar. According to Ian Whittaker, an analyst at Liberum, the increased likelihood of a takeover bid comes from the historical and present interest of major US media companies in the UK market. Whittaker believes that not only established media giants but also new media and tech companies may be interested in making a bid for ITV. NBC Universal, which owns the production company behind Downton Abbey, has been rumored to have had an interest in bidding for ITV in the past. John Malone's Liberty Global, which owns Virgin Media, has a 9.9% stake in ITV, and Malone is also a major shareholder in Discovery, which has acquired European assets including Eurosport and the TV rights to the Olympics. Whittaker has recommended that investors "buy" ITV's stock, citing the company's undervalued price following Friday's share price fall. "Despite the post-Brexit vote, the fundamentals of ITV's business remain unchanged. Even if we assume a significant decline in advertising revenue similar to the post-Lehman crisis, ITV would still appear undervalued with a attractive dividend yield. In fact, even in a worst-case scenario, ITV's stock price would still be considered cheap. Liberum's analysis compared the 8.3% decline in TV advertising in 2009, triggered by the global recession following Lehman Brothers' collapse, to the 8.7% fall in 2010. Meanwhile, media stocks continued to decline, with Sky falling by almost 3%, Trinity Mirror (owner of the Daily Mirror) dropping 10%, the Daily Mail declining by almost 4%, and WPP decreasing by 2.3%."

At the Bespoked Handmade UK Bicycle Show in Bristol earlier this year, visitors would have noticed a resurgence in bike building in the UK. Among the 100 exhibitors, showcasing custom steel and titanium bikes, one builder stood out for his choice of material: carbon fibre. While most road bikes are now made of carbon fibre, custom frames built from the lightweight material are rare due to the technical challenges involved. However, Richard Craddock, based in Worcestershire, is overcoming these barriers. Craddock spent years designing cycles for various brands and racing for an amateur team in France before deciding to build a carbon bike tailored to his own needs. After almost four years of development and testing, he launched his Filament bespoke carbon frames to the public. Since then, he hasn't stopped building. So, what sets his carbon bikes apart? "The primary unique selling point is custom geometry," says Craddock. "Two riders of the same height could have different body types, and I can build a frame that accommodates their weight and dimensions exactly, without compromise." He achieves this through a combination of custom geometry, tube diameters, fibre and resin types, and the number and sequence of plys used for joining the tubes. Perfecting the joining process was a major challenge, enabling him to create custom frames without the need for expensive moulds. Now, his biggest challenge is meeting the demands of his customers. One recent project was building a bespoke carbon tandem bike, which its owners used to set a mixed-team UK 10-mile time trial record. Beyond geometry, paint job, and components, Craddock can offer bespoke features that are rare on off-the-shelf cycles. For example, the bike pictured features Sram's new wireless eTap gear-changing system, which Craddock was able to design a frame around, with zero provision for cables, unlike some major manufacturers who simply plug redundant holes with rubber. "Despite the meticulous attention to detail that goes into each bike, Craddock's creations often come with a lower price tag than high-end mass-produced models from leading manufacturers. According to Craddock, most of his customers are discerning cyclists who have had their share of great bikes but are still seeking that perfect ride. His custom frames begin at £2,680."

Big newspaper managers, like Mark Thompson at the New York Times, become indignant when adblocking companies demand payment in exchange for allowing their ads to be viewed. This scenario is reminiscent of the Godfather's unsavory dealings. However, eyebrows may raise when Thompson announces that he's planning to sell a premium, ad-free digital package to readers. According to Thompson, the goal is to provide users with as many choices as possible, recognizing that some subscribers and non-subscribers would prefer an ad-free experience. This seems to imply that, for a higher fee, the newspaper will block ads for you, a concept that could have a significant impact on the American media landscape. In fact, this idea is reminiscent of the licence fee model, which was used during Thompson's tenure as director general at the BBC.

Stuart Rose, the former Marks & Spencer CEO who took the reins as chairman of the Britain Stronger in Europe campaign, has attributed the Leave victory to voters' disillusionment with politicians and a decline in trust towards big business. "I'm not a politician, and this outcome was always going to be determined by politicians," Lord Rose said. "It's a reflection of the broader issues affecting the world. People are clearly unhappy with the current state of affairs and want to be heard and see change – that's a political issue." When asked if business leaders could have done more to sway voters in favor of the status quo, Rose pointed to the growing disconnect between the "man on the street" and big business. "There has been a loss of trust, and we need to think about how to rebuild it," he said. "This erosion of trust has been building over time, since the last recession, and is fueled by issues like the banking crisis and the eurozone crisis, as well as business practices that people don't like. These cumulative grievances have left a bad taste in people's mouths, and we need to address them." After playing a key role at the campaign's outset, Rose was sidelined in March following a controversy surrounding his comments to a parliamentary committee, in which he stated that wages would increase if Britain left the EU. Although he maintains he was misquoted, his remarks were seized upon by the Leave campaign. Rose continued to work behind the scenes until the end of the campaign. "It reminded me that politicians operate in a political arena, while business leaders operate in a business environment, and sometimes they communicate in different ways," he said, reflecting on his experience. When asked if mistakes were made in the Remain campaign's approach, Rose acknowledged that their message wasn't as strong as others. "It's time to take a step back, put our heads together, and reflect on what happened over the coming days, weeks, and months," he said. "The outcome of the vote sends a clear signal that not everything is perfect from a UK perspective," Rose said. "Now, it's crucial to ensure that the UK's departure from the EU is handled effectively to minimize the economic impact on Britain." Rose emphasized the importance of preparing for the future, saying, "There will be a lot of work to do, navigating a lot of uncertainty." He has previously predicted that leaving the EU would lead to a recession. "I believe there will be a negative consequence," he stated. "In simple terms, if the pound falls and remains low, prices will increase, and if prices rise, the cost of living will also increase. It doesn't require a genius to understand this."

As the retail sector becomes increasingly automated, we're faced with concerns that go beyond the superficial benefits of choice, convenience, and rapid delivery. I question whether there's genuine demand for having goods delivered to our doorstep within 30 minutes of ordering, or if our modern sense of satisfaction is overly reliant on instant gratification. In an automated society, where will the wages come from to purchase these goods? The automation of jobs, which many people rely on, raises concerns that politicians are neglecting. The UK's recent experience with Brexit showed that politicians were out of touch with the anger of those affected; now, they seem eager to rush headlong into a future with unclear consequences. Unresolved issues abound: the need for a universal basic income to support those displaced from the workforce, as well as the necessary taxation on corporate profits; the loss of peace, quiet, privacy, safety, and security; and the fundamental question of what humans will do in the future and what our role will be. It's crucial that we consider these questions before intelligent robots start answering them.

Today is the last day for Microsoft's year-long free Windows 10 upgrade offer for Windows 7 and 8 users, which means you can claim a free license or face a cost of over £80. If you're still undecided, you have until 11am on Saturday to take advantage of the free upgrade. After that, you'll be stuck with your current version of Windows unless you purchase an upgrade. For those frustrated with Microsoft's aggressive promotion of Windows 10, the end of the free upgrade period may come as a welcome relief. Many users are happy with Windows 7, which has become a solid and reliable operating system, but Windows 10 is arguably the best version Microsoft has ever created. While there are concerns about its use of cloud services and user tracking, Windows 10 is the most secure version yet. If you're running Windows 8 or 8.1, the free update to Windows 10 is highly recommended, as it refines the good aspects of the older operating system without the irritating features like the charms bar and gestures. Updating is straightforward: visit the Windows 10 help page, download page, or click "yes" to Microsoft's upgrade notification. Windows 10 will also receive a significant update on August 2, which adds features like stylus support, Windows Hello for apps and websites, and improvements to Cortana and Edge browser extensions. Should you take your last chance at a free upgrade to Windows 10? "Microsoft is offering a $10,000 reward for a seamless automatic Windows 10 installation, and in a review of the final version, it's clear that Windows 10 might just be the company's best operating system yet."

According to research on Europe's cities with the highest concentration of high net worth individuals, one in three people in Monaco are millionaires, with Zurich a close second. London ranks fourth, despite having a large number of millionaires living in its affluent areas like Mayfair, which account for only one in 29 of the city's citizens. Edinburgh, the only other UK city to make the top 20, has an estimated one in 67 of its inhabitants with assets worth over $1 million. Dublin, a surprise entry into the top 10, has a higher density of millionaires than many other European capitals, with most of them earning their wealth from the city's thriving tech industry. According to researcher Oliver Williams, Dublin's tech scene has attracted talent from both Europe and the US, contributing to its high number of millionaires.

The research, conducted by WealthInsight in partnership with Spear's Magazine, defines millionaires as individuals with assets worth over $1 million, excluding the value of their primary residence. Monaco continues to add more millionaires per capita than any other city, with a 6% increase in density since the last ranking two years ago. The principality's reputation as a tax haven for billionaires has been reinforced by the controversy surrounding Tina Green, wife of former BHS boss Phillip Green, who has been a resident of Monaco since 1998.

Credit Suisse's annual research on global wealth has found that inequality is growing worldwide, with half of the planet's wealth now held by just 1% of the population. According to recent research, the middle class has been disproportionately affected, with the very rich benefiting at their expense. A notable finding is that for the first time, China has more individuals in the middle class (109 million) than the United States (92 million). In 2015, Oxfam warned that by 2016, the top 1% of the global population would hold more wealth than the remaining 99%. A ranking of the top 20 European cities by millionaire density reveals that Monaco has the highest proportion at 31.1%, followed by Zurich (24.3%), Geneva (17.7%), and London (3.4%), with the remaining cities ranging from 2.9% to 0.6%.

British Gas lost nearly 400,000 customers in the first six months of 2016, a 3% decline, as increased competition among energy suppliers prompted households to switch providers. According to its parent company, Centrica, falling gas and power prices led to the emergence of new suppliers, intensifying the competition for customers. The decline in customer numbers was also attributed to a large number of long-term contracts expiring simultaneously, leaving British Gas with 14.26 million accounts. However, customer numbers began to rise again in June, the company reported. Claire Osborne, an energy analyst at uSwitch, noted that British Gas's market share is being eroded by smaller and larger suppliers alike. She suggested that the only way for British Gas to regain customers is by launching competitive deals. Notably, British Gas is the only major supplier to have lowered its standard gas prices three times since the start of last year, making its standard variable tariff the lowest among the big six. However, its best deal is still significantly more expensive than the cheapest option on the market, making it likely that customers will find better savings by switching to other providers. Centrica reported a 6% decline in operating profit at its UK home business, which fell to £635 million, partly due to a one-off pension credit in the previous year. The decline also reflected lower energy consumption among customers. The company's total revenue fell 13% to £13.4 billion. Centrica has implemented £141 million in cost cuts in the first half and plans to achieve £750 million in savings by 2020. The company is currently reducing its workforce by 6,000 jobs, with plans to cut 3,000 staff by the end of the year. Iain Conn, Centrica's CEO, stated that the first half of the year was challenging, but the company has responded strongly and made significant progress. The company has appointed Stephen Hester, the former CEO of Royal Bank of Scotland, as a senior independent director. Hester began his role as a non-executive director on June 1st.

Following the EU referendum, Britain's top company bosses embarked on a buying spree, spending a record £18.5m on their own company shares in the following weeks. According to data from Olivetree Financial, compiled for FT Money, directors of FTSE 100 and FTSE 250 companies made more than £18.5m in share purchases between June 23 and July. This is the largest amount of individual director buys in at least 10 years, Olivetree noted. The sectors most affected by the Brexit news - banks, housebuilders, retailers, and travel companies - saw the largest director purchases. Many boardroom directors have benefited from these deals as the stock market rebounded following the initial dramatic falls. The majority of these transactions took place in late June and early July. The largest single transaction in the FTSE 100 was made by the Darwazah family, Hikma Pharmaceuticals' founding shareholders, who purchased £3.3m of shares the day after the Brexit vote. Tony Pidgley, chairman of Berkeley Group, bought nearly £800,000 of shares on June 27 and has seen their value increase by 15% since then. Lloyds Banking Group saw the most director purchases, with 21 directors buying shares worth over £750,000. Provident Financial was second, with seven directors buying nearly £1.5m of stock, followed by Vodafone, where five directors purchased £1.4m of shares. The data shows that 69 directors from 23 FTSE 100 companies bought their own company shares, totaling £10.5m. Eighteen top-level bosses, including chief executives, chairmen, and chief financial officers, accounted for 37% of the total amount. On the FTSE 250, 108 directors from 63 companies bought shares in their own businesses, with 39 top-level executives responsible for just over half of the total £8m spent. Four FTSE 100 companies have experienced significant share sales by their directors: Mondi, a paper supplier, National Grid, SABMiller, a brewer, and United Utilities. Meanwhile, two other firms, Coca-Cola Hellenic, a bottling company, and Vodafone, have seen both buying and selling activity by their directors.

McDonald's is planning to create over 5,000 new jobs in the UK by the end of 2017, a move that demonstrates confidence in the economy despite the uncertainty following the EU referendum. The company plans to achieve this by opening 25 new restaurants, extending the operating hours of existing sites, and introducing new services such as table service. Business Secretary Greg Clark welcomed the announcement, stating that it is "great news for the UK economy" and that the government is committed to supporting businesses to thrive.

Despite the uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit from the EU, McDonald's is pushing forward with its expansion plans. The company's CEO, Paul Pomroy, emphasized that all new jobs will be permanent, with a mix of full-time and part-time positions. McDonald's has faced criticism for its use of zero-hours contracts, which affect an estimated 80,000 workers. However, the company is now offering staff the option to switch to fixed-hours contracts and has expanded a trial to nine restaurants, which has seen one in five workers opt for the change.

The company's decision to revamp its employment policy was driven by feedback from workers, who reported difficulties in securing loans, mortgages, and mobile phone contracts due to the uncertainty of their employment status. Pomroy stated that the company considered delaying its expansion plans after the EU referendum, but has instead chosen to accelerate its growth. He emphasized the importance of big businesses like McDonald's demonstrating confidence in the UK economy and offering reassurance to the public.

Pomroy drew parallels with the last recession, saying that he has learned a great deal from it and is now focused on positioning McDonald's as an "employer of choice" in the UK. The company's decision to create new jobs and expand its operations is seen as a vote of confidence in the UK economy and a demonstration of its commitment to the country. "In my opinion, a successful retailer must consistently deliver and stay focused, without getting sidetracked. McDonald's hasn't observed any indication of a slowdown in its restaurant operations. While some employees and customers may be concerned about the situation, we haven't actually seen a decline in our business. As the CEO, my job has become slightly more challenging, but it was already demanding. McDonald's employs over 110,000 people in the UK and has added more than 15,000 to its workforce in the past five years, making the recent expansion plans a significant acceleration of our growth."

The New European, a pro-EU newspaper, will continue to publish beyond its initial four-week trial period after exceeding its sales targets, its publisher Archant has announced. Launched on June 24, the newspaper, aimed at the 48% of the UK that voted to remain in the EU, has sold more than 40,000 copies of its first edition, with subsequent issues also performing well. Archant has decided to continue producing the newspaper on a rolling basis, but made it clear that it will cease publication if interest wanes. In contrast, The New Day newspaper, which launched in February, saw its daily sales drop to an estimated 30,000 before it was shut down in May, despite its publisher Trinity Mirror targeting a circulation of 200,000 copies. The New European has attracted high-profile contributors, including novelist Howard Jacobson, journalist Jonathan Freedland, venture capitalist Saul Klein, and former Labour spin doctor Alastair Campbell, who has called for a second referendum. "We're thrilled by the reaction and support we've received for this unusual newspaper launch," said Archant's chief content officer, Matt Kelly. "We'll continue to publish as long as the zeitgeist demands it." Archant, primarily a regional publisher, has shown a willingness to experiment with focused projects, such as the "pop-up" New European, which went from concept to launch in just nine days. According to Archant's chief marketing officer, Will Hattam, the company's scale and agility allow it to produce a high-quality print product for a national audience while also being able to quickly adapt and profitably serve a newly formed community.

The latest concern for Europe is the possibility of Quitaly, a scenario in which Italy might abandon the euro and return to using the lira. Italy's economy has been struggling for over two decades, with little to no growth and declining competitiveness in export markets. This sluggish growth has led to high levels of unemployment, resulting in a significant amount of non-performing loans that are now crippling Italian banks. The potential bad debts have nearly doubled to €360 billion over the past five years, accounting for 18% of all outstanding loans. While the non-performing loans are a symptom of the problem, they do not cause it. Unlike Greece, Ireland, and Spain, Italy did not experience an economic boom before the 2008-09 financial crisis, and its performance has been consistently poor. As a result, the economy is 10% smaller than it was before the crisis, and unemployment is high, particularly in southern Italy. Before joining the euro, Italy could have made itself more competitive by devaluing the lira, but that option is no longer available. This creates a significant risk: a European slowdown following Brexit, combined with Italy's already weak economy, could lead to bank failures and small investors being forced to absorb losses. If the Five Star Movement, which has pledged to hold a referendum on leaving the euro, were to come to power, the possibility of Quitaly could not be ruled out. In the event of a Quitaly, the single currency would likely collapse.

Google is taking a stand against spam callers with an updated version of its phone app for Android devices, which can identify and help block spammers. The app update, part of Google's efforts to separate core phone features from operating system updates, is now available for Nexus and Android One devices, including the Nexus 6P and Nexus 5X. Building on its existing caller ID system, which has been available for several years, the new app extension helps identify suspicious business numbers not stored in your contacts. When an incoming call is flagged as potentially spammy, the app displays a prominent red banner and offers users the option to permanently block the number or whitelist false positives. While other third-party apps, such as Truecaller, have offered similar functionality for years, Google's integration of this feature into its default Android app marks a significant milestone. Apple iPhone users, however, have been limited by the platform's restrictive nature, but the upcoming iOS 10 update, set to release in September for iPhone 5 and newer devices, will introduce a caller ID extension system for spam alerts, potentially enabling similar functionality on iOS devices.

According to a recent report by the Association of Residential Letting Agents (Arla), nearly half of lettings agents are reporting that landlords are becoming increasingly nervous due to the uncertainty surrounding Brexit. Specifically, 12% of agents have reported a decline in asking rents over the past 10 days. While Arla's report suggests that the rental market has so far responded to Brexit in a calm manner, the organization warns that continued uncertainty could lead to turbulence in the coming months. David Cox, managing director of Arla, emphasized the need for the new government to prioritize housing and the rental market, citing concerns that a lack of certainty could lead to institutional investors pulling out of the market, ultimately impacting tenants by reducing supply and increasing rents.

The report also found that almost 36% of Arla members have reported a reduction or no change in the number of prospective tenants looking for properties. Notably, overall supply and demand for rental accommodation increased in June, with prospective tenants seeing a 12% average increase and properties on agents' books rising by an average of 3%. According to Cox, the key takeaway from the Brexit vote is that supply and demand remain a significant issue in the rental market. If supply continues to dwindle against growing demand, renting will become more difficult and expensive for tenants, regardless of the eventual implications of Brexit. "A recent report by the Taxpayer's Alliance, released on Monday, recommends slashing stamp duty on homes by half and eventually eliminating it altogether. The report argues that the current tax is exacerbating supply shortages and driving up rents for tenants. Specifically, it suggests abolishing the 3% surcharge on buy-to-let and additional homes, warning that investors will likely pass on the costs to tenants, further increasing rents."

According to a report released on Monday, the number of applications to build new shops has dropped by 9% over the past year, marking the seventh consecutive decline. In 2015, there were 6,700 applications for new retail developments, a decrease from 7,360 in the previous year. This represents a nearly 50% decline from the pre-recession peak of 11,900 applications in 2008. The report highlights the ongoing challenges faced by shopkeepers as consumers increasingly turn to online shopping, with many traditional retailers struggling to compete with online-only retailers like Asos and Boohoo. Despite efforts by traditional retailers to expand their online presence, many are failing to keep pace with online-only brands, which have contributed to the recent failures of retailers such as BHS, Austin Reed, and My Local. The report suggests that the uncertainty surrounding the Brexit vote could exacerbate these challenges, with potential negative impacts on the UK economy. According to Aimee Barrable of EMW, the continued success of online retailers has led to a decrease in the appetite for new shop openings, with many retailers instead opting to develop their online services or repurpose existing space. The recent high-profile closures could lead to an increase in available retail space, potentially attracting retailers looking to expand their high street presence. Additionally, some retailers may delay committing to new shop developments until the economic impact of the Brexit vote becomes clearer. Last week, official statistics showed a 0.9% decline in retail sales between May and June, exceeding the 0.6% decline expected by economists. While the decline was partly attributed to inclement weather, the figures also hinted at the impact of the Brexit vote on consumer spending.

PricewaterhouseCoopers has been fined £2.3 million by the Financial Reporting Council (FRC) for its auditing of Cattles and Welcome Financial Services in 2007. The FRC also issued the accountancy firm a severe reprimand. The fine was reduced from £3.5 million after mitigation and a settlement discount. PwC must also pay £750,000 towards the FRC's costs. The FRC stated that the original fine of £3.5 million would have been the largest ever. This penalty comes after PwC was sued by Cattles, which alleged that the accountants acted negligently in their auditing of the Yorkshire firm during the financial crisis. Cattles claimed that the loan book of Welcome was weaker than stated in PwC's audit. The lawsuit was brought on behalf of creditors to Cattles, which lent to people with poor credit histories and entered into a financial restructuring scheme in 2011. PwC and its audit engagement partner, Simon Bradburn, have admitted that their conduct fell short of expected standards in respect of the 2007 financial statements. The FRC stated that PwC had insufficient audit evidence regarding the loan loss provision and failed to identify inadequate disclosure of the impairment policy in the financial statements. The watchdog said that the disclosures were not in compliance with accountancy rules. Gareth Rees QC, executive counsel to the FRC, stated that the substantial fines imposed in this case reflect the seriousness of the audit failings and will send a strong signal to the audit community about the importance of upholding high standards of professional conduct in audit work. "He commended PwC's and Bradburn's constructive approach, which facilitated the settlement. The admissions of misconduct have led to a substantial reduction in time and costs, and the fines imposed have been lowered as a result. PwC stated: "Although the FRC acknowledged that we were deliberately misled by third parties, we acknowledge that certain aspects of our 2007 audit did not meet expected standards. Audit quality is a top priority for PwC, and the FRC's annual audit quality assessments have shown a trend of improvement in our work over several years."

Microsoft has issued an apology after its Bing translation service mistakenly translated the Arabic term "Daesh", which refers to the Islamic State, as "Saudi Arabia" in English. The error was first noticed by Saudi social media users, who responded by calling for a boycott of all Microsoft products, causing the incident to go viral and sparking a public outcry. Dr. Mamdouh Najjar, Microsoft's vice president for Saudi Arabia, personally apologized to the Saudi people and the country, saying that the mistake was unintentional. Najjar attributed the error to Bing's reliance on crowdsourced translations, which can promote alternative translations to the top spot if they receive sufficient suggestions. He noted that the service can be manipulated by substituting correct translations with alternative ones, and that the company is investigating whether this occurred in this case. Microsoft has apologized to Saudi officials and has taken steps to correct the error and prevent similar mistakes in the future.

As the summer slowdown approaches, it's a good time to discuss potential takeover rumors. Analysts at RBC have been analyzing satellite communication specialist Inmarsat and believe it could be a prime target for a bid. In a recent note, RBC analyst Wilton Fry wrote: "Given Inmarsat's lower stock price, particularly in US dollar terms, the rapid evolution of the industry's competitive landscape, and historical precedents, we think it's reasonable to consider potential M&A activity." Fry went on to assess whether Echostar or Dish Network might be interested in acquiring Inmarsat. Echostar and Dish Network have recently secured funding and Echostar now has around $3 billion in cash reserves, which is likely to be used to fund new satellite projects. However, Fry believes there's a possibility that Echostar or Dish may consider acquiring Inmarsat due to the strategic and operational benefits of a combination. A potential bid for Inmarsat could help resolve several interlocking issues: Dish has a significant amount of US spectrum but needs terrestrial deployment, while Echostar and Inmarsat both own European S-band spectrum that could be used for mobile services. Mobile operators need spectrum to accommodate growing data demands, and Deutsche Telekom is involved in Inmarsat's S-band project and owns T-Mobile USA. Inmarsat is a global company that needs more Ka-band capacity, while Echostar has Ka-band capabilities but wants to expand globally. Combining Echostar's regional expertise with Inmarsat's global reach could fulfill Echostar's global ambitions, help Inmarsat add capacity in dense areas, protect Echostar's Hughes business, enhance in-flight opportunities, and counter ViaSat's aspirations while yielding significant operational savings from combined satellite control functions. "In contrast to Inmarsat, Echostar has a significant cash reserve of $3 billion and lower debt levels, despite being smaller in size ($3.6 billion versus $5.0 billion) and having a lower rating (5 times 2017 estimated EBITDA versus 10 times). To illustrate, a 37% premium (12.5 times 2017 estimated EBITDA) with a 30% cash/70% equity structure would result in NewCo's debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 3.2 times, which is comparable to Inmarsat's current leverage. RBC has set a target price of £11.50 per share for Inmarsat, while its shares are currently trading at 805.5p, down 1p."

"Hello puzzle enthusiasts! Today, we have a clever challenge courtesy of Jelmer Steenhuis, a renowned Dutch puzzle designer. This modern spin on an ancient riddle is sure to delight partygoers and puzzle lovers alike. Three friends set out to a carnival with a 1.2-liter jerry can filled with rum punch. Upon arrival, they decide to split the drinks among three separate sound systems. To do so, they must divide the punch equally among themselves. Fortunately, they brought two large bottles to help with the task. However, they soon discover that these bottles lack measurements. One of the friends finds an empty 50cl Red Stripe can and a 15cl vial marked 'rave juice' on the ground. There's a nearby water tap to clean the can and vial. Using only these vessels and the knowledge that the jerry can initially held 1.2 liters of punch, how do the friends manage to divide the punch into three equal portions? Assume that no liquid is spilled when pouring from one container to another. I'll return with the solution at 5pm today. Please refrain from posting spoilers in the comments. Jelmer, a lawyer turned puzzle designer, is best known in the Netherlands for his crosswords and word games, which have appeared in various publications. If you speak Dutch, you can find some of his puzzles on his website. I post a new puzzle every two weeks on Mondays. If you'd like to propose a puzzle for this column, please email me. My latest book, Football School: Where Football Explains the World, is now available and uses football to explain various subjects like math, English, geography, and more. You can find me on Twitter, Facebook, Google+, my personal website, or my Guardian math blog."

Fiona Millar's article (Education, 23 August) highlights the arguments in favor of grammar schools, including the notion that there are "clever" children and the rest. However, proponents of this idea should consider real-life examples. Is a child who excels in math but struggles with written communication a "clever" child or not? What about one who is skilled in reading and writing but has a talent for art and craftsmanship? Or a refugee who performs poorly on the 11-plus due to limited English proficiency? Is a child who barely passes the test because they missed weeks of school due to homelessness truly "clever"? Or one who barely scrapes by with private tutoring? The idea of categorizing children into "clever" and "not clever" is nonsensical, as is the notion that two types of schools are needed to provide different forms of education.

I was thrilled to read Michael Liversidge's letter (24 August) about his academic achievements despite his poor O-level performance. I was a student at the same school, which had direct grant status at the time, and my father, Don, was one of Michael's history tutors. Shortly before our O-level exams, I recall overhearing Don refer to several of my classmates as "nice guys, but not very bright." One of them, Chris Penny, went on to work at GCHQ, where he claimed to be a cleaner, although his funeral attendance last year suggested a more significant role. Another, Matthew Harding, left to become a tea-boy in a finance house, but he eventually owned the business and Chelsea football club. Good grades on academic exams are a clear indicator of academic aptitude, nothing more.

The selective school system not only resulted in the majority of students being rejected at age 11, but it also segregated children within families. In 1958, I took the 11-plus exam and was accepted into a grammar school, while my twin brother didn't pass and attended a secondary modern. Although I didn't excel enough to continue in the sixth form, I transferred to a further education college instead. There, I met someone who shared with me that he had also failed the 11-plus. His parents were so concerned about the social stigma associated with the local secondary modern that they sent him to a school in a neighboring town, whose uniform was unfamiliar to their neighbors.

"My 19-year-old son has developed a significant phobia of interviews, which has limited his job prospects. He's forced to choose between not working at all or taking on contract laborer jobs that are poorly paid and demanding. As an introverted and reserved individual, he struggles with talking about himself and his qualifications. He left school with six GCSEs at C grade, including math, English language, and science, which we thought was a respectable achievement, considering he never enjoyed school and struggled with most subjects. He may have dyslexia. After dropping out of a BTec in engineering without completing the course, his struggles began when he applied for weekend work at two large supermarkets at the age of 16. Despite doing his best in the interviews, he was asked to give a two-minute presentation at one, which left him terrified. He didn't receive any job offers and has since interpreted this as a sign that he's incompetent and unable to pass interviews. He's a capable young man, and I know it's okay for him to start with manual labor, but I believe he's capable of more. An apprenticeship in a trade would be ideal, but he refuses to consider any roles I suggest, citing his fear of not passing the interview. How can I support him in overcoming this fear, even if it means giving him space to figure it out on his own?"

Jimmy Choo, the luxury shoe and bag retailer, has been thriving since the EU referendum, with its prospects "never looking better" according to Chairman Peter Harf. The company is celebrating its 20th anniversary and has reported a 9.2% revenue growth for the first six months of the year, with operating profits increasing by 42.6% to £25.3m. The retailer is expanding globally, with plans to open around 10 new stores each year, and currently has 147 stores worldwide, including 10 in the UK. Despite generating only 9.5% of its revenue in sterling, Jimmy Choo benefits from the weaker pound, with 28% of its operating costs denominated in sterling. The company's men's footwear, including its popular Grove loafers, has become its fastest-growing category, accounting for 8% of revenues and expected to rise "well into double digits". Jimmy Choo is also expanding in China, where it is increasing its presence, and has seen strong like-for-like growth in the first half of the year. The company has also recorded growth in Hong Kong and Japan, where revenues rose by 22%. Unlike some other luxury goods retailers, such as Burberry, Jimmy Choo has not been significantly affected by a decline in Chinese tourist spending, which has been impacted by terrorist attacks in Europe since 2015. However, the company's UK stores have seen growth, with all locations having been refurbished. Jimmy Choo was founded in 1996 by shoe designer Jimmy Choo and Tamara Mellon, then the Vogue accessories editor.

This year, the UK has seen the largest number of car production in over a decade, with more than 1 million vehicles built in the first seven months. According to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, car production increased by 7.6% in July, reaching 126,566 units. So far in 2016, production has risen by 12.3% to 1,023,723 units, marking the first time since 2004 that the 1 million milestone has been reached in July. Despite the uncertainty surrounding the Brexit vote in June, the industry has seen a significant boost. Production for the UK market increased by 14.1% in July, while exports rose by 6%. Notably, almost 80% of cars manufactured this year, over 750,000 units, were destined for overseas markets, with the EU being the largest export market. Mike Hawes, CEO of the SMMT, attributes the industry's success to the demand for new British-built models worldwide. Hawes notes that manufacturers have invested heavily in developing new models and producing them competitively in the UK. However, he emphasizes that future success will depend on continued new car demand and attracting further investment, which will require the UK to demonstrate its competitiveness and openness to business. Following the EU referendum, the SMMT warned of a potential skills shortage if the rights of EU workers to work in the UK were restricted. Toyota Europe's CEO, Johan van Zyl, has stated that the company's future presence in Britain will depend on the outcome of negotiations between the UK and Brussels.
