The UK economy has defied expectations and avoided the recession predicted by many forecasters in the immediate aftermath of the Brexit vote. According to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), the first batch of economic data since the June 23 vote shows that the service sector, which accounts for approximately 80% of the UK economy, expanded by 0.4% in July. This is a remarkable performance, given the turmoil in financial markets and the crash in business and consumer confidence that occurred during the same period. As a result, analysts are revising their growth forecasts for the third quarter, with estimates ranging from 0.4% to 0.5%. The upward revision to growth in the second quarter, from 0.6% to 0.7%, has also bolstered hopes of avoiding a recession. Prior to the Brexit vote, the economy had significant momentum, and while it is likely to slow in the second half of 2016, it will not experience two consecutive quarters of declining output, which is the technical definition of a recession.

However, the government received less welcome news, as the UK's balance of payments deficit widened in the second quarter, reaching an alarming 5.7% of GDP in the first three months of 2016. The deterioration in the UK's trade performance was the primary driver of this increase, highlighting the imbalance in the economy. In essence, domestic producers are struggling to keep up with consumer demand. The post-Brexit decline in the value of sterling will make exports more competitive, but it will also curb consumer spending by making imports more expensive. Turning around the balance of payments will be a significant challenge, regardless of the outcome of the referendum.

In terms of policy, the Bank of England may reconsider cutting interest rates again in November, given the economy's resilience in the face of Brexit. The current interest rate of 0.25% is already at a record low, and the bank may be hesitant to reduce it further. The Bank of England, Threadneedle Street, may choose to conserve its resources for future use, allowing Chancellor Philip Hammond to take the lead. Despite the recent positive growth news, stimulus measures in the autumn statement still seem likely. This is because the uncertainty surrounding the Brexit vote is likely to have a more significant impact on long-term business decisions rather than consumer spending. Hammond would be wise to temporarily pause deficit reduction during the two-year Brexit negotiation period, using the extra £30 billion to fund public investment. This approach would have a double benefit: it would help maintain economic growth and ensure that growth is more balanced.

The owner of the Daily Mirror has achieved £20 million in cost savings this year, despite the tough trading conditions that continue to affect newspaper publishers. Trinity Mirror stated that the trading environment remains challenging, and the company is focusing on mitigating the decline in print revenue by increasing digital revenue and implementing cost-cutting measures. The company has exceeded its initial target of £15 million in structural cost savings, reaching £20 million for the year. Trinity Mirror, which also publishes regional newspapers such as the Manchester Evening News and Liverpool Echo, reported that print advertising revenue fell by 21% and newspaper sales revenue dropped by 6% in the third quarter. Total revenues decreased by 9% in the third quarter, slightly more than the 8% drop reported in the first half of the year. The company stated that publishing revenue has decreased by 10%, with print revenue falling by 12% and digital revenue increasing by 11%. Digital display advertising and transactional revenues grew by 24% as the company's online audience expanded. Despite the challenging trading environment, the company expressed confidence that its focus on growing digital revenue and reducing costs will result in profits in line with market expectations. In related news, Daily Mail & General Trust, owner of the Daily Mail, Mail Online, and Metro, announced plans to cut over 400 jobs this year. DMGT reported that print advertising revenue fell by 19% in September, compared to a 12% decline in the 11 months leading up to August.

Get ready to relive your childhood, 1980s kids! Teddy Ruxpin, the beloved talking animatronic toy, is making a comeback with a modern makeover. Gone are the cassette tapes and plastic eyes, replaced by a 4GB hard drive and animated LCD eyes. Wicked Cool Toys, the company behind the revamped Cabbage Patch Kid doll, is bringing back Teddy Ruxpin after an early prototype was showcased at the Dallas Toy Fair. The toy is scheduled to launch in 2017, but Wicked Cool Toys co-president Jeremy Padawer couldn't resist sharing the news with YouTube's Mommy and Gracie Show, saying, "The bear had to come out of the bag. We've shown Teddy a little early."

The company is targeting the original fans of Teddy Ruxpin, now grown up and becoming parents, who are nostalgic for the toy that was first launched in 1985. The toy was an instant hit, selling $93 million worth of units (1.4 million) in its first year and eventually selling over 8 million units and 11 million books. Teddy Ruxpin was one of the best-selling toys of the 1980s, alongside Polly Pocket, Glo Worm, Pound Puppies, and Glo Worm.

The original Teddy Ruxpin came with a slot for cassette tapes, which the toy would "read" to children while moving its eyes and mouth. The toy's creator, Ken Forsse, also wrote an accompanying fantasy world, following Teddy and his best friend, a caterpillar named Grubby, as they battled monsters and villains in a quest to find magic crystals. These stories were featured in the toy's accompanying story tapes and a 65-episode TV cartoon series.

Teddy Ruxpin was named one of the most memorable and creative toys of the 20th century by the Toy Industry Association in 2003 and one of the greatest toys of all time by Time magazine. Despite its popularity, Worlds of Wonder, the company that first made Teddy Ruxpin, struggled after the 1987 stock market crash and filed for bankruptcy. The license to manufacture the toy was later sold to Hasbro, which released a new version in the early 1990s. As the license was transferred to other companies, Teddy Ruxpin underwent several updates, with the most recent version being released in 2006, featuring digital audio cartridges instead of cassettes. According to Michael Rinzler, founding partner of Wicked Cool Toys, "Teddy Ruxpin's innovative play-pattern and integration of technology were well ahead of their time in the 80s, and with growing parental interest, now is the perfect opportunity to revive this beloved brand." The latest version of the toy comes equipped with a 4GB hard drive, capable of storing 40 stories, and can be paired with an iPad app, allowing children to read along as the toy narrates the stories. The toy's plushy hand features a button for navigating between stories, while a button in its foot enables a sing-along mode. For those seeking a blast of 80s nostalgia, the original Teddy Ruxpin commercial is available to view.

I've had a fixed-rate mortgage with Nationwide for approximately four years, initially for £100,000, but I've reduced it to £61,000 through overpayments. Now that I've had an offer accepted on a £685,000 house, I want to transfer my mortgage. However, Nationwide has refused to do so, insisting that I apply for a new mortgage instead. When I provided them with my past two years' earnings - £53,000 and £34,000 respectively - I was told that since I'm moving out of the area, I need to provide future predicted earnings. As a foster carer, this is not a straightforward process, and I'm only seeking a 10% mortgage. Despite my perfect payment history, with no missed payments or credit refusals, I've been told that there's no point in appealing the decision. If I choose to redeem my mortgage and switch to another lender, I'll face an early repayment fee of £3,000. Is this a fair request?

After taking up my case, Nationwide has reviewed its decision and agreed to allow me to port my mortgage. The lender claims that it's their duty to assess customers' financial situations and ability to repay loans for every mortgage application. I welcome letters and encourage readers to email us at consumer.champions@theguardian.com or write to Consumer Champions, Money, the Guardian, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU, including a daytime phone number.

House of Fraser's profits plummeted nearly 50% in the first half of the year, citing a "very challenging retail environment" due to unseasonable weather and Brexit uncertainty. The department store's underlying profits fell 46% to £5m, from £9.2m the previous year, excluding interest payments, tax, and other one-off items. The decline in profits was attributed to the increased cost of online delivery and a decrease in sales of House of Fraser's own brands. Total sales remained steady at £573.5m, but the group's established department stores experienced a 2.5% slump. Meanwhile, underlying sales, which include a 17.8% rise in online sales, showed a 0.9% increase. House of Fraser's CEO, Nigel Oddy, described the trading environment as "extremely volatile" and attributed the profit slump to a combination of factors, including record temperatures in September and uncertainty surrounding the EU referendum. Oddy noted that shoppers are now more likely to buy products to wear immediately, rather than waiting for sales. He also cited consumer confidence concerns about the impact of Brexit on household finances as a contributing factor. To combat these challenges, House of Fraser is introducing new brands and concessions, including five Hamleys toy areas and All Saints, Monsoon, and Mulberry. "Despite struggling, the department store's performance stood in stark contrast to the impressive results of online retailer Boohoo.com. The company reported a remarkable 40% surge in sales and a 129% increase in pre-tax profits for the six-month period ending August 31. Boohoo.com's success can be attributed to its ability to attract 28% more customers and increase the average transaction value as it expanded its presence in Europe and the US, while also broadening its product offerings in menswear, lingerie, and plus-size women's clothing."

Thomas Cook's summer bookings declined by 4% due to a significant drop in demand for holidays in Turkey following a series of terrorist attacks and an attempted coup. According to a recent trading update, summer bookings excluding Turkey increased by 4%, but a 40% decline in trips to Turkey resulted in a total booking decrease. Bookings in continental Europe were heavily impacted, particularly among German tourists who shunned Turkey, while bookings in the UK rose by 1%. Thomas Cook has been severely affected by terrorist attacks in Tunisia, Egypt, and Turkey since summer 2015, with the company offering customers with bookings to Turkey free cancellation after the failed military coup in July. Bookings from Belgium also decreased following the terrorist attacks on Brussels in March. The company warned in July that it had slumped to a quarterly loss and would miss its annual profit target. Thomas Cook's CEO, Peter Fankhauser, has stated that the travel industry is experiencing the most turbulent period he has seen in his 30-year career, citing terrorist attacks and other incidents as major factors affecting consumer confidence. Despite the challenges, Thomas Cook's shares rose 4% to 73p, with the company maintaining its reduced guidance for an operating profit of £300m for the year ending September 30, down from £310m the previous year. Group bookings were in line with expectations, with customers shifting their focus from Turkey to destinations such as the Balearic and Canary islands, the US, Bulgaria, and Cuba. Fankhauser noted that the summer season has progressed largely as expected, with customer demand remaining strong except for Turkey, where demand remains volatile. He also mentioned that sales for the winter season are in line with last year's figures, while summer 2017 bookings suggest that customers are booking early to secure their preferred destinations and hotels. Demand for holidays among UK consumers appears to be unaffected by the uncertainty surrounding the Brexit vote on June 23, with UK summer bookings excluding Turkey rising 13% and making Britain Thomas Cook's strongest region. The winter season has also started well in the UK, with bookings up 8%.

Earlier today, I presented you with a set of puzzles, each crafted by William Hartston, also known as Bill from Gogglebox. The puzzles were as follows:

1. What is the next number in the sequence: 23, 9, 20, 14, 14, 9, 20, 6,...?

2. The series appears to be a code, where each term is the first letter of a monarch's name. For example, Mary I corresponds to the first letter "M", George III corresponds to the third letter "G", and so on. Why might Henry I be a fitting conclusion to this series?

3. What comes next in the sequence: 2.1, 3.5, 3.3, 2.3, 1.3, 2.4, 2.5, 2.6, 1.8,...?

4. What is the next number in the sequence: 1, 2, 9, 12, 70, 89, 97, 102,...?

The solutions to these puzzles are:

1. The answer is 19, as the numbers correspond to the alphabet positions of the first letters of the words in the question.

2. The code is indeed a clever one, as it spells out the word "monarch" when each term is taken to represent the first letter of a monarch's name.

3. The sequence appears to be related to the layout of a QWERTY keyboard, where each term corresponds to the row and column position of a letter in alphabetical order.

4. The answer is 112, as each number in the sequence is one less than the corresponding number when viewed upside down.

Bill, the creator of these puzzles, shares an interesting anecdote about how he came up with the fourth puzzle. He was approached by a Cambridge mathematician who was about to compete in a puzzle-solving competition against Oxford. The mathematician asked Bill to come up with an original puzzle for the informal portion of the contest, and Bill's creation was the result. Although no one was able to solve it, everyone agrees that the puzzle is fair and logical. "I'd like to express my gratitude to Bill once again for allowing me to use these puzzles. Don't miss his latest book, "Even More Things That Nobody Knows: 501 Further Mysteries of Life, the Universe and Everything", which will be available in paperback in November. I typically post a new puzzle every two weeks on a Monday. If you have a puzzle you'd like to share, please feel free to email me - I'd love to hear it! As an author, I've written several books on mathematics, as well as the children's book "Football School: Where Football Explains the World", which is full of fascinating facts that parents often don't share, such as when footballers use the bathroom, why eagles are a common mascot for football teams, and even how to play football on Mars. You can find me on Twitter, Facebook, Google+, my personal website, or my Guardian maths blog."

John Simpson, a veteran BBC journalist, has accused successive governments of displaying "savagery" and taking "ideological delight" in attacking the corporation. Simpson, who has spent five decades at the BBC, including his current role as world affairs editor, told The Guardian that the BBC and the National Health Service (NHS) should be controlled by non-partisan, non-political groups that don't have an axe to grind. He believes that both sides of the House of Commons frequently attack the BBC because it refuses to conform to their party lines. Simpson's strongest criticism was reserved for Tony Blair and his former press secretary Alistair Campbell, whom he accused of being involved in the Hutton affair and of colluding with Rupert Murdoch. "It's astonishing to see the British prime minister cozying up to someone who has no interest in Britain, is deeply opposed to Britain, and is hostile to the country's main national broadcaster," Simpson said. He believes that most governments he has worked with over his 50-year career at the BBC have a "disgraceful political obsession" to cut down the BBC. "I'm not saying that cuts can't be made, but it's the brutality and ideological fervor with which they're implemented that's disturbing," he said. Simpson also criticized the government's decision to keep the BBC underfunded since 2010, saying it's "absolutely disgraceful." He also expressed his disapproval of the draft BBC charter, which requires the corporation to reveal the salaries of staff earning over £150,000, saying it's just a way for the government to demonstrate its control. Simpson made these comments just three days after being released from the hospital, where he had been treated for kidney failure caused by a reaction to eating kedgeree. "It's acceptable for individuals like myself, who receive favorable treatment. However, as you progress down the hierarchy, it becomes significantly more challenging. People are anxious about their job security... there's a harsh environment, particularly towards junior staff members."

"After a brief holiday to recharge, I'll begin filming the Panorama special. I plan to travel to Iraq, Russia, China, and possibly the US, and I'm eager to visit a particularly troubled region like the Congo."

Initially, there was a plan for a short series, but BBC commissioners rejected it. "They told me that we don't want current affairs journalists covering current events," I was informed. "I believe what they meant was that nowadays they prefer to feature celebrities like Joanna Lumley."

My latest book, We Chose to Speak of War and Strife, is a tribute to the foreign correspondents of yesteryear, who I believe are a dying breed. They've been impacted by the financial struggles of the media and the increased use of technology.

British Prime Minister Theresa May has publicly expressed her full support for Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, amid growing indications that he may extend his eight-year term beyond the initial five-year period. May praised Carney's efforts to navigate the UK economy through the post-Brexit period and said she would support him if he decides to delay his departure from Threadneedle Street until 2021. According to May's spokeswoman, the Prime Minister has consistently expressed her admiration for Carney's work and would be supportive of him staying on beyond his initial term. The spokeswoman added that May has a good working relationship with Carney and intends to continue it.

Carney has stated that he will make a decision about his future plans before the end of the year, but has also emphasized the need to resolve the matter before then. His next public appearance will be at a press conference on Thursday to discuss the Bank's quarterly inflation report, which will be released for the first time since the Bank cut interest rates to a record low in August.

May's recent comments at the Conservative party conference, in which she criticized the side-effects of ultra-low interest rates and money creation under the quantitative easing program, had sparked speculation about a rift between Downing Street and the Bank. However, No 10 quickly apologized to Carney, insisting that the remarks were not intended to convey a lack of confidence in his leadership. Despite this, senior Conservatives, including William Hague and Michael Gove, have since launched strong attacks on the Bank's monetary policy.

Carney has been the Bank's Governor since July 2013, when he initially stated that he would only serve for five years. "He has been deliberating on whether to stick to his original plan or stay at Threadneedle Street until 2021. Chancellor Philip Hammond has already expressed his support for Mark Carney serving a full eight-year term. Hammond believes that the governor's departure would cause unnecessary turmoil, especially given the pound's recent struggles on the foreign exchange market."

Apple has finally put an end to one of the most frustrating and potentially embarrassing aspects of the MacBook Pro: the Mac startup chime is no longer audible. From now on, new MacBook Pros, both with and without the new emoji bar, will quietly boot up as soon as they're turned on. The chime, which was first introduced with the Macintosh Quadra line of computers in 1991, served as a signal that the computer had passed its initial diagnostic tests and was ready to begin the boot sequence. Initially, the chime was a C-major chord, but it was changed to an F-sharp chord starting in 1998 with the release of the first iMac. While it was possible to mute the startup chime if the computer was muted before being turned off, the loud and often jarring sound had become more of a nuisance than a helpful indicator for most Mac laptop users. For many, the startup chime was a source of embarrassment, whether it was in a library, a coffee shop, or on public transportation. In any case, it's time to bid farewell to the Mac startup chime, which will no longer disrupt the silent startup ritual.

I placed an order for a mixed case of beer from Beer Hawk online and paid in full, expecting three-day delivery. However, it took 10 days for the order to arrive, and the tracking information showed that the case had not even left the warehouse. Beer Hawk's responses to my emails have been sporadic, with occasional promises that the beers would be sent out soon, but they never materialized. A review of recent posts on Reviews.co.uk reveals a pattern of dissatisfied customers, and I've also noticed negative feedback on their Facebook page, which is promptly deleted. When I check the status of my order, it remains stuck in "pending" mode. As a occasional customer, I was considering ordering more regularly, but the poor service has left me feeling let down and regretful, leading me to decide to take my business elsewhere.

Beer Hawk, a specialist beer retailer, claims to "hunt out" the world's best beer from over 500 options. However, a quick internet search reveals that customers have had difficulties with delivery and customer service. When I contacted them, someone answered promptly, which led to a phone call from co-founder and director Chris France. France explained that the company has recently moved to new premises and upgraded its warehouse management system, resulting in a small number of delayed orders, including mine. He acknowledged that the company failed to respond quickly to my emails and missed its own 24-hour response target. France apologized and offered a full refund and the option to accept the beer I ordered for free as a token of their apology. He emphasized the importance of good customer service, which is fundamental to their business. "Beer Hawk consistently scores 4.7 out of 5, and our investment in a new warehouse and systems aims to further improve this rating. Unfortunately, some customers have experienced a temporary disruption, and I have personally apologized to ML for this inconvenience. We value your feedback and welcome letters, though please note that we cannot respond individually. You can reach us at consumer.champions@theguardian.com or by writing to Consumer Champions, Money, The Guardian, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Please include a daytime phone number with your correspondence."

A cross-party group of nearly 90 MPs, led by former Conservative chairman and minister Grant Shapps, has called on ministers to take action to eradicate mobile signal "not spots" that leave some UK residents with worse phone reception than overseas visitors. The British Infrastructure Group (BIG) has declared that the time for excuses from mobile network providers is over, citing the unacceptable state of mobile connectivity in some areas of Britain. In a report, the MPs argued that it is unacceptable that some parts of the country still have poor mobile coverage, while visitors from abroad can expect better reception due to their networks' national roaming capabilities. The group proposed an amendment to the government's digital economy bill, which would allow Ofcom to fine mobile operators that fail to meet targets set in a 2014 agreement. Under that agreement, the four major network operators (MNOs) pledged to invest £5 billion in improving coverage across the UK by December 2017 in exchange for the government not introducing national roaming. However, the BIG report found little evidence to suggest that the mobile sector will meet its targets to provide coverage to 90% of the UK's geographic area, and is calling for a progress update by the end of 2016. According to Shapps, "If you have a foreign SIM card and use it in the UK, you'll get better coverage than if you were using one of the UK's companies. It's astonishing." The MPs also urged customers to be able to terminate their mobile agreements without penalty if their operator fails to provide a satisfactory level of coverage in their area. A spokesperson for the Department for Culture, Media and Sport stated: "We understand the inconvenience of poor mobile coverage, which is why we have made it mandatory for each mobile network operator to provide coverage to at least 90% of the UK by the end of next year." The mobile phone operators claim they are working diligently to enhance coverage. An EE spokesperson told the Daily Mail: "While we acknowledge the importance of increased mobile coverage for a digital Britain, this report neglects the significant advancements in mobile coverage since 2014."

The European Union's pan-privacy watchdogs have issued a warning to WhatsApp, urging it to halt the transfer of personal data to its parent company Facebook. The Article 29 Working Party, a collective of EU data protection authorities, expressed serious concerns over WhatsApp's recent privacy policy change and the sharing of user phone numbers with Facebook. In a letter to WhatsApp, the Article 29 Working Party requested that the company provide all relevant information and pause the sharing of user data until adequate legal protections are in place.

WhatsApp has responded to the concerns, stating that it has had constructive conversations with the authorities and remains committed to respecting applicable law. Meanwhile, the Article 29 Working Party has also written to Yahoo regarding a massive data breach in 2014, which exposed the email credentials of 500 million users. The watchdogs have requested information on all aspects of the breach and demanded that Yahoo notify users of the "adverse effects" and cooperate with national data protection authorities' inquiries and investigations.

The Article 29 Working Party has also sought information from Yahoo regarding its practice of scanning customers' incoming emails for specific information provided by US intelligence officials. The watchdogs have invited Yahoo to provide information on the legal basis and compatibility with EU law of this activity.

The Working Party will discuss the WhatsApp and Yahoo privacy cases in November. The letters come as European nations express concern over WhatsApp's changes and Yahoo's mishandling of its hack and the revelations over US intelligence operations. In related developments, Germany has ordered Facebook to stop collecting WhatsApp user data and delete any data it has already acquired, while the United Nations has warned that Yahoo's actions raise serious human rights concerns.

Google's parent company, Alphabet, surprised analysts by reporting a 20.2% increase in quarterly revenue, while Amazon fell short of expectations due to increased spending ahead of the holiday season. Amazon's profit dropped to $252 million, or 52 cents per share, missing analysts' predictions of 85 cents per share. The company's revenue reached $32.71 billion, but is expected to reach between $42 billion and $45.5 billion in the fourth quarter. Meanwhile, Alphabet continues to dominate the mobile advertising market, along with Facebook, thanks to robust sales on mobile devices and YouTube. The company plans to repurchase around $7 billion of its Class C stock and saw its shares rise 1.6% in after-hours trading. Google's ad revenue jumped 18.1% to $19.82 billion, accounting for 89.1% of its total revenue, with paid clicks increasing 33%. However, the average cost-per-click fell 11%, down from a 7% drop in the previous quarter. Analysts had predicted a 7.9% decline. The decline in cost-per-click is attributed to the shift from desktop to mobile devices, where ad space is limited and cheaper. According to eMarketer, Google is expected to capture 56.9% of the global search ad revenue market in 2016, with $52.88 billion in revenue. Google's "Other Revenue" segment, which includes its cloud business, saw a 38.8% increase, while Alphabet's "Other Bets" generated revenue of $197 million but reported an operating loss of $865 million. "In the previous year, the company reported revenue of $141 million and a loss of $980 million. Other Bets, a division of Alphabet, comprises various businesses, including Google Fiber, Nest, self-driving cars, and X, the company's research facility focused on innovative "moon shot" projects. Alphabet's consolidated revenue increased to $22.45 billion in the third quarter ending September 30, up from $18.68 billion in the same period the previous year. The company's net income also rose to $5.06 billion. Since the start of the year, Alphabet's shares have appreciated by 5.1%."

The Royal Bank of Scotland has been threatened with a £1.25 billion lawsuit by a group of private investors over its 2008 cash call. The RBoS Shareholder Action Group, which represents 27,000 retail investors, issued the warning after reports that other shareholders were considering settling out of court. The group, one of at least three bringing claims related to the rights issue in 2008, is eager to take on Fred Goodwin and RBS in court in March. The group is the only one suing Goodwin, who was RBS's CEO at the time of the £45 billion taxpayer bailout, and three of the bank's former executives. The legal action is on behalf of thousands of investors, both private and institutional, who lost money by subscribing to shares during the 2008 RBS rights issue. The announcement was made ahead of RBS's third-quarter results, which will be closely scrutinized for any further provisions related to the case. In August, RBS set aside £700 million for the case after mediation talks in July failed to reach a settlement. The total claim by all the investors involved totals £4 billion. The court action by disgruntled investors is just one of many factors that could feature in the bank's results on Friday, when it is expected to report further losses on top of the £52 billion it has already incurred since the bailout. The bank is also expected to provide an update on the potential spin-out of 300 branches, which were previously slated to be rebranded Williams & Glyn, as well as face questions about the alleged mistreatment of small-business customers. Additionally, RBS has warned investors that it faces a difficult-to-quantify settlement with the US Department of Justice (DoJ) over the sale of mortgage bonds in the run-up to the 2008 financial crisis. Chancellor Philip Hammond recently stated that he cannot sell off any of the 73% taxpayer stake in the bank for now. "At the time, he acknowledged that it's not feasible to sell RBS shares at a price that returns taxpayers' investment, citing the challenges surrounding the spin-off of Williams & Glyn and the ongoing lawsuit with the DoJ. Currently, RBS shares are trading at around 190p, significantly below the 502p average price paid by taxpayers during the financial crisis."

The payment protection insurance scandal has cost banks and financial services companies over £40 billion to resolve. The cost of the scandal, the largest in UK financial services history, has increased by £600 million after Barclays set aside additional funds to handle claims. According to data from New City Agenda, this latest contribution from Barclays brings the total provisions to £40.2 billion, with Lloyds Banking Group accounting for £17 billion of that amount. The large payouts have been cited as a factor in the surge in car sales and holiday bookings. In fact, the payouts could be seen as a boost to household income, equivalent to one penny off income tax, which would cost £4 billion. However, not all the money has been distributed directly to consumers. According to the Financial Conduct Authority, from January 2011 to July 2018, banks and other firms that sold PPI distributed around £25 billion to customers. Claims management companies have received up to £5 billion of this amount. The banks have also incurred significant costs in handling the claims, which they have set aside in anticipation of more applications for compensation. Over 50 million PPI policies were sold, with banks responsible for around 45 million policies worth £40 billion. The Financial Conduct Authority has closed a consultation on setting a deadline for claims, which could result in a cut-off point of June 2019 for remaining customers to make their claims. The deadline will also trigger a £40 million advertising campaign to encourage customers to come forward and beat the deadline.

I'm not convinced that the Daily Star's front page on Wednesday was clever (although I acknowledge that the Star is not typically known for its cleverness). The previous day's front page had carried the headline "Pete Burns dies of heart attack at 57" and reported that the "pop icon" had passed away following a massive heart attack. Therefore, the following day's front page, "Pete Burns: How I came back from the dead", was puzzling. Had the initial report been incorrect, or was Pete Burns still alive? Had a miracle occurred? Apparently not. According to the article, Pete Burns had revealed a haunting secret just before his fatal heart attack: he had previously been thought to have died, and a priest had been summoned to administer last rites. This revelation allegedly came from a haunting final interview conducted weeks before his death, which the Star quoted extensively (although it has yet to upload the interview to its website). It seems clear that the Wednesday headline was intended to suggest that reports of his death had been exaggerated, as Mark Twain once said. Moreover, it also has a poor taste to it. I'm aware of the dark irony: Pete Burns was a member of the 1980s band Dead or Alive.

I previously reported that the Buenos Aires Herald, the only English-language daily newspaper in Latin America, would be transitioning to a weekly publication. An emailer asked why we should care about the fate of a newspaper in Argentina. While the tone of the question was somewhat chauvinistic, the importance of reporting on media developments elsewhere lies in its ability to provide a broader perspective on the "worldwide phenomenon" of journalism in crisis. The Buenos Aires Herald's editorial on the matter highlights a universal concern: the crisis facing the journalism industry. The paper expressed its "unspeakable sadness" at having to cease daily publication, citing the "dramatic change" in the media industry, which is driven by people's preference for accessing news for free online rather than through print. The Herald acknowledged that this shift could have severe consequences, including the potential loss of up to 2,000 journalist jobs in Argentina in 2016, which would have a significant impact on the profession. The paper is not immune to these changes, as it is reducing its staff significantly due to the transition to a weekly publication. In fact, 14 employees are leaving the company today. The Herald's history dates back 140 years, and it has had its share of notable moments, including its defiance of Argentina's military dictatorship in the 1970s and 1980s. The paper's editor at the time, Robert Cox, was forced into exile due to threats and intimidation, but his heroism was recognized in 2010 when he was granted honorary citizenship. Starting November 4, the weekly Herald will be published on Fridays, allowing readers to enjoy it at their leisure over the weekend. The emailer might want to consider the implications of the decline in full-time journalists for democracies around the world. "I acknowledge that we can sometimes exaggerate our importance to society and that we are far from flawless. However, as the Herald editorial so aptly put it, "freedom of expression is a delicate flower" that requires careful handling. Despite the challenges and controversies that often come with our profession, the benefits of a free press far outweigh its drawbacks. While we may not be perfect, it's worth lamenting the decline of journalism rather than crying for ourselves."

Gina Rinehart, Australia's richest woman, has invested £245 million in the UK's largest potash mine, located on the edge of the North York Moors national park. The £1.7 billion mine, which was approved last year after a lengthy planning battle, promises to restore the region's mining heritage and create over 1,000 jobs. The project received a significant boost on Tuesday when Sirius Minerals, the company behind the Yorkshire mine, announced a US$300 million deal with Rinehart's Australian agricultural company, Hancock Prospecting. The mine, situated on protected moorland overlooking Whitby and Robin Hood's Bay, aims to produce up to 20 million tonnes of polyhalite, a type of potash fertilizer, per year. Under the deal, Rinehart will acquire $50 million worth of Sirius shares and pay $250 million for a 5% royalty stream on the first 13 million tonnes of fertilizer produced annually, as well as the right to purchase up to 20,000 tonnes of product each year for use on her expanding Australian agricultural holdings. Rinehart stated that the project aligns with Hancock's focus on agriculture, as it delivers a new and natural product that has demonstrated improved yields in field tests across various crop types. She added that Sirius has a large, high-quality mineral resource and is located in a stable jurisdiction with a competitive tax rate, making it an attractive investment opportunity. The mine shaft, which is over a mile deep, was approved by a narrow margin in June 2015 after a four-year planning dispute that drew opposition from conservationists. Notably, the project was supported by 93% of local residents who wrote to the council, with 81% of those living within the national park. However, the project faced opposition from several organizations, including the National Trust, Natural England, the Campaign for National Parks, the North Yorkshire Moors Association, the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, the Campaign to Protect Rural England, and the Yorkshire Wildlife Trust. According to Sirius, the mine is expected to boost North Yorkshire's economy by 10%, injecting £48 million directly into the local area, which has struggled to recover from the decline of the coal and fishing industries. The mined polyhalite will be transported via a 23-mile underground conveyor belt beneath the North York Moors national park to a handling facility in Teesside. Chris Fraser, Sirius's managing director and chief executive, expressed his delight at signing the agreement with a reputable and experienced mining company, boasting strong leadership and a growing agricultural interest.

A surprising turn of events has occurred at the Student Accommodation Awards, hosted by Property Week, as a panel of 10 students invited to judge the "student experience" category refused to choose a winner in protest of increasing rent prices. The students, handpicked by Property Week, instead criticized the entrants for pricing out poorer students and contributing to the "social cleansing of education". The panel cited a 2015 study by the National Union of Students, which showed that university rent in the UK increased by 18% over two years, reaching an average of £146 per week. The report attributed the rise to the growth of private providers. In response to the students' decision, a spokesperson for the Student Accommodation Awards stated that the industry needs to do better and that the category would be removed from the inaugural event, with a review for 2017. The awards will continue to encourage the industry to prioritize the student experience.

Jenny Killin, welfare officer at the University of Aberdeen students' association, was part of the panel and expressed her concerns about the "real student experience" being a choice between paying bills or buying food. She emphasized that students are accumulating huge levels of debt, primarily to benefit private businesses. Killin tweeted an open letter to Property Week, pointing out that students' maintenance loans barely cover the cheapest rooms at some institutions. The letter emphasized that students cannot celebrate or award a "for-profit sector" that is failing many of their peers.

This development follows a series of university rent strikes and demonstrations coordinated by student activists over the past year. "A recent blog post in the Guardian features an anonymous student activist who argues that rent strikes are more than just a complaint about rising student housing costs. Rather than being seen as entitled students complaining about paying rent, the activist contends that the real issue is that high rents are preventing poorer students from accessing higher education. To stay up-to-date on the latest news and insights from Guardian Students, follow us on Twitter @GdnStudents and become a member to receive exclusive benefits and our weekly newsletter."

I have taken on the responsibility of managing the financial affairs of an elderly individual suffering from dementia. In March 2013, he joined Money Club, paying an annual fee of £98, despite not having a computer or the mental capacity to use the service. It is unclear how he was sold the membership, as he was already experiencing memory loss at the time. An additional £98 was taken in March 2014, and subsequently, 20 more payments have been made through direct debit, totaling £2,148. I have tried to contact Money Club without success. According to the records, he should have only been charged three payments of £98 from 2013 to 2016.

Money Club has a history of cold calling, offering a free trial, and then committing customers to an annual subscription without fully disclosing the terms. Despite its claims to be the "UK's premier shopping club," the company runs a discount and cashback website. Several readers have reported being overcharged due to the annual £98 subscription being randomly debited. One reader recently shared that their account had been debited 29 times over a five-year period.

Money Club attributes the issue to a computer upgrade, stating that the frequency of payments was left blank, resulting in arbitrary debits. They claim that the error was not detected because there is no evidence of the individual using the club. The company is refunding all payments, but it is essential to cancel the direct debit. If you need assistance, please email Anna Tims at your.problems@observer.co.uk or write to Your Problems, The Observer, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU, including your address and phone number.

Nils Pratley's article ("PM needs to stand firm on executive pay ratios", 29 November) highlights the fact that directors are already trying to weaken Theresa May's initial proposal to shed light on employee pay ratios. May has consistently supported her government's austerity policies, which have had devastating effects on the most vulnerable members of our society since 2010. Now is the time for her to follow through on her promise. What's the risk in requiring companies to publish details of every employee's contract, including terms of employment, pension contributions, share options, severance terms, and other benefits? Not all executives are self-serving, but many are. The boards of our leading banks and financial institutions, often working with unsavory characters, created the problems we're facing today. It's time for business leaders to take responsibility and show that they treat their employees fairly. How many can honestly say that they do?

Regarding worker representation on boards, Greg Clark's statement on BBC Radio 4's Today programme ("We are not going to make it happen") is concerning. He claimed the government doesn't want to "overturn what has been a successful system" that has the confidence of businesses worldwide. But what constitutes success? It certainly hasn't been good for workers, whom the government is supposed to represent. Democracy shouldn't be limited to votes from self-serving entities. We should also consider the success of worker representation in Germany and other European countries.

To join the debate, email guardian.letters@theguardian.com. For more Guardian letters, visit gu.com/letters.

Rupert Murdoch is likely to suffer significant losses on his $100 million investment in Theranos, a blood testing startup that has been plagued by scandals exposed by the Wall Street Journal, his flagship publication. Murdoch invested $100 million in Theranos between 2014 and 2015, when the company's valuation was soaring due to its promise to revolutionize blood testing with low-cost finger pricks. The Wall Street Journal reported that Murdoch was part of a group of wealthy investors who pumped $632 million into Theranos's latest funding round, valuing the company at nearly $9 billion and making it the highest-valued private healthcare startup in the US. Before investing, Murdoch reportedly toured Theranos's laboratories in Palo Alto and inspected its proprietary devices. However, the Wall Street Journal, which is owned by Murdoch's News Corp, has published a series of investigative stories questioning the accuracy of Theranos's testing and management techniques. The WSJ investigation, which persisted despite intense pressure on its whistleblower from Theranos and its board of high-profile figures, led to a government investigation that found the company's practices put patients' lives at risk. As a result, Theranos's CEO, Elizabeth Holmes, was banned from the blood testing business for two years, and the company was forced to shut down its labs. The company, which Holmes founded at the age of 19 in 2003, is now facing both criminal and civil investigations by the US attorney's office in San Francisco and the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is investigating whether the company misled investors and regulators. Some investors have launched a lawsuit against the company, claiming they were misled, and hope to attract others to join the suit. Other high-profile Theranos investors include billionaire Riley Bechtel, chairman of the private construction giant Bechtel Group, and Cox Enterprises, a family-controlled conglomerate. The company also secured big names for its board, including Henry Kissinger and George Shultz, both former secretaries of state. "Earlier this month, The Wall Street Journal uncovered a shocking revelation: Tyler Shultz, the 26-year-old grandson of former Secretary of State George Shultz, was the whistleblower who came forward with concerns about Theranos. Shultz, who joined the company in 2013, left Theranos in 2014 after his warnings were dismissed as arrogant, patronizing, and reckless. Neither News Corp nor Theranos chose to comment on the matter."

I've been a personal customer of HSBC since 1964, but recently they announced that they will be closing the four accounts held by the campaign organization Searchlight, citing a "review". When I followed up with the bank, they insisted that their decision was final and wouldn't provide any further explanation. Searchlight, which has been fighting against racism and fascism for 52 years, is a well-respected organization that has published a magazine since 1975. We're not affiliated with any political party and are multi-faith. Our income comes from occasional grants, donations, and subscriptions, which are paid in by cheque, standing order, or bank transfer. We have very few international transactions and can't think of anything in our account use that could raise concerns. The only reason I can think of for the closure is that the fascist individuals and organizations we combat may have maliciously provided false information to the bank, and HSBC accepted it without investigation. This sudden closure is very disruptive, and we're applying to open new accounts with another bank, but we're unsure if they'll accept our application due to HSBC's actions.

HSBC's response to our situation is concerning, as they're refusing to reconsider their decision, except for encouraging us to speak to the media. When I contact the bank, I receive a flurry of phone calls, and then senior officials beg for a meeting. However, the outcome is always the same: the four accounts are reinstated, but with no further explanation. The bank's press office is only willing to provide a vague statement, saying that they aim to provide the highest standard of customer service and work closely with customers to resolve issues as soon as possible. "I'm increasingly receiving reports of bank accounts being closed without warning, often due to banks' overcautious reactions to US anti-money laundering regulations. HSBC, for instance, narrowly avoided prosecution by the US Congress, which may have led it to become overly vigilant in scrutinizing accounts with political or foreign transaction ties. This can affect anyone, from ordinary households to prominent advocacy groups. Unfortunately, it's rare for banks to reverse their decisions, even if their actions seem puzzling. If you're experiencing a similar issue, you can reach out to Anna Tims at your.problems@observer.co.uk or write to The Observer at Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Please include your address and phone number."

A group of former BHS workers and trade union representatives are planning to visit the headquarters of Sir Philip Green's Arcadia business to demand that he fill the £571m deficit in the collapsed department store chain's pension scheme. Over 100,000 people have signed a petition calling on Green to honor his promise to "sort" the pension scheme, which has more than 20,000 members. The petition, led by John Hannett, general secretary of the shopworkers' trade union Usdaw, will be delivered to Arcadia on Wednesday. Green had previously promised to address the pension scheme's issues during a parliamentary hearing in June, but has since failed to reach an agreement with the Pensions Regulator, which has launched legal proceedings against him and Dominic Chappell, the former owners of BHS. Hannett emphasized that Green needs to contribute more than £250m to the scheme, calling any less "derisory". He urged Green to "do the right thing" and fulfill his promise, stating that anything less would be unacceptable for former staff who spent their careers at BHS. The petition includes comments from BHS workers, such as "This man's greed is unbelievable and I worked for him." The collapse of BHS in April led to the loss of 11,000 jobs and a £571m pension deficit. A parliamentary investigation found that BHS was systematically plundered under Green's and Chappell's leadership, with Green and his family collecting at least £580m from the retailer while Chappell's company Retail Acquisitions received an estimated £17m.

Harland and Wolff Heavy Industries Ltd, the Belfast shipyard that built the Titanic, has secured a £20m contract to manufacture 60 steel foundation jackets for the East Anglia One offshore windfarm. The contract will safeguard 200 jobs and will see the company produce three-legged steel jackets that stand over 65 metres high and weigh over 845 tonnes. Work on the foundation jackets is set to begin in the second quarter of 2017 and is expected to be completed by the end of 2018. The East Anglia One windfarm, which is valued at £2.5bn, will generate enough electricity to power 500,000 homes by 2020. Jonathan Guest, Harland and Wolff's director of business development, praised Scottish Power Renewables for giving local fabricators the opportunity to work on the project. Keith Anderson, the chief executive of Scottish Power Renewables, said that the East Anglia One windfarm will be the best value offshore windfarm ever constructed, while also delivering industry-leading levels of UK content. Harland and Wolff, which was formed in 1862, is based in Belfast and has a rich history of shipbuilding, including the construction of the Titanic. The company has survived by diversifying away from shipbuilding and has been involved in the construction of oil and gas rigs, as well as the recasting of Halfpenny Bridge in Dublin. In recent years, Harland and Wolff has focused on the booming offshore windfarm industry, which now accounts for 75% of its work.

I previously reported that Bahraini authorities arrested politician Ebrahim Sharif nine days ago, following a visit to Bahrain by Prince Charles. Sharif was charged with "inciting hatred" against the Gulf monarchy's rulers, which carries a possible three-year jail sentence. I am pleased to announce that the charges against him have been dropped, according to a tweet from Bahrain's UK embassy. Sharif was detained after giving an interview to the Associated Press, in which he expressed concerns that Prince Charles's visit could "whitewash" Bahrain's treatment of dissidents. The Bahraini chief prosecutor took action after receiving a complaint from the Cyber Crime Directorate about Sharif's alleged defamation of Bahrain's constitutional system. The US State Department had called for the charges to be dropped, and the British Foreign Office had pledged to raise Sharif's case with the Bahraini government. Ebrahim Sharif, the former leader of Bahrain's secular National Democratic Action Society, has a history of political activism, having spent four years in prison until 2015 and being rearrested and sentenced to another year in prison for making a political speech.

My husband, Harry Jones, who passed away at the age of 86, had a lifelong commitment to education, serving as a dedicated teacher and college principal at both sixth-form and technical colleges, as well as in adult education. Born and raised in County Durham, Harry was the son of William Jones, a miner, and his wife, May (née Cowley). His father was forced to begin working in the mines at the age of 12 to support the family, while his mother, May, left school at 14 but was an avid reader. May's access to the library on the estate of the Backhouses, the Darlington bankers, where she worked as a housekeeper and her husband was a coachman, provided Harry with a pre-school education. The family relocated to Coventry in 1940 due to unemployment in Durham, where they experienced the challenges of wartime air raids. At the time, grammar schools were fee-paying institutions that only accepted a select few, and Harry was fortunate enough to secure a spot at King Edward VI school in Nuneaton. However, his secondary education was disrupted when the school was bombed, and pupils were forced to attend school only on Tuesdays and Thursdays to receive work to complete at home. Even when full-time schooling resumed, the school lacked essential facilities such as laboratories, a gymnasium, and a library. Despite these challenges, Harry excelled academically and was an exceptional student. In addition to his academic achievements, he was an accomplished rugby player, selected for Warwickshire's under-18 team, editor of the school magazine, and a talented actor who played Prospero and Bottom in school productions. He also won awards for public speaking and was recognized as the best all-around athlete. After completing his national service as a technical instructor, Harry claimed that the army taught him how to teach in just six weeks. He then went on to attend Birmingham University, where we met. Harry began his teaching career as a lecturer in English at West Bromwich and later became a senior lecturer in liberal studies at Ipswich. Throughout his career, he supported the movement to liberalize traditional technical colleges, which ultimately led to the establishment of new universities. As the head of department at Northampton College of Further Education, vice principal at Dacorum College in Hemel Hempstead, and principal at Borehamwood College of Further Education, he conceptualized a student-focused fusion of sixth-form college, technical college, and adult education, serving as a community resource. As principal of Isle College in Wisbech from 1978, he worked tirelessly to bring this vision to life. He fostered a sense of community among staff by encouraging them to participate in local events and was an active member of various organizations, publishing local history studies and delivering talks to local groups. In his retirement, starting from 1993, he enjoyed a wide range of activities, including literature, theatre, film, music, politics, and football. He remained open to new ideas and developed expertise in computer technology and the internet. A dedicated supporter of the Labour party, he believed it had provided him with the opportunities he had in life. However, nothing was more important to him than his family, whom he loved and cherished. He is survived by his spouse, two sons, Gavin and Duncan, and five grandchildren, Edward, Natasha, Louise, Sara, and Jeremy.

Sports Direct has announced a surprise deal to sell the Dunlop sportswear brand to a Japanese buyer, Sumitomo Rubber Industries, for $137.5 million (£112 million). As part of the agreement, Sumitomo will acquire the trademark rights to the Dunlop brand overseas, as well as its sporting goods and licensing businesses. Mike Ashley, the founder and major shareholder of Sports Direct, acquired Dunlop Slazenger in 2004 for an estimated £40 million, three years before listing his sportswear retail chain on the stock exchange. The 107-year-old Dunlop brand is synonymous with sports such as tennis, squash, badminton, and golf, and has been used by notable athletes including Rod Laver, John McEnroe, Steffi Graf, Darren Clarke, and Lee Westwood. Sports Direct stated that it no longer has the resources to manage international brands, and needs to focus on its core UK businesses and relationships with third-party brands. The Dunlop business generated a pre-tax profit of £4 million on sales of £41.8 million, according to Sports Direct. Sumitomo Rubber Industries, originally known as the Dunlop Rubber Company, has a tyre business and a sports division that produces tennis and golf equipment. The company already owns the rights to the Dunlop brand in other markets. Sports Direct has faced challenges in recent years, including criticism of its working practices and weak trading. In December, the company reported that profits had more than halved to £71.6 million in the six months to October 23. The company's chairman, Keith Hellawell, attributed the decline to an "extreme political, union and media campaign" against the company. An undercover investigation by The Guardian last year revealed that Sports Direct workers were being paid below the minimum wage, and a parliamentary committee report later compared conditions at the company's Shirebrook warehouse to a Victorian workhouse. Since the controversy, the company has been compelled to pay £1 million in back wages to employees and provide staff with guaranteed working hours. As a result, Sports Direct's stock price has plummeted by more than half over the past year, with shares currently trading at 272.4p. The retailer's profit margins have also been significantly impacted by the pound's sharp depreciation following the Brexit vote. Despite the challenges, Sports Direct still maintains a substantial portfolio of brands, including Slazenger, Everlast, Lonsdale, and Karrimor.

European Central Bank policymaker Jens Weidmann has cautioned that a bailout of struggling Italian bank Monte dei Paschi is not a foregone conclusion. As the president of Germany's Bundesbank, Weidmann believes the Italian government should carefully consider whether to rescue the bank if it is in a precarious financial state. According to Weidmann, the bank must be financially healthy at its core in order for the measures planned by the Italian government to be effective. He emphasized that the funds cannot be used to cover expected losses, and all aspects must be thoroughly examined. Weidmann, a member of the ECB's governing council, made these comments in an article published in German newspaper Bild. The ECB has taken a tough stance with Monte dei Paschi, refusing to grant the bank additional time to find private investors. The Italian government approved a state bailout plan last Friday after the bank failed to secure €5 billion in private investment. The plan involves dipping into a €20 billion fund approved by the government earlier this month to prop up the bank. Monte dei Paschi's poor performance in the ECB's "stress tests" prompted the government to take action. The stress tests, designed to ensure that taxpayers are not left with the bill for multi-billion pound bailouts, revealed that Monte dei Paschi was in a weak financial position. The bank was instructed to improve its finances by the end of the year or face being wound down. Weidmann stressed that the rules are intended to protect taxpayers and place responsibility on investors. He believes that state funds should only be used as a last resort, which is why the bar is set high. Monte dei Paschi's troubles began to mount after the 2008 banking crisis, when it made a costly acquisition of Banca Antonveneta for €9 billion, more than doubling its size and making it Italy's third-largest bank behind UniCredit and Intesa Sanpaolo. The deal, which was part of a complex bidding war involving Santander and ABN Amro, ultimately contributed to the taxpayer bailout of Royal Bank of Scotland. Monte dei Paschi's financial woes escalated three years ago, when it sought a €4 billion bailout from the government amid a scandal over derivatives contracts and allegations of fraud. The bank has since returned to the government for funding after talks with private investors fell through, with Qatar's sovereign wealth fund reportedly playing a key role in the collapse of the plan by refusing to participate. The Italian government already has a 4% stake in Monte dei Paschi.

It's hard to believe it's been a decade since I earned my master's degree in peace and development from the University of Leeds. Back then, I would often stroll through the beautiful municipal gardens near my home, feeling grateful for the abundance of local amenities we took for granted. The parks, community centers, libraries, and toilets were all part of the fabric of our community, provided by the local government. However, the recent wave of central-government austerity measures has left these very same amenities on the brink of disappearance. Local volunteers are now struggling to take over the management of these assets, which are being transferred from the council to private companies with little accountability.

The latest proposal from Bradford metropolitan district council is to hand over many of its local halls to community groups, provided they are willing and able to take on the responsibility. Our town hall in Silsden is on the list, and we are determined to fight to retain it. For the past two years, a local volunteer group has been working hard to promote the use of the hall, and the council has been paying for its upkeep and staffing. This arrangement has been successful, with the hall operating at almost no cost to the taxpayer.

As I walk through the park these days, I can't help but feel a sense of loss. This is not just a recent development; it's been happening over the past few years. The question is, what will our community be like if this continued dismantling of local state provision continues?

Thousands of consumers may be holding worthless car hire bookings for the Christmas period after Atlaschoice, the company they booked through, failed to pay the firms providing the actual cars. Customers who booked through the website have reported being told at car rental desks that their booking would not be honored unless they paid again, in some cases hundreds of pounds, because Atlaschoice had not paid the car's actual provider. Frustrated customers of the west London-based car hire booking firm, which acted as a booking agent for major car hire brands, have taken to social media to report the issue. "I'm cancelling my rental car, keeping my money, and being given no other option just two days before I fly home for Christmas. Seriously?" tweeted Tom Richards. Chris Clifton-Brown also shared his experience online: "I booked through them recently and when I arrived to collect my car, the hire firm informed me that Atlaschoice is not paying the actual hire firms. I had to pay the hire firm for the car again, even though Atlaschoice had already taken my money." Despite being in business since 1990, Atlaschoice did not respond to calls or emails. The website was still operational, but it appears to have stopped taking new bookings. Although Atlaschoice is not a well-known brand, many customers may have used the booking agent website through TravelSupermarket, a popular travel comparison site. The company also partnered with several other major online travel businesses. The Christmas period is typically one of the busiest for car hire operators, and many customers may be unable to pay for their car hire a second time. A TravelSupermarket spokesperson told The Guardian that the company removed Atlaschoice from its listings three weeks ago. "They missed paying us at the end of November, and we were unable to reach them, so we took them off our site as a precautionary measure. Until then, there was no indication of financial difficulties, and payments were up to date. We've tried to contact them by phone, email, and letter, but have received no response." "If you booked a car through Atlaschoice, you're advised to contact the car supplier to confirm whether your booking has been paid for and will be honored. Additionally, you should reach out to your bank card provider. For credit card users, Section 75 rights will protect them, as the card provider is jointly liable for the booking cost if it exceeds £100. Debit card users may face more difficulty in getting a refund, but they may be eligible for a chargeback scheme. Unfortunately, Atlaschoice did not respond to the Guardian's requests for comment."

I was in urgent need of new glass for my windows and turned to Google to find a local company. I came across Emergency Response Group and provided them with my measurements. They quoted me £400 to replace six windows, which I agreed to as I needed the work done quickly. They took my card details, promising to charge me once the job was complete. When the glaziers arrived, they informed me that two of my windows required safety glass, which hadn't been mentioned previously. They said they would return to complete the work within a week, but I never heard back from them.

Later that month, I checked my credit card statement and was surprised to see that £54 had been debited by Emergency Response Group, citing a "cancellation fee." I was never informed about this fee beforehand, and I certainly hadn't cancelled the job. After making 20 unsuccessful phone calls, I'm still waiting for my £54 back.

I've since discovered that I'm not the only one to have a frustrating experience with this company. A quick Google search reveals that Emergency Response Group has a poor reputation, with a 1.2/5 star rating and numerous critical reviews from customers. When I contacted the company about my experience, they claimed to have called me with the updated price for the extra work, but I never received the call. They charged me the £54 call-out fee, citing their terms and conditions. They've since offered to refund half of the fee as a gesture of goodwill.

In hindsight, I wish I had taken the time to thoroughly research the company before signing up. A few extra minutes on the internet would have saved me a lot of time and effort.
