I'm paying attention to the ongoing negotiations regarding the future of the ATM network, which may lead to a charge for Link cash machine withdrawals (as reported on January 19). In 2005, I led a Treasury committee inquiry into cash machine fees and discovered that hundreds of local areas were being unfairly burdened with high charges. In Speke, a low-income area in Liverpool, consumers were facing charges of £1.50 for every cash withdrawal. I established a working group comprising banks, consumer groups, and ATM operators, and the banks unanimously committed to maintaining a large network of free cash machines. As a result, a "financial inclusion premium" was introduced for operators of free cash machines in 1,500 under-served low-income areas. The importance of the free-to-use ATM network has grown significantly since banks have closed over 1,000 branches in the past two years. If we were to return to the patchwork of agreements that existed in the 1990s, when consumers faced excessive cash machine charges and challenger banks were penalized, it would be a disaster for both consumers and banks. It's crucial that, as part of the current negotiations, banks, ATM operators, the Payment Systems Regulator, and the Bank of England work together to agree a deal that ensures the long-term viability of a widespread network of free-to-use cash machines and promotes financial inclusion and competition.

Regarding HSBC, when its chairman, Douglas Flint, appeared before the Treasury select committee in 2015, he expressed shame over a "terrible list" of issues. He wasn't wrong; the list included Libor manipulation, mortgage mis-selling, Forex rigging, and weaknesses in money laundering and tax avoidance at its Swiss subsidiary. Unfortunately, we can now add disregard for local communities and high streets to that list. Last year, HSBC closed over 200 branches, more than any other major bank, and it has just announced another 62 closures this year, including in my constituency of Wood Green. HSBC's commitment to being the "world's local bank" seems to be fading away. If this trend continues, it's possible that all branches will be gone by the end of 2019. This decision will undoubtedly have a significant impact on the many residents and businesses that rely on in-person services at local branches, as well as the dedicated staff who work at these locations. I have requested an urgent meeting with HSBC's leadership to discuss these proposals and will be urging them to reconsider their plan. As the Labour MP for Hornsey & Wood Green, I am concerned about the effects of this decision and will be advocating for a change in course.

Lonmin, a platinum miner, is facing criticism for its treatment of its workers, nearly five years after a violent incident at its Marikana mine in South Africa claimed the lives of dozens of people. At the company's annual meeting, CEO Ben Magara acknowledged that progress on building homes for its 33,000 employees had been slower than expected, but attributed the delay to the low price of platinum, which makes it difficult for the company to stay financially stable. The 2012 Marikana massacre, in which 34 people were killed, was sparked by a strike by workers demanding a living wage from Lonmin. The former Bishop of Pretoria, Johannes Seoka, who was on the phone with one of the victims when the police opened fire, believes that the company should take more responsibility for the tragedy. "If they had engaged with the workers, the massacre would not have happened," he said. Seoka and Amnesty International are calling on Lonmin to accelerate its efforts to provide housing for its workers, many of whom live in informal communities without basic amenities like electricity or running water. Last year, Lonmin reached a deal with workers to increase the basic monthly pay of rock drill operators to nearly 12,500 South African rand (£744) by 2018, but one shareholder questioned the reasonableness of the wage demands. "I don't understand what they want to spend it on," she said, comparing the amount to her own pension and disability allowance. Lonmin has taken steps to support the families of the Marikana massacre victims, including offering them jobs, paying for their children's education, and agreeing to improve housing and wages.

Imperial Brands' shareholders have effectively blocked a pay increase for CEO Alison Cooper, a move that may have implications for other FTSE 100 companies seeking to boost their executives' bonuses. The company, which owns Gauloises and John Player cigarettes, unexpectedly announced on Thursday that it would not put its new pay policy to a vote at its annual meeting on February 1, as originally planned. The policy would have increased Cooper's pay from £5.5m to a potential £8.5m per year by expanding bonus opportunities. The decision suggests that Imperial Brands did not expect to receive overwhelming support from investors. The influential proxy voting agency ISS had recommended voting against the policy, indicating a significant revolt was likely. Imperial Brands' chairman, Mark Williamson, stated that investors had changed their minds about supporting the plan. "We have been engaging with shareholders for some time and while we received significant support, it is clear that views have shifted, and it is now in the best interest of the company to withdraw the resolution," he said. Williamson added that the board believes revising the policy is necessary to attract and retain top talent and ensure the company's sustainable growth. David Haines, chairman of the remuneration committee, argued that the pay rise was necessary not only for Cooper but also for other executives, as it is significantly below the average for companies of Imperial Brands' size. Critics of high pay saw the move as a warning to company executives against pushing through pay increases, but urged investors to maintain their pressure. Stefan Stern, director of the High Pay Centre, said, "This is the first sign that some institutions will be more resistant this year, so it looks like good news." "While one instance of effective criticism may not be enough to spark a'shareholder spring', the question remains whether asset managers will continue to actively engage in critical discussions. During her campaign to become prime minister, Theresa May drew attention to pay inequality. However, the government has since published a consultation that appears to backtrack on its initial plans to require workers to be represented on company boards to curb excessive bonuses. Recently, BlackRock, the world's largest fund manager, which has hired George Osborne as an advisor, has signaled a more prominent stance on executive pay. As one of the top three investors in FTSE 100 companies due to its significant size, BlackRock has written to major companies on the stock market, warning that it will be monitoring companies that justify pay increases by comparing themselves to their rivals' pay."

British astronaut Tim Peake has announced plans to return to the International Space Station for a second mission with the European Space Agency. The announcement was made at the Science Museum in London, where a Soyuz capsule that brought Peake and two other astronauts back to Earth in June is now on display. "Reunited with Soyuz TMA-19M, which has a few scars from reentry," Peake tweeted on Thursday morning. The details of his next mission, including its name and schedule, have not been released, but it is unlikely to take place before 2019. European Space Agency missions to the space station typically last around six months.

The next European astronaut to launch into space will be Italian astronaut Paolo Nespoli in May. "It's what every astronaut wants to do," Peake told Sky News, adding that he and his fellow astronauts from 2009 are all expected to get a second mission to the space station, which is "wonderful." Peake emphasized the importance and excitement of the work being done on the space station, saying it's natural to want to return. He also expressed a longing for the view of planet Earth, which he described as "the most spectacular thing you can possibly see."

Peake, a 44-year-old former helicopter test pilot and father of two from West Sussex, became the first British astronaut to join a European Space Agency mission in December 2015. He spent six months on the space station, during which he participated in over 250 experiments. Some of his notable achievements included running the London Marathon on a treadmill and inspiring over a million schoolchildren through educational outreach activities. One of the highlights of his time in space was a spacewalk with Nasa astronaut Tim Kopra, although the mission was cut short after Kopra noticed water leaking into his helmet. The Soyuz capsule, which carried Peake and his two crewmates, Kopra and Russian cosmonaut Yuri Malenchenko, to and from the space station, measures less than two meters in width. His mission was dubbed "Principia," a nod to Sir Isaac Newton's groundbreaking work on the laws of motion and gravity, which bears the same name.

The Governor of the Bank of England has cautioned that a new generation of online-only lenders is emerging, posing a threat to the financial system if not properly regulated. Mark Carney warned that these online lenders, untested in a recession, could trigger the next financial crisis if they fail to repay their loans, leaving customers with significant losses. He also highlighted the risk of cyber-attacks stripping customers of their digital money, leaving them without the traditional protection offered by regulators.

Carney's warning comes after a similar warning was issued by Adair Turner, the former chief financial regulator, who warned that losses on internet-based loans could make even the worst bankers look like "lending geniuses". Speaking at a conference in Germany, Carney noted that digital money could potentially allow millions of people excluded from the mainstream banking system to access loans securely. However, he emphasized the need for the authorities to adopt a more intense focus on financial regulations, lending rules, and operational and cyber risks to ensure the industry's growth is sustainable.

In the UK, online lenders, known as fintech lenders, have become increasingly popular, accounting for around 14% of new lending to small and medium-sized businesses last year. These lenders typically offer loans with funds provided directly by investors, similar to the securitized loans used by banks like Northern Rock before the 2008 financial crisis. Carney cautioned that the rapid growth of online lending could lead to emerging vulnerabilities that regulators would need to address.

The UK is expected to become a global leader in online lending, putting pressure on the Bank to adopt regulations that protect customers without stifling the industry. The growth of online lending has been hindered by the volatility of digital currencies like Bitcoin, which has limited its adoption due to concerns about its value and security. In recent months, Bitcoin's value has rebounded, and the popularity of blockchain electronic wallets, which function like bank accounts, has led some analysts to predict a surge in adoption this year. Traditionally, payment services relied on cash, debit and credit cards, and wire transfers. However, fintech companies are now offering domestic and cross-border payment services on a large scale through digital wallets or prepaid e-money. According to Carney, tech firms take a share of payment revenues and often gain access to the entirety of customer transaction data. In doing so, they are systematically accumulating the kind of customer insights I used to gain through my daily interactions with customers as a bank teller, he noted, referencing his first job as a bank teller.

Snapchat is revising its guidelines for publishers on its Discover platform, banning the posting of explicit images without editorial significance and clarifying rules to prevent the spread of misinformation. According to a Snap spokesperson, the changes aim to "empower our editorial partners to maintain Snapchat as a trustworthy, factual, and safe environment for all users." The company has struggled to balance keeping the platform age-appropriate for younger users (Snapchat bars children under 13 from creating accounts, but allows 13- to 17-year-olds to use the service) with allowing publications on Discover editorial freedom. For instance, The Daily Mail has faced user complaints for frequently posting semi-nude images as its "cover" on the service. One user told The Guardian, "I find it incredibly offensive that I can't opt out of seeing these images and that I'm forced to see them every time I open the app to see my friends' stories." Another user reported, "A few weeks ago, a definite line was crossed. The image was of a completely nude female, taken from the side, so you can't see the nipples, but her breasts were dangling over her boyfriend who she was mounting. She was dressed on the bottom, and I believe her boyfriend was completely dressed." Due to the prominence of Discover features in the app, the cover story is visible to all users, including those who only use the service to communicate with friends and family. In July 2016, Snapchat faced a lawsuit over sexualized Discover stories, which was eventually settled out of court. Under the new rules, news organizations will need to provide justification or demonstrate editorial value before posting such stories to the service. Snap is planning to introduce a new tool in February that will enable publishers to age-gate their content, presenting different stories to users under and over the age of 18, according to the New York Times. In addition to the rules against questionable images, Snapchat Discover will also take steps to address the issue of fake news, a problem that has plagued many social networks. Going forward, publishers will be required to fact-check their Discover stories, both those published within the app and those linked to from it. While Snap gives publishers editorial independence, the company does follow up with them if readers raise questions about the sourcing, accuracy, or other factors of their content, according to BuzzFeed News.

Media lawyers were correct to highlight the ineffectiveness of protecting journalistic sources in the digital age, as noted in a recent report (February 23). They might also have pointed out that, despite 19 years of whistleblowing legislation, there is no general requirement for employers to maintain the confidentiality of whistleblowers or allow anonymous reporting of suspected wrongdoing. (David Lewis, Whistleblowing Research Unit, Middlesex University)

David Butler's statement that "the last time Labour was in as hopeless a position as it is today, we had three consecutive election victories lying in wait" (Letters, February 25) is misleading. If he is referring to the same year as me, it was actually three consecutive election defeats. As a 56-year-old, I'm not looking forward to waiting that long. (Rebecca Linton, Leicester)

Anne McElvoy's use of the words "tergiversations" and "fissiparous" (Opinion, February 27) to describe the challenges faced by Theresa May left me searching through dictionaries. I'm sure she could have chosen more accessible words to convey her points. Perhaps "shilly-shallying" and "divisive" would have been more effective? (Maggie Linden, London)

Regarding the "Nelson one-roll" (Letters, February 25), it's worth noting that Nelson cake is a regional British dessert, typically consisting of crushed biscuits, dried fruit, and syrup sandwiched between two layers of pastry. It's also known as Nelson squares. (Susanne Woodman, Watford)

I couldn't help but notice the phrase "audible gasps were heard" in the Oscars report (theguardian.com, February 27). It's reasonable to assume that inaudible gasps were not heard. (Rhoda Koenig, London)

Jacqueline Knight is correct that Worcestershire sauce contains anchovies (Letters, February 27). A suitable vegetarian alternative is Henderson's Relish from Sheffield, a delicious and anchovy-free condiment. (Maggie Hoyles, Sheffield)

"Hello puzzle enthusiasts! I'm excited to introduce you to a new type of puzzle, known as a dissection puzzle, where you need to reassemble shapes. Here's a challenge to get you started: a carpenter requires a square piece of wood measuring 30 inches by 30 inches, but the only suitable piece available is a rectangle measuring 25 inches by 36 inches. How can the carpenter cut the wood into two pieces that can be glued together to form the desired square? I'll be back at 5pm GMT with the solution, but for now, let's keep the discussion going without any spoilers! Instead, feel free to share your thoughts on power tools and other dissection puzzles.

UPDATE: The solution is now available. I post a new puzzle every two weeks on a Monday, and if you'd like to receive an email notification each time, please send me your email address.

If you have a great puzzle you'd like to share, I'm always on the lookout for new challenges. You can email me your suggestion.

I'd like to thank Martin Usher for providing today's puzzle. My latest book, Can You Solve My Problems, A Casebook of Ingenious, Perplexing and Totally Satisfying Puzzles, is now available. Additionally, my children's book Football School: Where Football Explains The World, co-authored with Ben Lyttleton, was recently shortlisted for the Blue Peter Book Award 2017."

Over the past few days, numerous tributes have been paid to Steve Hewlett. Here's another, which focuses on his exceptional qualities as a host rather than his journalistic brilliance or his courage in the face of mortality. My point is that whenever you joined him in the Media Show studio, Steve was always in complete control. His authoritative voice conveyed his confidence. Unlike politicians, who often require extensive training to speak with sincerity, Steve possessed this quality instinctively. His honesty was immediately apparent, from the moment the cameras rolled. This was particularly valuable when discussing the BBC itself, as Steve was intimately familiar with the corporation's inner workings. While he had a deep affection for the BBC, he was not afraid to express his frustration when it failed to engage with the public during times of crisis. As we sat in the heart of Broadcasting House, waiting for a response that never came, Steve's dry delivery conveyed his disappointment. His straightforward style is a legacy for those who will follow in his footsteps, working on the BBC but not necessarily being beholden to it.

The looming regulatory threat of Article 40, which requires publishers to pay legal costs regardless of the outcome, has been a long-standing concern for local newspaper editors. Lord Justice Leveson's insistence on a regulator offering affordable arbitration was a major sticking point, as editors argued it would be a final blow to a struggling industry. This led to a litmus test for MPs and ministers, who were unsure how to proceed. As a result, the culture, media, and sport committee has given Ipso, a non-Leveson-compliant regulator, a year to implement an acceptable arbitration scheme. If Ipso fails to do so, the recognition of section 40 will pass to its rival, Impress. The choice between the two schemes is clear: Impress charges £75 upfront for a three- to six-month process, while Ipso offers super-silky barristers for a downpayment of £300, with potentially much more to follow. A key difference is that Impress caps arbitrators' fees at £3,500, regardless of the outcome, and does not charge legal costs if the plaintiff wins. This has raised concerns among local newspapers, who fear they could lose financially. Ipso, on the other hand, has more flexible costings and obligations, but its fees are higher and less transparent. The question is, can we get some hard data to help make a decision? The answer depends on whether the demand for arbitration is as high as its proponents claim. So far, no one has taken advantage of the arbitration option, despite the fact that it is available. It may be that ordinary complaints regulation is sufficient, or that no-win-no-fee solicitors have already cornered the market. But can't we at least gather more information before making a decision? "Can arbitration develop a single, comprehensive approach that applies universally?"

Channel Nine has issued an apology to billionaire Gina Rinehart for its depiction of her in the 2015 miniseries The House of Hancock, and has agreed not to distribute the program again. Rinehart had initiated legal action against Nine and the production company, Cordell Jigsaw, over the two-part miniseries, which told the story of one of Australia's wealthiest mining families. In a statement, Nine and Cordell Jigsaw apologized to Rinehart, clarifying that the program was a drama, not a documentary, and that certain aspects were fictionalized for dramatic purposes. The statement acknowledged Rinehart's close relationships with her family members and her significant contributions to Australia's industry and economy. Nine and Cordell Jigsaw also apologized for any hurt or offense caused by the broadcast and its promotion, and agreed to pay Rinehart's legal costs, estimated to be in the six figures. Additionally, the program will not be sold to streaming channels, foreign markets, or released on DVD. The first episode of the miniseries attracted over 1.4 million viewers when it aired on the Nine network in February 2015. Rinehart had previously won the right to review the second episode before its broadcast and had ordered certain parts to be edited out. She later took legal action against Nine and Cordell Jigsaw for defamation, claiming that the program was "twisted" and "offensive" and that some scenes were "entirely false". In a statement, Rinehart expressed satisfaction with receiving a public apology for the "inaccurate and distorted" miniseries, stating that the case was not about money. "Mrs Rinehart took a stand to defend her beloved family members against the unfair and defamatory rumors that were spreading, particularly since some family members were no longer alive to speak for themselves. She urged politicians to implement long-overdue reforms to shield public figures from false and misleading media portrayals. Notably, a January Oxfam report listed Mrs Rinehart as one of the top 1% wealthiest Australians."

I'm South Ribble, a 43-year-old non-metropolitan district in Lancashire, home to 109,000 people. I've never been there myself, but I've heard it's the best place to live in Britain - at least, for people in their 20s. Is it a hotspot for clubbing? Well, it has an active Rotary Club branch, but I'm not sure about trendy coffee shops or nightclubs. There is a Starbucks in Walton-le-Dale, though! Are there any... unsavory characters lurking in abandoned buildings? I don't think so - the council website doesn't mention anything like that. But there are plans for an Ikea, which might be a draw for some young people. So, why would they choose to live here? Well, it's relatively affordable, with an average house price of £157,000, which is £138,000 cheaper than the national average. And it seems to have a lot going for it - employment opportunities, green spaces, and a surprisingly high proportion of residents in their 20s and 30s. According to Channel 4's "The UK's Best Place to Live," South Ribble takes the top spot. Warrington came second, and Blaby took third place. The researchers at the University of Sheffield used ONS statistics to determine the rankings, so it's not just my opinion! If you're looking for somewhere closer to London, though, you might be out of luck - the south-east didn't make the top 50, and property prices in the capital are four times higher than in South Ribble. So, I suppose it's no surprise that South Ribble is the top choice. Just don't ask me when to put out the bins - that's a local secret! "The recycling bins are labeled specifically: blue for glass, cans, and plastic bottles; green for paper and card; brown for garden and food waste; and grey for non-recyclable materials. I'm shocked to hear that in some areas, people simply dump all their waste over park railings at night. I'm sure you're aware that some people have a certain attitude, saying "wherever I live is cool by default" because of their youth, ambition, and creativity. On the other hand, it's best to avoid making requests like "would you like to attend a Rotary club meeting tonight?""

Note: I've tried to maintain the original tone and humor of the text while making the language more formal and polished.

Peter Smith, a 77-year-old former colleague and friend who has passed away, dedicated his career to teaching day-release classes to Yorkshire and Derbyshire workers from various industries, including coal mining, steelworking, railways, engineering, and local authorities. The courses were arranged by trade unions in partnership with their employers, and the syllabuses were co-created by students and instructors. Topics covered included economic and social history, and students presented papers to one another, exploring subjects such as collective bargaining and global politics. I first met Peter in 1966 at Sheffield University's Department of Extramural Studies, where he had recently joined six months prior. He was committed to fostering students' independent thought and understanding, recognizing that adult education in the social sciences was a collaborative process rather than mere instruction. Throughout his life, Peter touched and enriched the lives of many, but perhaps his most enduring legacy stems from his work with the union-backed Society of Industrial Tutors. Born to Austen Smith and Isabel (née Reed), Peter was the son of a junior school headteacher in Sunderland. After leaving school, he studied economics at Manchester University and began teaching liberal studies at Stockport College of Technology in 1962. That same year, he met his future wife, Helen Naughton, while working for the Labour party in a north Manchester constituency. In 1965, Peter joined the extramural program at Sheffield University, and he and Helen married the following year. He played a key role in the Sheffield Vietnam campaign and led a large contingent to the famous anti-war protest outside the US embassy in London's Grosvenor Square in 1968. In 1969, he became principal lecturer and head of liberal studies at Teesside Polytechnic, where he served on the governing body and helped the institution achieve university status in 1992. Peter and Helen settled in Stockton-on-Tees in 1970 and lived there for over 40 years. He joined the Open University in that year, teaching social sciences and politics part-time for 45 years until his retirement in 2015. Even in retirement, Peter remained a dedicated advocate for justice and peace. "A skilled athlete, he continued to excel at squash well into his 70s. He leaves behind Helen, his children Kate, Tessa, and Adam, as well as his granddaughter Anna."

My husband and I are contemplating changing our joint tenancy to a tenancy in common to safeguard our children's inheritance. We're considering this move to ensure that we can leave our respective shares of the property to our daughters, while still allowing us to remain in the property should either of us pass away. I believe this is a way to grant a "life interest" to the surviving spouse. Currently, as joint tenants, we have a joint will that leaves the property to the surviving spouse and, in the event of both our deaths, to our children. Additionally, our will stipulates that each of our six grandchildren will receive £10,000 when we both pass away, provided there is sufficient assets in our estate. If we become tenants in common, do we need to update our existing wills to reflect the new arrangement, specifically to provide for a life interest to the surviving spouse and to leave our respective shares of the estate to our daughters and grandchildren, as outlined in our current will?

SMF Answer: Yes, if we decide to own our home as tenants in common by severing our joint tenancy, we will need to draft new wills. Additionally, since we currently have a joint will, which is not recognized under UK law, we will need to create individual wills that "mirror" each other, with identical provisions. It's not possible to specify in a will who inherits property that is jointly owned under a joint tenancy, as the property automatically passes to the surviving joint tenant(s) upon the death of the other(s). However, if we own the property as tenants in common, we can specify in our will who inherits our share of the property upon our death. Nevertheless, simply leaving our share to our daughters does not automatically create a "life interest" in the property for our spouse. "To ensure that your spouse can remain in the house until their death, your will must explicitly state this intention. Currently, as joint tenants, when one of you passes away, the surviving spouse will automatically inherit the property and have the right to live in it until their own death, without the need for a will to specify this. Upon the surviving spouse's death, your daughters will inherit the property, assuming they don't change their will to leave the property to someone else. If you're concerned about this, converting to tenants in common can protect at least your share of your children's inheritance, provided you update your will accordingly."

I rented wedding attire for myself and my seven groomsmen from Moss Bros on London's Regent Street, and we were measured in early January. I chose a faded blue French Connection suit and was told it would be ready for pickup at my local Ilford branch by the beginning of March, four weeks before the wedding. However, a month later, I received a call from the Ilford branch claiming that only my measurements were on the order form. Upon reviewing the paperwork, I discovered that the suit ordered was bright blue, and shirts I hadn't requested had been added. I called the store and was told that the faded blue suit was unavailable, that the groomsmen's measurements had been lost, and that the promised large-order discount had only been applied to one of the eight suits. I was left back at square one.

I then selected a faded blue Ted Baker suit, which I was told would arrive at the start of March. However, when I rang on March 1st, I was informed that it was unavailable. To make matters worse, they had also ordered the wrong color waistcoats, and the discount had only been applied to three suits. With only four weeks until my wedding, I was left with no idea what was happening with my suit, despite ordering it three months in advance and paying a £340 deposit.

Unfortunately, the saga didn't end there. It took eight days for the Moss Bros press office to respond to my alert, during which time the Ted Baker suit arrived and turned out to be different from the one I had tried on, forcing me to choose yet another option that wouldn't be ready until two days before the wedding. When I lodged a formal complaint via the website, I was told that since the order had been corrected, my complaint was closed. After chasing the issue, the press office finally took action, arranging for the suits to be ready three weeks earlier than agreed and offering to courier replacements if needed. "You might expect an apology to come with a substantial discount, but unfortunately, that's not the case. Instead, you'll receive a £50 gift card and a bottle of champagne as a token of goodwill for the inconvenience and stress caused. A valuable lesson to take away is to thoroughly review your order form before payment to avoid any potential mistakes. If you need assistance, please don't hesitate to reach out to Anna Tims at your.problems@observer.co.uk or send a letter to Your Problems, The Observer, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Please include your contact information, including an address and phone number."

The only silver lining for the struggling Nightly Show might be its impending demise, given its dismal ratings have plummeted below those of the old News at Ten program. When significant news breaks, the entertainment series is relegated to a secondary role, as seen last week. The show's return the following day seemed awkward, with Dermot O'Leary delivering a glowing tribute to London before gratefully moving on to Ant and Dec. News and entertainment are distinct services that cannot be easily switched on or off; constructing a league table of the worst events is impractical and unnecessary. ITV's attempt to create a US-style daily chat show is understandable, but it's not suitable for the 10pm time slot, where viewers expect to stay informed about current events. As for the BBC's executive board, don't treat the selection process like a Paddy Power betting guide when Tony Hall retires. Charlotte Moore, James Harding, and James Purnell are still the top contenders, and it's difficult to predict a single winner without compromising the entire board's decision. As a result, all three candidates are waiting patiently for their chance to shine. However, it's important to note that Anne Bulford and Tim Davie, who made the transition from other roles to become BBC executives, don't have an inherent advantage in the race. This competition is far from over.

Pret a Manger has reversed its decision to offer hundreds of teenagers unpaid work experience this summer, instead announcing that it will pay them an hourly wage. The company had initially planned to offer 500 16- to 18-year-olds a week of unpaid work experience in an effort to address its looming recruitment crisis. However, after facing criticism from campaigners, Pret's CEO Clive Schlee tweeted that the company will pay all participants its hourly starting rate, in addition to providing free food. The minimum wage for under 18s in the UK is £4 an hour, while for 18- to 20-year-olds it is £5.55 an hour. Pret's recruitment efforts are being impacted by Brexit, as the company relies heavily on non-UK workers and only one in 50 of its job applicants are born in the UK. The company's new work experience program, dubbed "Big Experience Week", aims to give participants a taste of various aspects of the business, including food production, customer service, and social responsibility. Pret's human resources director, Andrea Wareham, believes that the company's struggles to attract British applicants are symptomatic of a wider cultural bias against careers in the hospitality industry. Wareham argues that British schools and parents need to take the industry more seriously, as it has undergone significant changes and growth over the past 20 years. The company is concerned that it will struggle to recruit enough staff if it is forced to turn its back on EU nationals after Brexit. Pret hopes to offer permanent roles to participants who wish to apply after their work experience week and will stay in touch with those who want to remain in education and apply in the future. The company will promote its Big Experience Week initiative through partnerships with schools that are already part of its leavers program. Additionally, it will launch a social media campaign to raise awareness. To attract more British workers, Pret plans to boost recruitment advertising on social media, double the intake for its school leavers program, and collaborate with Jobcentre Plus.

The Fiat Tipo, dubbed a "multijet lounge," left me with mixed emotions. Was it designed for speed or relaxation? As I sat behind the wheel, I wondered if I should be revving the engine or sipping coffee. The cabin is spacious, but it's marred by annoying quirks. The gear housing is loose, often slipping into second gear when I intended to shift into neutral. This inconsistency made me doubt my own abilities, as if I was trapped in a bad relationship. The car's frame design is unusual, with large plastic panels at the rear, which creates a blind spot when parking on a curve. The dashboard is cluttered with red accents, giving me a sense of unease, as if I was being told something important in a dream. The interior doesn't exude luxury, with a small, hard-to-read screen and storage compartments that don't align with my hand's natural reach. However, the Tipo has its redeeming qualities. It doesn't look or feel like a small car, and its emissions are impressively low – the first car I've driven in a long time to achieve under 100g/km. The exterior styling is a nostalgic ode to the 1980s, with curved lines that evoke a sense of retro charm. The boot space is ample for my needs, but I wouldn't dare try to transport anything larger than a shopping bag. The front seats offer generous leg room, while the rear seats are a bit cramped. The Fiat Tipo's design is so retro that it's reminiscent of the 80s, when it was common for not all family members to be equally comfortable. The turbo diesel engine, however, is a different story. In the city, it's sluggish to respond, then suddenly delivers a burst of power, as if it's been waiting for permission to unleash its full potential. On the motorway, the acceleration is smoother, especially in the higher gears, although the stiff posture can become tiring over time. After an hour or so, I started to feel restless, like I was watching a children's movie that lacked the magic of Pixar. The Tipo is a decent car, suitable for starting a family, but it may not be stylish or cool enough for some people's tastes. If you find it lacking in these areas, the problem may not be with the car, but with your expectations. On the other hand, I'm not sure I'm immune to these criticisms either. Here are some key stats about the Fiat Tipo:

* Price: £18,545
* Top speed: 124mph
* Acceleration: 0-62mph in 9.8 seconds
* Combined fuel consumption: 76mpg
* CO2 emissions: 98g/km
* Eco rating: 9/10
* Cool rating: 6/10

What's drawing me to Petworth and Pulborough? Perhaps it's the charming staff at Hennings wine merchants, or the knowledgeable bookshop employees who can guide you through the topographical section. I'm still searching for the perfect antiques dealers, but the towns are filled with plummy-voiced experts who could easily be suspects in a whodunit. And then there are the enigmatic figures who seem to operate behind the high walls of the stately homes that dominate the area, evoking the atmosphere of a Miss Marple mystery. The towns themselves are idyllic, with tile-covered cottages, porches dripping with roses, and wisteria galore. I even spotted a woman who bore a striking resemblance to Joan Hickson, the iconic actress who played Miss Marple, picking up a korma at Meghdoot's Indian restaurant.

Petworth is often overshadowed by its famous stately home, which boasts works by Titian and Turner. However, Pulborough has a more worldly feel, with its railway station and connections to Horsham, Bognor Regis, and London. It's the kind of place where I imagine Agatha Christie's characters would have lived, surrounded by the sounds of jazz and the whispers of romantic scandals.

Despite its charms, Petworth is also a bit too perfect, with coach parties and tourists flocking to the area. The looming walls of the stately home can make one feel like a peasant, and the town's exclusivity can be off-putting. However, it's well connected, with regular trains to Horsham, Bognor Regis, and London, as well as easy driving access to the A27, the coast, and Gatwick Airport.

For families, there are several excellent schools to choose from, including St Mary's CofE and Fittleworth CofE, which are both rated "good" by Ofsted, and the "outstanding" Weald and Midhurst Rother College.

If you're looking for a place to relax and soak up the atmosphere, the Angel pub in Petworth is a great spot, with its cozy inglenooks, medieval floorboards, and friendly locals who could easily be suspects in a mystery novel. "Looking for a unique property? Consider Wisteria-ed stone cottages, Georgian town houses, 18th-century farmhouses, mills, and estates with land, as well as gabled old houses with a rich history. You'll find plenty of beautiful properties here, but be prepared to pay a premium. Prices range from:

* Large detached homes and townhouses: £700,000-£2.5m
* Detached and smaller townhouses: £400,000-£700,000
* Semis: £275,000-£500,000
* Terraces and cottages: £250,000-£400,000
* Rentals: a few options available, with three-bedroom houses priced at £1,150-£2,000 per month.

If you're looking for a real bargain, consider a unique property like this 10-bedroom former railway station in Petworth, available for £1.4m through Chesworths.

When you're not house hunting, enjoy the local amenities, such as the RSPB's Pulborough Brooks nature reserve, which features a well-stocked shop and a cafe with scenic views. Other attractions include Petworth House and the gardens of Parham House and Storrington, one of the country's finest Elizabethan manors.

If you live in Petworth or Pulborough, share your thoughts on the area by joining the debate below. And if you have a favorite haunt or pet hate in Blaenavon, Gwent, email us at lets.move@theguardian.com by Tuesday, March 28."

Instagram has rolled out two-factor authentication, a crucial security feature that safeguards accounts from being compromised due to password reuse or phishing attacks. To enable this feature, users can opt in by navigating to their profile settings, selecting "two-factor authentication," and choosing the option to "require security code." Once enabled, the app will send a six-digit code to users' phones every time they log in, providing an additional layer of protection against account hacking. This simple yet effective measure is recommended by security experts for all users, and Instagram joins a growing list of social networks, including Facebook, Twitter, and Google, that offer some form of two-factor verification. However, it's worth noting that each platform's method is slightly different, with Twitter requiring login approval on a trusted device and Google using an open standard to link with its authenticator app. For a step-by-step guide to enabling two-factor authentication on various services, users can refer to the site Turn It On. Additionally, WhatsApp has introduced a unique method of account security, called two-step verification, which is worth considering. In any case, two-factor authentication is a free and easy way to secure accounts against intruders, making it an essential step for online protection.

The number of individuals filing for insolvency surged to its highest level in nearly three years during the first quarter of 2017, a stark indication of the intensifying financial pressure faced by UK households. In England and Wales, personal insolvencies reached 24,531 between January and March, a 6.7% increase from the previous quarter and a 15.7% jump from the same period a year earlier. According to the Insolvency Service, this marks the highest number of individual cases since the second quarter of 2014. The rise in insolvencies coincides with a challenging period for UK households, as rising inflation and stagnant pay growth continue to squeeze incomes. The annual inflation rate has reached 2.3% and is expected to rise to 3% in the coming months, as the effects of the weaker pound since the Brexit vote begin to manifest in higher prices. Meanwhile, regular pay growth has slowed to 1.9% compared to a year earlier. Joanna Elson, CEO of the Money Advice Trust, expressed concern over the insolvency figures, stating that growing household debt and increased pressure on budgets from inflation are cause for worry. "We anticipate a greater demand for free debt advice throughout 2017 and urge anyone struggling with their finances or concerned about falling behind to seek help as early as possible," she said. In the first quarter, individual voluntary arrangements accounted for 59% of personal insolvencies, debt relief orders made up 25%, and bankruptcies accounted for 16%. IVAs involve sharing debt among creditors, while DROs are available to those with less than £20,000 of debt who do not own their primary residence. Adrian Hyde, president of R3, noted that while borrowing rates remain at record lows, rising inflation and slowing real wage growth will restrict people's financial flexibility. "Despite a few years of stability, personal insolvency rates are still relatively low, and the recent uptick in bankruptcies has been modest. However, the steady increase in personal insolvencies may signal that the post-recession surge in consumer borrowing and spending is beginning to plateau. The official statistics only tell part of the story, as hundreds of thousands of individuals on debt management plans are not included in the numbers. Meanwhile, the Insolvency Service reported a 4.5% rise in corporate insolvencies in the first quarter of the year compared to the previous quarter, and a 5.3% increase compared to the same period last year."

AstraZeneca faced another shareholder backlash over executive pay, with nearly 39% of investors opposing a £13m package for its chief executive. The pharmaceutical company's 2016 remuneration report received a similar level of opposition as three years ago, with nearly 40% of investors voting against it at the annual meeting in London. In contrast, the new pay policy received strong support, with 96% of investors backing it. AstraZeneca's chief executive, Pascal Soriot, received a total pay package of £13.4m last year, which included a £1.2m annual salary, a £1.2m annual bonus, and a £6.9m payment from a long-term incentive plan, as well as a one-off payment of £3.6m in compensation for lost bonuses. Royal London Asset Management, which holds 1% of AstraZeneca shares, voted against the remuneration report and the chair of the remuneration committee, but supported the new pay policy. AstraZeneca made changes to its long-term bonus plans after consulting with its largest shareholders, aiming to simplify and make them fairer. The company stated that its remuneration committee would continue to engage with shareholders to address any concerns following the annual general meeting. Two advisory groups, PIRC and Institutional Shareholder Services, had recommended that shareholders vote against the remuneration report and policy, citing the £6.9m long-term incentive plan payment as "excessive". AstraZeneca has faced several shareholder protests over executive pay in recent years, including a row that led to the ousting of its chief executive in 2012. This year, the housebuilding firm Persimmon faced a near 10% protest vote over executive pay, while Crest Nicholson pushed ahead with plans to pay out controversial bonuses despite a 58% rejection of its remuneration report.

Amazon has introduced the Echo Look, a voice-controlled camera designed to be a bedroom companion that provides fashion advice and suggests what to wear, thanks to its AI assistant Alexa. The camera, available by invitation only in the US for $200 (£156), stands on a shelf and features four LEDs for lighting, a depth-sensing system, and a microphone array, similar to other Alexa-powered Echo devices. With its depth information, the camera produces blurred backgrounds in full-length selfies, allowing users to capture their best angles. The device can also record videos, giving users the opportunity to show off their outfits. However, the Echo Look is more than just a camera with Alexa, as Amazon's machine-learning system compares photos of different outfits and provides a "style check" to determine which one is most fashionable at that moment. According to Amazon, the style advice will improve over time as more users participate and fashion experts contribute their expertise. In addition to its fashion-focused features, the Echo Look performs all the usual tasks of other Echo devices, such as setting alarms, answering questions, and playing music. For users' peace of mind, a button on the side allows them to turn off both the camera and microphone. Whether the Echo Look will be a success remains to be seen, but its ability to take full-length photos and videos may appeal to selfie enthusiasts who are already active on social media.

Waymo, Google's self-driving car spin-off, is launching a public trial, allowing residents of Phoenix, Arizona, to apply for full-time access to its fleet of 600 self-driving minivans. The trial aims to recruit "hundreds" of participants with diverse backgrounds and transportation needs, who will be able to ride in the vehicles and provide feedback. According to Waymo's head, John Krafcik, the goal is to give participants unrestricted access to the fleet, allowing them to use the vehicles daily, at any time, to travel anywhere within a designated area roughly twice the size of San Francisco. Arizona has been actively courting self-driving car researchers, offering a more favorable regulatory environment and even launching social media campaigns to attract companies from Silicon Valley. The state's governor, Doug Ducey, has been aggressively pursuing companies like Uber, which was banned from testing in California after regulatory breaches. Waymo has been testing 100 self-driving minivans on public roads since earlier this year and plans to add another 500 vehicles to its fleet. Krafcik emphasized the importance of the trial, stating that the early riders will play a crucial role in shaping the development of self-driving technology, which has the potential to transform various areas, including personal cars, public transportation, ride-hailing, logistics, and more, making our lives and cities safer, more convenient, and more accessible. Currently, Waymo's program is more like a subsidized taxi service than a fully open self-driving car release. While the company aims to develop vehicles that require no human intervention, its early trial involves having a test driver in each vehicle to monitor the rides at all times. As a result, households that apply don't need driving licenses or the physical ability to take control of the car. Waymo's corporate history is varied, having originated as a Google subsidiary called X Labs. When Google restructured into Alphabet, X Labs was spun off and rebranded as Waymo in 2016. This spin-off marked a new direction for the company, which had previously focused on building a fully autonomous car. Now, Waymo is taking a more collaborative approach, partnering with existing manufacturers like Chrysler to add self-driving features to production vehicles.

Left-handed individuals, also known as lefties or southpaws, are often stereotyped as being clumsy and accident-prone. However, this notion is not supported by robust evidence. Would you rather be seen as creative geniuses, like Paul McCartney and Michelangelo, who are also left-handed? Research on handedness has uncovered a range of interesting facts. For instance, men are more likely to be left-handed. Studies have also suggested that left-handed college graduates earn more, and that low birth weight, mental illness, autism, cerebral palsy, heart disease, and certain types of cancer are associated with left-handedness. On the other hand, the idea that left-handed people die younger is a myth. Left-handed individuals do have an advantage in sports, as their opponents receive less practice against them. Additionally, they might be worse drivers, according to a survey conducted by a car insurance company. While this survey might be flawed, it's still worth discussing. The survey found that 28% of left-handed drivers had received a speeding ticket, compared to 19% of right-handed drivers. For parking tickets, the figures were 26% for lefties and 23% for righties. Over a 60-year driving lifetime, left-handed drivers caused an average of nine accidents, compared to eight for right-handed drivers. Interestingly, left-handed drivers were slightly less likely to have damaged their own car (35% vs 38%) and slightly more likely to have passed their driving test on the first attempt (53% vs 49%). "It's important to note that this phenomenon may not be related to the skill level of left-handed individuals. It's possible that cars and roads were simply designed with right-handed people in mind. I've often thought that's the reason I receive so many parking tickets. Some might agree. If you're sympathetic to the cause, you could chant 'Rights for lefties!' and avoid making snide comments like 'Next, they'll be demanding equal marriage rights…'"

Melrose Industries, a UK-based turnaround specialist, is set to distribute a massive £160m bonus to its top four directors, making it one of the largest corporate payouts in the City. The bonus, which is part of a five-year incentive plan approved by investors in 2012, will be shared among the company's three co-founders and its finance chief. Based on the average share price over the past 40 days, the total bonus pot is worth £240m. The four directors - Christopher Miller, David Roper, Simon Peckham, and Geoff Martin - will receive 68% of the bonus, amounting to £40m each in shares. The remaining 32% will be distributed among 20 senior managers. The executives can sell shares to cover their £70m income tax bill but must retain at least half of the remaining shares for at least two years. The directors have a history of retaining their shares, having only sold them to cover tax bills in the past. The bonus plan is designed to align the interests of the directors with those of shareholders, with £3.5bn returned to investors over the five-year period. Melrose Industries has a track record of buying and turning around struggling manufacturing businesses, and its share price has soared from 42.97p five years ago to 236p on Wednesday. The company was founded and floated on the stock market in 2003 by Miller, Roper, and Peckham, who invested about £3m in the business. With its share price expected to rise further, Melrose Industries is likely to rejoin the FTSE 250 index soon. Despite declaring a statutory loss of £69.3m last year, the company made an underlying pretax profit of £96m, with revenues of £889m. The bonus payouts are among the largest in City history, but pale in comparison to the £70m compensation package awarded to WPP CEO Sir Martin Sorrell in 2015, which included a £63m payout from a long-term incentive scheme that sparked a shareholder revolt. Tony Pidgley, the founder and chairman of Berkeley Group, received paychecks of £21.5m and £23.3m over the past two years. At Melrose, Peckham was paid £987,000 last year, while Martin received £803,000, Miller £549,000, and Roper £548,000. A new three-year incentive plan, set to begin on Thursday, was approved by 83% of shareholders at the company's annual meeting earlier this month. This plan includes several "shareholder-friendly" provisions, such as malus clauses, which allow share payouts to be clawed back in certain circumstances. The size of the payout will depend on how much executives improve acquired businesses and successfully sell them. Last summer, Melrose acquired Nortek, a US company that manufactures kitchen stove hoods and extractor fans, for £2.2bn.

British Airways has faced a severe crisis after a power surge brought down its IT systems on Saturday morning, causing backup systems to fail. The airline's response to the crisis has been heavily criticized, with hundreds of passengers left stranded and experts accusing BA of failing them. The value of BA's parent company, IAG, has taken a hit, with a staggering £500 million wiped off its value. Paul Charles, a crisis-response expert with experience at Eurostar and Virgin Atlantic, is baffled by BA's slow response to the crisis. "You need to respond within an hour with a clear statement on what's happening," he says. "It took BA's CEO seven hours to record a video message on Twitter. That's unacceptable." Charles, who now runs a travel consultancy, believes that BA's brand is strong enough to recover from this crisis, but notes that it's being eroded by the airline's poor response. "When airlines don't have a good crisis plan in place, it can lead to a decline in their brand," he warns. United Airlines faced a similar crisis when it blamed a passenger who was dragged off an overbooked plane, but later admitted its initial response was wrong. The airline's stock price recovered after it apologized and improved its response. Malaysia Airlines was nationalized after the loss of two planes in 2014, highlighting the severity of the consequences of a crisis in the airline industry. According to Charles, airlines and airports have a unique ability to fascinate the public and media, which can amplify even minor crises. Effective crisis management plans typically involve clear command structures and a list of key stakeholders that the CEO personally contacts, including major corporate clients and travel agencies. Charles has handled his fair share of crises, but one of the most notable was a single complaint about the food on a Virgin flight from Mumbai to London. The complaint, which went viral in 2009, was made by an anonymous passenger who sent an email to Richard Branson, complete with photos of his meal and a humorous review. The passenger joked that the mashed potato looked like it had been "passed through the digestive tract of a bird." This incident quickly turned into a global negative story, serving as an early lesson in the power of social media. Charles recalls that the company responded quickly and turned the situation around by offering the passenger a role as a food tester for future menus.

A new monument in Moscow has been unveiled at the Institute of Education, HSE University, celebrating an unlikely hero: the anonymous peer reviewer. The 1.5-tonne concrete die, adorned with ominous phrases like "Major Changes" and "Reject" on its six sides, was funded through a crowdfunding campaign that attracted support from renowned researchers, including Nobel laureates Erik Maskin and Andre Geim. The project, which cost around $1,300, offered backers rewards such as replica dice and having their paper title inscribed on the monument. The idea for the monument was conceived by Igor Chirikov, director of the Centre of Sociology of Higher Education, who had been sitting on the concrete block in the institute's grounds for years. "Peer reviewing is a matter of love and hate," Chirikov said, emphasizing the importance of peer review in ensuring the quality of research. He wanted to highlight the impact of reviewers on research, but with a touch of irony to motivate researchers who often receive negative feedback. The crowdfunding campaign poked fun at the academic process with satirical comments from anonymous reviewers, such as "I would suggest a second feasibility study...and you should also assess viewer reactions over a 5-year period." The proposal also joked that the monument could become a site of academic pilgrimage, where researchers would visit to touch the "Accept" side and hope for the gods of peer review to smile upon them. Of course, some unsuccessful researchers might choose to curse the monument instead, and that's their prerogative. At the unveiling event, attendees were invited to wear masks as a tribute to the anonymous aspect of peer review. "We are currently navigating a transformative period, where science is increasingly global. The academic community faces significant challenges today. Rather than dwelling on the difficulties and lamenting the situation, we can choose to move forward with optimism," said Yaroslav Kuzminov, rector of HSE. "We are firmly committed to this approach."

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) has begun a new round of redundancies, targeting 120 staff members, according to Managing Director Michelle Guthrie. In a statement to Senate estimates, Guthrie confirmed that the job losses, which she had previously signaled in March, were underway. This latest round of redundancies will affect senior and middle management roles based in Sydney. Guthrie acknowledged that redundancies are regrettable but necessary to fund the ABC's work. In March, she had announced that 150 to 200 positions would be made redundant, including efficiency initiatives in television and news that resulted in a reduction of approximately 70 employees. The ABC has begun consulting with affected employees in some divisions, with more consultations set to take place over the next few days. Guthrie also defended the ABC's digital presence, responding to criticism from Fairfax Media's CEO Greg Hywood. She emphasized that the public expects the ABC to make its full range of content, including high-quality journalism, available on all platforms, including digital. Guthrie rejected the notion that the ABC should be used as a scapegoat for the challenges facing the digital media landscape. Hywood had accused the ABC of stealing Fairfax traffic by aggressively expanding into digital news and then paying Google to prioritize ABC websites in search engine results. Guthrie countered that the ABC is simply providing high-quality content to its audience, which puts pressure on commercial media to adapt to the changing media landscape. ABC staff are bracing for job cuts on Thursday, when they will meet with management to discuss the latest round of redundancies. The cuts are expected to particularly affect Radio National. In the first round of job cuts in March, up to 85 technical staff on television programs, including 7.30 and Foreign Correspondent, were made redundant, despite Guthrie's characterization of the cuts as streamlining middle management. "In the midst of significant upheaval in the media industry, the ABC's role in informing, educating, and entertaining the nation is more crucial than ever," said Guthrie. "A thriving, productive, and effective ABC is essential, and it's more important than ever that we prioritize our responsibilities." As a public broadcaster, the ABC operates within a fixed budget, and the ABC Act requires us to be both efficient and effective in carrying out our duties. Guthrie referred to the planned cuts as "eliminating duplication in certain content areas." We will allocate an additional $2.9 million to arts, science, and education, and an extra $2 million to new programming as part of a dedicated cross-platform education strategy. "We are simplifying our organizational structure and reducing management layers, and the resulting savings will be invested in new initiatives that bring Australian stories to our audience," Guthrie explained. "Every dollar we save will be used to create engaging, audience-facing content that showcases Australia's unique stories."

While all parties in the general election have made mental health a key issue, the reality on the ground is starkly different. As students and former students of the University of East Anglia's renowned counselling program, we are dismayed by the university's decision to close the course, leaving many students unable to complete their professional qualifications. This abrupt move, made without adequate consultation, prioritizes the university's interests over those of students, staff, and the local community. The irony is not lost on us, as Prince Harry, a vocal advocate for mental health, recently praised the importance of in-depth listening relationships – a key component of our program. The closure will not only affect the course itself but also the therapy organizations where students have volunteered and the university's own counselling service. The university's management-speak explanation for the closure, citing the need for "greater alignment" and a "coherent portfolio of activity," rings hollow. If mental health is truly a priority, then what is the point of offering courses if there are no qualified counsellors to deliver them?

A new credit union, retailCURe, is launching today, backed by high street names such as John Lewis and Debenhams, with the aim of helping shop workers avoid payday lenders. Theo Paphitis, a former Dragons' Den star, has invested a six-figure sum in the not-for-profit enterprise, saying "I'm in". Credit unions are financial cooperatives owned and controlled by their members, which have traditionally served low-income individuals but are now targeting people of all incomes. They offer a vital alternative to banks, payday lenders, and loan sharks. retailCURe, which is open to anyone aged 16 or over who works in retail or a support industry, aims to provide a solution for the 4.5 million people in this sector who are often on low pay. The retail sector is one of the UK's largest employers, but it also has a high number of part-time workers, and salaries in the sector have been declining. retailCURe is run by the retail industry for the retail industry, and other high street names supporting it include Iceland, New Look, and Pets at Home, with more expected to join. Members will have access to loans from £500 to £5,000 at interest rates ranging from 9.9% to 26.8% APR, with two-thirds of loans issued so far having an interest rate of less than 10% APR. In contrast, many payday lenders charge over 1,000% APR. The credit union is also offering "market-beating" rates up to 3% on its savings accounts. "To become a member of retailCURe, you'll need to open a simple easy access account with a minimum deposit of £1 and commit to regular savings. Once you've done this, you'll be eligible to apply for a loan or additional savings accounts. Additionally, some employers will offer the option for employees to have their wages automatically deposited into their credit union account."

Rolls-Royce has committed to preserving 7,000 engineering jobs in the East Midlands as part of a £150 million investment, its largest single outlay in the UK in over a decade. The company has reached an agreement with trade unions to safeguard the work of nearly a third of its 22,300-strong UK workforce for the next five years, as it prepares to double its engine production. Rolls-Royce has scrapped plans to close a precision machining facility in Derby, saving 150 jobs that were at risk, and will create 200 new positions by building a new testing facility for jet engines. The £150 million investment includes £90 million for the construction of a new testbed in Derby, Rolls-Royce's sixth in the city, where it will test its new range of UltraFan engines, which are designed to be more fuel-efficient than previous models. The testbed will also be used to test the Trent 900, Trent 1000, and Trent XWB engines, which power commercial jets such as the Airbus A380, Boeing's Dreamliner, and the Airbus A350. The overall plan also includes investment in Rolls-Royce's large engine maintenance, repair, and overhaul facility, as well as its sites in Hucknall and Annesley, Nottinghamshire. Unite, the trade union, has hailed the plan as a success, saying it "effectively secures the manufacturing base of Rolls-Royce in the UK for the next 20 years, along with 7,000 high-quality jobs." Len McCluskey, Unite's general secretary, said: "This is great news for our world-beating workforce making world-class engines and a testament to the hard work of our shop stewards and members. It's a good day for British manufacturing, but we must not let it be undone by a botched Brexit. The government must now play its part by pursuing a 'jobs first' Brexit and securing tariff-free access to the single market and customs union. Failure to do so risks future investment and decent high-quality manufacturing jobs." "Rolls-Royce's decision to safeguard UK jobs arrives just four months after the company reported a historic £4.6 billion pre-tax loss, largely attributed to the effects of Brexit on the pound and the costs associated with settling corruption allegations. Business Secretary Greg Clark emphasized that the investment underscores the UK's vital role in the global aerospace industry. He also noted that the UK and Rolls-Royce are renowned worldwide for their innovative engineering expertise."

Researchers have captured the first-ever footage of cockatoos performing drum solos with sticks and seedpods, which are believed to be a form of musical display to attract the opposite sex. Scientists spent seven years tracking the elusive Cape York palm cockatoos in the unspoiled wilderness of northern Queensland, finally capturing the extraordinary behavior on camera. The footage shows 18 male cockatoos delivering over 130 drum solos, each with its own unique pattern and flair. Most of these performances took place in front of females, with the males adding embellishments such as calls, blushing, and raised feathers to win them over. Researchers from the Australian National University observed the birds preparing their drumming tools and then banging out sequences of 27 to 92 beats, showcasing their impressive rhythmic skills. The birds' drumming styles varied greatly, ranging from rapid-fire strikes to more laid-back, repetitive beats. According to the study published in Science Advances, the cockatoos' drumming behavior shares key elements with human instrumental music, including the manufacture of sound tools, consistent performance contexts, and individual styles. The researchers liken the birds to solo artists or drummers in rock bands, who have an internal sense of rhythm and generate the motor pattern to create the beat. This behavior is all the more remarkable, as tool manufacture is rare in the animal kingdom and is usually linked to foraging for food.

Miguel Gómez Garza embarked on his final expedition to the Yucatán Peninsula to gather information for his book, "Parrots of Mexico," when an extraordinary encounter awaited him. As he stood by a tree laden with pods, a favorite snack of parrots, he waited patiently for the birds to arrive. His persistence paid off when a group of half a dozen parrots flew in, their striking red fronts and blue wing tips unlike any species he had previously encountered in the area. The parrots' distinctive calls, unlike any on record, left Gómez Garza in awe. "I couldn't believe my eyes," he exclaimed. "The different noise belonged to a different parrot." As an ornithologist and veterinarian at the Autonomous University of Nuevo León in Monterrey, Mexico, Gómez Garza was thrilled to have discovered a new species of parrot. An international team of scientists has now published research on the newly discovered blue-winged Amazon parrot, or Amazona gomezgarzai, in honor of its discoverer. Measuring 25cm in height, this parrot boasts a loud, short, and repetitive call reminiscent of the soundtrack to Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho. One of its calls eerily imitates that of a hawk, a natural predator of parrots. Scientists speculate that this mimicry may serve as a deterrent, scaring other birds away and leaving more seeds, fruit, and flowers for the parrots to feast on. After obtaining permission from the Mexican authorities, Gómez Garza captured a male and female parrot for further study, collaborating with Tony Silva at the University of Florida and Pawel Mackiewicz at the University of Wroclaw. DNA tests conducted on the parrots, described in the journal PeerJ, revealed that this new species evolved from the white-fronted parrots (Amazona albifrons) native to the region approximately 120,000 years ago. Due to the parrots' rarity, the tests were performed without causing them harm. "In recent history, I believe this is the first time a scientific description has been completed without the species being threatened with extinction," said Gómez Garza. He noted that conservation plans are already underway to protect the species. Mackiewicz estimated that there are likely fewer than 100 blue-winged Amazon parrots remaining, making conservation efforts a top priority. According to Gómez Garza, parrots worldwide are vulnerable to habitat destruction. While the international illegal trade of parrots has decreased in recent years, it still persists locally for certain species. Gómez Garza emphasized that raising awareness will be crucial in saving wild parrots globally."

Three billionaire shareholders who triggered Ten's voluntary administration will provide financial support to the network until a new owner is found, according to administrators KordaMenthe. Ten was forced to halt trading and enter voluntary administration last month after financial backers Lachlan Murdoch and Bruce Gordon failed to guarantee a $250m loan. At a creditors' meeting in Sydney on Monday, Ten's administrators announced that leading shareholders Gordon and Murdoch, who now jointly own 22.5% of the network, along with James Packer, have agreed to provide the necessary funds to keep Ten operational. According to partner Mark Korda, the network has sufficient cash resources for now, but the shareholder guarantors will establish a financing facility by the end of the week to ensure Ten's continued operation. Ten reported a significant half-year loss of $232m in April and warned that its future as a going concern was uncertain if it couldn't secure another loan. The first creditors' meeting since Ten's voluntary administration on June 13 took place on Monday, and a 14-member creditors' committee was appointed to oversee the network's administration. The committee includes representatives from various stakeholders, including Ten employees, Cricket Australia, CBS, Fox, Endemol Shine, Fremantle Media, the Commonwealth Bank, and investment vehicles Birketu and Illyria. Judith Fox, CEO of the Australian Shareholders' Association, who was excluded from the meeting, expressed a preference for the network to be re-listed, the business to be salvaged, and shareholders' stakes to continue. The Australian Financial Review has reported that the Commonwealth Bank, a major creditor, may appoint a receiver as early as this week, but Korda downplayed the threat, saying a receivership would not impact Ten's long-term viability. "David Gordon, the chairman of Ten, has received an apology from the Australian newspaper after it published an incorrect report on Monday claiming he sold most of his shares before the company went into voluntary administration. The article was promptly removed from the newspaper's website on Monday morning."

Google is taking steps to ensure the confidentiality of business communications by stopping the scanning of email content sent by Gmail users. The company had previously read the content of personal Gmail accounts to deliver targeted advertisements, but is now stopping this practice to align its business and consumer products more closely. Google's business email service, part of G Suite, has never involved scanning emails for advertising purposes. In a blog post, Diane Greene, senior vice president of Google Cloud, confirmed that G Suite's Gmail is not used for ads personalization, and that this change will also apply to the company's free consumer Gmail service. Starting later this year, consumer Gmail content will no longer be used or scanned for advertising purposes. Although G Suite customers have never had their messages scanned for advertising, some potential customers were deterred by the misconception that they were. To address this, Google is making it clear that G Suite emails will not be used for advertising purposes. While G Suite emails will still be scanned for security reasons, such as detecting spam and phishing attempts, the company is making changes to its advertising policies on Gmail to better serve its enterprise customers. This move reflects Google's growing focus on its enterprise customers, who are increasingly important to the company's cloud computing platforms. "The company will still advertise on the service, but its ads will now be tailored to individual users, using data collected from their online behavior, including search history, browsing habits, and physical location."

The Daily Mail responded with a strong and forceful tone (Letters, June 23). That metaphor, which implies a sense of urgency and intensity, speaks volumes. Left-wing individuals don't resort to aggression or hostility towards others, including Daily Mail readers, but rather use satire and mild criticism. The increasing number of death threats in our society primarily come from extreme right-wing individuals, as even Charles Foster might agree. It's not the readers who are driving the extreme right-wing agenda at the Mail, but rather the editors, who go beyond simply expressing opinions. Has this letter put me in a vulnerable position? Virginia Cumming, London

As Charles Foster notes, it's not always possible to determine someone's political stance based on the newspapers they read. A late colleague of mine used to buy the Daily Mail every day, which surprised me given his political views. I once asked him why he continued to purchase the paper, given our differing political beliefs. He replied, "The Daily Mail is the only paper that holds Tony Blair accountable." Nigel Stapley, Wrexham
