"Despite rising house prices across the UK, many people are struggling to enter the property market, even with low mortgage rates. The issue is particularly pronounced for ethnic minority communities, who are significantly less likely to own their homes compared to white British individuals. We're interested in hearing from people from Black, Asian, and Minority Ethnic (BME) backgrounds about their experiences with the housing market. Whether you're considering buying a home or not, we want to hear about your personal circumstances and any challenges you face. Share your stories and help us understand the reasons behind these statistics. Do you or your family hope to own a home in the future? Are you already a homeowner or has the housing market deterred you? What obstacles do you encounter? What do you think contributes to the disparities in homeownership rates? Share your experiences anonymously if you prefer, and we'll feature a selection in our reporting."

My uncle Saad Mahmood Hikmat, who has passed away at the age of 79, left an indelible mark on musical education in Iraq and Jordan. As a sound engineer at Iraqi TV and radio, Saad played a crucial role in establishing reputable recording studios in Baghdad. From 1960, he dedicated himself to teaching music at the Institute of Hope, a school for children with sensory impairments, where he developed innovative methods to reach his students. One of his most cherished projects was the music and ballet school he helped establish in Baghdad in 1968, where he served as a key staff member and played a significant role in directing the institution. Many of its students still fondly remember him, and his three children and four nieces and nephews are proud graduates of the school. Born in Baghdad, Saad was the fourth of six children to Mahmood Jasim Hikmat and Kadria Raoof Al-Attar, who worked for the Iraqi government. From a young age, Saad demonstrated a natural talent for music and the accordion, which his father encouraged. After completing his high school education, Saad was admitted to the Institute of Fine Arts (later the Academy of Fine Arts) in Baghdad in 1952, where he studied music with both Western and Iraqi teachers. He graduated as a skilled pianist, accordion player, and piano tuner, and further honed his craft through travels to Italy, Greece, Poland, and the former USSR. Saad had a deep appreciation for jazz, and his encounter with Duke Ellington in the 1960s was a highlight of his career. The Duke was impressed by Saad's talent, and his compositions, which included songs, school marches, and a ballet, blended elements of Western music. While Saad was not one for public performances, he was always willing to lend his skills to a good cause, such as playing Bach to accompany a church choir in Baghdad at the request of a priest. In 2003, Saad relocated to Amman, Jordan, where he continued to share his passion for music. "He spent his time in that place teaching music privately and also volunteered to teach at the Institute of Light, an organization that supports visually impaired children. He leaves behind his wife, Rasmiya Mohammad Ali, a dedicated social worker whom he married in 1968, as well as their three children, Basheer, Omar, and Fatima."

SoftBank's humanoid robot Pepper has taken on a new role - that of a Buddhist priest for funerals. Building on the concept of a German "blessing bot", Pepper's updated software allows it to chant sutras in a robotic voice while tapping a drum, providing a more affordable alternative to a human priest for funeral services. At a recent funeral industry fair in Tokyo, Nissei Eco showcased Pepper, a plastic molding maker, which is looking to disrupt the market by offering its services for just £350 per funeral, significantly cheaper than the average cost of £20,000 in Japan. With Japan's aging and shrinking population, many Buddhist priests are struggling to make ends meet, prompting some to seek part-time work outside their temple duties. According to Michio Inamura, Nissei's executive adviser, Pepper could fill the gap when a human priest is unavailable. Funeral organizers can even customize Pepper's appearance by dressing it in a Buddhist monk's robe and live-stream the ceremony for those who cannot attend in person. Buddhist priest Tetsugi Matsuo, who attended the expo, expressed interest in seeing if Pepper could convey the "heart" aspect of religion, which he believes is the foundation of faith. While Pepper has not yet been hired for a funeral, it seems likely that robots will eventually play a role in the funeral industry, given their increasing presence in various aspects of life.

Ken Burns' new documentary series on the Vietnam war (reviewed by Tim Dowling on September 26) has sparked a discussion about the technique of transforming still images into moving ones, which is often referred to as the "Ken Burns effect." However, in the UK, this technique is more commonly associated with Ken Morse, a renowned cameraman known for his mastery of the rostrum camera. Morse's techniques have been so influential that his name is now used in software that achieves similar results with less physical effort, although possibly with less creative flair. Interestingly, Morse is also famous for working with a parrot on his shoulder, a feat shared only by Long John Silver. Unfortunately, I have no update on the parrot's current status.

The Wall Street Journal has announced that it will discontinue its Asian and European editions as part of a broader editorial restructuring and in response to declining revenue. The company will cease publication of its European edition on Friday, while its Asian edition will stop printing on October 7th, marking the end of a 40-year history. The decision comes after News Corp, the paper's parent company, reported a significant loss of $643 million for the fiscal year ending June 30th, a stark contrast to the $235 million profit reported the previous year. The paper's separate Asian edition was launched in 1976, followed by its European edition in 1983. While the US edition of the WSJ will still be available in select cities at a later date, the paper plans to focus on encouraging customers in Asia and Europe to read its digital edition. The decision to discontinue the foreign editions was made due to the growth of digital subscriptions, which have increased by 322,000 in the most recent quarter, reaching a total of 1.27 million. This move is part of a larger restructuring effort, which includes a previous round of buyouts and layoffs in 2016. Additionally, the paper has seen a significant number of reporters and editors leave in the past year, reportedly due to frustration with the paper's coverage of US President Donald Trump.

Imperial Brands, a leading tobacco company, is working on a rescue deal for Palmer & Harvey, the UK's largest cigarette supplier, which employs 4,000 people and supplies tobacco products to Tesco and other retailers. Palmer & Harvey, which was founded in 1925 and is owned by current and former employees, is struggling to stay afloat and is expected to receive funding from Imperial and Japan Tobacco International to keep its operations running while it negotiates a rescue deal with Carlyle, a private equity firm. The deal is expected to include an extension of Tesco's three-year distribution contract with Palmer & Harvey, which accounts for around 40% of the wholesaler's revenues. The wholesale sector has been shaken by Tesco's recent takeover of Booker, a cash and carry group, which is currently under investigation by the competition watchdog. Industry experts warn that if Tesco shifts its business from Palmer & Harvey to Booker, the former will struggle to compete. However, Tesco may extend its contract with Palmer & Harvey in an attempt to secure approval for its Booker takeover from the Competition and Markets Authority. Palmer & Harvey, based in Hove, East Sussex, supplies 12,000 products, including chilled foods and alcohol, to 90,000 shops across the country, including large retailers, corner stores, and petrol station forecourts. The company is run by Tony Reed, a former Tesco executive who previously managed the supermarket's 3,000 convenience stores, and is expected to remain in charge after the rescue deal is completed.

British consumers are dipping deeper into their savings due to the strain of rising prices and stagnant real wages, according to recent figures. The growth rate of personal bank deposits has slowed to its lowest annual rate since the financial crisis, with a mere 2.2% increase in August, the weakest month since May 2009. This decline is partly attributed to £1 billion being withdrawn from cash ISA accounts, as tax changes allow individuals to earn up to £1,000 in interest tax-free. According to UK Finance, households are saving less each month, rather than borrowing more, as the growth in personal deposits has slowed alongside a slowdown in consumer credit borrowing. Annual growth in credit card borrowing slowed to 5% in August, down from 5.3% the previous month, while personal loan and overdraft usage fell by 1.6% on an annual basis. Overall, the annual growth in consumer credit slowed from 1.9% in July to 1.5% in August. Despite a decline in consumer confidence due to rising prices and Brexit uncertainty, retail sales growth suggests that shoppers have not yet cut back on spending. Retail sales volumes rose by 1% in August, following a revised 0.6% increase in July. There had been concerns that consumers were increasingly relying on credit cards and loans to fund their spending habits. However, the falling rate of bank deposits also indicates that consumers are drawing on their savings. According to the latest ONS figures, the amount of household money available for saving has fallen to an all-time low in the first three months of this year. The amount being set aside as savings has slipped to 1.7% of disposable income, a fraction of the near-10% average for the last 50 years. A year ago, this rate was more than three times the current rate. The purchasing power of British consumers is expected to face further strain due to inflation, with the Bank of England predicting that the consumer price index (CPI) will reach a peak above 3% in October. As of August, the CPI inflation rate stood at 2.9%, driven by the increasing cost of importing fuel, clothing, and food. The Bank of England has kept interest rates unchanged this month, but warned that it may raise rates for the first time in a decade as early as November to combat rising inflation. According to Mohammad Jamei, senior economist at UK Finance, "Some households in the UK have chosen to save less, while others have not increased their borrowing."

According to leading City businesses, London and Frankfurt will likely lose their status as global financial hubs to New York and Singapore unless a free trade agreement on financial services is reached after Brexit. A report from key UK banks, law firms, and fund managers proposes a "bespoke" free trade deal that would allow British and EU-based financial companies to sell products and services without tariffs, taxes, or quotas in each other's markets. The agreement would include a new joint dispute resolution body, comprising judges and independent experts, to resolve any breaches. If the UK loses its "passporting" rights, British pensioners and EU consumers could face dire consequences, including potential difficulties in paying out personal pension or insurance contracts. To address these concerns, the International Regulatory Strategy Group, sponsored by the City of London Corporation and TheCityUK, has developed a plan for a free trade agreement. The report, launched in Brussels by ISRG council chair Mark Hoban, a former City minister, suggests that setting up the free trade area would be straightforward, given the similarity of EU and UK regulatory regimes. Hoban emphasized that the plan is ambitious but would benefit the entire continent. He warned that if London loses its status as the world's leading financial hub, activity would likely shift to New York or Singapore, rather than within the EU, resulting in losses for businesses and families. Rachel Kent, a partner at Hogan Lovells and co-author of the report, noted that the proposed agreement mirrors the free trade area agreement between Canada and the EU, which aims to grant financial institutions reciprocal access to each other's markets in the future. According to Kent, the report's starting point is that both the EU and the UK have expressed a desire to secure future arrangements for free trade in financial services. She emphasized that an enhanced free trade agreement, as proposed in the report, is technically and legally feasible and would form a dedicated financial services chapter within a broader EU-UK agreement. The proposal includes a forum of regulators that would collaborate on a joint response to new global standards, as well as involvement in supervision and enforcement, with regular meetings. Kent highlighted that the 95-page report is the first comprehensive piece of work produced by any sector. Additionally, she suggested that the model could be applied to other highly regulated industries, such as pharmaceuticals and aviation.

According to reports, the BBC's political editor, Laura Kuenssberg, is receiving protection from security guards at the Labour party conference this week due to the abuse she has faced over her role. Kuenssberg, who has previously been jeered by some Labour supporters, will be accompanied by a security team both inside and outside the conference zone in Brighton, the reports stated. The BBC's political editor has frequently been targeted with sexist abuse online, and the corporation is understood to have provided her with a bodyguard during the general election campaign. The BBC declined to comment on the reports of Kuenssberg's protection at the Labour conference, citing a policy of not commenting on security issues. However, The Times published a photo of Kuenssberg with a former soldier who now works as a security consultant for the BBC. The abuse aimed at Kuenssberg has been sparked by complaints that she is not neutral and treats the Labour leader and his party unfairly. However, she has also been targeted by supporters of other parties. In the past, Kuenssberg has faced hostility from other groups, including Ukip, where she was booed and barraged with questions at a press conference before the general election. The BBC's chairman, David Clementi, has called for politicians and social media companies to take action against the increasingly explicit and aggressive abuse suffered by BBC journalists, particularly women, who are being targeted on a daily basis.

The Alfa Romeo Giulietta boasts a price tag of £18,555, a top speed of 121mph, and can accelerate from 0-62mph in 9.4 seconds. Its fuel efficiency is decent, with an MPG of 45.6, and it emits 144g/km of CO2. At first glance, the Giulietta is a stunning Italian car with a name that references the iconic love story of Romeo and Juliet. However, after spending a week with the car, you may find yourself seeking relationship counseling. Like many relationships, the Giulietta's charm wears off quickly. Its dramatic lines and rimless headlamps initially draw you in, but the codpiece grille's plunging design is less appealing once you've gotten to know the car. The key fob's unlock sound is a jarring, ear-piercing beep that may be off-putting to some. While it's unusual to dismiss a car based on its security tone, the Giulietta's beep is particularly unpleasant. As you enter the car, you're met with a mid-size hatchback with a decent-sized boot, but the seats feel cramped and lack legroom for passengers in the back. The materials used throughout the car's interior are also lacking, with unyielding plastics that don't provide a pleasant tactile experience. The driver's touch points – the door handle, steering wheel, and gear stick – are particularly important, but they fail to impress. The instrument panel's tiny text is another disappointment, making it difficult to read. When you start the engine, it sounds promising, but the pedals' unusual arrangement is a strange problem to contend with. I'm torn between thinking the pedals are too high or too close together. As someone with size-10 feet, I've developed a peculiar habit on each drive: I have to remove my right shoe because I'm prone to accidentally hitting the brake and accelerating simultaneously. While this might be manageable for a rally driver, it's unsettling for a mere mortal like myself. Once you get past the initial jitters, the drive becomes exhilarating and rewarding. The Giulietta boasts a robust lineup of turbocharged petrol engines, as well as impressively efficient MultiJet turbodiesels. Opt for the 1.6-litre diesel, and you'll enjoy up to 74.3mpg while emitting a mere 99g/km of CO2. On the open road, the Giulietta truly shines – it's quiet, responsive, and comfortable. Unfortunately, this impressive performance comes too late to salvage the overall experience. While the Giulietta has great looks and a fantastic engine, it's not the kind of partner I'd want to commit to for the long haul.

I rented a car from Hertz through Holiday Autos in August, collecting it from Memphis airport and arranging to return it eight days later in Brooklyn, New York. The upfront cost was £548. Unfortunately, we were two hours late arriving at the drop-off location, which had closed at noon. The Hertz helpline advised me to take the car to an alternative location, West 34th Street. The staff at the new location were pleasant, informing me that I wouldn't need to complete any paperwork and would receive an email confirmation. However, I never received the confirmation. Upon reviewing my credit card statement, I noticed a second charge of £579 from Hertz. After inquiring, I was told that this was for the late return and a one-way fee for returning the car at a different location. While I accept the late charge, I find it excessive to be charged over £500 for dropping off the car at an office just seven miles away. I have complained to Holiday Autos, but they are refusing to provide a refund or assist in resolving the issue with Hertz.

Hertz attributed the extra charge to an error in the original booking, stating that the distance-based one-way fee between Memphis and Brooklyn was not calculated correctly at the time of the initial booking. According to Hertz, when I dropped off the car at the new location, the computer automatically applied the correct fee. In response to my complaint, Hertz has since refunded the charge.

If you have a consumer complaint, we'd like to hear from you. Please email us at consumer.champions@theguardian.com or write to Consumer Champions, Money, The Guardian, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Be sure to include a daytime phone number.

A legal loophole that allows parents to avoid paying child maintenance by holding their money in a joint account with a new partner is set to be closed within months. The government is overhauling the laws to ensure that parents can no longer dodge their child support obligations by hiding their money in a joint account. Currently, only money held in a sole account can be seized for payment, but the new rules, which will come into effect early next year, will make joint accounts liable for maintenance payments as well. The Department for Work and Pensions will ensure that only the funds belonging to the paying parent are targeted, and joint accounts will only be used when the parent in question does not have their own account or their account does not have enough to cover what they owe. The change is expected to result in the collection of over £390,000 in additional child maintenance. According to Minister for Child Maintenance Caroline Dinenage, the priority is to ensure that children receive the support they need, and the new power will be another tool to tackle parents who try to cheat their way out of paying towards their children.

Brian Cathcart's assertion that Impress is an "independent" regulator and the Press Recognition Panel is "a body independent of government" is misleading. In reality, the panel's independence is limited by the royal decree that established it, which outlines strict rules for membership, appointment, and operation. Furthermore, the panel relies entirely on government funding and its decisions carry the weight of law, as any newspaper that doesn't comply with an approved regulator may face legal consequences. This setup is little more than state regulation of the press in disguise, with the label of "independence" being used as a facade.

In our latest installment of cringe-worthy tech products, I'd like to introduce the "Smile mirror," a mirror designed specifically for cancer patients that only becomes reflective when they smile. Conceived by Berk Ilhan, the idea behind this product is rooted in the facial feedback hypothesis, which suggests that even fake smiling can boost mood and improve immune function. However, the evidence supporting this claim is shaky at best. What's more, it's possible to smile in front of a regular mirror without any special technology. The product features a screen with a camera that uses facial recognition to detect a smile, which then turns the screen reflective. Ilhan, the creator, has stated that he developed the mirror while studying at the School of Visual Arts in New York, after consulting with oncologists and cancer patients. One patient reportedly found it difficult to confront their illness, prompting Ilhan to take a rather literal approach. While the idea may have come from a good place, I find this product to be one of the more absurd concepts to emerge. To make matters worse, the Smile mirror comes with a hefty price tag of $2,000 to $3,000. It's unlikely that the cash-strapped NHS will prioritize this product, as Ilhan hopes to sell it to hospitals. Initial reactions to the mirror have been overwhelmingly negative.

As for Ilhan's plans, he intends to crowdfund the product on Kickstarter soon. If you're a cancer patient tired of being told to "think positive" or a woman who's been told to smile enough by men, then start saving up.

The Changing Media Summit is back on March 7, 2018, bringing together industry leaders to address the most pressing issues of our time. This year, we're shining a spotlight on the importance of responsibility across the media landscape. As mainstream media faces growing accusations of bias and misinformation, we'll explore what constitutes balance in news reporting. Meanwhile, new and independent outlets are gaining traction, and we'll examine how they can collaborate with mainstream media to better serve readers and the public. The changing media landscape has also put social media platforms under intense scrutiny. We'll discuss the responsibility these platforms bear for the content they host and whether they should be held to the same standards as traditional news providers. Additionally, we'll delve into the critical issue of responsible data use, considering the risks of AI-powered cyberattacks and the importance of data security. In the event of a data breach, how should brands respond, and how can they leverage IoT and AI technology as a defense? Furthermore, we'll examine the challenges facing the advertising industry, including the need for greater diversity and inclusion. We'll explore what brands and agencies are doing to drive change and whether new technologies like VR, AR, and home assistants can help propel narratives and make a lasting impact. Join us at the Changing Media Summit as we convene industry leaders to discuss the industry's approach to balance and responsibility.

Mark Zuckerberg has been asked by Damian Collins, the chair of the digital, culture, media and sport committee, to provide evidence of Russian-linked Facebook accounts' involvement in the EU referendum and the general election as part of an inquiry into "fake news". Collins has written to Zuckerberg after suspicions arose that Russian "actors" used Facebook to interfere in British politics. Facebook, which has 32 million users in the UK, has already provided evidence of Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election to several US Senate committees. In the US, Facebook disclosed last month that an influence operation believed to be based in Russia spent $100,000 on adverts promoting divisive political and social messages over a two-year period. In a letter to Zuckerberg, Collins stated that the committee is investigating the phenomenon of fake news and its impact on political discourse. He requested that Facebook provide details about adverts and pages paid for or set up by Russian-linked accounts, including the amount spent and the number of views. The committee has called for more evidence by November 7th and has asked Facebook to take a strong stance on fake news, similar to its approach to child abuse images and copyright privacy. Facebook announced that it had updated its software in January to prevent false news from appearing in its "trending topics" section. The new algorithm takes into consideration not only the number of users sharing a topic but also the number of reputable news organizations publishing about it, as it is more likely to reflect real-world events being covered by multiple news outlets. In April, a pilot program was launched to help users identify fake news, but it only ran for three days. Despite these efforts, Facebook's attempts to combat fake news in the UK are trailing behind those in Germany, France, and the Netherlands, where the company is collaborating with established media outlets to flag disputed stories in users' newsfeeds. According to Collins, who spoke to the Guardian in April, he is not convinced that the company has sufficient fact-checkers to thoroughly scrutinize disputed content.

Sir Hector Sants, a former chief regulator of the City, is set to provide private testimony to the High Court in a case brought by Lloyds Banking Group shareholders against the bank and its former directors. The former CEO of the Financial Services Authority (FSA) had initially requested to give evidence in private, and this decision was made public after five media organizations, including the Guardian, applied to the court to learn more about the "special arrangements" in place for his testimony. Mr. Justice Norris made his ruling after hearing the application from the media organizations, which came on the fourth day of the case. The case, brought by approximately 6,000 Lloyds investors, seeks £600 million in compensation, claiming that they were not informed about loans made to HBOS when they voted to approve the takeover in November 2008. The claim is against Lloyds and five of its former directors, including Sir Victor Blank and Eric Daniels, who are contesting the claim. Lloyds announced the HBOS deal in September 2008, just after Lehman Brothers collapsed, marking the beginning of the financial crisis. The UK government eventually took a 43% stake in the enlarged Lloyds Banking Group but has since sold its remaining shares. In his ruling, Mr. Justice Norris emphasized that he is not conducting a public inquiry into the events of 2008. The case is expected to run for 14 weeks, with Sants scheduled to testify in December. The FSA has since been replaced by the Financial Conduct Authority. Blank and Daniels are set to testify in the coming weeks, along with three other former directors named in the case: Tim Tookey, Helen Weir, and Truett Tate.

The London Stock Exchange has released a 20-page circular explaining the departure of its CEO, Xavier Rolet, citing his "operating style" and shareholder concerns about his future tenure. The circular sets the stage for a shareholders' meeting on December 19, demanded by activist investor TCI, which seeks to oust the company's chairman, Donald Brydon, over his handling of Rolet's departure. TCI, the Children's Investment Fund Management, had previously opposed Rolet's departure, but dropped its objections after the LSE announced that Rolet would leave immediately, a year earlier than planned. The circular urges shareholders to support Brydon, stating that non-executive directors unanimously agreed in October to implement a "smooth" succession plan for Rolet. It notes that shareholders had been asking about Rolet's future plans, as he had offered to step down if the merger with Deutsche Börse had gone ahead. The alliance was blocked by the European Commission in March. The exchange also revealed that "aspects of Xavier Rolet's operating style" were considered by the board when developing the succession plan, but did not provide further details. TCI had initially called for Rolet to remain CEO until 2021, but the circular suggests that there was uncertainty about his willingness to stay, which had negatively impacted his relationship with the board. The LSE had been urging TCI to reconsider its call for a shareholder meeting after bringing forward Rolet's departure date and announcing that Brydon would not stand for re-election at the 2019 AGM. The row prompted an intervention by Bank of England governor Mark Carney, whose comments appear to have accelerated Rolet's departure.

The vice-chancellor of Bath University, Dame Glynis Breakwell, has refused to express embarrassment over the controversy surrounding her £468,000 pay package. Breakwell, who is the UK's highest-paid vice-chancellor, has agreed to step down but will continue to receive her full salary until her retirement in early 2019. She will take a sabbatical at the end of the current academic year and then retire, resulting in a total payout of around £600,000.

In an interview with BBC Radio 4's PM programme, Breakwell defended her salary, stating that she is not embarrassed by the controversy. She believes that the university's reputation is not being damaged by the criticism, and that the value and significance of the university are being recognized.

When asked if her pay package was excessive, Breakwell argued that the university is operating in a globally competitive market for talent in higher education, particularly when it comes to leaders. She also suggested that the recent criticism does not reflect the full picture, stating that while some people are angry and disillusioned, the majority do not feel that way.

Breakwell has faced criticism for her pay package, which was approved by the university's governing body. Despite narrowly surviving a no-confidence vote at the university senate last week, Breakwell remains defiant, insisting that the controversy has not damaged the university's reputation. However, campus protests against her are planned for Thursday, with staff and students expressing their discontent with her leadership.

Let me know if you'd like me to make any further changes!

The staff at HuffPost Australia are bracing themselves for potential layoffs as the company reviews its partnership with Fairfax Media. The website has stopped taking commissions from contributors, and the atmosphere is tense as employees await news about the future of the company. HuffPost Australia's editor-in-chief, Tory Maguire, declined to comment on the situation, but a spokesperson said that the company's joint venture partners are discussing the future of the website and no decisions have been made yet.

Lisa Wilkinson, a former co-host of the Nine Today show, is the editor-at-large at HuffPost Australia, a role that has been criticized for being underutilized. Despite earning a six-figure salary, Wilkinson has only filed one piece per month, and her last article was published in October. HuffPost Australia was launched in 2015, five years after the company first announced plans to set up an office in Australia.

The uncertainty surrounding HuffPost Australia's future is attributed to changes at the global Huffington Post empire after the departure of co-founder Arianna Huffington last year. In her farewell letter, Huffington announced that she would be stepping down as editor-in-chief to focus on her new venture, Thrive Global.

Fairfax Media chairman Greg Hywood had previously expressed enthusiasm for the partnership, saying that HuffPost Australia would be a valuable addition to the company's digital portfolio. However, concerns about the company's future have been heightened since the appointment of a new CEO, JJ Eastwood, who replaced founding CEO Chris Janz. Janz moved to a new role at Fairfax Media as director of publishing innovation in the company's recent restructuring. The local management board of HuffPost Australia comprises Guy Reypert, Fairfax Media's group director of digital ventures, and Jason Scott, CEO of Allure Media, a wholly owned subsidiary of Fairfax. Allure Media's CEO, Jason Scott, brings a wealth of experience to the role, having been hired for his expertise in digital publishing and his background in editing news and commentary at News Corp Australia. Launched in 2005 by Arianna Huffington, HuffPost is a unique blend of news, commentary, and opinion, featuring a diverse range of volunteer bloggers, including both well-known personalities and unknown writers.

Geoffrey Oldham, a dear colleague and friend who passed away at the age of 88, was a co-founder in 1966 of the Science Policy Research Unit (SPRU) at the University of Sussex. Throughout his life's work, he dedicated himself to establishing pioneering institutions that championed the intelligent and innovative application of science and technology to create a more sustainable and equitable world. His impact extended globally, and his kindness and enthusiasm inspired a vast network of colleagues and friends. Born in Harden, West Yorkshire, to Evelyn (nee Brooke) and Herbert Oldham, Geoff was the son of a NatWest bank manager. He attended Bingley grammar school and studied geology at the University of Reading, later being accepted for further studies at both Cambridge and Toronto universities. Following his wedding to Brenda Raven in September 1951, they embarked on a journey to Canada just 10 days later. Geoff earned his PhD in geophysics from the University of Toronto and worked in oil exploration, focusing on South America. However, he soon became disillusioned with the work and began to think about how he could use his skills to make a more meaningful difference. This led to a career change, during which he conducted research on science and technology in China and other Asian countries. As deputy director of SPRU from 1966 and later as its director from 1982 to 1992, Geoff drove policy research on science and technology in developing countries. He challenged the prevailing approach, which relied heavily on transferring technology and science from wealthy countries, and instead advocated for a greater emphasis on building the capacity of developing countries to create their own. This was a revolutionary idea at the time. Geoff also played a key role in establishing the International Development Research Centre of Canada (IDRC) in 1970, which has been hailed as the "jewel in the crown of Canadian aid." He then led the science and technology policy program at IDRC, fostering policy research across Asia, Africa, and Latin America. In recognition of his contributions to science, Geoff was appointed a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in 1990. After leaving his position as director of SPRU, Geoff remained actively engaged in various advisory roles, including high-level positions with the United Nations, the IDRC in Canada, and with ministers of science and technology in China. He also became a dedicated champion for addressing gender disparities in science and technology, collaborating with international initiatives such as GenderInSITE. Throughout his career, Geoff played a significant role in shaping the field of science and technology policy research, leaving a lasting legacy on the organizations that fund, conduct, and utilize it. Geoff is survived by his loving wife Brenda, their children Keith and Janice, and their 10 grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Unfortunately, two of his sons, David and Jon, preceded him in passing.

As a successful woman, Glynis Breakwell, the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Bath, has faced an unfair amount of negative criticism. Since taking the helm in 2001, Breakwell has led the university to remarkable achievements, including gold status in the teaching excellence framework, ranking among the top 12 universities in the UK in the research excellence framework, and being ranked fifth-best in the UK by the Guardian University 2018 guide. The university has made significant contributions to the local community and economy. As women academics, we are proud to be part of this institution and acknowledge Breakwell's leadership and support. However, we also acknowledge the criticisms of the university's governance, as outlined in the recent report from the Higher Education Funding Council. We believe it is essential to address these issues and work together to bring about necessary changes. Rather than focusing on personal attacks against the Vice-Chancellor, we should recognize the university's achievements and focus on improving governance. 

Those defending the Vice-Chancellor's £468,000 salary argue that under her leadership, the university has improved its league-table rankings and received accolades for teaching and research quality. However, it is unclear whether Breakwell has personally contributed to these achievements or if they are the result of the hard work and dedication of overstretched academic staff. These staff have faced an eight-year pay freeze, pension cuts, constant threats of redundancy, and ever-increasing workloads and targets, which have led to widespread stress, demoralization, and fear. "In the context of tax avoidance scandals, university vice-chancellors are not overpaid. The shift of power from academics to administrators in teaching and research has led to the emergence of a new type of academic manager who excels at navigating the complex and constantly changing bureaucratic systems used to assess teaching and research. These managers have become similar to tax accountants, who are often well-compensated for their expertise. If tax accountants are paid large sums for their efforts, it would be unfair to pay university administrators, including vice-chancellors, any less. Join the conversation by emailing guardian.letters@theguardian.com or visit gu.com/letters to read more Guardian letters."

According to official statistics, a growing number of independent faith schools are failing to meet Ofsted's standards due to concerns about leadership and the teaching of British values. The schools watchdog, Ofsted, has reported a significant decline in inspection outcomes for smaller, fee-paying schools, particularly faith schools. Latest figures show that 49% of private faith schools inspected by Ofsted were judged to be less than good at their most recent inspection, while 26% were deemed inadequate. This information was released as part of Ofsted's report on the inspections of non-association independent schools, which are smaller, fee-paying schools not affiliated with the Independent Schools Council. There are approximately 1,000 such schools. As of the end of August, 68% of these schools were judged to be good or outstanding at their most recent inspection, a four percentage point decline from the previous year. While independent special schools, which make up 40% of the group, have shown improvement, the decline in outcomes for other independent schools, including faith schools, is described as "stark", with the proportion judged good or outstanding decreasing from 79% in 2014 to 60%. According to Ofsted, part of the reason for the decline is the introduction of new standards three years ago that focus on leadership and fundamental British values. Since the Trojan horse affair in Birmingham in 2014, all schools have been required to teach and reflect British values. The Ofsted report, published on Thursday, stated that the new standards on fundamental British values assess requirements related to written policies on the curriculum, the quality of teaching, and the spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development of pupils. Notably, a higher proportion of weaker faith schools are failing to meet these requirements compared to schools with no faith. Specifically, 81 out of 139 independent Muslim schools were found to be less than good at their most recent inspection, while 39 were deemed inadequate. According to the report, a significant proportion of Christian schools received a rating of less than good, with over half of the 58 Jewish schools inspected deemed to be either "requires improvement" or inadequate. The decline in ratings was also attributed to Ofsted's takeover of inspections at faith schools, which led to a more substantial drop in the number of schools judged to be good or better than expected. Ofsted is concerned that struggling schools are taking too long to improve and has expressed particular worries about safeguarding, which was found to be ineffective in 17% of inspected schools. In contrast, independent special schools are making notable progress, with 78% of them rated good or outstanding, up from 74% in 2014. Only 9% of these schools were judged inadequate, compared to 19% of other independent schools.

In 1973, I was fortunate to have Heinz Wolff as the specialist judge for my school's team in the first heat of the BBC Young Scientists of the Year competition. Two years prior, a consultant at Guy's Hospital in London had approached our school with a request for assistance: they were seeking ways to help children with cerebral palsy, whose shoes wore out quickly due to their unique gait. Our school embarked on a research project to develop a solution, ultimately creating an automated machine that produced hard-wearing polypropylene toecaps to fit over their shoes. Heinz Wolff, with his infectious enthusiasm, took a keen interest in our project and our aspirations for the future. Despite his impressive intellect, he was surprisingly down-to-earth and approachable, maintaining the same warm demeanor both on and off screen. We went on to compete in the final round with different judges, although we didn't win, Heinz wrote to us with kind words of encouragement and invited us to spend a day with him after we completed our A-level exams. We eagerly accepted the invitation and were treated to a fascinating insight into his research. During our visit, he introduced us to a microwave oven, which was being assessed by his team, and we were amazed by its ability to boil a cup of water in just 30 seconds. Heinz had a remarkable ability to make science accessible and exciting, and he never lost his sense of wonder and curiosity. Above all, he was a warm, compassionate, and fun-loving person who made a lasting impression on me.

The first shipment of Russian gas to the UK may not be staying in the country for long, contradicting Moscow's claims that Britain would rely on it for supplies this winter. National Grid confirmed that a shipment of liquefied natural gas (LNG) from a Russian field targeted by US sanctions arrived at storage facilities in Kent on Thursday night. Russian media touted the delivery as a way to "keep Britons from freezing this winter," while the Russian embassy in the UK tweeted, "Feeling cold? Help is on the way." However, industry experts believe the UK is likely to be a stopover for the gas, which could fetch a higher price in Asia. Ed Cox, editor of global LNG at ICIS, cautioned against assuming Russian gas will supply the UK, noting that another empty LNG vessel is waiting outside the Isle of Grain to pick up the cargo. "The prices are much more attractive in Asia and India than they are in Europe," he said. Market sources told ICIS that the LNG was expected to be picked up by the other ship. A National Grid spokesperson clarified that the gas had not entered the national pipeline network that supplies homes and businesses. The Christophe de Margerie tanker arrived at the Isle of Grain on Thursday and has been offloading its gas to storage tanks before a planned departure on Friday. The icebreaker, which set off earlier this month from the Yamal LNG project in the Russian Arctic, is jointly owned by Novatek, China National Petroleum Corporation, and Total. The project is affected by US sanctions against Russian energy projects, although not directly by UK sanctions. Following the shutdown of a major North Sea oil and gas pipeline in mid-December due to a crack discovery, the UK's gas prices surged. However, Ineos, the owner of the Forties pipeline system, has since repaired the crack and expects normal operations to resume around the new year. UK gas prices have since returned to normal levels, and according to Cox, the true story behind the price hike is not Russian gas, but rather imports from Belgium. Cox noted that the UK is on track to see record-high gas pipeline imports from Belgium, potentially reaching a four-and-a-half-year high.

Goldman Sachs has estimated that Donald Trump's recent tax changes in the US will reduce its profits by approximately $5 billion this year. The majority of this cost is attributed to the "repatriation tax," a measure designed to encourage multinational corporations to bring back the trillions of dollars they hold overseas to avoid tax. Goldman Sachs, which reported profits of $7.4 billion last year, stated that the enactment of the tax legislation will result in a reduction of around $5 billion in its earnings for the fourth quarter and year ending December 31, 2017. Two-thirds of this reduction is due to the repatriation tax, while the remaining third is attributed to the implementation of the territorial tax system and the revaluation of US deferred tax assets at lower corporate tax rates. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the bank explained that the tax overhaul will lead to a decrease in its earnings, primarily due to the repatriation tax and the implementation of the territorial tax system.

The recent tax overhaul in the US, approved by Congress last week, includes significant tax cuts for corporations and wealthy individuals. The reduction in corporate tax rates, from 35% to 21%, is intended to encourage multinational corporations to repatriate their cash from overseas. According to Citigroup, US companies are estimated to hold around $2.5 trillion in capital overseas. Companies had previously maintained that they had a responsibility to their shareholders to keep this money abroad rather than bringing it back to the US and paying large tax bills.

The tax overhaul will allow Apple to repatriate its $252.3 billion foreign cash reserves without incurring a significant tax burden. Apple's large amount of untaxed profits held overseas has become a major political issue and a challenge for the company. Amgen, a drugmaker, has stated that it expects to pay between $6 billion and $6.5 billion to repatriate its cash to the US. Goldman Sachs has also reported that the rest of the $5 billion reduction in its profits will come from the cost of implementing the territorial tax system and changes that will make it more difficult for companies to deduct past losses from future tax bills. Barclays has estimated that the change to "deferred tax assets" will cost it around £1 billion. The tax changes were implemented under the guidance of Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, who praised the bill as "great for hardworking workers". Prior to his government role, Mnuchin spent 17 years at Goldman Sachs, until 2002.

According to a recent forecast by British scientists, global temperatures may surpass the internationally agreed 1.5C limit within the next five years, prompting concerns about the effectiveness of global efforts to combat climate change. The Met Office forecasting service predicts that global temperatures will exceed 1C above pre-industrial levels in the period from 2018 to 2022, and may even temporarily breach the 1.5C threshold set by the Paris climate agreement in 2015. "It's now possible that continued warming from greenhouse gases and natural variability could combine to cause a temporary spike above 1.5C in the next five years," said Stephen Belcher, chief scientist at the Met Office. Global temperatures have been steadily rising over the past 20 years, with each of the last three years exceeding the 1C threshold. Last year was the second hottest on record, with no significant boost from the El Niño effect. The 1.5C threshold was set as an ambitious target at the Paris climate conference because scientists believe that a world warmer than that would be prone to extreme and unpredictable climate events, leading to consequences such as droughts, habitat loss, food insecurity, and mass migration. Previously, some predictions had suggested that the threshold would not be breached until the 2040s. However, Met Office scientists emphasize that a single year of temperatures above 1.5C does not necessarily indicate a sustained period of warmer temperatures. The majority of scientists agree that human activities are contributing to global warming and climate change.

My father, Edgar Young, who passed away at the age of 93, was part of a remarkable group of teachers who graduated from Bognor Regis emergency teacher training college in West Sussex after World War II. The college, led by the innovative Roy Macklin, focused on the character and experience of its students rather than formal qualifications, in response to the severe teacher shortage caused by Rab Butler's 1944 Education Act. During the war, Edgar worked as a shipwright in Portsmouth dockyard, but he felt a calling to primary school teaching and shared Macklin's vision of education as a guide for living, rather than just a narrowly vocational or academic pursuit. The college offered a 50-week intensive course for mature students, mostly former servicemen and women, who brought practical skills and worldly experience to the classroom. These students, who had often traveled extensively, were seen as particularly talented and effective educators by heads and school inspectors. Born in Portsmouth to a family of skilled dockyard workers, Edgar was the son of John and Lilian (known as "Cissie"). He attended the Northern grammar school until the war disrupted his further education. During his first teaching practice in Portsmouth in 1950, he encountered children who had never seen the sea, despite being just a mile from the water, and others who had no shoes. Edgar taught at Horndean primary school in Hampshire for many years, working late to prepare individual learning cards for each child and taking every opportunity to extend lessons into the village and surrounding countryside. He was an integral part of village life, and he and his wife, Iris (nee Lott), whom he married in 1950, were active members of the local Merchistoun Hall community association. In his free time, he studied for a diploma in education. Edgar's opposition to the 11-plus, as well as his union membership, slowed his career development, which was considered unconventional at the time. In 1970, Edgar was appointed deputy head at Wildground junior school in Hythe, near the New Forest. Upon his retirement in 1984, he led guided walks in his free time. In 2001, Edgar and his wife Iris relocated to a sheltered housing complex in Southsea, where his older sister Joyce, a former headteacher, was also living. Edgar dedicated himself to caring for both his sister and wife until their passing. Throughout his life, Edgar remained a teetotaller and non-smoker. Seventy years after leaving the dockyard, he was diagnosed with mesothelioma, a condition common among former employees. Just hours before his death, Edgar was working on the Guardian quick crossword puzzle. Edgar leaves behind two sons, Kevin and [your name], three grandchildren, Ann, Martin, and Sam, and a great-granddaughter, Freyja.

Picking a primary school for your child can be a revealing experience. Friends who may not be familiar with the Lord's Prayer suddenly become experts on Corinthians to get their children into the local Church of England school. Even those who claim to be socially liberal may secretly be closet Tories, willing to do whatever it takes to get their child into a good school. Some parents may even consider moving in with their in-laws to secure a spot in a desirable catchment area. But where do you start your search? Ofsted reports focus too much on maths and literacy, while Year 6 Sats results are too narrow in their scope. The Good Schools Guide, the Daily Telegraph's guide, and even Tatler's guide are all questionable sources. The Sunday Times recently named East Ham's St Stephen's as the UK's best primary school, the first state school to achieve this honor. According to the government's annual assessment of the "three Rs" - reading, writing, and maths - London primary schools dominate the rankings, followed closely by those in the north-east and south-east. The top-performing primary school overall is Meysey Hampton CofE in Cirencester. Ultimately, why not choose a primary school that just feels right for your child? Some schools, like Downshall Primary in Essex, go the extra mile by bringing in elderly visitors to interact with the children. Others, like Findern Primary in Derby, have found that removing shoes at the door and providing slippers for students while they study can improve academic results. Who would have thought that such unconventional approaches could be so effective?

Randolph Quirk was a long-time family acquaintance. Whenever he and his wife, Jean, visited our home, it was filled with joy and merriment. He was also known for his intense competitiveness. During a holiday in Northumberland in the 1960s, Quirk challenged a Roman Catholic priest, Alec Fraser, who was our guest, to a motor race on a two-lane, straight but twisty road. Quirk drove his Morris Minor with his family, while Fraser piloted an Austin Standard. The two drivers took the race seriously, repeatedly overtaking or blocking each other, sometimes side by side, and exchanging shouts and gestures. Quirk finished second. As he stepped out of his car, he extended his hand to the priest and said with a grin: "You missed your calling, Father."

Facebook is introducing a new set of tools to help users make informed decisions about their privacy, in response to the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). According to Facebook's Chief Operating Officer, Sheryl Sandberg, the company is launching a "privacy centre" that will consolidate all core privacy settings in one place, making it easier for users to manage their data. Sandberg explained that the creation of the "privacy centre" was prompted by the GDPR's requirements to give Europeans more control over their information and how companies use it. Sandberg emphasized that Facebook's focus on transparency and control has given the company a strong foundation to meet all the requirements of the GDPR and to continue investing in products and educational tools to protect privacy. Companies that fail to comply with the GDPR can face a maximum penalty of 4% of their global annual turnover or €20m, whichever is greater. In Facebook's case, the maximum possible fine would be $1.1bn, based on its 2016 revenue of $27.6bn. Sandberg also announced that Facebook will work to prevent the abuse of its platform by those seeking to harm the democratic process worldwide and will tackle the issue of fake news. To achieve this, the company plans to double the number of people working on safety and security to 20,000 by the end of the year. Sandberg emphasized that preventing individuals from being part of ad networks, preventing advertising, and removing the financial incentive are key steps in combating fake news. Facebook product manager Samidh Chakrabarti expressed his hesitation, stating, "I wish I could confidently assert that the benefits of social media will ultimately outweigh the drawbacks, but I'm unable to make that guarantee." Meanwhile, the irony of social media executives not using social media themselves is highlighted by the phrase "Never get high on your own supply."

Prezzo, a popular Italian restaurant chain, is set to close around a third of its 300 UK locations, putting approximately 1,000 jobs at risk. The chain, owned by TPG Capital, a US private equity group, is attempting to revamp its business strategy to stay afloat, similar to what Byron and Jamie's Italian have done. As part of its restructuring plan, Prezzo will ask its creditors to approve proposals that would reduce rent payments for its restaurants. Around 100 underperforming outlets, including all Chimichanga branches, are likely to close permanently to help the company achieve long-term financial stability. Although landlords have yet to agree to the plan, known as a company voluntary arrangement (CVA), it is expected to result in around 1,000 job losses among the 4,500-strong UK workforce. According to sources, staff will be transferred to surviving restaurants wherever possible. Prezzo is one of several high-street restaurant chains to announce restructuring plans, as companies face challenges such as rising business rates, increased staff costs, and fragile consumer confidence. The crowded casual dining sector is also experiencing stiff competition, following the influx of private-equity backed firms. Last month, Byron's creditors agreed to a CVA, and Jamie's Italian entered into a similar arrangement this month. Prezzo's directors believe the company is in better shape than either Byron or Jamie's Italian, having made a profit of £5m last year and holding £11m in cash reserves. However, the CVA will still reshape the business, cutting out less profitable restaurants to reflect declining sales. A CVA involves creditors agreeing to forgo some of what they are owed by a business rather than risk it going out of business altogether. "When a restaurant chain is facing financial difficulties, a common solution is for landlords to accept reduced rent payments. A Company Voluntary Arrangement (CVA) requires the agreement of creditors who collectively hold a claim of more than 75% of the company's outstanding debt, with the remaining 25% being bound by the same terms if the CVA is approved."

The UK's universities have excelled in the latest world university rankings, dominating 10 subject areas, but engineering and technology subjects have fallen behind the arts and humanities. According to the 2018 QS world university rankings, published on February 28, the UK is home to the world's top universities in 10 subjects, two more than last year. UK universities occupy a third of the top three positions globally, but these are concentrated in the arts and humanities. In contrast, UK universities have only topped the world's lists for engineering and technology subjects twice, whereas they have made the top three lists for arts and humanities subjects 10 times. The rankings come as the UK government is considering funding reforms that may lead to universities reducing fees for social science and humanities courses due to their lower costs, while science and technology courses may become more expensive. The results demonstrate the resilience of the UK's universities in the face of Brexit. According to Ben Sowter, research director at QS, "While there are still concerns about the UK's relationship with EU research programs and student mobility frameworks post-Brexit, these results offer grounds for optimism." At least one UK institution was ranked in the world's top three in 32 of the 48 subjects. Seven UK universities lead the world rankings in 10 areas, with the University of Oxford excelling in four subjects: anatomy and physiology, archaeology, English language and literature, and geography. This makes it one of only three universities to perform best in more than one subject, along with Harvard University, which tops the rankings in 14 subjects, and Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), which tops the rankings in 12 subjects. The University of Cambridge has been ranked as the world's best in anthropology, after failing to achieve a top spot in any subject last year. The Royal College of Art has been recognized as the world leader in art and design, with the UCL Institute of Education ranked first in education. The University of Sussex has taken the top spot in development studies for the second time, outperforming Harvard University. Meanwhile, Loughborough University leads the way in sports-related subjects, and the University of Sheffield excels in library and information management. The University of Cambridge and the University of Oxford are notable for having the most top 10 departments, with 37 and 35 subjects respectively.
