It's challenging for savers, as the best-paying easy-access cash ISAs from Virgin Money and Leeds Building Society offer a paltry 1.21% interest rate. Meanwhile, official data released earlier this month showed that inflation remained high at 3% in January, resulting in savers losing money in real terms. This may help explain the significant decline in popularity of cash ISAs, with government data revealing a £20 billion drop in investments over the past 12 months. However, interest rates appear to be on the rise. Bank of England Governor Mark Carney recently informed MPs that there will likely be "more than three rate increases" in the coming years. Lloyds, on the other hand, predicts a gentle increase in the official interest rate, reaching 1.25% by 2020 (currently 0.5%). To secure the best rates, savers must lock their money away for a fixed period. Charter Savings Bank is offering a table-topping 2.25% interest rate on its five-year fixed-rate ISA, up from 2.11%. The bank has also increased its one-year and two-year fixed-rate ISA rates to 1.46% and 1.67%, respectively. Virgin Money is offering 1.66% on its two-year fixed-rate ISA. Another reason why cash ISAs may be out of favor is that some individuals now view them as unnecessary. Since April 2016, the first £1,000 in interest earned on savings is tax-free for basic-rate taxpayers, and £500 for those on the higher rate. This is known as the personal savings allowance, which means most people no longer pay tax on savings interest. The only strong argument in favor of cash ISAs is that the money will remain tax-free indefinitely. Alternatively, shares-based ISAs offer a vast range of options. Index trackers, which aim to match the gains and losses of indices such as the FTSE 100, can be a cost-effective way to access the stock market, with fund managers like Vanguard, Legal & General, and Fidelity offering low fees, often below 0.1% per year, and in some cases as low as 0.06%.

Since October, Apple's refurbishment centre in Elk Grove, California has been making around 20 false emergency calls per day, with the cause still unknown. Over the past four months, emergency dispatchers have received approximately 1,600 accidental calls from the centre, with no one on the other end. According to police dispatcher Jamie Hudson, these calls have been coming from Apple and are taking up valuable seconds away from real emergencies. "We're able to quickly identify the location of the call, so when we receive one from Apple, the address will pop up with their location," Hudson explained. The refurbishment centre handles Apple devices, including iPhones and Apple Watches, which recently gained 4G connectivity in some models, allowing them to make emergency calls without requiring a phone or internet connection. Dispatchers have reported hearing people in the background discussing Apple devices, maintenance, and repairs, but it's unclear how the calls are being triggered. Both the iPhone and Apple Watch can make emergency calls without a SIM card or phone contract. The calls began shortly after the release of iOS 11 in September, which introduced an "Emergency SOS" feature that can automatically call emergency services and contacts through a series of gestures. Apple devices can trigger the emergency call feature in different ways, such as rapidly pressing the power button five times on older iPhones or pressing and holding the power button and volume button on iPhone 8 and X models. On the Apple Watch, pressing and holding the power button is enough to trigger the emergency call. In a statement, Apple said it is aware of the 911 calls originating from its Elk Grove repair and refurbishment facility and is working with local law enforcement to investigate the cause and prevent future incidents. Ottawa County dispatchers reportedly contacted local news station WNEM to express frustration over the fact that Apple Watch users were making 10 accidental calls per week. Meanwhile, Tolland County issued a warning to smartwatch owners after noticing a surge in unintentional wrist-dials. Additionally, some Apple HomePod users have been left annoyed by the device's tendency to leave unsightly marks on their furniture, with some even joking that they don't want to be told to "oil my wood" in response to the issue.

The UK Treasury is considering a new tax on digital companies like Facebook and Google, as it pushes for a global agreement on a fairer system for taxing online businesses. Chancellor Philip Hammond is expected to announce the results of a consultation on updating the tax system to reflect the nature of digital businesses in next month's spring statement. Financial Secretary to the Treasury Mel Stride emphasized the need for digital companies to pay "fair" levels of tax, suggesting a system where tax is levied based on where companies earn their revenue, rather than just taxing profits. Stride noted that digital companies are generating significant value in the UK through their platforms, but the current tax regime is not taxing these activities fairly. He expressed the government's desire to move towards a fairer system. Treasury sources revealed that the government's first preference is to reform the international tax system through the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), but if progress cannot be made at the global level, the UK would be prepared to implement unilateral changes. Several large digital companies have faced criticism in recent years for paying very little tax in the UK, often through complex avoidance schemes. Facebook, for example, paid just £5.1m in corporation tax in the UK last year, despite revenues nearly quadrupling to £842.4m due to increased advertising sales. The OECD's efforts to reform its tax policies have been hindered by a disagreement between countries. Some nations, such as the United States, want to impose higher taxes on internet companies, while others, like Luxembourg and Ireland, prioritize attracting foreign investment by maintaining low corporate tax rates. Pascal Saint-Amans, the OECD's director of tax policy, recently expressed frustration, stating, "Countries are left with a sour taste in their mouths because there's no consensus on taxing the profits of digitalized companies." A recent report from the Royal Society of Arts proposes increasing taxes on companies like Amazon, Facebook, and Apple as a potential means of funding a universal basic income for all citizens.

According to the Australia Institute's latest national energy emissions audit, the large Tesla battery in South Australia is consistently meeting the peak energy demand each day, effectively "taking the straw off the camel's back." The report also shows that emissions from the National Electricity Market (NEM) decreased in January, reaching their lowest levels since 2004, largely due to the federal large-scale renewable energy target.

Energy expert Hugh Saddler analyzed the consumption and output of electricity from the Hornsdale Power Reserve, which includes the Tesla battery. He found that the battery follows a consistent pattern, charging overnight when wind generation is abundant and cheap, and discharging into the grid during the late afternoon when demand and spot market prices are at their peak.

While only 30% of the battery's 100MW capacity is devoted to trading, the rest is used to stabilize the energy system by maintaining the grid frequency at 50 Hz and 240 volts. Despite the relatively small contribution to demand smoothing, Saddler notes that the battery is still providing a valuable service, demonstrating the important role energy storage can play in the system.

"The SA battery is providing critical power at the critical moment, taking the straw off the camel's back," Saddler said. The battery effectively time-shifts wind generation, exploiting the difference in wholesale energy prices throughout the day. "The world's biggest battery, in SA, is working in harmony with wind farms," Saddler added.

Peak wind production is the cheapest way to charge the battery, and it stands ready to fill demand gaps if they emerge. The battery charges up overnight, when prices are low, and then hits the grid at the right time to keep price spikes lower than they would be otherwise.

The Australia Institute's report also found that emissions from the NEM decreased to 152.8 Mt of CO2-equivalent in January, the lowest level since 2004. "Despite relatively flat demand, the decrease in coal-fired power generation was driven by the increased output of large-scale renewable energy projects and the decline of Australia's aging coal-fired power station fleet. However, Saddler emphasized that with the renewable energy target nearing completion, Australia urgently needs a post-2021 energy policy to reduce its reliance on coal in the National Electricity Market."

The UK's economy grew at a slower pace than initially estimated in the final quarter of 2017, further widening the gap between Britain and other major economies as it prepares to leave the European Union. The Office for National Statistics revised its estimate for UK growth in the fourth quarter down to 0.4%, missing economists' forecasts that the rate would remain unchanged. The revised figure was attributed to lower-than-expected production and a decrease in consumer spending, which was influenced by the price rises triggered by the sharp fall in the pound following the Brexit vote. The weaker performance in the final quarter of the year led to a downward revision in the UK's overall growth rate for 2017, which was revised down from 1.8% to 1.7%, the weakest rate in five years. As the global economy continues to recover, the UK is falling behind other major economies, including Germany, which grew by 2.2% in 2017, France, which grew by 1.9%, and the US, which expanded by 2.3%. According to Darren Morgan, a statistician at the ONS, a small number of revisions to various industries, including mining, energy generation, and services, contributed to the downward revision in quarterly growth. Services continued to drive growth at the end of 2017, but consumer-facing industries slowed due to price rises, which squeezed household budgets. The UK economy's reliance on consumer spending for growth has decreased, as households have become more reluctant to spend due to falling real pay and inflation outpacing wage growth. Household spending grew by just 0.3% in the fourth quarter and by 1.8% in 2017 overall, the slowest rate of annual growth since 2012. Businesses also appeared hesitant to invest, with business investment remaining flat in the final quarter of 2017. The downward revision in growth came a day after the ONS released figures showing a surprise increase in unemployment in the three months to December. "The disappointing economic data presents a potential challenge for the Bank of England, which had previously hinted that it may raise interest rates as soon as May. However, Samuel Tombs, chief UK economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, believes that the latest GDP figures indicate the economy is still fragile and does not require another rate hike so soon."

Fairfax Media's half-year profit has plummeted by more than 50%, and the company has announced plans to close or sell 28 of its New Zealand newspapers. The decline in earnings to $38.5 million, down from $83 million a year ago, comes on the heels of a similar profit drop reported by Domain, a real estate listings company spun off from Fairfax in November. Fairfax's chief executive and managing director, Greg Hywood, revealed that the company is offloading 35% of its smaller community titles in New Zealand, known as Stuff, to accelerate the shift towards digital revenue. This move may affect up to 60 staff across various titles, including NZ Dairy Farmer and Christchurch Mail. However, there was a bright spot on the digital front, as online subscriptions to Fairfax's Australian Metro mastheads, including the Sydney Morning Herald, The Age, and the Australian Financial Review, increased by almost 50,000 to over 283,000. Hywood credited the company's next-generation publishing model, which includes new websites and apps, for driving engagement and revenue growth. Fairfax's earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation rose 1.3% to $146.9 million, while underlying net profit slipped 9.9% to $76.3 million. Hywood highlighted earnings per share of 3.3 cents and announced an interim dividend of 1.1 cents per share, fully franked. He also signaled that Fairfax is open to collaborating with Rupert Murdoch's Australian newspaper arm to reduce printing and transport costs, and will take advantage of opportunities arising from media consolidation to benefit shareholders. Fairfax Media has taken the next step in its recent positive talks with News Corp Australia, aiming to achieve industry-wide efficiencies in printing and distribution. The company has already had success in collaborating with News on shared trucking and printing titles in Queensland, and is now building on this partnership by jointly appointing advisors to explore deeper strategic opportunities. Fairfax's joint venture with Nine, streaming service Stan, has seen significant growth, with an active subscriber base of 930,000 and an 83% increase in subscription revenue driven by original content such as Romper Stomper and new seasons of popular shows like Unreal, Billions, Better Call Saul, and Younger. Meanwhile, the company is facing challenges in its New Zealand business, where it is appealing a high court decision upholding the country's competition regulator's ruling to block a merger between NZME and Stuff.

When I met John Perry Barlow in a Chinese restaurant in 1995, he confided that writing was a chore he'd rather avoid. "I'd rather pump septic tanks," he said, frustrated by the uncertainty of whether his words would have any impact. We were all attending the Computers, Freedom and Privacy conference nearby, where Barlow was crafting his Declaration of the Independence of Cyberspace, a modern take on Thomas Paine's Common Sense. While some critics found his piece over-the-top, Barlow would shrug off the criticism, joking that his friend Mitch Kapor thought he needed a "hyperbolectomy." Despite the skepticism, Barlow remained committed to his words, and 20 years later, his influential writings on the internet's disruption - including hacking, copyright, and more - continued to inspire thousands to join the fight for a free, open, and democratic internet.

Rupert Murdoch has agreed to maintain control of Sky News for at least 10 years, as 21st Century Fox has strengthened its offer to address concerns about media plurality in the UK. The Competition and Markets Authority previously expressed concerns that Murdoch's bid for Sky would give his family too much control over UK news media. Fox, which is controlled by the Murdoch family trust, also owns News Corp, the publisher of the Sun and the Times. To address these concerns, Fox has proposed a "firewall" to protect Sky News from potential meddling by the Murdochs. Initially, Fox offered a five-year funding guarantee for Sky News, but has now matched its previous commitment to run a "Sky-branded" news service for at least 10 years and guarantee funding over that period. However, the funding level for the second five years is less certain, as Fox has said it will be determined by market conditions and the level of investment required to maintain the service. The revised remedies also include increased independence for Sky News, with the Sky News board required to publish an annual statement confirming that there have been no instances of influence or attempted influence by the head of Sky News. Fox will also include a copy of this statement in its annual report.

Facebook is introducing a range of new tools to give users more control over their privacy, ahead of the implementation of new EU data protection regulations. The changes come after a tumultuous two weeks for the company, which is still reeling from the fallout of the Cambridge Analytica scandal. One of the new features, a unified privacy dashboard, was previously discussed by Facebook's chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, back in January. In a blog post announcing the changes, two Facebook executives acknowledged that the company has more work to do to enforce its policies and educate users about their data choices. They noted that users have been complaining that privacy settings and other important tools are too hard to find, and that the company must do more to keep people informed. Facebook's chief privacy officer and deputy general counsel, Erin Egan and Ashlie Beringer, stated that most of the updates have been in the works for some time, but the recent events have underscored their importance. The new features will be available to all users, not just those in countries covered by the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which takes effect on May 25. On mobile devices, users will now be able to access all their settings in a single place, rather than having to navigate through nearly 20 different screens. They will also have a separate "privacy shortcuts" menu, which provides a centralized hub for options related to data protection, ad personalization, and on-platform privacy. Additionally, Facebook is introducing a new "access your information" tool, which allows users to find, download, and delete their Facebook data. However, the company is not committing to making it easier for users to delete their accounts entirely. Currently, Facebook's option to permanently delete an account is hidden in the help menu, taking a backseat to the non-permanent "deactivation" option that leaves all user data on Facebook's servers and accessible to its data-mining tools. Despite this, Facebook claims that it will make changes to its terms of service and data policies in response to user feedback, including updates that will increase transparency. According to Facebook, these changes are aimed at transparency, not at gaining new rights to collect, use, or share user data, as stated by Egan and Beringer.

A recent video of an Asian elephant "smoking" in a forest in southern India has left wildlife experts perplexed, as they have never observed such behavior before. The footage, captured by Vinay Kumar, a scientist with the Wildlife Conservation Society's India program, shows an elephant picking up an object with its trunk and blowing out a puff of smoke. The 48-second video was shot in April 2016 but only recently posted online. Biologists from the WCS describe the footage as the "first known video documentation of a wild elephant exhibiting such behavior," leaving scientists and experts scratching their heads.

According to the WCS, the elephant may have been using charcoal, which has toxin-binding properties that could have medicinal value for the animals. Charcoal is also a natural laxative and is commonly found in forests after wildfires, lightning strikes, or controlled burns. While elephants have not been observed blowing ash before, animal self-medication, or zoopharmacognosy, is a relatively common phenomenon in the animal kingdom.

Studies have shown that other animals engage in self-medication, such as red colobus monkeys in Zanzibar, which eat charcoal to counteract toxic substances in their food. Bonobos have also been observed swallowing leaves with rough surfaces to remove parasites from their systems. Additionally, red and green macaws eat clay to kill bacteria in their systems, and pregnant elephants in Kenya are believed to eat leaves that may help speed up the delivery process.

India is home to more than 27,000 Asian elephants, which make up about 60% of the global population, according to a 2017 census. The number has decreased by 10% since the 2012 census, but the government attributes this decline to more accurate counting methods.

As Facebook users continue to abandon the platform in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, many are discovering that the social network has been collecting far more data about them than they realized, including detailed records of their phone calls and text messages. The #deletefacebook movement gained momentum after it was revealed that Facebook had shared the personal information of 50 million users with a Cambridge psychologist, without their explicit consent, which ultimately ended up in the hands of election consultancy Cambridge Analytica. Despite user requests to delete their accounts, Facebook instead pushes users towards "deactivation," which leaves all personal data stored on the company's servers. When users attempt to permanently delete their accounts, Facebook suggests downloading a copy of their data, which reveals the extent of the company's data harvesting practices. One user, Dylan McKay, reported that his data logs contained metadata from every cellular call he made between October 2016 and July 2017, as well as metadata about every text message he received or sent. Many other users expressed unease upon discovering the extent of the data being logged, including contacts in their address books, calendars, and friends' birthdays. In response to concerns about contact uploading, a Facebook spokesperson explained that the practice is designed to make it easy for users to connect with others. "When you sign in to a messaging or social app on your phone, it's a common practice to upload your phone contacts to help you find the people you want to connect with," the spokesperson said. The spokesperson also emphasized that contact uploading is optional and that users are explicitly asked for permission to upload their contacts, which is explained in the app's terms of service. You can delete previously uploaded information at any time and access all available information in your account and activity log through our Download Your Information tool. Facebook requests permission to upload personal data for specific reasons, such as uploading address books to help users find friends and improve content prioritization. The Messenger app for Android requires permission to access call and SMS logs for similar purposes. Note that users can stop continuous contact uploading and delete all previously uploaded contacts by disabling the continuous uploading setting in the Messenger app. Additionally, permanently deleting a Facebook account will also delete all previously uploaded contacts and prevent future uploads.

Elaine Herzberg, a 49-year-old woman, was tragically killed last Sunday when an Uber autonomous vehicle struck her at approximately 40mph while she was crossing the road in Tempe, Arizona. The police investigation revealed that there was an operator in the Volvo SUV at the time of the collision, and it appears that the car did not slow down before impact. Robert Williams, an assembly worker at Ford's Flat Rock plant in Michigan, holds the unfortunate distinction of being the first recorded human fatality caused by a robot. On January 25, 1979, Williams was crushed to death by the arm of a one-tonne robot on the production line. His family received a $10 million settlement in damages, with the court concluding that Williams' death was a result of inadequate safety measures. In a 2016 study, researchers found a link between robot-assisted surgery and the deaths of 144 patients between 2008 and 2013. The causes of death included parts falling into patients' bodies, machines malfunctioning, and loss of video feeds. The study noted that despite widespread adoption of robotic systems, technical difficulties and complications still occur during procedures. Micah Johnson is believed to be the first person killed by a police robot. In July 2016, Johnson was involved in a standoff with Dallas law enforcement after fatally shooting five officers and injuring seven others. Police detonated a bomb-disposal robot loaded with C-4 explosive near Johnson, stating that they saw no other option. In October 2007, nine South African soldiers were injured when an Oerlikon GDF-005 semi-autonomous anti-aircraft gun malfunctioned and fired 250 high-explosive rounds during a training exercise. The weapon, capable of tracking targets and reloading automatically, is believed to have jammed before firing. An expert described the incident as "bad luck" rather than a design flaw.

Marks & Spencer has replaced the head of its high-end food halls with Stuart Machin, a veteran of the supermarket industry, tasked with reducing prices and improving food offerings. Machin, who has previously worked at Asda, Sainsbury's, and Tesco, collaborated with M&S Chairman Archie Norman on the turnaround of Coles Supermarkets in Australia. Norman, who has been critical of M&S's performance, warned last year that the company had been "drifting" for over 15 years and pledged to lead a radical overhaul of the business alongside CEO Steve Rowe. As a result of Machin's appointment, the current food division head, Andy Adcock, will leave M&S at the end of April, after a decade-long tenure that began in 2009. Rowe expressed confidence in Machin, stating, "He gets food retailing and has first-class experience driving change in large food retailers." M&S's food halls, once a crown jewel, have struggled in recent years, with Rowe attributing the decline to high prices, mistakes in product offerings, and attempts to reduce waste that resulted in empty shelves. The company has since scaled back plans to open new food stores. Rowe emphasized the need for M&S to "sharpen its prices, improve its products, drive profitability, and grow market share," and believes Machin is the right leader to achieve these goals. Machin will start next month and is part of a broader turnaround effort that includes a major overhaul of M&S's UK store estate. "Mark Machin's new role bears a resemblance to that of Jill McDonald, the former Halfords CEO who was tasked with revitalizing the company's struggling clothing and homewares division last year. Additionally, M&S has brought in business expert Julian Richer, founder of Richer Sounds, to help drive cultural change within the organization. Machin is joining M&S from the furniture division of Steinhoff International, a South African company facing challenges, where he led the Bensons for Beds and Harveys chains. "My passion lies in food retail," Machin said. "While M&S has many reasons to be proud of its food offerings, there are also opportunities to capitalize on and deliver under the transformation plan outlined by Steve."

The CEO of Sainsbury's, Mike Coupe, was caught on camera singing "We're in the Money" from the musical 42nd Street while waiting to be interviewed by ITV on the same day he announced a major merger with Asda. In a clip released by the broadcaster, Coupe is seen belting out the tune: "We're in the money, the sky is sunny. Let's lend it, spend it, send it rolling along." Sainsbury's didn't find the situation amusing, and Coupe apologized for his choice of song, saying he was simply composing himself before the interview. "It was an unfortunate choice of song from the musical 42nd Street, which I saw last year. I apologize if I've offended anyone," Coupe said, who is an accomplished musician. A Sainsbury's spokesperson defended Coupe, saying, "We all know these songs get stuck in your head. To read anything more into this private moment is ridiculous."

The National Crime Agency is launching a new investigation into a massive banking fraud at HBOS to determine whether a full-scale criminal investigation is warranted. This announcement is a setback for Lloyds Banking Group, which acquired HBOS in 2008. Six individuals, including two former HBOS employees, were sentenced to prison in 2017 for perpetrating the fraud, which centered on the Reading branch of the bank. A judge described the scheme as "utterly corrupt" and devastating for small business owners, who were cheated, defeated, and left penniless. The scam occurred between 2003 and 2008 and involved Lynden Scourfield, a former HBOS employee responsible for overseeing struggling businesses. Scourfield was bribed by David Mills, the owner of a financial consultancy, to load loans onto struggling companies and refer them to Mills's business. Many of the firms went bankrupt, and some owners lost their homes. Although the original investigation resulted in sentences totaling over 47 years, controversy surrounding the case has persisted. The NCA will conduct a six-month pre-investigative review into allegations of fraud related to the HBOS branch in Reading, at the request of Thames Valley Police. The review will examine allegations that fell outside the scope of the original investigation. The NCA stated that several companies have reported significant fraud allegations, including claims of asset stripping through corrupt consultants and fraud and money laundering. The sums involved could be substantial, running into tens of millions of pounds. Lloyds initially denied any wrongdoing at its Reading branch, but following the conviction of two former employees, the police and crime commissioner of Thames Valley Police claimed that HBOS must have known about the fraudulent activities in its Reading branch as early as February 2008. Lloyds has welcomed the investigation and pledged to fully cooperate with the NCA.

Ian Seabrook has rescued a 1972 AC Invacar Model 70 from a boggy field in Sussex and is now preparing it for an epic 170-mile journey from his home in Wales to the eccentric Festival of the Unexceptional in Buckinghamshire on July 14th. The festival, which celebrates unusual cars, will feature mint-condition Austin Allegros and cherished Datsun Sunnys, and Ian's Invacar is sure to be a crowd-pleaser. Although the Invacar was effectively banned from the road in 2003, Ian managed to secure insurance, tax, and testing for his vehicle, which has revealed a significant oil leak and carburettor fault. Despite these issues, Ian has only managed to drive 17 miles so far, let alone the 170-mile trip ahead. The AC Invacar Model 70 was designed to be a standard invalid carriage, with the engine from the Austrian-built Fiat 500, a Steyr-Puch air-cooled flat twin of 493cc and 20bhp. Between 1972 and 1977, around 18,000 Invacars were built, with AC and Invacar Ltd each producing half of that total. Invacar Ltd was founded by the same company that built Greeves motorcycles, which also built the first Invacar in 1948. The Invacars, all of which were ice blue, were often referred to as Thundersley Invacars due to the company's base in Thundersley. However, the scheme was eventually ended in 1977 due to safety concerns, including the lack of crash protection, instability, and the fact that wheelchair users did not need to take a proper driving test to operate the vehicles. A decision was made to allow individuals who already owned an Invacar to keep it, but the program ultimately came to a close in 2003. Within a week, the remaining Invacars (estimated to be several hundred) were collected from their owners. The cars were leased to the end user. When Ian took his TWC 725K for its inaugural drive, he found it both terrifying and exhilarating, but was also plagued by numerous issues. It will be a minor miracle if he makes it to the festival without any major setbacks, but we wish him the best of luck. You can follow Ian's adventures on YouTube at HubNut, or contact Martin Love at martin.love@observer.co.uk or @MartinLove166 on Twitter.

Snap is doubling down on its hardware business by launching a new version of its Spectacles camera-glasses, which boasts a better camera, the ability to take still images, and water resistance. The new model comes as Snapchat tries to bounce back from the disappointing performance of the first generation, which generated significant buzz when it was initially released in limited quantities in November 2016, but failed to sell well after its wider release. Over the lifetime of the product, Snap managed to sell only 220,000 units, which ultimately led to the company writing off unsold inventory worth almost $40 million. This time around, the new Spectacles will be available on Snap's website for £149.99 and will launch simultaneously in the UK, US, Canada, and France, with a wider European release to follow. Like the first model, the Spectacles can capture video in short 10-second increments, recording in a circular format that can be viewed in the Snapchat app or exported for other uses. However, this new version can also take still photos with a resolution of 1642 pixels, 50% higher than the previous model's video resolution, and can even shoot underwater. The glasses also feature stereo mics and post-processing to reduce noise, allowing for clearer and higher-quality sound. Snap's decision to recommit to Spectacles is surprising, given that many competitors are abandoning the smart glasses market. Intel, for example, launched its own smart glasses in February but cancelled the project in April, citing market dynamics that didn't support further investment. Similarly, Google Glass, which was launched in 2013, was met with controversy and eventually discontinued in 2015. Snap believes that its focus on hardware is crucial to its future success. Snap's co-founder, Evan Spiegel, views the company as a "camera company" at its core. This perspective extends beyond traditional photo and video tools to encompass features that enable augmented reality technology and innovative ways to interact with digital elements in the physical world.

Homebase, the Australian-owned DIY chain, saw a 20% decline in sales in March, exacerbated by the "beast from the east" weather event. The cold snap led to a significant drop in demand for plants and garden furniture, adding to the company's woes. The poor March trading resulted in a 15.4% decline in like-for-like sales for the first three months of 2018, worse than the 15.1% decline in the previous quarter. Wesfarmers, Homebase's parent company, had planned to convert the chain into a Bunnings store, but only 23 of the 250 stores have been converted so far, and it is unclear if the company will continue with the costly refurbishments. The company's managing director, Rob Scott, had previously considered pulling out of the UK market, citing the disastrous takeover of Homebase. Wesfarmers wrote off A$1bn (£543m) earlier this year due to the failed takeover, and is now reportedly considering offering over £100m to find a buyer or pursuing a company voluntary arrangement (CVA) to dump loss-making stores. The decline in sales has been partly attributed to the actions of the original Australian management team, who axed senior managers and key departments, including home furnishings, which had appealed to British shoppers. Damian McGloughlin, a former B&Q executive, has been brought in to run the chain. The Bunnings group managing director, Michael Schneider, stated that progress on several Homebase projects is "satisfactory," focusing on improving store standards, ranges, and promotions.

Pharmaceutical company Shire, known for its ADHD medication Adderall, has recommended a £46 billion takeover bid from Japan's largest pharmaceutical company, Takeda. If approved by investors, this deal would be one of the largest pharmaceutical transactions in history, ranking behind Pfizer's $112 billion acquisition of Warner Lambert in 2000. The revised offer values Shire at £49 per share, approximately £5 more than Takeda's initial bid. After rejecting several previous offers, Shire's board stated that it would be willing to recommend the revised proposal to shareholders, subject to satisfactory resolution of the remaining terms, including a due diligence review by Shire of Takeda. The company has set a new deadline of May 8th for the negotiations to be concluded, although this date may be extended. If the deal is completed, Shire shareholders would own approximately half of the combined company, with shares listed in Japan and the US. According to Atsushi Seki, a pharma analyst at UBS, "With Shire's board willing to recommend the deal, Shire's acquisition becomes realistic, but there are still several hurdles to overcome, including the absence of other bidders and a special shareholder meeting to approve the deal." Britain's largest pharmaceutical company, GSK, has ruled itself out of the bidding process, while US company Allergan, which produces Botox, dropped out earlier this month. Shire's shares in London closed at £38.20, down 2.8%, below the offer price, indicating skepticism in the market about the deal. Takeda's shares plummeted over 7% on the Tokyo stock exchange, reflecting concerns that a deal of this size could put excessive pressure on the company's finances. The acquisition would give Takeda Shire's lucrative rare diseases portfolio, propelling the Japanese company, led by CEO Christophe Weber, into the top ranks of global pharmaceutical companies. Founded in 1986 above a shop in Basingstoke, Hampshire, Shire is best known for its ADHD medication Adderall, but has focused on rare diseases in recent years. "While headquartered in Dublin for tax reasons, the company's actual operations are centered in Boston. In recent years, it has significantly reduced its UK presence and now primarily conducts its business in the United States."

A recent study by the UK's media regulator reveals that British adults are becoming less dependent on Facebook for socializing with friends, as they increasingly turn to other social media platforms. According to the regulator's annual survey, the percentage of British social media users who consider Facebook their primary online profile has decreased from 80% to 70% over the past 12 months. Meanwhile, the popularity of WhatsApp has surged, with 16% of internet users now considering it their main online profile, up from 7% a year ago. Although primarily a messaging service, WhatsApp is becoming a significant platform for discussing news and sharing information through groups centered around specific interests. The shift away from Facebook is particularly pronounced among younger internet users, with 13% of 16- to 24-year-olds naming Snapchat as their preferred social media platform, while 9% prefer Instagram over Facebook. The Ofcom survey, which interviewed 1,875 individuals aged 16 and above, found that the decline in Facebook's popularity occurred before the Cambridge Analytica scandal, which raised concerns about Facebook's data usage and damaged the company's reputation. Despite this, Facebook may not be overly concerned, as the company remains the dominant player in the social media landscape, with over half of British adults having an account. Furthermore, the shift in attention to WhatsApp and Instagram is not catastrophic for Facebook, as both platforms are already owned by the company. The Ofcom survey also found that the average British adult spends 24 hours a week online and is becoming less reliant on traditional television, with over half of adults now watching on-demand or streaming content. Despite the report's findings, many internet users lack a clear understanding of online regulation. Specifically, nearly a third of users mistakenly believe that YouTube regulates video content posted by the general public, thinking that rules govern offensive, harmful, unfair, inaccurate, or biased content. While most Britons believe the benefits of being online outweigh the risks, many expressed concerns about the impact of prolonged internet use. In fact, a significant proportion of users reported feeling overwhelmed by their online connectivity and wished to reduce their online time. Moreover, nearly half of internet users have encountered hateful content online in the past year. According to Ofcom, there is a significant wealth divide in how Britons use the internet, with poorer individuals relying more heavily on smartphones and exhibiting lower levels of online confidence and critical understanding. Facebook declined to comment on the report's findings.

While most people don't celebrate soggy May bank holidays, young students preparing for exams might actually benefit from them, as research suggests that hotter temperatures can negatively impact grades. A comprehensive study by US researchers found that even a small increase in temperature can lead to a decline in exam scores. The study, which analyzed data from over 10 million secondary students across 13 years, revealed that a 0.5°C rise in average temperature corresponds to a 1% drop in average exam scores. In the UK, the situation is even more challenging, as air conditioning, which could potentially mitigate the negative effects, is rarely found in British schools. It's not surprising, given that the hot periods in the UK are relatively rare and don't justify the cost of installing air conditioning. However, June is the month when average high temperatures tend to exceed 21°C (70°F), which is when the negative effects on exam performance become apparent. This raises the question of why we schedule important exams during this time, when distractions like sports tournaments and heatwaves are common. Wouldn't it make more sense to allow students to take their exams online when it's most convenient for their learning and comfort? While it may seem like a simple idea, changing the academic year is actually a complex issue. Schools, large firms, universities, and even the law courts follow a similar September-to-July schedule. Moreover, the UK government, which is also subject to this schedule, may find it difficult to argue for changing the system when they themselves benefit from it. The UK's rigorous exam marking system, which relies on students taking tests at the same time, may be overly rigid, but it has a significant benefit: the scores required for a given grade change each year based on average scores. "Fortunately, if a sweltering summer temporarily impairs children's cognitive abilities, they shouldn't suffer any lasting consequences. And if this summer proves to be another unremarkable, rainy British summer, they can breathe a sigh of relief."

The UK government may sell off another portion of its stake in Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) as early as this week, with rumors suggesting that the Treasury is planning to resume its privatization efforts. The sale could involve around 10% of the bank, generating approximately £3 billion, but would still result in a significant loss for taxpayers, who bailed out RBS during the 2008 financial crisis. The Treasury's long-term goal is to sell its 70.5% stake and return RBS to the private sector, but the current share price may delay this decision. RBS's value has decreased by about 12% since the government last sold off shares in 2015, and the government is prepared to write off a significant portion of the £45.5 billion it spent on the bailout. UK Government Investments (UKGI), the company responsible for managing the Treasury's assets, declined to comment on the potential sale. However, according to a Sky News report, bankers and investors are expecting an announcement as early as this week, with one fund manager stating that the City is "abuzz with speculation" about an imminent sale. The government's decision to resume its share disposal plan was facilitated by a relatively lenient settlement with the US Department of Justice earlier this month, in which RBS agreed to pay $4.9 billion to settle an investigation into the sale of financial products linked to risky mortgages. The settlement, which was less than half the worst-case scenario, has paved the way for the government to resume selling off its stake in RBS. Chancellor Philip Hammond has stated that the agreement will allow the government to proceed with the sale, which has already led to a sharp increase in RBS's shares. The Office for Budget Responsibility forecasts that the government will raise £15 billion from the sale of its stakes over the next five years. RBS is set to hold its annual general meeting in Edinburgh on Wednesday, which will be buoyed by the bank's first annual profit since the crisis and its promise to resume paying dividends. "While some shareholders may push for greater oversight and executive compensation reform, tensions are running high due to a scathing report exposing widespread mistreatment of small businesses by RBS following the financial crisis. The bank's recent decision to shut down 162 branches and eliminate 800 jobs has further stoked discontent. RBS has declined to comment on the matter."

Michael Rosen's article questioning the success of school academies fails to consider the worst-case scenario: closure. A devastating example of this is Burnt Yates school in north Yorkshire, a small rural primary school with excellent facilities and a dedicated trust, which will close its doors at the end of the academic year. Despite its rich history, dating back to 1760, the school was unable to find an academic partner to take it over, and its efforts to amalgamate with other schools were unsuccessful. The school's demise can be attributed to a series of poor decisions by the local authority, culminating in a poor Ofsted report that sealed its fate. The community rallied around the school, but ultimately, the lack of funding meant that closure was the only option. I blame Michael Gove's academies plan, which has led to the erosion of local accountability and the loss of schools like Burnt Yates, which would still be thriving if it weren't for his policies.

Regarding the civil servant quoted in Michael Rosen's letter, I must correct the record. The department does, in fact, publish data on sponsored academy primary schools, which have been forced out of local control. The statistics show that these schools, along with free schools, consistently underperform compared to average schools. This is not surprising, given that sponsored academies tend to have a higher proportion of students from disadvantaged backgrounds. What is more concerning is that, despite having more time to improve, the results of these schools do not show any significant improvement. As a former primary school governor in Cornwall, I can attest to the devastating consequences of the academies program. The governors were dismissed, the headteacher was pushed out, and the school was effectively taken over by a neighboring institution. "According to the latest SATs results, the ACE academy chain's performance has fallen even further below average. Last year's results at other ACE schools were only marginally better. The lack of effective oversight has enabled ACE to expand its network by taking on more schools and opening a new free school, despite its modest academic achievements. Join the debate by emailing guardian.letters@theguardian.com or visit gu.com/letters to read more Guardian letters."

The earliest known case of dandruff has been discovered in a small, feathered dinosaur that lived around 125 million years ago. Paleontologists found tiny fossilized skin flakes on a crow-sized microraptor, a meat-eating dinosaur with wings on all four limbs. Similar flakes were also found on two other feathered dinosaurs, beipiaosaurus and sinornithosaurus, as well as a primitive bird called confuciusornis. The fossilized skin flakes are the only evidence scientists have of how dinosaurs shed their skin. Unlike modern reptiles, which typically shed their skin in large sheets, the feathered dinosaurs shed their skin in tiny flakes. According to Maria McNamara, a paleontologist at University College Cork, "This is the only fossil dandruff known. Until now, we had no evidence for how dinosaurs shed their skin." Images taken with an electron microscope show that the fossilized dandruff is extremely well-preserved and almost identical to that found on modern birds. Like human dandruff, the skin flakes are made up of tough cells called corneocytes that are rich in the protein keratin. The study, published in Nature Communications, suggests that dinosaurs with feathers evolved skin to cope with their plumage as far back as the Middle Jurassic period. "Even in the early stages of feather evolution, they had already adapted their skin to this more modern structure," McNamara said. The fossilized remains of the animals were found in rock formations in northeastern China. Beipiaosaurus and sinornithosaurus, which grew to over 2 meters in length, were significantly larger than the 1-meter-long microraptor. Unlike modern birds, which have fatty corneocytes that help them lose heat during flight, the dinosaur dandruff cells lacked fat, suggesting that the animals did not generate as much heat, possibly because they were not capable of flying long distances or at all. Many dinosaurs with feathers were not skilled fliers. "Rather, their feathers had multiple functions, including keeping them warm, blending in with their surroundings for camouflage, and potentially showcasing their vibrant colors to attract mates with dazzling displays."

I fell victim to identity fraud last year, and when I checked my credit report, I discovered a current account at Santander that I had not opened. The fraudster had taken out a £11,420 loan from Sainsbury's Bank and deposited the funds into the Santander account. Sainsbury's Bank was informed and raised an indemnity against Santander to recover the money, but told me that my credit file wouldn't be corrected until the issue was resolved. Although the Santander account has been closed, the bank loan still appears on my credit report. This situation seems to be a blatant disregard for my right to have inaccurate information corrected.

The high cost of relying on two large financial institutions to communicate is evident in this case. Sainsbury's claims that it only learned about my complaint when the Observer contacted them, and as a result, it decided to restore my credit record, which typically takes 60 days. However, Santander insists that it notified Sainsbury's as soon as I reported the fraud and agreed to arrange an indemnity and close the loan. Despite this, nothing happened until eight days after I contacted Sainsbury's. Sainsbury's initially told me that it hadn't been informed of the fraud, but it had actually been chasing Santander for the indemnity. Santander claimed that it had never received an indemnity request and would need 30 days to process one. Fortunately, it was decided that modern technology could be used to expedite the indemnity process. Sainsbury's has since admitted that it was contacted by Santander when I discovered the fraud, but claims that Santander failed to respond to its requests for an indemnity. As a result, Sainsbury's has amended my credit file and paid me £100 in compensation.

It's unclear which bank's inaction caused the delay, but it's clear that if I had wanted to apply for credit during the weeks of waiting, I would have been refused. Even if action had been taken promptly, the 60-day timescale for amending a credit record is far too long. "Need assistance? Reach out to Anna Tims at your.problems@observer.co.uk or send a letter to Your Problems, The Observer, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Don't forget to include your contact information, including your address and phone number."

A federal investigation into a fatal accident involving a self-driving Uber SUV in March has revealed that the vehicle's emergency braking system was deliberately disabled. According to a preliminary report from the National Transportation Safety Board, the vehicle's guidance system detected the pedestrian, a 49-year-old woman, six seconds before impact, but the emergency braking system was not activated to avoid "erratic vehicle behavior". Instead, the system relied on the human backup driver to intervene, but it did not alert the driver to the impending danger. The vehicle was traveling at 43 miles per hour when it struck the pedestrian, who was pushing a bicycle across a boulevard in Tempe, Arizona. The report states that the sensors detected the need to brake 1.3 seconds before impact, but the brakes were not applied until after the fatal collision. In an interview with NTSB investigators, the backup driver said she was monitoring the self-driving interface at the time of the accident. In response to the incident, Uber has suspended testing in Arizona and will focus on more limited testing in Pittsburgh and California. The company is also conducting an internal review of its self-driving vehicle program and has brought in a former NTSB chairman to advise on its safety culture. The NTSB's preliminary report is not intended to assign blame for the accident, but rather to provide an initial analysis of the incident. An expert in liability law has suggested that the incident highlights the need for greater regulatory oversight in the testing of self-driving vehicles, and that Uber's decision to suspend testing in Arizona is a significant setback for the company. "States must exercise extreme caution when establishing and regulating these programs to avoid a patchwork of 50 different systems. We can't afford to have multiple, uncoordinated approaches, which could lead to experimentation with the technology at the risk of injuries and fatalities. To protect the public, states need to develop a more systematic approach. The question is, how can we achieve this?"

The UK's competition regulator, the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA), has proposed a crackdown on hotel booking websites that may be misleading consumers. The CMA has been investigating the industry since October and has identified several areas of concern. While the CMA did not name the specific companies under investigation, major players like Expedia and Booking.com are among those being scrutinized. The regulator is examining whether a hotel's ranking on a website is influenced by the commission it pays, which could lead to hotels that pay more commission being prioritized. The CMA has expressed concern that the way booking sites display information about room availability, such as the number of people looking at a room and how long a price is available, can create a false impression of availability and pressure customers into making a hasty decision. According to the CMA, 70% of people who shop around for accommodation use hotel booking sites, but many have found that the final price paid was inflated by unexpected extra charges such as taxes and booking fees added later. The CMA's chief executive, Andrea Coscelli, emphasized the importance of transparency in the industry, saying, "Booking sites can make it easier to choose your holiday, but only if people can trust them." The regulator is demanding that the sites review their practices and provide a response within the next few months. If necessary, the CMA is prepared to take legal action to ensure that consumers receive a fair deal. Guy Anker, deputy editor of MoneySavingExpert.com, welcomed the CMA's move, saying, "Hotel prices on booking and comparison sites can often be misleading. We hope the CMA will clamp down hard on sites that fail to show the true cost upfront and claim false discounts or pressure-sell by suggesting the hotel is almost sold out."

Fastjet, a low-cost African airline, is on the brink of bankruptcy and has warned its shareholders that its shares will stop trading on Friday unless it can quickly raise more funds. The airline, which was founded in 2012 with the backing of easyJet's founder Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou, is currently in talks with major shareholders to secure additional funding, but has no guarantee of success. In a statement, Fastjet revealed that it has continued to burn through cash, with its reserves dwindling from $7.5 million to just $3.3 million in a month. The company warned that it is at risk of being unable to continue trading as a going concern. Fastjet launched operations in Tanzania with the aim of becoming a pan-African low-cost carrier, but has struggled with issues including inadequate banking infrastructure, overambitious plane orders, and high office costs. The airline's shares plummeted 70% on Wednesday, leaving them at just £3.70, valuing the company at around £19 million. Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou, who owned the Fastjet brand until last year, expressed disappointment at the news, citing his concerns about the company's management, which he had previously raised with the board. He plans to attend the airline's upcoming AGM to voice his objections and vote against the proposed resolutions. Fastjet has expanded its operations to South Africa, Zimbabwe, Zambia, and Mozambique. While it has never transported more than one million passengers annually, the airline currently operates only four small Embraer aircraft, having previously used Airbus A319s that were not fully utilized. Until 2016, it incurred an average annual loss of $50 million. The airline has yet to release its 2017 financial results, which must be published by Friday to avoid delisting from London's Alternative Investment Market (AIM).

Carpetright has reported a significant annual loss of £70.5 million, primarily due to weak trading and the costs associated with a major restructuring effort that involves the closure of 92 stores. The retailer described the past year as "very difficult" and noted a 3.6% decline in sales at its established UK stores for the year ending April 28. Carpetright's trading has been severely impacted in the first eight weeks of the current financial year, particularly due to the withdrawal of products by some suppliers and the hot weather, which has kept customers away. The company had announced its store closure plan in April, which put 300 jobs at risk, and is now seeking rent reductions of up to 50% on 113 additional stores through a company voluntary arrangement (CVA). This process aims to prevent administration and allow the company to recover from its struggles, which are largely attributed to weaker consumer spending and a slowdown in the housing market. Carpetright's CEO, Wilf Walsh, emphasized the company's focus on implementing its recovery plan, stating that the CVA and recapitalization offer a chance to rebuild the business, which remains the market leader in floor coverings with strong brand recognition. By the end of September, Carpetright expects to have closed 81 of the 92 targeted stores. The company's revenue for the year to April 28 fell by 3% to £443.8 million. According to David Madden, an analyst at CMC Markets, Carpetright's situation has deteriorated significantly in 2018, with multiple profit warnings and a corresponding impact on its share price. However, the CVA has provided the company with some much-needed breathing space. Following the announcement, Carpetright's shares fell by 2%.

Over the past 100 years, the most significant change to human life has come to a standstill in 2010. Prior to that, life expectancy in Britain had been steadily increasing, with men born in the 1920s and 1930s enjoying unusually long and healthy lives. This increase in lifespan has had far-reaching impacts on various aspects of life, including housing, healthcare, and pensions. As a result, the NHS requires increasingly large sums of money, the state pension age has had to be raised, and house prices have been driven up by people living in their homes for longer. However, a recent analysis by the Office for National Statistics has revealed that the trend of increasing longevity has come to a halt. The ONS found that the trend line stopped in 2010 and has remained flat since then. The reasons behind this sudden halt are unclear, but potential factors include austerity measures, reduced NHS spending, flu outbreaks, rising obesity and diabetes rates, and the increasing prevalence of "multimorbidity" - where individuals develop multiple health conditions simultaneously. The ONS did not attempt to identify the cause of the halt, but instead aimed to verify whether the statistics indeed show a decline in longevity. The study's findings are concerning, as they indicate that the trend towards improving life expectancy has slowed significantly. According to the ONS, the slowdown began in the second quarter of 2009 for men and soon after for women. The analysis also found that between 2011 and 2013, and again between 2014 and 2016, only a small number of local authorities in England showed statistically significant increases in life expectancy for both men and women. This is a stark contrast to the equivalent period 10 years earlier, when many more local authorities reported significant increases in life expectancy. While it's possible that this is just a temporary blip, other concerning data from the weekly register of deaths in England and Wales this year adds to the worrying trend. The statistics reveal that the number of deaths is significantly higher than the average over the past five years. While the academic discussion surrounding stagnation in longevity has primarily focused on austerity and the National Health Service (NHS), there are other substantial financial implications to consider, particularly for pensions. Pension companies repeatedly advise savers to plan for a retirement lasting 25 years or more, but maybe this assumption is flawed. Just a year ago, the Government Actuary's Department proposed a potential state pension age of 70 for individuals currently under the age of 30. It's possible that they were incorrect in this estimation as well. Perhaps we should now reconsider increasing the state pension age and instead focus on maintaining the current age.

On International Women in Engineering Day, we take a moment to acknowledge the remarkable accomplishments of female engineers worldwide. However, in the UK, women make up only 11% of the engineering profession. Engineering is responsible for many everyday conveniences, such as roads, bridges, and clean water, as well as cutting-edge technologies like AI, robotics, and smartphones. To encourage more women to pursue engineering, we must effectively communicate its diverse applications to young women. By doing so, we can inspire a new generation of women to join a field that offers the opportunity to work on innovative projects that shape the future. Once women are in the profession, we must strive to support and empower them to reach their full potential. According to the Create the Future report, a global study by the Queen Elizabeth Prize for Engineering, 92% of respondents believe that engineering has a significant impact on people's daily lives. A more balanced engineering sector is crucial for building a better future for all. - Yasmin Ali, Ambassador, Queen Elizabeth Prize for Engineering.
