Mike Ashley, the founder of Sports Direct, has engaged in talks about providing an emergency funding deal to House of Fraser, the struggling department store chain he already owns an 11% stake in. According to a report by Sky News, Ashley was approached by bankers advising House of Fraser to consider a £50m loan. In June, House of Fraser announced plans to close 31 of its 59 stores, putting 6,000 jobs at risk. The retailer secured a temporary reprieve from its lenders, who agreed to extend loans while it undergoes restructuring under a company voluntary arrangement scheme. C.banner, the Chinese owner of Hamleys, had agreed to invest £70m in House of Fraser, conditional on the CVA being implemented. However, the CVA plans are now in doubt due to a legal challenge in Scotland, where a group of landlords argue that the restructuring plan would unfairly harm their financial interests. House of Fraser's CEO, Alex Williamson, has described the CVA as the "last viable" option for the business. After winning a legal challenge to obtain House of Fraser's business plans, Ashley gained valuable information that could aid an investment bid. Ashley acquired his 11% stake in House of Fraser in 2014, when 89% of the business was sold to Chinese conglomerate Sanpower in a deal worth £480m. He also has a 29.7% stake in Debenhams and strategic investments in businesses such as Goals Soccer Centres and French Connection. House of Fraser is one of several retailers to seek controversial CVAs as Britain's high streets struggle with rising costs, weak consumer confidence, and competition from online-only rivals like Amazon.

Samuel Smith Old Brewery, one of the oldest breweries in Britain, and its chairman, Humphrey Smith, have been fined nearly £30,000 for refusing to provide vital documents about their pension scheme. In 2015, the Pension Regulator (TPR) requested information about the brewery's pension plans to ensure the Yorkshire-based brewer and pub owner was providing enough funding for the final-salary pension schemes of over 2,000 employees. However, Smith, 73, dismissed the request as "tiresome" and refused to comply, prompting the TPR to launch court proceedings. The company and Smith pleaded guilty to the offence in May, and on Monday, they were sentenced at Brighton magistrates court. The court fined the brewery £26,750 and its chairman £8,000, as well as ordering costs of £1,240. Judge Teresa Szagun criticized the brewery's tone, calling it "deliberately inflammatory," and said the company's refusal to provide information had put the future and security of 2,000 employees at risk. The total fine, including a victim surcharge and costs, came out to £27,990. Nicola Parish, a representative of the TPR, stated that "issuing a court summons and receiving compliance with our requests will not halt criminal proceedings, as Mr. Smith has recently learned." Samuel Smith Old Brewery operates a network of 300 pubs across the UK. In 2017, Smith implemented a strict no-swearing policy and banned music in all pubs to avoid paying music copyright royalties.

"In your opinion, is the Help-to-Buy scheme a good option for my sons, who are 30 and 35 and have been renting for 15 years? They're considering using the scheme to get on the property ladder, but they're unsure after reading negative reviews. As their parent, I'm worried about the potential stress and fear they might experience if they choose this path. Should they instead aim to save longer for a bigger deposit to buy an older property?

I think my sons are wise to be cautious about the Help-to-Buy scheme. If they can afford to buy a property without using the scheme, it would make more sense. According to the Help to Buy Buyers' Guide published by the Homes and Communities Agency, if you can already secure a 90% mortgage, you should carefully consider whether a Help-to-Buy equity loan is right for you. There may be better options available.

Help-to-Buy can be a good option if you're looking to buy a new-build property from a registered house builder and need the 20% equity loan (40% in London) to complete the purchase. However, it's not suitable if you don't want a new-build Help-to-Buy home or don't need government assistance. Unlike the government bonuses paid into Help-to-Buy and Lifetime ISAs, the Help-to-Buy equity loan is not free money. Although there's no interest to pay in the first five years, you'll need to pay a monthly management fee of £1. After five years, interest will start to be charged on the loan." "The primary concern with an equity loan is that if house values increase, so does the amount you'll need to repay, either when you sell the property or make a voluntary repayment (incurring a £200 administration fee). Furthermore, interest rates on Help-to-Buy mortgages are less competitive than those for standard mortgages. Considering your sons have mixed opinions about the Help-to-Buy scheme and are under 40, I recommend they opt for the free government funding that comes with saving in a Lifetime ISA for property purchase."

Over the past year, scientist Jess Wade has been actively addressing gender bias on Wikipedia by writing over 270 entries about influential women in science who have been forgotten, such as Susan Goldberg, the first female editor of National Geographic. Research has shown that only 16% of Wikipedia editors are female, and a mere 17% of entries about notable individuals are about women. A 2016 study by Oxford University revealed that the majority of content about most African countries on Wikipedia was written by editors from Europe and North America, with only 16% of content about sub-Saharan Africa being written by people from the region. In contrast, most entries about European countries were written in Europe.

The language of a Wikipedia entry has also been found to influence the sources used, leading to different versions of the truth. For example, an English-language article about Russia's annexation of Crimea cited 24% of sources as Ukrainian and 20% as Russian, whereas the German version cited only 10% of sources as Russian and 3% as Ukrainian.

A 2011 study analyzed almost 30,000 Wikipedia entries about US politics and found a slight bias towards the Democrats. The study found that entries were more likely to use Democratic phrases (such as "civil rights") than Republican phrases (such as "illegal immigration"). Although later entries were less biased, the study concluded that the average old political article on Wikipedia leans Democratic.

A 2011 paper reviewed thousands of Wikipedia articles and found that, although most articles were accurate, recent events received the most coverage. The author analyzed US gubernatorial elections since 1978 and found that coverage before 2001 was scarce, reflecting the limited expertise and interests of contributors.

The Daily Mail has published a front-page correction and issued disciplinary notes to senior staff after falsely claiming that an Iraqi man who won compensation from the British government was an insurgent who had been found with a bomb. The newspaper's original story, published on December 15 under the headline "Another human rights fiasco!", falsely claimed that Abd Ali Hameed al-Waheed had been caught with a bomb and had won £33,000 in compensation because British soldiers had kept him in custody for too long. However, the judge's decision to award al-Waheed compensation actually stemmed from his unlawful imprisonment and mistreatment by British armed forces during the Iraq war. The newspaper ran the story despite the judge concluding that the claims about al-Waheed being caught with a bomb were "pure fiction" and had been discredited shortly after his detention. The Independent Press Standards Organisation (Ipso) ordered the correction after finding that the Daily Mail had breached rules on accuracy in its reporting of the case. Ipso stated that the newspaper's failure to clarify that the bomb claims had been disproven seriously misrepresented the basis of the judgment. The judge found that there was no evidence to support the claim that al-Waheed was an insurgent and that he had been detained without legal basis for 33 days in 2007. The compensation award was broken down into £3,300 for unlawful detention, £15,000 for being beaten after his arrest, and £15,000 for ill treatment. The Daily Mail defended its reporting by stating that it had relied on a three-page summary of the 239-page judgment and previous reporting on the case. However, Ipso rejected this explanation, arguing that it was unreasonable for the newspaper to rely on previous press coverage that referenced the "red-handed" claim without verifying the accuracy of the information. According to the newspaper, a major internal investigation was conducted after the decision to publish, and as a consequence, seven senior staff members received strongly worded disciplinary notes. These notes made it explicitly clear that if similar errors occurred in the future, the employees' careers would be in jeopardy.

The James Webb Space Telescope, a highly ambitious project, has been rescheduled to launch in March 2021. Initially, it was set to take off in October, but the project has faced numerous delays since its inception in 1996. Initially, the budget was estimated at $500 million and the launch date was slated for 2007. However, the mission's technical requirements proved to be extremely challenging, leading to delays and cost overruns. In 2011, the US Congress considered canceling the mission, but ultimately capped the cost at around $8 billion. The latest delay, caused by anomalous test results that require investigation, will bring the total budget to approximately $9.6 billion (£7.8 billion). The source of the additional funding is currently being debated. During a recent testimony before the House Science Committee in Washington, NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine suggested that the agency might slow down the development of the Wide-Field Infrared Survey Telescope (WFIRST) and redirect funds to JWST. The European Space Agency, a partner in the JWST project, will launch the telescope from Kourou, French Guiana, in South America. They will also provide two instruments for the mission.

BP has agreed to acquire US shale oil and gas fields from BHP for $10.5 billion, marking its largest acquisition in nearly two decades. According to BP's CEO Bob Dudley, the deal is "transformational" and will significantly enhance the company's US shale presence. The acquisition will increase BP's US oil and gas production by nearly 20% and marks a new era of growth for the company, which has been recovering from the financial burden of the Deepwater Horizon disaster. The deal covers 470,000 acres of assets, including fields in the Permian Basin in west Texas, the Eagle Ford in south Texas, and Haynesville in east Texas and Louisiana. Analysts have praised the deal, with Eagle Ford being considered the most valuable due to its scale and economics, and the Permian offering the greatest long-term potential. BHP purchased the fields in 2011 but has struggled to make them profitable, leading to their sale last August. BP believes its approach will differ from BHP's, bringing $350 million in synergies from its other US operations and capital efficiencies. According to Bernard Looney, CEO of BP's upstream division, the acquisition gives the company access to some of the best acreage in the best basins, including the Permian Basin, which is considered the most-talked-about oil play in the world. While BP was not desperate to make a deal, the company believes the quality of the resources made the acquisition worthwhile. Following the deal's completion, BP's US production is expected to increase from 744,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day to 885,000 boe/d. According to Maxim Petrov, a senior analyst at Wood Mackenzie, the deal "transforms BP's US business" by making it more competitive with its peers. BP is making conservative assumptions about the amount of oil and gas that can be pumped in the short term, due to regional bottlenecks in infrastructure such as pipelines. According to Looney, the company believes that the infrastructure will be fully developed within the next two years. The acquisition will be entirely financed through cash and is being partially funded by the company's decision to divest its interests in the Greater Kuparuk Area in Alaska, which is expected to generate $5-6 billion. BP's deal significantly surpasses its recent $200 million investment in Europe's largest solar company and its £130 million purchase of the UK's largest electric car charging network. BHP has announced that it will return the proceeds from the sale to its investors, and as a result, its shares closed the day up 2.3% in Australia, at A$34.40. In contrast, BP's share price declined by 1.5%. The company's largest transaction in recent history was its acquisition of Atlantic Richfield, an American oil company, in 1999.

A scathing report by a committee of MPs has accused local councils of pushing vulnerable people further into financial distress by using bailiffs too aggressively to collect council tax arrears. In 2016, a staggering 2.3 million debt cases were referred to bailiffs by local authorities, according to data provided to the House of Commons Treasury committee. The report criticized the "overzealous" pursuit of debtors, saying that the public sector should be setting an example for responsible debt collection, but instead, its approach risks further entrenching financial difficulties. MPs called for a reform of the debt collection approach, urging it to meet industry best practices. The report highlighted evidence from StepChange, a debt charity, which found that one-third of its clients had council tax arrears averaging £1,000. Phil Andrew, from StepChange, expressed concern about the aggressive tactics used by government agencies to collect debts, including the quick resort to bailiffs. The case of Jerome Rogers, a 20-year-old courier who took his own life after being pursued by bailiffs for two parking fines, has raised concerns about the need for fundamental changes to the debt collection industry. Earlier this week, Creditfix, a personal insolvency firm, identified 55 councils across the UK that consistently reject payment plans offered by those in financial difficulties, leaving them with no choice but to declare bankruptcy. Gillian Guy, CEO of Citizens Advice, welcomed the report, saying that MPs are right to criticize the government and local authorities for their poor debt collection practices, which fail to protect vulnerable individuals. The report also made several other recommendations, including the urgent introduction of caps on high-cost credit, such as overdraft fees, by the Financial Conduct Authority. The report also proposes reforms to the tax relief on pension contributions, deeming it an inefficient way to encourage people to save for their retirement. Nicky Morgan, chair of the Treasury committee, noted that the inquiry highlighted several weaknesses in household finances, including excessive debt, inadequate rainy day savings, and insufficient pension savings. According to Morgan, the committee's report presents a series of recommendations for the government to consider, aimed at helping households build more resilient financial foundations. She emphasized that while financial regulators and guidance bodies have important roles to play, the government should not shift responsibility to them.

Fever-Tree, a 13-year-old drinks company, has reached a record value of £4.5 billion after exceeding profit forecasts, driven by Britain's insatiable demand for gin. The surge in its share price has propelled the company's value to nearly match that of Royal Mail and surpass the combined stock market value of WH Smith, Debenhams, the AA, and Saga. Fever-Tree's rapid growth can be attributed to the soaring popularity of premium gin, which has doubled UK sales to £1.2 billion in the past six years, according to the Wine and Spirit Trade Association. A YouGov poll found that gin is the most beloved spirit in the UK, with 29% of drinkers voting it their favorite. Riding the wave of gin's popularity has transformed Fever-Tree into one of the UK's fastest-growing major companies, making co-founders Charles Rolls and Tim Warrilow multi-millionaires in the process. The pair founded Fever-Tree in 2005, naming it after the colloquial term for the cinchona tree, the bark of which produces quinine, a key ingredient in tonic water. Since the company's stock market float in 2014, Rolls has sold shares worth over £150 million, while Warrilow has sold shares worth £41 million. They still own 14% of the company, a stake worth nearly £600 million, and received payouts of over £630,000 on Tuesday after the group increased its dividend by 40%. Fever-Tree's shares jumped by as much as 15% to an all-time high of £39.87, driven by profits rising by a third to £34 million in the first six months of the year, on sales up 45% higher to £104 million. The shares settled back to give the company a stock market value of £4.2 billion, still more than 30 times its value when it floated four years ago. Fever-Tree reported particularly strong performance in the UK over the Christmas period, with an "impressive rate of sales growth," but noted that it still has room to expand. Warrilow noted, "While this milestone is impressive, we still have a substantial opportunity ahead of us across all our regions as Fever-Tree continues to shape the mixer category's future." Additionally, Fever-Tree announced two new distribution agreements: one in the US with Southern Glazer's Wine and Spirits, a leading wine and spirits distributor, and another with Grupo Damm, a Spanish company that produces Estrella Damm, a well-known beer from Barcelona.

A major UK transport operator, Stagecoach, is set to conduct a trial of a full-sized driverless bus for the first time in the country later this year. The single-decker bus will operate autonomously within the company's depots until the necessary laws are changed to permit passenger transportation. The bus is being adapted with technology similar to that used in a recent trial of driverless pods in Greenwich, south-east London. According to Stagecoach, the bus will be able to park and refuel itself within the depots, as well as navigate to wash points, without the need for a human driver. The company believes that wider adoption of self-driving buses could lead to safer and more efficient operations, as well as increased space within its depots.

Even when the bus is on public roads, the sensor system could provide earlier warnings to other road users, such as cyclists or pedestrians, who may be in blind spots or approaching unexpectedly. Sam Greer, Stagecoach's UK bus engineering director, described the project as exciting and potentially transformative, stating that it could improve safety and efficiency within depots and, in the long term, revolutionize bus travel.

This move by a traditional bus operator using a full-size vehicle could mark a significant step towards the wider adoption of autonomous vehicles in the UK, where so far only smaller pods and shuttle vehicles have been used in public spaces. In contrast, passenger services using small driverless vehicles have been trialed in France, while China has tested larger driverless buses on major city roads in Shenzhen. The trials in Greenwich suggested that passengers may be more receptive to larger autonomous vehicles for public transportation than smaller pods. While driverless trains have been in operation for some time, researchers found that users had concerns about sharing vehicles with strangers, with 85% of participants expressing comfort with autonomous technology but only 46% willing to ride-share. "Many respondents indicated that they were not willing to pay a substantial amount above the standard bus fare to use autonomous driverless pods."

A total lunar eclipse will be visible from most of Europe, Asia, Australia, and South America on July 27. Unfortunately, North America will miss this spectacular event. During a total lunar eclipse, the moon passes through the Earth's shadow, taking on a deep red hue. This breathtaking sight occurs because of the way sunlight bends through the Earth's atmosphere, scattering the blue component and refracting the red light. As a result, the sky appears blue to us, while the red light is directed behind the Earth and onto the Moon. In the UK, the eclipse will begin before the moon rises, with Earth's shadow already crossing the lunar surface around 8:50pm. Thirty minutes later, the moon will reach the midpoint of the eclipse and take on its characteristic red color. By 10:15pm, the moon will have left Earth's shadow, bringing the eclipse to a close.

Craig Jones, a successful local politician, has a personal connection to Wonga, having turned to the payday lender for help when he was struggling financially. In 2011, Jones was working on a zero-hours contract and experienced a lull in work, leading him to take out a small Wonga loan to "tide me over" until his finances improved. However, his situation didn't improve, and he found himself taking out multiple loans from different sources, eventually borrowing several hundred pounds. He was eventually able to pay off his debt after securing permanent work.

At the time, Wonga was thriving, with profits tripling to £45.8m on revenues of £185m in 2011. The company was valued at £15bn by 2015, but its fortunes took a turn for the worse the following year when it was embroiled in a scandal over fake legal letters and ordered to pay millions in compensation. Wonga was forced to write off £220m of debts owed by 330,000 borrowers and never fully recovered from the fallout.

As a result of the scandal, Jones received compensation from Wonga in the region of £800. In a tweet, he praised Labour MP Stella Creasy, a leading campaigner against payday loans, and acknowledged that he had fallen prey to the industry's tactics himself. Jones is now employed full-time and has served as a Labour councillor on East Staffordshire borough council since 2016. He acknowledged that Wonga filled a market gap, noting that its instant decision loans made it an easy and overly accessible way to access credit when needed, almost too easy. However, he also pointed out that Wonga preyed on individuals who might not have been able to access other forms of credit. Jones emphasized the need for a campaign to make credit unions more accessible.

Aston Martin, the luxury carmaker, was founded in a small London workshop in 1913 by engineer Robert Bamford and car enthusiast Lionel Martin. The company's name was born a year later, after their prototype successfully completed the Aston Hill Climb track in Buckinghamshire. Aston Martin made its international racing debut in the 1922 French Grand Prix, but faced financial struggles and was rescued in 1926 by a group of investors. The company developed a reputation for engineering and design, competing in the Le Mans 24 Hours for the first time in 1928. Production of its road cars increased in the 1930s, with a record 140 cars built in 1937. In 1947, English industrialist David Brown acquired the company, expanding operations and relocating production from Kensington to Feltham. The company moved its production base again in 1955 to Newport Pagnell. The iconic Aston Martin DB5 was introduced in 1963, and its famous partnership with James Bond began a year later in the film Goldfinger, starring Sean Connery. Bond has since driven an Aston Martin in several films, including GoldenEye, Tomorrow Never Dies, and Skyfall. The company changed hands several times in the 1970s and 1980s, and in 1987, Ford Motor Company acquired a 75% stake. The DB moniker, inspired by David Brown's initials, was revived with the introduction of the DB7 in 1993, the year Ford took full ownership of the company. Aston Martin opened its first purpose-built factory in Gaydon, Warwickshire, in 2003. The company returned to racing in 2005 with the DBR9, a race car based on the DB9 road car. In 2007, Aston Martin was sold to a consortium of two Kuwaiti investment houses, Investment Dar and Adeem Investment, for nearly £1 billion. "Today, Aston Martin is one of the world's leading sports car manufacturers, thanks in large part to the efforts of its current CEO, Andy Palmer. Palmer has successfully transformed the company by updating its product range and guiding it back to profitability after a period of financial losses. The company is poised to make its stock market debut in London later this year, with an initial public offering that is expected to value the company at £5 billion."

Toyota, the Japanese automaker, is set to invest $500 million (£388 million) in ride-hailing giant Uber to further develop their partnership on self-driving cars. The investment aims to help the companies catch up with their rivals in the race to create autonomous vehicles for the mass market. The partnership will use technology from both companies to create purpose-built Toyota cars that will be deployed across Uber's ride-sharing network starting in 2021. Toyota's investment values Uber at $72 billion, despite the company's significant losses of $4.5 billion in 2017. According to Shigeki Tomoyama, Toyota's executive vice-president, the agreement marks an important milestone in the company's transformation into a mobility company, enabling the safe and secure expansion of mobility services like ride-sharing.

The deal is a significant step towards Uber's revival of its self-driving business, which was halted following a fatal crash in Tempe, Arizona, in March. Uber subsequently withdrew its autonomous cars from the road, laid off hundreds of test drivers, and closed its self-driving testing hub in Arizona. Under the new agreement, Uber will combine its autonomous driving system with Toyota's Guardian technology, which offers some automated safety features but does not enable fully autonomous driving. The companies plan to integrate the combined technology into Toyota's Sienna minivans, which will be used on Uber's ride-hailing network starting in 2021.

The partnership will put Uber and Toyota in competition with other major players in the autonomous vehicle market, including Waymo, the driverless car business of Alphabet, the owner of Google. Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber's CEO, described the deal as the first of its kind for the company. "Our goal is to deploy the world's safest self-driving cars on the Uber network, and this agreement is another significant step towards making that a reality," he said. "Uber's advanced technology and Toyota's commitment to safety and manufacturing prowess make this partnership a natural fit."

If you haven't taken a math exam in a while or have a family member or roommate studying for one, you might be wondering what's involved in a modern GCSE math paper. Here's your chance to test your skills with these 20 questions, taken from actual papers from last year. Please note that we can't replicate the exact exam conditions. In reality, students taking GCSE math exams in England and Wales spend four and a half hours sitting for exams. One of those papers is 90 minutes long, and students aren't allowed to use calculators. Unlike an online quiz, not all questions are multiple-choice, and students must show their work to earn full marks. After taking this quiz, you'll get a sense of the types of math questions students are expected to answer. Good luck, and let us know how you do in the comments. If you're more comfortable with words than numbers, try our arts and humanities essay questions instead. [Source: AQA's 2017 GCSE papers.]

Ticketmaster has been praised by Rob Davies for shutting down its resale sites (Report, 18 August). Some of us recall a time before Ticketmaster, when we could simply call the box office of a theatre or concert hall and reserve a ticket at face value. However, "ticket partners" soon took over the box office's responsibilities, and we were left footing the bill. Today, we're charged a booking fee for every ticket, which can be a flat rate or a percentage, and on top of that, there's a transaction fee that significantly adds to the cost of a night out. Imagine shopping at a supermarket and being charged a "shopping fee" for each item, followed by a "transaction fee" at checkout. I believe ticket companies are unnecessary middlemen, and I'll only praise them when they cease to exist entirely.

Superdrug has alerted its online customers to change their passwords after the company was targeted by hackers who claim to have stolen the personal details of thousands of people. The hackers, who contacted Superdrug on Monday evening, allegedly obtained the details of 20,000 customers, including names, addresses, dates of birth, and phone numbers. However, Superdrug has confirmed that only 386 accounts have been compromised so far. According to the company, the hackers gained access to the accounts by using email addresses and passwords stolen from other websites. Superdrug has assured customers that payment card information was not stolen.

In response to the breach, Superdrug is advising customers to change their passwords and has notified the police and Action Fraud, the UK's national fraud and cyber-crime arm, of the incident. The company has also apologized for any inconvenience caused by difficulties customers may be experiencing when trying to change their passwords. One customer reported trying and failing to change her password on four different devices.

This is the latest in a series of high-profile data breaches to affect high street retailers. Last month, Dixons Carphone revealed that personal data belonging to 10 million customers may have been accessed illegally, nearly 10 times as many as initially thought.

Elite private schools are urging universities to reduce the use of unconditional offers for undergraduate places, citing concerns that students may become complacent and not strive for high A-level grades. According to Mike Buchanan, executive director of the Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference (HMC), which represents many of the country's most prestigious independent schools, students tend to "take their foot off the gas" after accepting unconditional offers, which do not require specific A-level grades. Buchanan, a former headteacher, believes that students will carry their academic achievements with them throughout their careers and thus should be motivated to work hard. He is calling on universities to only offer unconditional places to students who have been interviewed or whose schools have provided additional information. Historically, only a small number of students received unconditional offers, but the government's removal of the cap on funded undergraduate numbers has allowed universities to expand and compete aggressively for students and tuition fees. While there is limited evidence on the impact of unconditional offers on students' final grades, private school heads have long been concerned about the potential impact on their school's results and league table rankings. Some employers place significant weight on A-level grades when recruiting for graduate trainee programs, which means that students who underperform may struggle in the job market. The HMC's call follows that of Education Minister Sam Gyimah, who in July criticized the rise in unconditional offers as "completely irresponsible to students" and urged universities to limit their use. Typically, universities make conditional offers, specifying the A-level grades required to secure a place. However, in a more competitive market, unconditional offers have become more common, even among research-intensive institutions in the Russell Group. According to Ucas, the administrator of university applications, 7% of the 950,000 offers made this year were unconditional, with roughly one-fifth of the 250,000 applicants to English universities receiving at least one such offer. Ucas noted that unconditional offers were more prevalent for older students who already held qualifications, as well as for those applying to creative arts courses who submit portfolios or attend auditions, and for students with mental health difficulties. University vice-chancellors have defended unconditional offers, citing their benefits in allowing for earlier engagement between universities and students, and making it easier to plan courses and accommodation.

A recent phonics screening check for six-year-olds has revealed that white boys from disadvantaged backgrounds are significantly underachieving even at the earliest stage of their education. According to the results, which were broken down by ethnic group, gender, and free school meal eligibility, white boys who receive free school meals (FSM) are the lowest-achieving group, with only 62% meeting the required standard. Although the results show a two percentage point improvement from last year, disadvantaged white boys still lag behind their peers. Overall, more than four in five pupils (82%) met the expected standard in the phonics screening check, a one percentage point increase from 2017. Chinese girls who do not receive FSM were the highest-performing group. The phonics screening check involves pupils reading a list of 40 words aloud, half of which are nonsense, and the pass mark was set at 32. Pupils who do not meet the standard will retake the check at the end of year 2, by which time 92% are expected to meet the required standard. The analysis also revealed that fewer than half (44%) of pupils with special educational needs (SEN) reached the pass mark, compared to 89% of pupils with no identified SEN. The Department for Education also published provisional results for key stage 1 teacher assessments, which showed a slight drop in the number of six- and seven-year-olds reaching the expected standard in reading and maths. In reading, 75% of children reached the expected standard, down from 76% last year, while in maths, 76% reached the required mark, compared to 75% in 2017. The government reported that 163,000 more six-year-olds are on track to become fluent readers than in 2012, when the phonics check was introduced. However, the test remains controversial among some teachers and parents, with a recent survey finding that 85% of heads believe the test should not be compulsory and 65% of teachers want it scrapped. Wendy Scott, a representative of the More Than A Score campaign group, stated: "Heads, teachers, and parents are in agreement that the phonics check is a waste of valuable teaching time. Instead of fostering a love of reading, five and six-year-olds are spending months being drilled on nonsensical words solely to prepare for a test."

School Standards Minister Nick Gibb said: "This is a significant achievement, having a positive impact on the education and lives of hundreds of thousands of children. We are committed to ensuring that every child, not just most, has the opportunity to reach their full potential."

Tech billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes and his wife Annie have acquired Australia's most expensive home, the historic Fairwater estate in Point Piper, for a reported $100 million. The sprawling 1.12-hectare property on Sydney Harbour has been in the hands of the Fairfax family for over a century. Cannon-Brookes, co-founder of software company Atlassian, expressed his delight with the purchase, stating that he and his family are looking forward to continuing the legacy of this beautiful Sydney home. The family is particularly excited to raise their four young children in this historic property. Fairwater is the largest privately held property on Sydney Harbour and one of the most significant heritage homes in Australia. Built in 1882, the waterfront estate stretches from New South Head Road to Seven Shillings Beach and has been the residence of the Fairfax publishing family since 1900. The property was previously owned by Mary Fairfax, who passed away in September last year. According to the New South Wales heritage register, Fairwater is of rare historic, aesthetic, social, and scientific significance. During Mary Fairfax's long residence, the home was adorned with priceless artworks, including a 2-metre tall bronze nude Rodin sculpture and paintings by Chagall, Degas, and Arthur Boyd. The property was listed for sale this month, despite rumors that it would be bequeathed to the state of NSW, and reportedly took less than two weeks to sell. Atlassian, founded by Cannon-Brookes and Scott Farquhar in Sydney in 2002, was worth $29.9 billion at the beginning of September. The pair, who attended the University of NSW together, are now among the 10 richest Australians. Interestingly, Farquhar, Cannon-Brookes' business partner, purchased the neighboring estate Elaine for over $70 million last year, which was previously owned by the Fairfax family.

Bentley has joined the growing list of carmakers warning that a no-deal Brexit would harm its sales and ability to invest, potentially leading to a temporary shutdown of its Crewe, Cheshire factory. According to Bentley's CEO, Adrian Hallmark, the company is stockpiling some components and switching to a different port to bring in certain parts ahead of Brexit. Bentley produces around 11,000 cars per year in Crewe. If a Brexit deal is not reached by the end of the year, Bentley may stockpile more parts and close its factory for a few extra days, Hallmark said. The majority of Bentley's key parts, including engines and bodies, come from the European Union, primarily Germany. "We may work for four days, or we may have a longer Christmas break and a longer Easter break if there is no deal, so that we can smooth the period between now and the middle of next year," Hallmark explained. BMW has already announced plans to shut its Mini plant for a month after the UK's departure from the EU on March 29, in an effort to minimize the impact of a no-deal Brexit. Britain's car manufacturers, many of which are foreign-owned, are concerned about the potential for tariffs and long delays in importing components. Over half (56%) of the parts used by British car manufacturers come from abroad, with the majority (79%) coming from the EU, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders. "In the best-case scenario, a no-deal Brexit would be an annoying impact on our annual profitability, while in the worst-case scenario, it would be quite damaging," Hallmark said. "A full no-deal Brexit would hurt our company, limiting our ability to invest." Jaguar Land Rover, Britain's largest car manufacturer, warned last month that a hard Brexit could result in tens of thousands of job losses and cost the company £1.2 billion per year, wiping out its profits. Aston Martin has relocated approximately 2,000 staff to a three-day workweek at its Castle Bromwich plant in the West Midlands. The luxury car manufacturer is stockpiling engines in preparation for Brexit and is even considering airlifting components if motorway traffic to and from Dover becomes severely disrupted. A Bentley spokesperson confirmed that this contingency plan is also being considered by the company, although no such measures are currently in place. "All options are being explored at this time," the spokesperson stated. This announcement comes as Bentley continues to struggle financially, with the company reporting a significant decline in sales. Between January 1 and September 30, Bentley sold 6,654 vehicles, a 12% decrease from the 7,498 vehicles sold during the same period the previous year. The company's sales revenue dropped to €1.1 billion (£980 million) from €1.3 billion, and its operating loss widened to €137 million from €31 million, largely due to exchange rate fluctuations and delays in the launch of the new Continental GT model.

"Every week, we receive a question from a Guardian Money reader, and we're counting on you to help them out. A selection of the best answers will be featured in our Saturday paper. I'm a 26-year-old man who's just landed my first'real' job, but my excitement was quickly dampened by the dress code: smart casual. To be honest, I'm not entirely sure what that means. Should I opt for a blazer and chinos from Marks & Spencer, or is there a more affordable option? I'm particularly curious about whether jeans are acceptable. My dad jokingly suggested I head to C&A or Burton, but I'd love some more practical advice. If you have a problem you'd like to solve, please email your suggestions to money@theguardian.com or write to us at Money, The Guardian, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU."

A students' union at Liverpool John Moores University has introduced guidelines for fancy dress after a controversy surrounding a homelessness-themed party hosted by the university's trampolining society. The society's annual "tramps' night out" event, which was published in the student paper the Liverpool Tab, featured students wearing ripped clothes and painted faces to appear dirty, with signs asking for spare change. The society apologized for any offense caused, stating that it was never their intention to cause upset and that they would change their annual theme. The students' union launched an investigation and announced that it would introduce guidelines for future fancy dress events to prevent similar incidents. According to the union, they do not endorse costumes that could be deemed offensive or discriminatory and will work closely with clubs and societies to ensure that such incidents do not occur again.

A last-minute intervention by the local council has saved nearly 600 jobs at the iconic Kendals department store in Manchester. The 182-year-old House of Fraser store, located on Deansgate, was on track to close its doors in January after Mike Ashley's Sports Direct failed to agree on new rental terms with the building's landlords. However, a deal was reached on Friday night, with the Manchester city council playing a crucial role. Council leader Sir Richard Leese praised the outcome, saying it was "fantastic news for the city" and that the council was proud to have played a constructive part in saving the iconic store and hundreds of jobs. Leese thanked all parties involved for their cooperation in the process.

The rescue deal comes as a welcome boost for Ashley, who is set to appear before MPs on the housing, communities and local government committee next week to discuss the future of the high street. Ashley has been vocal about his desire to see more done to support struggling high streets, and has called for landlords and politicians to take action. He bought House of Fraser out of administration in August for £90m and has since pledged to keep 23 of its 59 stores open. Ashley is currently in talks with landlords and has offered rock-bottom rents in some cases.

In a statement announcing the Kendals deal, Ashley said that when landlords, local authorities, and retailers work together, "the outcomes can be outstanding." He added that the deal demonstrates that with cooperation, the high street can be revitalized. A massive Kendals store, spanning nearly 390,000 square feet, was acquired by a private investor in 2016 for £85 million. Manchester City Council had previously hailed the store as an institution, praising its iconic art deco design as a treasured aspect of the city's architectural heritage. The store supports a staff of 568 employees.

The Bank of England has come under fire for its lavish summer party, which cost £100,000. The event, held at the Bank's sports ground in Roehampton, south-west London, featured a bake-off competition, treasure hunt, fun run, and bouncy castle. Over 2,500 staff and their families attended the party, which was hosted by Governor Mark Carney. The Bank's choir and band also performed at the event. According to a Freedom of Information request, the Bank spent £58,000 on food and drink alone, £27,000 on entertainment, and £10,400 on "additional expenses". The total cost of the party was £95,674, excluding VAT. A Bank spokesperson defended the event, saying it was a long-held tradition aimed at recognizing employees' hard work and dedication. The Bank also highlighted that the event was open to all employees and their families. In comparison, the Bank's Christmas drinks reception last year cost £4,700, although £682 of that was spent on wine. The Bank has faced criticism in the past for its spending habits, including a £390,000 bill racked up by two of its US-based economic advisers over two-and-a-half years.

According to the Confederation of British Industry, a staggering 90% of businesses have reported that Brexit has hindered their ability to recruit and train staff this year. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation, the industry's professional body, warns that the public sector, including the NHS and schools, may face a shortage of skilled workers for up to seven more years, based on current demand. The Office for National Statistics recently revealed that the number of EU citizens arriving in the UK for work has reached a six-year low. Matthew Fell, the CBI's chief UK policy director, commented on the situation, saying: "These latest statistics underscore the ongoing trend of declining net EU migration, which is exacerbating skills shortages across all levels in the UK. In 2018, a staggering 92% of businesses cited Brexit as a major obstacle to recruiting and training staff. This means that hospitals, schools, and housebuilders are already struggling to find the staff they need. The proposed ban on overseas workers earning less than £30,000 will only make the situation worse." Research by the REC found that candidate availability is declining month by month, with 75% of employers reporting that they have little or no capacity to expand. The REC's report, Public Sector 2025, predicts a seven-year shortage of skilled workers, even before any post-Brexit migration crackdown takes effect. According to the report, 10,000 EU staff have left the NHS since the EU referendum. The report also found that 77% of recruitment specialists believe there will be shortages in health and care roles within the next five years, and half of school recruiters expect teacher shortages in the same period. Net migration from the EU to the UK was 74,000 in the year to June 2018, the lowest level since 2012.

The Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Motors alliance has decided not to appoint a new interim chairman to replace Carlos Ghosn, who was arrested in Japan on suspicion of underreporting income. Osamu Masuko, CEO of Mitsubishi Motors, announced that the alliance will now be led by the heads of the three companies, rather than a single figurehead like Ghosn. Speaking in Tokyo, Masuko stated that the alliance's capital structure was not discussed during a recent meeting in Amsterdam, but changes to the governance structure are seen as a possibility. Ghosn, who was the architect of the alliance and chaired the boards of all three companies, has been in detention for 10 days and may be charged with a crime after his detention is extended for another 10 days. The arrest has raised questions about the future of the alliance, which has been led by Ghosn since its inception. While Nissan and Mitsubishi quickly removed Ghosn as chair of their respective boards, Renault chose not to do so and has allowed him to remain as chairman and CEO. The alliance's leadership, excluding Ghosn, met in Amsterdam for an operational review, which was scheduled before the arrest. The meeting focused on operational issues, including research and development, basic components, and technology sharing. A separate meeting of the Renault-Nissan BV board would be required to remove Ghosn from his position. In a joint statement, the three companies reaffirmed their commitment to the alliance, stating that they have "all – individually and collectively – emphatically reiterated their strong commitment to the alliance." The statement added that the alliance has achieved significant success over the past two decades and remains committed to its goals. Car industry analysts have questioned whether Renault can maintain its dominant position in the alliance. Renault has a significant stake of 43.4% in Nissan, which in turn owns 15% of Renault and 34% of Mitsubishi. The alliance's combined output in 2017 reached 10.6 million cars. In recent years, Nissan has been the primary contributor to the alliance's profits, leading some analysts to speculate that any restructuring could result in a more prominent role for the company. Furthermore, any changes could also lead to a greater involvement for Mitsubishi, which currently has no formal representation on the board of Renault-Nissan BV.

Journalists at the Financial Times have passed a vote of no confidence in the newspaper's chief executive, John Ridding, following a contentious "town hall" meeting that was live-streamed to all staff. The meeting was marred by the sudden stoppage of the webcast, preventing those not in attendance from watching a debate about issues including Ridding's multimillion-pound pay package. The National Union of Journalists (NUJ) chapel at the Financial Times had already reached a low point in its relations with management in the summer, when it emerged that Ridding had received a £2.6m salary while the newspaper made an operating profit of £5.2m. The backlash prompted Ridding to return about £500,000 of his pay, but the NUJ chapel has now passed a vote of no confidence in him, citing his failure to address serious concerns at the Financial Times. The chapel's statement accused Ridding of demonstrating a "complete disregard for transparency" by stopping the live broadcast, which prevented all staff from hearing the questions and responses. The vote of no confidence was prompted by Ridding's perceived lack of engagement with staff concerns, including transparency, better governance, and high executive pay. Ridding had previously defended his pay, stating that it was independently assessed and benchmarked with substantial performance-related incentives when the Japanese publishing business Nikkei acquired the newspaper in 2015. "Pearson, the former owner of the Financial Times, has agreed to sell the newspaper's London headquarters for £115 million. The Financial Times has occupied the building at One Southwark Bridge since 1987. Next year, the newspaper will relocate back to its original offices at Bracken House in the City."

The UK's Gambling Commission has taken the largest enforcement action in its history, resulting in three online casino firms agreeing to pay out a total of £14 million. The penalties stem from failures in systems designed to prevent money-laundering and protect problem gamblers. Casumo has been ordered to pay a penalty package of £5.85 million, while Videoslots will pay £1 million instead of a financial penalty. Daub Alderney was previously fined £7.1 million. In a separate case, CZ Holdings has surrendered its license to operate in the UK after the regulator launched an investigation. Six other firms are still under investigation. Additionally, three individuals have had their licenses to serve as directors of gambling companies revoked, four were issued warnings, and three are under investigation. The total payout exceeds the largest fine previously handed out by the Gambling Commission, which was £7.8 million to online casino firm 888. The company had allowed over 7,000 self-excluded individuals to continue betting.

Jeremy Wright, Secretary of State for the Department of Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, warned that online operators that ignore their duty to protect players will face consequences. He emphasized that protecting vulnerable consumers is the top priority and that gambling operators must adhere to robust requirements to safeguard players and prevent money-laundering.

The Gambling Commission has become stricter in its enforcement over the past two years, issuing millions of pounds in fines to companies like William Hill, Ladbrokes, Paddy Power, and SkyBet for failures related to money-laundering and problem gambling. The commission's CEO, Neil McArthur, urged online casino operators to "sit up and pay attention" and take responsibility for properly applying their policies and procedures. "We require operators to have a deep understanding of their customers and to ask the necessary questions to ensure compliance with anti-money laundering and social responsibility regulations. Additionally, anyone in a position of authority should be aware that we will not only take regulatory action against businesses that fail to comply, but also hold individuals accountable if they are responsible for an operator's shortcomings."

A new bill introduced in New York City aims to prohibit cashless businesses, which have become increasingly popular in the city and nationwide. These businesses refuse to accept paper currency and instead require customers to pay with debit or credit cards. While some business owners argue that cashless transactions are quicker and easier, City Councilman Ritchie Torres believes that this practice disproportionately affects low-income individuals and people of color who may not have access to bank accounts or credit cards. Torres, who introduced the legislation, argues that a cashless business model has an exclusionary effect on the impoverished, the homeless, and the underbanked. According to Torres, nearly 12% of New Yorkers do not have bank accounts, and many people struggle to maintain an account due to minimum balance requirements, fees, or lack of proper ID. Unauthorized immigrants, in particular, may face significant barriers to opening a bank account.

Torres believes that the proposed ban is necessary to prevent a "gentrification of the marketplace" and to ensure that all individuals have equal access to goods and services. He sees this as a new frontier of anti-discrimination law, one that addresses the unequal impact of cashless transactions on marginalized communities.

However, Andrew Rigie, head of the New York City Hospitality Alliance, argues that there should be a balance between the benefits of cashless transactions and the need to ensure that all customers have access to goods and services. While cashless restaurants may offer operational and worker safety benefits, they should not discriminate against individuals who do not have credit cards.

The global trade dispute between the US, China, and some of America's traditional allies has reached a new level of intensity ahead of the G20 summit in Argentina. In a recent interview, US President Donald Trump warned China that he plans to impose higher tariffs on Chinese goods, sending stock markets in London and New York tumbling on Tuesday. Trump's comments, published in the Wall Street Journal, made it "highly unlikely" that he would heed Beijing's call to refrain from increasing tariffs starting next year. This move would raise the existing 10% US import tariff on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods to 25% from January 1. Economists at Rabobank warn that if the US-China trade war escalates further, the global economy could suffer significantly over the next decade, potentially losing up to 2% of GDP growth by 2030. Senior economist Hugo Erken notes that an ongoing trade war between the world's two largest economies has far-reaching consequences that extend beyond their borders, with no real winners in a globalized economy. Trump's comments also suggested that Apple products, such as iPhones and laptops, could be subject to tariffs, despite previously being exempt. This sparked a sell-off in Apple shares, putting the company at risk of losing its title as the world's most valuable firm to Microsoft. Recent developments, including the renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) between the US, Mexico, and Canada, have helped to cool tensions between the White House and other countries. "Despite previous optimism, Trump has recently hinted at imposing higher import tariffs on China. Meanwhile, he has dampened expectations of a trade agreement between the UK and the US if Theresa May secures parliamentary backing for her Brexit deal. The US government is also examining car imports on national security grounds, which could potentially lead to higher tariffs on European-made vehicles."

Uber's European operation has been fined £385,000 for a data breach that affected nearly 3 million British users, according to the Information Commissioner's Office. In November 2016, attackers gained access to Uber's cloud servers using stolen credentials and downloaded 16 large files containing sensitive information, including the records of 35 million users worldwide. The compromised data included passengers' full names, phone numbers, email addresses, and the location where they signed up, as well as drivers' weekly pay, trip summaries, and in some cases, driver's license numbers. The Information Commissioner's Office found that the breach was caused by inadequate information security measures and was exacerbated by Uber US's decision not to disclose the attack, instead opting to pay $100,000 to the hackers in a "bug bounty" arrangement. The ICO noted that this was not a typical bug bounty scenario, as the hackers maliciously exploited the vulnerability and stole personal data, rather than simply identifying and reporting the issue. As a result, none of the affected individuals were notified of the breach, and the company only began monitoring accounts for fraud 12 months later. The potential fine was reduced due to the fact that Uber's European branches were not informed of the breach, and there was no evidence that the compromised data was misused. In a related case, Uber US was ordered to pay $148 million for failing to notify drivers about the breach. "We have implemented numerous technical enhancements to strengthen the security of our systems, both immediately following the incident and over the years since. Additionally, we have made significant changes to our leadership structure to ensure transparency with regulatory bodies and customers going forward. Notably, we have appointed our first chief privacy officer, data protection officer, and chief trust and security officer this year. We take our mistakes as opportunities to learn and are committed to earning the trust of our users every day. The timing of the breach meant that we were subject to the Data Protection Act 1998, which capped the financial penalty at £500,000. However, if the same breach had occurred under the Data Protection Act 2018, which incorporates the EU's General Data Protection Regulation into British law, the potential fine would be significantly higher, up to 4% of our global revenue."

I'm an avid gardener who recently received a generous gift of over £150-worth of Wyevale garden centre gift cards for my summer birthday. I had specifically requested Wyevale because of its large location near my home, which has been there for years. However, when I visited last weekend, I was surprised to find that it had been transformed into a Dobbies garden centre. The staff told me that I couldn't use the gift cards there, but I could redeem them at other centres. Unfortunately, the three closest options are a significant drive away, which seems unfair given that the company's change of ownership is not my fault.

It was unfortunate timing, as the sale of this centre to Dobbies was only completed two and a half weeks prior. What's more, I wasn't aware that customers can redeem their gift cards online in addition to in-store, a fact that is not widely communicated. Wyevale has stated that there are still over 100 centres in operation and has made efforts to inform its Garden Club members about the changes. The company assures that no one will lose the value of their voucher due to the sales, and gift cards have a two-year expiry date.

Given the current retail turmoil, I would advise readers holding Wyevale gift cards to use them as soon as possible. Wyevale's spokesperson emphasized that customer loyalty is crucial and that once a local centre changes ownership, gift cards can be redeemed in a way that suits the customer best, either online or in-person at their nearest centre. To redeem gift cards online, customers are asked to contact customer services, who will provide a specific code. "Get in touch with us at consumer.champions@theguardian.com or send a letter to Consumer Champions, Money, The Guardian, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Please provide a daytime phone number. Please note that all submissions are subject to our terms and conditions, which govern the publication of letters."

Carole Cadwalladr, a journalist for The Observer and Guardian, has been awarded the Foreign Press Association's top honor for print and web story of the year. Her reporting exposed the links between Cambridge Analytica, pro-Brexit campaigners in the UK, and the Trump presidential election team. Other notable nominees included Amelia Gentleman, a Guardian colleague of Cadwalladr's, who wrote about the Windrush scandal, as well as Stephen Bleach of the Sunday Times, who shared his experience of abuse by the Catholic church, and Reuters journalists Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo, who were jailed for their reporting on the Rohingya massacre in Myanmar. Cadwalladr's award-winning article revealed the identity of Christopher Wylie, a whistleblower who helped create a tool used by former Trump adviser Steve Bannon to target political advertising at voters. Wylie, who chose to waive his anonymity, described the tool as "Steve Bannon's psychological warfare mindfuck tool" and expressed concern about Cambridge Analytica's activities. The piece was part of a series of articles Cadwalladr has written on the subject, which have earned her numerous awards, including the Orwell journalism prize. The Foreign Press Association awards ceremony took place in London on Monday evening, where Cadwalladr was recognized for her work. Other winners included David Goldblatt and Daniel Nolan, who won the sports story of the year award for their Guardian long read on Viktor Orban's football obsession. Hannah Rae Armstrong was nominated for the same award for her Guardian long read on sheep fighting, and Sophie Elmhirst was shortlisted for the arts culture story of the year award for her Guardian long read on the woman who turns actors into stars.

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) has revealed that its former managing director, Michelle Guthrie, received a termination payment of over $800,000 after being let go by the public broadcaster. According to the ABC, the payout was made in accordance with Guthrie's contractual entitlements, which were determined by the Remuneration Tribunal, a body that oversees the pay of federal public servants. The ABC confirmed the sum after verifying it with individuals involved in the negotiations.

Guthrie was terminated by the ABC board just two years into her five-year term as managing director. The decision came after she clashed with former chairman Justin Milne over several issues, including allegations that he pressured her to consider political sensitivities in Canberra. The controversy led to Milne's resignation, and Guthrie has since launched a case against the ABC with the Fair Work Commission, alleging "adverse action" by the board.

Guthrie, the first female managing director of the ABC, received a total remuneration package of $963,991 in the previous financial year. The $800,000 payout is likely to consist of entitlements such as superannuation, leave entitlements, and salary in lieu of notice. If Guthrie's case is successful, she could receive significantly more in damages.

Guthrie and Milne have both been invited to appear before the Senate ABC inquiry on Friday, which is investigating allegations of political interference. Guthrie's spokesperson declined to comment on the matter.

NASA engineers are set to embark on their least favorite task in space on Monday: landing a robot spaceship on Mars. The target is Elysium Planitia, where the InSight probe will gently touch down to analyze seismic activity on the red planet. Despite sending more probes to Mars than any other planet, more than half of these missions have failed, with the final stages of landing proving particularly perilous. The thin Martian atmosphere, which is just 1% of Earth's, poses a significant challenge, as there is little friction to slow down a spacecraft. This has contributed to past failures, making NASA engineers nervous as they guide their $800 million InSight craft on a 300 million-mile journey to a tiny target zone measuring just 15 miles by 6 miles. If InSight passes through this precise keyhole, it should land in the middle of Elysium Planitia. However, it will still need a heat-resistant capsule, parachute, and rockets to slow down from 12,000mph to 5mph and ensure a soft and safe landing after a seven-minute descent. The most recent attempt to land on Mars was made two years ago by a European probe, which unfortunately crashed on the planet's surface. Despite this, NASA remains confident of success. The InSight mission, which stands for Interior Exploration using Seismic Investigations, Geodesy and Heat Transport, aims to help scientists understand the early evolution of Mars and other planets in the solar system, including Earth, by using instruments to probe deep beneath the planet's surface and measure temperatures and seismic activity.

Researchers in Mexico have been studying the unique abilities of cave-dwelling tetra fish to better understand why some animals can regenerate tissue while others cannot. In a recent experiment, scientists removed parts of the heart from both river and cave-dwelling fish of the species Astyanax mexicanus and found that while the river fish were able to regenerate tissue, the cave fish only developed scars. The salamander's remarkable ability to regrow a lost tail to its full length is a complex process that involves cells migrating to the wound and slowly regenerating the tail over the course of a few weeks. The regenerated tail is fully functional and identical to the original, with the spinal cord and nerves fully restored. The axolotl, a relative of the salamander, is even more impressive in its regenerative abilities, able to regrow not just its tail but also its limbs, skin, and almost any other body part. In fact, researchers have found that each time a limb is removed, it regrows almost perfectly, making the axolotl a valuable subject for studying human limb regeneration. Starfish, with their five limbs, are able to regrow arms that detach from their central disc, and some species have even been observed to regrow an entire body from a lost arm. To accomplish this, starfish store nutrients in the detached arm until they are able to regrow their mouth. The sea cucumber has a remarkable ability to rapidly mend its organs, regrowing damaged parts and healing deep wounds in as little as a week. This remarkable skill is crucial for the sea cucumber, as it often jettisons certain organs as a distraction technique to defend itself against predators like crabs and turtles.

Crispin Odey, a Brexit-backing billionaire, has seen his share of profits from his hedge fund decline by £4m, as several bets he made against the UK economy and British businesses did not pay off as expected. According to accounts filed at Companies House, Odey received £1.5m from Odey Asset Management in the year ending April 5, a 72% drop from the £5.5m he earned in the previous year. The hedge fund, which Odey founded in 1991, reported a 52% decline in profit to £8.8m, largely due to his bets against the pound and various UK retailers not yielding immediate results. Odey Asset Management has taken a £149m short position against UK shops, banks, estate agents, and property companies. However, the fund has performed exceptionally well in recent months, as the pound has continued to fall and the share prices of several British businesses Odey bet against have plummeted. The fund has gained more than 50% so far this year, including a 7% return in October, making it one of the world's top-performing hedge funds, according to the Financial Times. Last month, the fund made millions from a bet against Intu, the shopping centre owner, whose shares dropped 42% after a proposed takeover collapsed. Odey also benefited from a £33m bet against Debenhams, whose shares have declined by 85% over the past year. Odey was a prominent supporter of the Brexit campaign and donated almost £900,000 to pro-Brexit efforts. He made huge bets against the pound and government bonds leading up to the June 2016 referendum and reportedly made an estimated £220m profit when the pound collapsed following the leave victory. The day after the referendum, Odey told the BBC that he felt like he was experiencing the Italian expression "Il mattino ha l'oro in bocca" (the morning has gold in its mouth), and that he has since boasted that each day of Brexit-related political crisis is a "good day" for him and his hedge fund. "He recently told the Times that he had a good day, despite the pound falling 2% that day. According to him, bad days often work in his favor. He has consistently called for Prime Minister Theresa May to resign and has expressed a desire for Boris Johnson to take her place."

On Christmas Day, thousands of people who had just unwrapped new smart speakers were left disappointed when Amazon's voice-controlled virtual assistant Alexa suddenly malfunctioned. The crash occurred when servers controlling Alexa became overwhelmed with questions and requests, causing the digital butler to respond with a generic message: "Sorry, I'm having trouble understanding you right now." The outage, which began around 10am GMT, left Amazon customers unable to play festive music, turn on their living room lights, or access cooking instructions for Christmas dinner. Richard Hyland, a Twitter user, sarcastically remarked: "What a perfect time for Amazon's Alexa to crash - just when people might want to register new devices, play music, or access recipes." Alexa functions by sending voice commands from an Amazon Echo device to a server, where a computer interprets them. The instructions are then sent back to the Echo, which plays music, reads the weather, and performs tasks such as turning on lights. Around lunchtime, Amazon's customer service account tweeted that some Echo devices in Europe had experienced intermittent connectivity issues over the past two hours, but assured customers that the issues had since been resolved. An Amazon spokesperson later confirmed that the company had experienced a brief issue that intermittently affected some Alexa customers' ability to interact with the service, but said the Alexa service was now operating normally.

The all-new Range Rover Evoque is priced at £31,600 and is expected to be delivered in spring 2019. As someone who's not always great at identifying a clear winner, I've often found myself at odds with car designers when it comes to aesthetics. In fact, I've previously deemed the Porsche Cayenne, Nissan Juke, and Range Rover Evoque to be three of the ugliest cars of the past decade - yet all three have gone on to achieve massive success. The latest iteration of the baby Range Rover is likely to be even more popular than its predecessor, which is now in its second generation as a compact SUV. While some elements remain the same, such as the clamshell bonnet and bulging wheel arches, the overall design has matured, becoming more sophisticated, clean, and less pretentious. Under the hood, significant changes have been made, including the addition of mild-hybrid systems to all automatic variants, which will reduce fuel consumption and CO2 emissions. One of the most impressive new features is the "ClearSight Ground View" system, which uses cameras on the side mirrors and front axle to provide a "through-the-bonnet" view on the infotainment screen, designed to eliminate those "blind faith" moments when navigating steep slopes or tight parking spaces. The more I see of the new Evoque, the more it's growing on me. You can reach me at martin.love@observer.co.uk or follow me on Twitter @MartinLove166.
