The UK's economy experienced a modest rebound in the three months to September, driven primarily by households with limited financial resources. Official statistics revealed that the economy recovered from the cold winter earlier in the year, as consumers splurged during the World Cup and a prolonged heatwave. However, more detailed data from the Office for National Statistics showed that consumers, burdened by rising utility bills and transportation costs, had to rely on their savings to maintain their spending habits, as their disposable income remained stagnant. According to Rob Kent-Smith, statistician at the ONS, households have spent more than they earned for an unprecedented eighth consecutive quarter, raising concerns about their ability to sustain their spending and drive the economy. Recent surveys have fueled concerns that consumer spending is losing momentum, with several high street retailers reporting dismal sales in November. The online retailer Asos's surprise profit warning has added to these concerns, as analysts had grown accustomed to web-based operators weathering the spending downturn. Business investment has declined for the third consecutive quarter, a trend not seen since the depths of the financial crisis a decade ago. This cumulative effect is expected to reduce GDP growth in the final quarter of 2018 to nearly zero. The Bank of England attributed the decline in business investment to Brexit uncertainty, although the risk of border disruptions has led to increased spending on warehousing and port capacity. Companies are stockpiling goods at their highest level since 2016, suggesting they are under pressure to build large inventories in preparation for a potential no-deal Brexit. Earlier on Friday, the GfK monthly health check found consumer confidence at its lowest level in five years, and a Lloyds bank monitor registered the lowest business morale since the 2016 Brexit referendum. The Bank of England lowered its growth forecasts on Thursday, predicting quarterly expansion of 0.2% for the last three months of 2018 and the first three months of 2019.

The BBC's headquarters in central London has been placed under lockdown due to a peaceful protest by climate change activists from Extinction Rebellion, who are demanding that the national broadcaster declare a "climate and ecological emergency" and make the environment its top editorial priority. The protest, which began on Friday afternoon, has locked down Broadcasting House, preventing BBC staff and guests from entering or leaving the building. Security personnel are keeping the protesters, who are calling for a meeting with the BBC's director general, Tony Hall, away from the entrance. The activists, who are demanding that the BBC broadcast about climate change with the same level of urgency as it did during World War II, have also organized protests at BBC offices in several other cities, including Bristol, Glasgow, Cambridge, Birmingham, Truro, Sheffield, Bangor, and Berlin. The campaign group, which launched two months ago, has gained international attention and support from public figures, including former Archbishop of Canterbury Rowan Williams. Since its launch, Extinction Rebellion has used civil disobedience tactics, including blocking bridges and gluing themselves to government buildings, to draw attention to the threat of climate and ecological change. The BBC has faced criticism for its coverage of climate change, particularly for giving airtime to climate change skeptics, such as Lord Lawson, who disagree with the scientific consensus. In response, the head of news, Fran Unsworth, has acknowledged that the corporation has struggled to get climate change coverage right, saying that "climate change has been a difficult subject for the BBC, and we get coverage of it wrong too often." She emphasized that to maintain impartiality, the BBC doesn't need to feature individuals who deny climate change; it's similar to not including someone who disputes Manchester United's 2-0 win last Saturday. The referee's decision is final, she said.

The BBC acknowledged receipt of a letter from a newly formed campaign group, but declined to comment on the request for a meeting with the director general.

A spokesperson for the BBC highlighted the organization's commitment to sustainability, stating, "We're proud of our leadership in this area and have outlined further actions, including reducing energy consumption, eliminating single-use plastics, and minimizing the environmental impact of necessary travel." The spokesperson added that the corporation has made significant progress in reducing its carbon footprint, having cut it by a third during the previous charter period. The spokesperson also cited the impact of popular programs like Blue Planet II and Dynasties, which have contributed to a shift in public debate on the effects of human activity on the environment.

Amazon, the world's largest company by market capitalization, reported impressive earnings and profits late on Thursday. The company achieved its third consecutive record profit, thanks to a strong holiday retail season and its growing high-margin businesses, including cloud computing and advertising. The Seattle-based company posted a profit of $3.03 billion, or $6.04 per share, a significant increase from $1.86 billion, or $3.75 per share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue grew 20% to $72.38 billion. Amazon's voice-controlled virtual assistant Alexa and the devices that play it played a key role in the company's performance. According to Jeff Bezos, Amazon's founder and CEO, "Alexa was very busy during the holiday season. Echo Dot was the best-selling item across all products on Amazon globally, and customers purchased millions more devices from the Echo family compared to last year." Notably, Amazon's cloud-computing division reported a 45% jump in revenue in the fourth quarter, solidifying its lead over Google and Microsoft. The division has been growing at a rate of 40% per year and is a high-margin business compared to retail. The cloud business has become crucial to Amazon's success, contributing not only to revenue but also to profits. Sales at Amazon Web Services climbed to $7.43 billion from $5.11 billion a year ago, exceeding analyst estimates of $7.29 billion. The segment accounts for around 10% of total revenue. Amazon's stock has risen 18% over the past year, and its market capitalization, which exceeded $840 billion as of Thursday afternoon, is the largest of any publicly traded company in the world. Amazon's stock price fell by almost 50 points from its closing price of $1,718 on concerns about reduced margins from sales in India and increased shipping costs in the US.

British car production plummeted to a five-year low in 2018, as manufacturers warned that the threat of a no-deal Brexit has led to a significant decline in new investment. According to figures released by the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), the UK auto industry lobby group, UK car factories produced 1.52 million vehicles last year, a 9.1% drop from 2017. Production for the domestic market fell by 16.3%, while investment in British car manufacturing almost halved to £588.6 million, the lowest level since 2012. The SMMT attributed this decline to Brexit uncertainty, with Mike Hawes, the organization's CEO, stating that "investment is effectively stalled" and that the industry is waiting to see what happens before making further investments. The global automotive industry is already facing multiple challenges, including declining car sales in China and a slump in demand for diesel vehicles in Europe. However, UK-based manufacturers are particularly concerned about the potential impact of a no-deal Brexit on their businesses, which rely heavily on "just-in-time" deliveries of parts. Delays at the border could be costly and risk British jobs, according to Hawes. He emphasized that Brexit uncertainty has already caused significant damage to output, investment, and jobs, and that severing frictionless trade links with the EU and other global markets could have devastating consequences. The SMMT analysis revealed that two-thirds of UK car exports go to countries with preferential trading arrangements, including the EU and the US, which would default to less favorable World Trade Organization terms if there is no transition period. EU countries accounted for more than half of the UK's car exports in 2018. Some major parts manufacturers, such as Germany's Schaeffler, have already cited Brexit as a reason for relocating jobs abroad. Ford's European president, Steven Armstrong, recently refused to rule out the possibility of closing plants that employ thousands of workers if a no-deal Brexit occurs. Hawes dismissed claims made by some Brexit-supporting MPs that German carmakers will pressure the EU to offer the UK a better deal than currently on the table, calling them "utter nonsense". He also expressed skepticism about the idea of a managed no-deal Brexit without a transition period, describing it as a "fantasy". Hawes joked that if this scenario is considered "Project Fear", then they are successfully making it a reality.

Social media is often criticized for presenting a sanitized and unrealistic portrayal of life, but it's refreshing to see celebrities like Kate Beckinsale and Nicky Campbell sharing genuine moments from their hospital beds. However, not everyone agrees, as evidenced by Sarah Vine's recent column in the Daily Mail, where she expresses her disapproval of "hospital selfies." As someone who has spent four days in the hospital over the past two months, I've found that sharing photos from my hospital bed has been a great way to stay connected with friends and family. I enjoy posting updates on Twitter and Instagram, and it's a way for my friends to keep up with my life and offer support. It's also helped me feel more connected to others, especially during times when illness can be isolating. Chronic illness, in particular, can make people feel unattractive and like they don't fit into societal beauty standards. But by sharing my own experiences, I'm trying to challenge that idea and show that people with disabilities or illnesses are still attractive and worthy of respect. The "hospital selfie" movement has also helped demystify disability and illness, and I've received many grateful messages from people who appreciate my openness about my health. These messages have come from others with epilepsy who feel less alone, from parents who want to show their children that they're not the only ones dealing with health issues, and from people who are looking for coping mechanisms and advice. By sharing my experiences, I hope to create a sense of community and connection with others, and to show that we're all in this together. "Additionally, I find it amusing that I resemble Pinhead from Hellraiser when I'm having an EEG - it's a humorous experience."

Vodafone has taken the top spot as the most-complained about broadband and landline provider in Ofcom's quarterly league table. This is the first time the company has appeared in the survey, having only recently become eligible due to its 1.5% market share. Vodafone's broadband service received 27 complaints per 100,000 subscribers, nearly double the industry average of 15, with customers citing issues such as switching providers, handling faults, and service quality. The company's landline service received 19 complaints per 100,000 subscribers, exceeding the industry average of 11, with similar complaints about provider switching, fault handling, and service. According to Ernest Doku, a telecoms analyst at uSwitch.com, Vodafone will likely feel the pressure, as customers are willing to switch providers when they're unhappy with the service. In the competitive telecoms market, these complaint tables can be a significant concern for companies.

Meanwhile, Virgin Media topped the list as the most-complained about pay-TV provider, with 19 complaints per 100,000 customers, more than double the industry average of seven. The majority of complaints related to contract issues. During the survey period, Virgin Media was dealing with a significant number of disgruntled customers who were upset about the removal of UKTV's 10 TV channels, including Gold and Dave, from the service due to a dispute over rights. Additionally, Virgin Mobile, a subsidiary of Virgin Media, generated the highest number of complaints per 100,000 customers in the pay-monthly mobile category, with 11 complaints, exceeding the industry average of four.

Lloyds Bank's new Lend a Hand mortgage offers first-time buyers the chance to borrow the full price of their new home, but with a significant condition: a relative must have a lump sum of 10% that they're willing to tie up for three years, and which can be used to pay off the mortgage if the borrower misses payments. This mortgage is not suitable for anyone without a family member who has a spare chunk of cash they're willing to use to help them get on the housing ladder. However, this is not a return to the pre-financial crisis era, when mortgages of up to 125% were available, leaving some borrowers trapped in negative equity.

Lloyds' deal offers a mortgage of up to £500,000, which can be arranged over 30 years at a competitive fixed rate of 2.99% for three years. During this period, the family member's cash will earn interest at 1.5% above the base rate, making it a good deal in the current market. After three years, the family member can withdraw their cash, and the borrower can either switch to Lloyds' standard variable rate or look for a new mortgage.

According to Andrew Hagger of Moneycomms.co.uk, if house prices remain stagnant until the end of the three-year period, someone who has opted for a 30-year term will have paid off 6.5% of their loan, leaving them needing a 93.5% mortgage to switch. Fortunately, Moneyfacts.co.uk figures show that there are remortgage deals available with the same rate as the Lloyds' loan, making it relatively painless to switch. However, if house prices decline, borrowers could face problems. "In the worst-case scenario, you may find yourself in negative equity, with a mortgage debt exceeding the value of your home, leaving you locked into a mortgage with Lloyds and facing financial penalties if you try to move. The uncertainty surrounding Brexit's impact on the housing market could be a significant deterrent from considering a 100% mortgage. For expert guidance on finding your new mortgage, use our online tool to compare thousands of deals from over 80 lenders with the Guardian Mortgage Service, powered by L&C."

A recent study has provided conclusive evidence that working mothers are indeed more stressed than others, with a staggering 18% increase in stress levels compared to the general population. This figure jumps to a whopping 40% for mothers of two children. The study, conducted by a team of researchers from Manchester and Essex universities, analyzed biological data from 6,025 participants in the UK Household Longitudinal Survey, the largest survey of its kind worldwide. The researchers controlled for various factors that could influence the results, such as age, ethnicity, education, occupation, and income, to isolate the impact of working hours and family conditions on stress levels. The study, published in the journal Sociology, found that neither working from home nor having flexible working hours had a significant effect on women's chronic stress levels. However, reducing the number of working hours did have a positive impact on stress levels. According to the researchers, work-family conflict is a significant contributor to increased psychological strain, stress, and decreased wellbeing. Parents of young children are particularly vulnerable to work-family conflict, which can have adverse effects on their stress responses. The study's findings are based on 11 biomarkers that measure the cumulative wear and tear on the body's physiological systems, which can indicate poor health and increased risk of death. The researchers conclude that chronic stress, resulting from repeated stressful events and combinations of social and environmental stressors, can have a significant impact on overall health. A recent study revealed that women working full-time while raising two children had biomarkers indicating chronic stress, including hormone levels and blood pressure, that were 40% higher compared to women working full-time with no children. Women working full-time with one child had 18% higher levels of stress than those with no children. According to Dr. Benzeval, flexible work practices aim to help employees achieve a better work-life balance, which should reduce work-family conflict. While the study found that reduced-hours flexible work arrangements did help moderate the relationship between family and work stressors, there was limited evidence that flexible work arrangements, such as flexplace or flextime, were associated with lower chronic stress responses. Notably, the researchers also discovered that reduced work hours could lead to lower chronic stress markers for fathers.

Britain's largest retailers and wholesalers have escalated their stockpiling efforts to their highest levels since the 2008 financial crisis, according to a recent industry report, with only 60 days remaining before the UK's scheduled departure from the EU. According to the latest report from the Confederation of British Industry's monthly distributive trades survey, retail businesses increased their stock-to-sales ratio in January to its highest level since February 2008. The report, closely monitored by the Bank of England for early indicators of the UK economy, reveals that retailers anticipate a decline in demand and have built up inventory in preparation for a potential no-deal Brexit at the end of March. As the UK's exit from the EU remains uncertain, a growing number of companies are intensifying their plans for a potentially chaotic no-deal Brexit. Luxury carmaker Bentley and retailers such as Dixons Carphone and Pets at Home have announced measures to secure their supplies in the event of disruptions at British ports. According to Rain Newton-Smith, chief economist at the CBI, "We're seeing early signs of companies preparing for a no-deal Brexit, with some wholesalers reporting that they're stockpiling in case the UK exits the EU without a deal." The CBI's distributive trades survey, which has been running since 1983, polled 103 retailers, wholesalers, and motor traders between December 27 and January 14. These companies represent a third of all employment in retailing. January sales volumes stabilized after a challenging festive trading period, but were still below average for the time of year, marking one of the worst periods since 2011. Sales of clothing, footwear, and leather goods, as well as hardware and DIY items, declined, while grocers and online sales reported increased volumes. The CBI predicts a more optimistic outlook for the coming month, with retailers expecting sales volumes and orders to rise in the year to February. According to Samuel Tombs, chief UK economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, "Retailers should be experiencing a surge in sales right now, thanks to the increasing pace of real wage growth and the ongoing growth in employment. However, the heightened uncertainty surrounding Brexit, which is reflected in the sharp decline in consumer confidence surveys towards the end of last year, is prompting consumers to be more cautious in their spending habits."

Netflix has emerged victorious in its battle with Amazon for dominance in the UK streaming market, with a significant increase in subscribers and a growing lead over its rival. According to a report from TV measurement body Barb, Netflix now has 9.7 million UK subscribers, compared to Amazon's Prime Video service, which has around 4.9 million users. The report reveals that Netflix added 2.2 million new subscribers in the year to the end of the third quarter 2018, more than double the 1.1 million subscribers Amazon gained during the same period. Netflix's growth has been fueled by a $13 billion budget for producing and licensing TV shows and films.

The report also highlights that while Netflix remains the most popular streaming service, Amazon has managed to attract a significant number of subscribers with families who have young children. This may be due to Amazon's unique offering, which bundles its video service with its Prime subscription package, which includes perks such as one-day delivery and access to Amazon Music. The report suggests that the presence of young children and the convenience of on-demand content and next-day delivery may be enticing families towards Amazon.

Overall, the UK's three largest subscription video-on-demand services - Netflix, Amazon, and Sky's Now TV - have added 3.45 million customers over the year, taking their combined total to 16.2 million. This represents a 27% annual increase and is more than the number of subscribers to traditional pay-TV packages from providers such as Sky, BT, Virgin Media, and TalkTalk. Sky's Now TV, in particular, has seen a significant increase, adding almost 200,000 customers to reach a total of 1.6 million subscribers. According to Barb's report, there has been a significant surge in the number of UK households that subscribe to two or more paid streaming services, increasing by 40% year-on-year from 2.8 million to 4 million. In the third quarter, nearly 12 million UK households had access to at least one of Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, or Sky's Now TV, representing a 22% year-on-year growth. The report also highlights a notable increase in the daily viewing time on services like Netflix, which rose by 17% year-on-year to 46 minutes. Interestingly, the 16- to 24-year-old age group spends significantly more time watching content each day, averaging 63 minutes.

Metro Bank's shares plummeted to record lows on Wednesday, following the lender's surprise announcement that it needs to raise an additional £350 million just months after its previous capital increase. The high street challenger also revealed that it is under investigation by the Financial Conduct Authority and Prudential Regulation Authority over a significant accounting error that was first disclosed last month. The news was made public alongside the bank's annual results on Tuesday night. Metro Bank's share price continued to fall on Wednesday, dropping by over 26% to around 950p just before the London market closed. The company's shares have lost half their value since the accounting issue was revealed. In January, Metro Bank confirmed that hundreds of millions of pounds in commercial property loans and loans to commercial buy-to-let operators had been misclassified in terms of risk. While the bank initially claimed to have discovered the error on its own, it later emerged that the Prudential Regulation Authority had actually caught the mistake. In response to the debacle, CEO Craig Donaldson has decided to forgo his annual bonus, which was worth £800,000 in 2017. He has also offered to resign, but has been given the full backing of the board and will remain in his position. After apologizing to investors, Donaldson denied that the latest capital raise was influenced by the loans misclassification. The bank raised £303 million from investors last July, after which Donaldson ruled out further capital increases to fuel the lender's growth in the medium term. When asked to respond to criticism over his change of heart, Donaldson said that the bank would always seek to raise capital when it was in its best interests and that the recent decision was made to raise capital ahead of the bank's growth. John Cronin, a financial analyst at Goodbody, described the recent slowdown in deposit growth and Metro Bank's consistent need for more core capital as "serious concerns". "He noted that it's still uncertain how the stock will perform in the coming days, but predicted that shares could drop to 729p. Royal London Asset Management, a major shareholder in Metro Bank, expressed concerns about the recent accounting error, citing it as a warning sign for investors. 'Governance issues often serve as a warning sign, and this case is no exception,' said the company. 'We are requesting a meeting with Metro Bank to discuss the steps they are taking to alleviate shareholder concerns and strengthen their governance and accounting practices.'"

Retail workers in the UK are more likely to face unemployment than find a new job, according to a recent report. The study by the Resolution Foundation found that the retail industry has the highest rate of redundancies in the economy, with a sharp increase in shop closures across the country. The report comes as major high street retailers such as Marks & Spencer, Debenhams, and HMV announce job cuts and store closures. The decline in consumer spending, exacerbated by inflation following the Brexit vote, and changing shopping habits have all contributed to the struggles of traditional brick-and-mortar stores, which typically employ more workers. The study revealed that a worrying 31% of retail workers who lose their jobs end up unemployed, compared to the average of 26% across all industries. Furthermore, two in five former retail workers are unemployed for at least six months, with younger workers facing greater risks. The report found that three in five former retail workers are under the age of 30, despite this age group making up only a third of the retail workforce. According to Daniel Tomlinson, research and policy analyst at the Resolution Foundation, "life has become tougher for those leaving retail, who are more likely to find themselves unemployed – and for longer, too." While policymakers cannot reverse the shift towards online shopping, they can and should focus on supporting those most affected. The study also found that there has been a long-term decline in retail employment in the UK since 2003, with the number of jobs in the sector shrinking from 10.8% to 9.5% of the overall workforce, equivalent to 320,000 missing positions. "Contrary to the stereotype of being a 'nation of shopkeepers', Britain now has a lower proportion of workers in wholesale and retail compared to Germany, according to the report. Despite multiple rounds of job cuts, the job market has adapted by creating new opportunities in industries such as hospitality and social care, although the increasing redundancy rate presents new challenges. The report also notes that the retail sector remains a low-paying industry, with the average hourly wage of £8.80 being approximately a third lower than the average pay across the entire economy, which stands at £12.73 per hour."

According to an analysis by Which?, British tourists traveling to Spain after a no-deal Brexit could face airport queues of five hours or more. The consumer group advises travelers to pack essentials like food, water, and even nappies to help them survive prolonged delays. Alicante airport, which serves popular resorts like Benidorm, is expected to be the most severely affected, with visitors to Tenerife, Lanzarote, and Málaga also likely to experience significant delays. Which? estimates that if EU airports spend an extra 90 seconds processing each UK passport, it could add five hours to the processing time for a Ryanair flight with 189 UK passengers. Alicante airport is particularly vulnerable due to its high volume of UK arrivals, processing up to 10 planes from the UK in a single hour. In total, 2.9 million British passport holders pass through the airport each year. While Portugal has announced plans to introduce special UK lanes at Faro airport and Funchal to facilitate fast-track access for British passport holders, regardless of the Brexit outcome, Spain has yet to confirm its position. Rory Boland, travel editor at Which?, warns that airports can be chaotic even in normal circumstances, and a no-deal Brexit could lead to extremely long queues. Until a deal is reached or airports announce alternative arrangements, travelers should prepare for the possibility of lengthy queues and pack accordingly, including essentials like food, water, and baby supplies. The analysis was based on data from the European Tourism Association (ETOA). According to the UK government's official advice in the event of a no-deal scenario, British tourists would not be entitled to use the designated lanes for EU, EEA, and Swiss nationals. They may be required to present a return or onward ticket and could face additional checks to ensure they have sufficient funds to cover the duration of their visit. Despite the potential challenges, Aena, Spain's largest airport operator, does not anticipate chaos at airports this summer, citing the high stakes involved. In fact, Aena believes that once the initial uncertainty is resolved, UK traffic can continue to thrive in both the short and long term.

Hammerson, the owner of prominent shopping centers like Birmingham's Bullring and London's Brent Cross, is in talks to sell off a significant portfolio of properties worth over £900 million, a move prompted by the crisis in Britain's retail sector. The FTSE 250-listed company has revealed that it is actively discussing the disposal of assets exceeding its £500 million target for 2019, following the sale of £570 million in property last year at an average price 7% below its book value in December 2017. The company is under pressure from activist investor Elliott Advisors, which owns a 5% stake, to accelerate its disposal plans after a 9.3% decline in property values in 2018. Hammerson's tenants include Patisserie Valerie, which recently avoided administration after a management buyout, as well as House of Fraser and New Look, which have both undergone company voluntary arrangements to avoid insolvency. The latter two have been forced to close stores and seek rent reductions from their landlords.

Hammerson's CEO, David Atkins, acknowledged that 2018 was a challenging year, particularly in the UK, due to tenant failures, structural shifts in retail, and a more cautious consumer. He noted that the company's destinations outside of the UK performed better, with a strong contribution from premium outlets. Hammerson's annual adjusted profit fell by 2.4% to £240.3 million, despite abandoning a planned £3.4 billion buyout of rival Intu and fending off a £4.9 billion takeover approach from Klépierre. The company has focused on its flagship malls as it navigates the shift to online shopping, citing the continued popularity of such centers for "big day out" experiences and strong growth in luxury sales. Elliott supports Hammerson's accelerated asset disposal program and the company's decision to add two independent non-executive directors to a new investment and disposal committee. Since June, Hammerson has used the sale proceeds to reduce its debt by £179m, bringing the total debt down to £3.4bn. The company plans to further reduce its debt to below £3bn by the end of the year.

A business owner in Ohio recently sparked controversy when he announced that he would no longer sell his products and services to supporters of Donald Trump. Was this decision a good one? The answer is likely self-evident. Joe, the owner of Joe's Music, a small musical instrument and accessory shop in Willoughby, Ohio, made the declaration in a recent Facebook post. In the post, he wrote, "Dear Trump sympathizers, I'm truly sorry, but I feel unclean and dirty accepting money from you. Please, politely shop somewhere else. I'd rather starve and close the store than participate in wrongdoing." He also posted a similar message on his shop's front door, essentially telling Trump supporters to stay away. The reaction was swift and overwhelming, with both supporters and detractors weighing in on social media and via phone calls. While some people expressed support for Joe's decision, others threatened him and his business. The police have had to increase their presence around his store as a result. Joe was caught off guard by the intense attention and ultimately backed down from his comments, removing the sign, deleting the Facebook post, and issuing an apology. He acknowledged that he had been insensitive to the feelings of Trump supporters and apologized for hurting them. However, the damage had already been done, and the news had gone viral. The incident serves as a cautionary tale for small business owners who may not be prepared for the intense political backlash that can come with taking a public stance. It's a reminder that taking a stand in politics requires a certain kind of personality and a thick skin. Joe should have stuck to his music, as he now faces the daunting task of rebuilding his business. Hopefully, this incident will soon fade from memory, and he can return to doing what he does best. However, the experience serves as a valuable lesson for small business owners who wish to engage in politics: think carefully before taking a public stance, as the reaction may be unexpected and costly. In Joe's case, his political views may ultimately alienate half of his customer base, depending on their stance on the president. It's clear that politics and small business don't mix. Instead of voicing his opinions, Joe would be wise to focus on understanding how Trump's policies will impact his trade and finding ways to benefit or adapt to them. His political views are best left for the voting booth.

Cromer is a charming town that seems stuck in the early 20th century. You half expect to see someone sporting a vintage mutton-chop or waxed moustache queuing up at Morrisons or Arthur Conan Doyle filling up his Prius at the local petrol station. In the late 19th century, Cromer and its neighboring towns, Overstrand and East Runton, were the epitome of luxury, earning Overstrand the nickname "village of millionaires." Today, the area is still dotted with large, beautifully restored homes in the Arts and Crafts style.

While Cromer may have lost some of its former luster over the years, it has undergone significant revitalization efforts. The municipal gardens are now sparkling, and the streets are filled with independent shops. While the town still has its share of shabby areas, its unique character remains intact. Visitors can still enjoy the town's famous crabs, the stunning tower of St Peter and St Paul, the historic boarding houses clinging to the cliffs, and the picturesque lanes of fishermen's homes. The town's pier, in particular, is a standout, with its fin-de-siècle architecture and stunning views of the North Sea.

Of course, Cromer is not without its drawbacks. It is located a significant distance from major cities and has limited motorway access. Additionally, coastal erosion is a concern in the area.

For those who do make the trip, there are plenty of amenities to enjoy. The town has several excellent primary and secondary schools, and the local train station offers regular services to Norwich and other nearby towns. When you're not exploring the town, you can hang out at Davies fish shop, slurp seafood ramen at Upstairs at No 1, or visit the magical Gunton Arms, a popular restaurant located just outside the town. Discover the charming town of Cromer, where you'll find a delightful mix of traditional Norfolk homes, including flinty pantiled cottages, townhouses, and late-19th-century arts and crafts-style properties. The town's compact center features a selection of Victorian seaside homes, while the surrounding areas offer a range of properties, including chunky semis and detached houses. Property prices in Cromer range from:

* Large detached houses and townhouses: £400,000-£650,000
* Detached houses and smaller townhouses: £250,000-£400,000

The largest collection of King Tutankhamun's treasures to ever leave Egypt is heading to London for an exclusive exhibition that will never be replicated. The Saatchi Gallery in London will be the sole UK venue for a global tour of 150 original artifacts from Tutankhamun's tomb, including 60 that have never left Egypt before. The tour marks the centennial anniversary of British explorer Howard Carter's sensational discovery of the boy pharaoh's tomb in 1922. After the tour, the treasures will be permanently displayed at the newly built Grand Egyptian Museum near the pyramids of Giza. "Come and see them while you can," urged Mostafa Waziry, secretary general of the Egyptian ministry of state for antiquities. "Visit them before they return to Egypt forever." The exhibition will feature a gold-inlaid miniature coffin containing the king's liver, a gilded wooden bed with lion feet, and a gilded wooden shrine depicting intimate scenes of royal domestic harmony. One of two life-sized guardian statues of the king, which flanked the sealed entrance to his burial chamber, will also make its debut outside of Cairo. Unfortunately, Tutankhamun's famous golden death mask will not be part of the show. The discovery of Tutankhamun's tomb is considered one of the most significant archaeological finds in history. Carter's account of the moment he first laid eyes on the tomb's treasures is still awe-inspiring: "Details of the room within emerged slowly from the mist, strange animals, statues, and gold – everywhere the glint of gold... I was struck dumb with amazement." When some of these treasures left Cairo for a 1972 exhibition at the British Museum, a record 1.6 million people visited, resulting in chaotic queues. The treasures from the tomb last appeared in London in 2007 at the O2, and the revenue from that exhibition was used to protect Egypt's antiquities and monuments. The 2020 exhibition will depart from previous ones by delving into the symbolism and importance of the king's burial artifacts. According to Philippa Adams, director of the Saatchi Gallery, "The discovery of Tutankhamun's tomb is a timeless tale known globally, and this exhibition will showcase these historic treasures in an innovative and immersive manner. We're thrilled and honored to host this culturally significant exhibition." The touring exhibition, which began in Los Angeles last year, will visit 10 cities worldwide. The Saatchi Gallery will host "Tutankhamun: Treasures of the Golden Pharaoh" from November 2, 2019, to May 3, 2020.

The creators of Fortnite have removed their ads from YouTube due to concerns that promotional content for the popular children's game was appearing alongside comments from pedophiles. Epic Games has confirmed that it has suspended its ad campaigns on the Google-owned platform, joining Nestlé in temporarily halting its advertising on the site amid the latest controversy surrounding inappropriate content. A YouTube user named Matt Watson recently posted a video exposing a "wormhole" that leads to a softcore pedophile ring on the site. Watson demonstrated how, with a new YouTube account, users can easily find videos filled with provocative comments about children. He stated in the video, "Pedophiles are trading social media contacts, sharing links to actual child pornography in YouTube comments, and trading unlisted videos in secret. YouTube's algorithm, due to a glitch in its programming, is facilitating their ability to do this." The scandal poses a significant challenge for YouTube, as the videos themselves are not necessarily problematic. Most of the videos feature young girls engaging in innocent activities, such as playing, exercising at home, or participating in gymnastics. The issue lies in the comments section, where YouTube users have left sexually suggestive messages and shared tips on how to take compromising still images of the children while pausing the videos. After watching a few such videos on a new YouTube account, Watson described how the site's algorithm would serve up an endless stream of videos featuring apparently underage children with inappropriate comments in the comments section. Many of these videos were also accompanied by ads from major brands like Nestlé, Fortnite, and Disney. The reaction to the story from the broader YouTube community has been mixed, with some prominent YouTubers accusing Watson of overreacting and criticizing him for going public with his claims that pedophiles were using the site's comments section. YouTubers accuse Watson of attempting to drive away advertisers, which would deprive them of their significant income and potentially trigger an "adpocalypse". This accusation is reminiscent of previous instances where large advertisers withdrew their support from the platform due to concerns about YouTube's inability to ensure their ads did not appear alongside disturbing or inappropriate content, such as videos from terrorist organizations or hate groups. In response to the latest allegations, a YouTube spokesperson stated: "We condemn any content that endangers minors as abhorrent and have clear policies prohibiting such content on our platform. We have taken swift action by deleting accounts and channels, reporting illegal activity to the authorities, and disabling comments on tens of millions of videos that feature minors. While there is still more work to be done, we are committed to improving our systems to detect and prevent abuse more effectively."

A Melbourne heart specialist clinic has been targeted by hackers who allegedly scrambled patient files in a ransom attempt. The Australian Cyber Security Centre is providing guidance and support to the Melbourne Heart Group, which leases space at the Cabrini hospital in Malvern. Due to the ongoing nature of the incident, the centre's spokesperson declined to comment further. The Australian Federal Police is also conducting a joint investigation with the centre. According to reports, the malware used to breach the clinic's security network is believed to be linked to North Korea or Russia, although the identity of the perpetrators remains unknown. A Melbourne Heart Group spokesperson confirmed that the hackers had encrypted the data, but declined to reveal whether the clinic had paid a ransom or how many files were compromised. The clinic released a statement saying it had experienced a cybersecurity incident in late January, which resulted in patient data being encrypted and becoming inaccessible. The statement assured patients that their privacy had not been compromised and that the clinic was working to resolve the issue with its IT provider. The clinic emphasized the importance of patient privacy and apologized for the incident, urging patients to contact the office for updates. Cabrini hospital clarified that the incident did not affect its own patient data or systems, as the specialists are responsible for their own data storage and information systems.

The battle for control of Superdry has reached its final round, with co-founder Julian Dunkerton facing off against management in a closely contested shareholder vote on Tuesday. In a pre-vote press conference, Dunkerton confidently declared, "I'm confident we'll win," as he seeks to rejoin the company he left last year. The multimillionaire entrepreneur received a late boost to his campaign, with two key shareholders, Investec and Schroders, appearing to back his bid to regain control. The duo, who control around 10% of Superdry's shares, join Dunkerton and designer James Holder, who founded the fashion label in 2003, in their fight against the company's current management. Holder is also seeking to return to designing clothes for the brand, which has struggled with declining sales and profits. To succeed, Dunkerton needs to secure a simple majority of votes cast on Tuesday. However, one insider suggests that the outcome is far from certain, saying, "It could go either way." The tension ahead of the vote was heightened on Friday when Schroders refused to commit to supporting Dunkerton, stating that it would make its decision based on the best interests of its clients and the company. Superdry has received public backing from Aberdeen Standard Investments, which holds around 10% of the company's shares, as well as from proxy voting advisory firms ISS and Pirc, whose views influence passive investment funds. "Sutherland, who stands at 6ft 6in, is reportedly prepared to defend himself against Dunkerton's accusations, which include being out of his depth in the fashion industry and leading a failed strategy. Superdry rose to fame in the 2000s by selling branded hoodies and vintage T-shirts, but Sutherland believes the brand needs to evolve and move forward. However, it's clear why Dunkerton is upset, given that his 18% stake has lost over £150m in value since he left the company, and the company's market value has plummeted so severely that it has been removed from the FTSE 250 index. The stakes are high on Tuesday, as Superdry has warned shareholders that Dunkerton's return will likely lead to a mass exodus of board directors. Get there early to secure a front-row seat for the drama that is sure to unfold."

The p-value is often misinterpreted, and your editorial is no exception. Specifically, it doesn't measure reliability or the likelihood of an observed result. What it actually expresses is the probability of observing the experimental result or a more extreme result if the experiment had no effect. This is known as the null hypothesis, which is a crucial aspect of the test. The test itself doesn't examine the possibility of an effect being present, although it's commonly used when one is suspected. As your editorial notes, it's only recently that scientists, including ourselves, have begun to grasp this logic, despite articles in the scientific literature highlighting this point for over 30 years.

Regarding Richard Wilkinson's letter about unemployment statistics, I'd like to raise a different concern. He mentions the 30 changes to the administrative definition of unemployment between 1979 and 2000, which aimed to reduce the "claimant count" numbers and make comparisons over time more challenging. However, the statistics published last week are consistent over the 44-year period covered, using an internationally agreed definition of unemployment and unaffected by changes in the benefits system. I agree with Richard that the record low unemployment rate raises further questions, particularly about how this statistic fits into a broader description of the labor market, including the experiences of people with low-paid and insecure jobs, such as those with zero-hours contracts. "While the unemployment rate is an important indicator, it's not the only metric that matters. - Paul Allin, Visiting Professor, Department of Mathematics, Imperial College London

A warning to Tesco Hudl tablet users: the retailer has discontinued software support, making it impossible to restore the device to factory settings, effectively rendering it useless. This issue first arose in January, and despite claims that a fix was being worked on, Tesco has now announced that the Hudl 1 and the first edition Hudl 2 have reached the end of their life cycle. Unfortunately, this means that the update previously implemented will not resolve the problem. This sudden and unexpected move has the potential to cause significant disruption, especially considering the Hudl tablets were incredibly popular and still have a thriving second-hand market due to their ease of use, speed, and power. It's unacceptable that Tesco has not made a formal announcement about this change, leaving many users in the dark. The £119 tablet was a best-seller between 2013 and 2015, offering a more affordable alternative to the iPad. For now, your tablet will continue to function normally if you do nothing, but avoid attempting to restore it to factory settings or update its operating system. Given the potential impact on hundreds of thousands of users, it's surprising that Tesco has not publicly addressed this issue, which has sparked widespread anger. However, Tesco assures us that it has not shut down the Hudl servers, and newer Hudl 2 devices can be fixed. The company is working on a solution for older models and is committed to resolving any outstanding issues. My dear friend John Slatter, who has passed away at the age of 73, was a renowned academic in the field of Russian studies. In addition to his research on the peasantry, he made significant contributions to the study of Russian émigrés in Britain during the final decades of the Tsarist regime. Born in Richmond, south-west London, John was adopted by Henrietta (née Grundy) and Albert Slatter, a wine taster. He attended Latymer Upper School in Hammersmith and later read Russian and French at Jesus College, Cambridge, where he graduated in 1966. It was during his time at Cambridge that I became close friends with John. In the summer of 1964, we traveled to Moscow to attend a language course, and it was on that trip that I introduced him to Irene Gottlieb, a student of Russian at the University of London. They were married on July 30, 1966, the day England won the World Cup. After completing his master's degree in social sciences and PhD on the peasantry and rural Soviets in the early years of Soviet power at the University of Birmingham, John joined the Centre for Russian and East European Studies as a lecturer in Russian history and language at the University of Durham, where he spent the remainder of his academic career. Irene, who was also a Russian language teacher, joined him at the university. John was a fit and active individual as a student, but in his 40s, he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. As his health declined, he continued to engage with Russian culture and current events through films, satellite television, and documentaries, and he maintained his love of music, which spanned classical, jazz, and beyond. It was John who first introduced me to the music of Charles Aznavour and Mozart's sublime G minor Piano Quartet. After retiring in 2003, John and Irene continued to spend their summers in Antibes, France, until recently. "John, despite his own health challenges, was a devoted and supportive partner to Irene, who faced significant health issues. The couple commemorated their 50th wedding anniversary in 2016 with immense joy. John was known for his kind, humorous, and selfless nature, as well as his strong moral compass, making him a loving husband and father. He leaves behind Irene, his two sons, Stephen and Paul, and their grandson, Sebastian."

Global financial markets plummeted on Friday, driven by growing concerns about a slowdown in the global economy, after eurozone factory output plummeted at its fastest rate in nearly six years. The sharp losses on European and Wall Street stock exchanges came after data showed that economic growth in the European single currency bloc remained weak in the first quarter of 2019, dispelling hopes of a rebound from a weak finish to last year. Economists attributed the poor industrial output figures to a slowdown in China and the global economy, raising the prospect that growth for the rest of 2019 would be weaker than expected. The New York stock market slumped, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing down 460 points, or 1.8%, while the FTSE 100 dropped 2% and markets across Europe suffered steep losses. The IHS Markit flash purchasing managers' index for euro area factory output, which tracks early warning signs of economic stress, showed that output contracted the most since December 2012, a period marked by the eurozone's sovereign debt crisis. Analysts attributed the decline to disruptions caused by Brexit, but noted that faltering demand for exports amid the US-China trade dispute had a more significant impact. Germany's manufacturing sector, which has increasingly relied on exports to China in recent years, recorded its steepest decline in output in seven years, with new factory orders deteriorating to the greatest extent since the financial crisis. Much of Germany's industry woes are linked to China's slowing economy, which was triggered by US President Donald Trump's imposition of import tariffs on Chinese goods in a bitter trade standoff with Beijing. Chinese car sales fell for the first time in almost 30 years last year, a significant blow to several German car manufacturers, which rely heavily on China as their largest export market. Germany narrowly avoided recession last year, and the PMI index, compiled by surveying around 5,000 companies across the euro area, showed that Germany and France were the worst performers. Other parts of the eurozone recorded stronger growth. According to Chris Williamson, the chief business economist at IHS Markit, the survey suggests that the economy is expected to grow by around 0.2% in the first quarter. Andrew Kenningham, the chief Europe economist at Capital Economics, notes that the bigger picture is that the eurozone economy is still moving at a slow pace, with Germany's manufacturing recession and Italy's broader downturn holding the region back.

Airbnb has taken a significant step towards avoiding strict national regulations after an advisor to the European Court of Justice (ECJ) recommended that the company be classified as a digital service provider. According to Maciej Szpunar, one of the ECJ's advocates general, Airbnb should be considered an information society service, which would allow it to operate freely across the EU. Szpunar rejected claims by a French tourism association that Airbnb should be subject to the same accounting, insurance, and financial obligations as traditional real estate providers. Airbnb, which is registered in Ireland, argues that its commercial activities in matching property owners with guests seeking accommodation do not constitute real estate brokerage. Szpunar stated that the French government had failed to properly notify the European Commission and Irish authorities of its intention to apply French law to Airbnb. He described the company as an online service that connects potential guests with hosts offering short-term accommodation. It remains unclear what the ECJ's opinion would have been if the French authorities had made the required notification. The opinion is non-binding, but the ECJ typically follows the advice of its advocates general in 80% of cases. Airbnb welcomed the opinion, saying it provides a clear overview of the applicable rules. The development is likely to benefit Airbnb, which has been fighting claims from cities worldwide, including Paris, Amsterdam, and Barcelona, that its services are changing neighborhoods and require stricter regulation. France is Airbnb's largest market after the US, and Paris is its biggest single city market, with approximately 65,000 listed homes. An Airbnb spokesperson said: "We appreciate the advocate general's opinion, which provides a clear overview of the rules applicable to collaborative economy platforms like Airbnb and how these rules foster opportunities for consumers. We also aim to be good partners, having worked with over 500 governments worldwide to help hosts share their homes, follow the rules, and pay their fair share of taxes." "Moving forward, our goal is to collaborate with all stakeholders to prioritize the needs and benefits of local communities in the development of sustainable travel practices for the 21st century."

Your first job interview is a big day, and as you walk in, your prospective employer extends a hand in greeting. Panic sets in - what do you do? Do you grasp it firmly and enthusiastically to show your eagerness? Do you take it gingerly to demonstrate respect? Or do you opt for something more unique, like a secret handshake? According to Nilesh Dosa, a youth mentor at Ernst & Young, schools are failing to teach young people the fundamental skills they need to succeed in interviews, including proper handshaking techniques. "We're producing academically talented students who lack the essential skills for the workforce," he says. Etiquette consultant Jo Bryant agrees, emphasizing that a strong handshake is crucial in making a good impression. "You can have all the qualifications in the world, but if you enter an interview with poor body language, eye contact, and a weak handshake, you won't get the job," she warns. "Your interviewer needs to like you and want to be around you." So, what is the correct way to shake hands? Bryant advises: "Maintain eye contact, be firm, and ensure your palms are together. Avoid bone-crushing, but also don't be too limp - that's a sign of underconfidence." She notes that a handshake that's too limp can feel like an empty gesture, while one that's too firm can be seen as arrogant. And what about sweaty hands? Unfortunately, they're hard to avoid, but Bryant suggests striking a balance between confidence and humility to make a positive impression. "When interacting with someone, you can discreetly wipe your hands before meeting them, not in their presence. Avoid using dominating body language, such as placing your hand on top of theirs or clasping their forearm. Bryant advises being natural and not trying too hard, as this can come across as wooden. To improve your handshaking skills, she recommends practicing with a friend and seeking feedback. This may seem unusual, but it's similar to how you would practice other social skills. Just as you would with any other skill, you can practice handshaking with a friend and get feedback on whether you're doing it correctly."

Nine Entertainment has sold its Australian Community Media & Printing business, which includes the Canberra Times, the Illawarra Mercury, and other regional papers, to a company controlled by Antony Catalano and Thorney Investment Group for $115 million. The sale, expected to be completed by the end of June, includes the Newcastle Herald, the Land, and Queensland Country Life. The company will retain a commercial relationship with the new owners and will continue to print some of its metropolitan mastheads, such as the Sydney Morning Herald, in regional areas. According to Hugh Marks, CEO of Nine, the sale aligns with the company's strategy to exit non-core businesses and focus on its digital assets. Marks stated that Nine will continue to work with the new owners where there are mutual benefits to both parties.

Antony Catalano, the former boss of Domain, had previously attempted to block the sale of Fairfax to Nine by buying up to 19.9% of Fairfax shares. The deal includes $10 million worth of advertising for Nine in ACM properties over the next three years. The ACM group of newspapers was previously owned by Rural Press and was sold to Fairfax Media in 2007 for $3 billion.

Marks had flagged the potential sale of the community papers soon after the merger with Fairfax last year. Nine is still in the market to sell its remaining former Fairfax properties, Stuff and Events. Marks told staff that Catalano and Thorney Investment Group saw the "future potential" of the newspapers, which no longer fit into Nine's national advertising strategy. "'They have a unique opportunity to achieve their future goals in a way that a publicly traded company like Nine might not be able to,' Marks said. 'I think the change in ownership is a positive development and sets the company up for success in the future.' Media, Entertainment and Arts Alliance media director Katelin McInerney urged Catalano and Thorney to prioritize job security, fair working conditions, and editorial independence. 'There are approximately 650 editorial staff employed across the country by the ACM group,' McInerney said. 'It's crucial that the individual audiences for each of the group's mastheads are respected. 'The ACM mastheads have fiercely loyal readers. The newspapers must continue to provide local news, information, and entertainment to the communities they serve. Their readers are entitled to have local editorial content, not generic news generated elsewhere.'"

The phenomenon of alien abductions has been shrouded in mystery since at least the 1960s, with some people convinced of its existence. While some may dismiss it as a fringe belief, the US Navy is taking the matter seriously, reportedly preparing new guidelines to encourage pilots to report any "unexplained aerial phenomena" without fear of ridicule. The term "unidentified flying objects" is no longer sufficient; from now on, we'll refer to these events as "unexplained aerial phenomena."

The concept of alien abductions was popularized in the 1990s through TV shows like "The X-Files," which led many to believe that extraterrestrial life was real. However, it's been revealed that the characters Mulder and Scully were fictional, leaving some to wonder how people continue to claim alien abductions. The answer is simple: people are wrong. Or is it?

Dr. Young-hae Chi, a lecturer at Oxford University, takes the alien abduction theory seriously, despite not being a psychologist or materials scientist. He teaches Korean at the faculty of oriental studies, but has also spoken at conferences about the topic. In a 2012 lecture, he disputed the idea that visiting aliens have sinister plans to take over the world, instead proposing that their secret breeding program to create alien-human hybrids is a noble effort to save humanity from environmental disaster.

Dr. Chi has written a book expanding on his theories, but critics may question whether he has any concrete evidence to support his claims. While the recent warming of the Earth is well-documented, there is no scientific evidence to support the existence of an alien breeding program. While some alleged alien abductees claim to have experienced "sexually oriented actions with aliens or other human abductees under mind control," I remain skeptical. Apparently, some recall seeing jars containing hybrid toddlers and fetuses on the alleged alien spaceships. I acknowledge that these individuals may have undergone a traumatic experience, but is there any concrete evidence to support the existence of aliens? Unfortunately, the lack of detectable evidence may be due to the fact that aliens allegedly reside in a different dimension. This sounds similar to the concept of ghosts, which are also often associated with unexplained phenomena. While it's true that "the absence of evidence isn't evidence of absence," I believe it's also important to consider the quality of the evidence presented.

Russian oligarch Evgeny Lebedev, owner of the Evening Standard and the Independent, is in discussions to sell his struggling London Live TV station. Lebedev and his father, Alexander, won the highly competitive bid for the license to launch London's first dedicated TV channel six years ago, a prized asset in the government's plan to establish dozens of local TV channels across the UK. The license was considered the most valuable TV license to be awarded since Channel 5 in 1997. A glamorous launch party in 2014 featured high-profile guests, including David Cameron, George Osborne, Elizabeth Hurley, Hugh Grant, Naomi Campbell, Ralph Fiennes, Tracey Emin, and Anna Friel. Initially, the plan was for London Live to help drive profitability across the Lebedevs' media portfolio, but it has instead become a financial drain. Despite hopes that the station would break even by 2017, London Live has never turned a profit, accumulating losses of £30 million to date, according to Companies House filings. Lebedev is reportedly in talks with That's Media, which owns licenses for 20 local TV stations, including Manchester, Cambridge, and Oxford, about potentially selling London Live. That's Media has been building a network by acquiring struggling local TV franchises, including five from STV in Scotland and Mustard TV from Archant in 2017. Lebedev has also held talks with David Montgomery, former CEO of the Daily and Sunday Mirror, who is now a director at Made Television. The value of the loss-making London Live to an existing local TV operator is unclear, but Archant sold Mustard TV to That's Media in exchange for a small stake in the local TV group. A spokesperson for London Live stated, "The local television sector is rapidly evolving, and as a significant player in the largest UK market, we regularly receive approaches for the business." "We refrain from discussing private business matters in public, so we won't comment on any specific conversations. Lebedev began exploring potential sales or mergers with local TV rivals and larger broadcasters about a year ago for London Live. Since its launch five years ago, London Live has faced repeated rounds of job cuts and has made repeated requests to Ofcom, the local TV regulator, to scale back its commitments to local programming and news."

Researchers in Philadelphia have made a groundbreaking discovery, revealing that taste buds contain odor-detecting proteins, which challenges the long-held idea that smell and taste combine in the brain to create flavor. According to Dr. Mehmet Hakan Ozdener, this finding opens up the possibility of using scents to influence our food choices, such as adding a subtle aroma to food to make it taste sweeter and reduce sugar intake. When driving at night, many people experience a phenomenon called motion-induced blindness, where the red lights of cars in front of us temporarily disappear if we glance at oncoming traffic. This effect, first observed in a lab in 1965, occurs when the brain ignores visual information when it's presented against a moving background. A fascinating connection exists between hearing and vision in speech perception, known as the McGurk effect. When the auditory component of a syllable is paired with the visual component of another, it can create the perception of a third sound. The sight of cutlery can significantly impact how we perceive the flavor of food, according to research conducted by the University of Oxford in 2013. For example, yoghurt tastes sweeter when eaten with a white spoon compared to a black spoon. There is a surprising crossover between smell and sound in human perception, with various experiments showing that people can associate certain smells with musical instruments and pitches. University of Oxford researchers found that participants consistently paired specific smells with certain instruments and pitches, such as a piano being associated with a fruity scent and brass with a musky odor. This phenomenon is thought to be caused by the olfactory tubercle, an area of the brain that responds to both auditory and olfactory stimuli.

Adani does not possess water permits with sufficient capacity to meet the initial construction phase of the Carmichael coal project, according to its own water consumption modeling. Despite repeatedly claiming it is "ready to start" building the mine, Adani has publicly blamed the Queensland government for delays in approving necessary management plans. However, environmental groups argue that the shortfall in Adani's water permits is evidence that the company's readiness claims are unfounded and intended to exert political pressure on decision-makers. Public records show that Adani holds two short-term water permits, for Mistake Creek and the Belyando River, which expire in April and June this year. These permits allow the company to extract a combined 1775 megalitres of water. Adani's own modeling, completed by consultant CDM Smith, estimates that the Carmichael mine will require 3358ML of water during the first year of construction. Carmel Flint, from the environmental group Lock the Gate, stated that the new information suggests Adani does not have the necessary water permits to construct the mine, further evidence that its claims of being ready to start work are false. "Adani has created a fake sense of urgency for approvals ahead of the election and has achieved its goal of securing a rushed approval from the Morrison government, which was tainted by political interference," Flint said. In response, Adani stated that it has the necessary water permits required for mining operations, but did not address the project's construction phase specifically. The company also mentioned that it has alternative potential water sources for the mine site, including groundwater, rainwater, and recycled water. Tom Crothers, the former Queensland government general manager of water allocation and planning, stated that the amount of water Adani could access without additional permits would be a mere "puddle" and far from sufficient to make up for the shortfall. Adani's claims to be ready to start construction on the Carmichael coalmine have become a hot topic on the federal election campaign trail. Just before the government entered caretaker mode, the federal environment minister, Melissa Price, approved Adani's groundwater plans. This approval has allowed LNP politicians and candidates in Queensland to claim that the project is being delayed by the state Labor government, citing the need for state approval of key management plans. In response, Adani has intensified its advertising campaign, featuring billboards, print ads, and letterbox drops that criticize the Queensland government for "moving the goalposts". In a statement to Guardian Australia in March, Adani denied that its campaign was political, claiming instead that its goal was to inform Queenslanders about the true status of its project.

PepsiCo has faced backlash after suing four Indian farmers who allegedly grew a patented strain of potatoes used in its Lay's crisps without permission. The company initially sought damages of around $150,000 from each farmer, claiming they broke the law by sourcing and dealing the potatoes. However, when the case went to court in Ahmedabad, India, PepsiCo offered to settle the dispute amicably. The case has sparked outrage among farmers and others, who fear PepsiCo is using its influence to interfere with India's food supply. The role of foreign companies in producing and selling food in India is a contentious issue, particularly when it comes to genetically modified crops. According to Kapil Shah, an activist defending the farmers, the case is about "India's seed sovereignty, food sovereignty, and country sovereignty." He added that it's spreading panic among farmers.

Several farmers' groups in India have come together to protest the court action. Ambubhai Patel, vice-president of the Bharatiya Kisan Sangh, a farmers' association linked to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata party (BJP), said they are lobbying the government to support the accused farmers and punish those harassing other farmers. Patel warned that the government cannot allow such intimidation and vowed to fight against it in court and on the streets if necessary. PepsiCo claimed that the farmers who grew its patented potatoes without permission were hurting the interests of many people who work with the company to produce potatoes for its Lay's crisps. The company supplies seeds to these farmers and subsequently buys back the potatoes. In a statement, a PepsiCo spokesperson said, "PepsiCo is India's largest process-grade potato buyer and one of the first companies to work with thousands of local farmers to grow a specific protected variety of potatoes for our Lay's crisps." The company's spokesperson later clarified that they were forced to take legal action as a last resort, and are deeply committed to resolving the issue. PepsiCo has faced criticism in the past for its environmental impact, including a boycott in an Indian state in 2017 due to concerns over excessive water usage in its manufacturing process. The recent controversy has stirred up memories of the drought, with some commentators expressing concerns that PepsiCo may be using the legal system to punish individuals who use the same groundwater used in their products. As one journalist, Ravi Nair, pointed out on Twitter, "Let's hope PepsiCo won't sue people for using the same groundwater used in Pepsi."

Barclays has reduced bonuses for its investment bankers and traders due to lower first-quarter profits, which were impacted by challenging market conditions. The bank reported a pre-tax profit of £1.5 billion for the January-to-March period, a decrease from £1.7 billion in the same period last year, but in line with City analysts' expectations. This figure excludes litigation and conduct charges, which would have resulted in a £1.5 billion profit compared to a £236 million loss in the same period last year. The bank's investment banking division has been under pressure from activist investor Edward Bramson, who is pushing for cost cuts and a seat on the board. Bramson, who owns 5.5% of Barclays' shares, will challenge CEO Jes Staley at the bank's annual general meeting next week. Barclays' international business, which includes the investment bank, saw a decline in pre-tax profit to £1.1 billion, while its UK business reported a rise in profits to £600 million, driven by strong mortgage applications. Staley stated that the bank cut bonuses to reduce costs and is "very comfortable" with its cost targets, which amounted to £3.3 billion in the first quarter. The bank took a £400 million charge in 2016 to align bonuses with revenues. "We are using our discretion around variable compensation to manage our costs and deliver expected profitability," Staley said. Barclays has indicated that it will implement further cost cuts if market conditions remain tough. Last month, Tim Throsby was removed as head of the investment bank after reportedly disagreeing with Staley over his profit targets. Following Throsby's departure, Staley took on a more hands-on role in managing the division. Staley has announced plans for future share buybacks, which would mark the first since he became CEO in 2015, although he did not provide a specific timeline. In regards to Brexit, Staley stated, "Everyone would like to put the uncertainty surrounding Brexit behind us, but it appears that it will not happen anytime soon."

I've had trouble getting my deposits back from SodaStream. When you order a gas cartridge online and pay a £10 deposit, they promise to refund it when you return the empty cartridge for recycling. However, I've had to chase them four times, and in three cases, they insisted they didn't owe me anything. The latest issue took several weeks to resolve. I use SodaStream to reduce my use of plastic sparkling water bottles, but this hassle is leaving a bad taste. RZ, Arundel, West Sussex

The Guardian's Consumer Champions wonder if SodaStream is struggling to keep up with the increased business due to the backlash against single-use plastic water bottles. It's strange that they offer an incentive for recycling, but customers have to jump through hoops to get their money back. SodaStream claims to have a dedicated UK-based team for customer inquiries, aiming to respond within two working days, although they sometimes fail to meet this standard. They're hiring more staff and investing in new technology to improve their service. Customers are advised to keep receipts in case of any issues, as this can help with investigations. We understand that your refund has been processed, and SodaStream has apologized. We welcome letters, but due to the volume, we cannot respond individually.
