My dear friend George Richardson, who has passed away at the age of 94, spent the majority of his professional life at Oxford University, where he served as the chief executive of Oxford University Press (OUP) from the mid-1970s to the late 1980s. Born in Cricklewood, north London, to Christina, a homemaker, and George, a businessman, he attended Banff grammar and Aberdeen central schools before studying mathematics and physics at Aberdeen University. After completing his studies, he joined the Admiralty's scientific research department in London, where he worked during World War II. Following the war, he returned to Oxford to pursue a second degree in philosophy, politics, and economics at Corpus Christi College. After a brief stint at the Foreign Office, he was elected a fellow of St John's College, Oxford, where he became a popular and respected tutor. He was a champion of reform in college affairs and was known for his ebullient personality. In 1974, he became the chief executive of OUP, a position he held until his retirement in 1988. During his tenure, he transformed the organization, enabling it to thrive despite economic challenges. After his retirement, he became the warden of Keble College, Oxford, and played a key role in shaping its future. In his later years, he was a frequent guest at various Oxford colleges, where he was beloved for his kindness, wit, and generosity of spirit. He was also a devoted husband to Isabel Chalk, with whom he had two sons, Graham and Andrew, and four grandchildren.

Fox News has issued an apology after a guest, Michael Knowles, made a disparaging comment about 16-year-old climate activist Greta Thunberg, calling her a "mentally ill Swedish child". Knowles appeared on Fox News's The Story on Monday, where he launched a scathing attack on Thunberg, who is currently campaigning in the US to raise awareness about the climate crisis. This was not the first time a Fox News personality had criticized Thunberg, as Laura Ingraham had previously compared her to the characters in Stephen King's horror story Children of the Corn. Thunberg had given a powerful speech at the United Nations summit, accusing world leaders of betraying young people by failing to take action on the climate crisis. Knowles, who was invited to discuss Thunberg's speech and the climate crisis, was dismissive of both, stating that if the issue were truly about science, it would be led by scientists, not politicians and a "mentally ill Swedish child" who is being exploited by her parents and the international left. Fellow commentator Christopher Hahn immediately criticized Knowles, saying, "You're a grown man attacking a child. Shame on you." A Fox News spokesperson subsequently apologized to Thunberg and viewers, calling Knowles's comment "disgraceful". Fox News has also announced that it has no plans to book Knowles as a guest in the future. Meanwhile, the channel has remained silent on Ingraham's previous attack on Thunberg, in which she incorrectly suggested that Thunberg wanted people to "cede control of our economy, our way of life, our way of transport, how many children you want to have, and if we don't go along, we will be punished by our own children". Stephen King has no sequel titled "Children of the Climate", as the title is a fictional creation. However, King's novel "The Children of the Corn" tells the story of a group of children in a remote town who believe anyone over the age of 19 should be killed. Meanwhile, Curtis Ingraham, the brother of conservative commentator Laura Ingraham, quickly responded to her recent statements, accusing her of making right-wing pronouncements for financial gain. He stated: "It's clear that my sister's paycheck takes precedence over the world her three adopted children will inherit. I can no longer apologize for a sibling I no longer recognize. Instead, I will continue to speak out against her monstrous behavior and bullying commentary, which stems from her anger."

The UK's accountancy regulator, the Financial Reporting Council (FRC), is urgently considering whether to investigate the collapse of Thomas Cook and impose penalties if necessary. The FRC has the authority to investigate and sanction auditors and accounting professionals who are members of the profession. The regulator announced its consideration of an investigation after the government expedited the Insolvency Service's probe into Thomas Cook's collapse. Thomas Cook's auditor is EY, which took over from PwC in 2017. Both EY and PwC are among the UK's four largest accountancy firms. Thomas Cook has had a series of finance chiefs over the past two years as its financial struggles deepened, and it has faced questions about its accounting methods. Sten Daugaard became chief financial officer in December 2018, replacing Bill Scott, who quit after less than a year due to Thomas Cook's profit warning. Scott had replaced Michael Healy in January 2018, who had served as CFO for five years. The FRC stated, "In light of recent developments at Thomas Cook, we are considering whether there is a case for investigation and enforcement action as a matter of urgency, in cooperation with the Insolvency Service." Daugaard changed Thomas Cook's accounting practices to include items that had been treated as exceptional costs for several years, including payments to directors and meeting banking covenants. EY disagreed with Thomas Cook's treatment of these items. In its first-half results reported in November, Thomas Cook recognized £28m in charges, including a £14m write-off of payments from hotels and £14m in flight disruption and business transformation costs. Daugaard told analysts in November that when he reviewed the company's books, he noticed the significant size of the exceptional costs. In May, Thomas Cook reported a £1.5bn first-half loss and issued its third profit warning in less than a year. The company had £1.2bn in debt and was forced to write down the value of its MyTravel UK package holiday business by £1.1bn. In its May accounts, EY expressed "significant doubt" about whether Thomas Cook could continue as a going concern. Thomas Cook ceased operations in the early hours of Monday, leaving 9,000 UK jobs in jeopardy and stranding 150,000 British tourists abroad. In response, the Civil Aviation Authority has launched a temporary airline, utilizing 40 chartered jets, to facilitate the return of stranded travelers. The Financial Reporting Council's enforcement division conducts investigations and may bring legal action against auditors, actuaries, and accountants if there is evidence of misconduct or a breach of professional standards.

As thousands of holidaymakers waited in overseas airports for the government's emergency airlift to bring them home, and Thomas Cook staff faced job losses, the company's former bosses came under fire for receiving payouts worth over £35 million over the past 12 years. Manny Fontenla-Novoa, who led the acquisition spree that left Thomas Cook with over £1 billion in debt, received more than £17 million during his nearly four-year tenure as CEO, boosted by bonuses awarded for slashing 2,800 jobs following the merger with MyTravel. He departed in 2011 as the company teetered on the brink of collapse. His successor, Harriet Green, was paid £4.7 million for less than three years, plus a share bonus worth an additional £5.6 million. She donated a third of the bonus to charity after the tragic deaths of two children from carbon monoxide poisoning in Thomas Cook accommodations in Corfu. Green also claimed £80,000 annually to cover her hotel expenses at the five-star Brown's hotel in London, where she resided during the week. Peter Fankhauser, who was at the helm when the company went bankrupt, received £8.3 million, including £4.3 million in bonuses. Labour's shadow chancellor, John McDonnell, urged Thomas Cook bosses to "examine their consciences," while the party's shadow minister of consumer affairs, Gill Furniss, called on them to return their bonuses. Meanwhile, a group of international hedge funds that bet against Thomas Cook have profited from its collapse. Nearly 11% of the company's shares were "shorted" ahead of its collapse. Short-sellers borrow shares in a company, sell them, and then buy them back at a lower price to pocket the profit. Two hedge funds, London-based TT International and Minneapolis-based Whitebox Advisers, made up the bulk of the shorts, holding around 7% of the company's shares, according to ShortTracker data. "Hedge funds other than Thomas Cook are poised to reap a significant gain from their investments in credit default swaps, a type of insurance that provides a payout when a company fails to meet its debt obligations. If Thomas Cook had successfully negotiated a deal over the weekend, these investments would have been essentially worthless. However, following the company's collapse, credit default swap payouts are now expected to total $250 million (£201 million), according to reports from Bloomberg."

Budweiser, a leading brewing company, is set to eliminate single-use plastic pack rings from its entire range of UK-produced beers, including top-selling brands Stella Artois, Budweiser, and Bud Light, by the end of 2020. To achieve this, the company is investing £6.3 million in upgrading its two UK factories to produce eco-friendly alternatives, such as recyclable paperboard and biodegradable wraps and boxes. This move is expected to reduce plastic waste by 850 tonnes annually, equivalent to the weight of 425 black cabs, 67 double-decker buses, or 10 blue whales. The switch will involve removing 250 tonnes of plastic rings used to hold beer can packs together (117 million plastic rings in total) and 600 tonnes of shrink film used for additional packaging around trays during shipping. As part of AB InBev, the world's largest brewer, Budweiser Brewing Group UK & Ireland produces over 870 million cans of beer each year and has a portfolio of popular brands, including Beck's, Bud Light, Budweiser, Corona, Michelob Ultra, and Stella Artois. Paula Lindenberg, president of Budweiser Brewing Group UK & Ireland, said: "This announcement ensures that the UK's favorite beers will soon come in recyclable paperboard packaging, empowering consumers to make more sustainable choices. We're proud of our progress so far, but we recognize that more needs to be done to address the issue of single-use plastics." The company is also committing to using 100% locally sourced barley and 100% renewable electricity generated from solar power. By removing plastic rings from all its UK products, including the popular Stella Artois pint can four-pack, Budweiser hopes to make a significant impact in reducing plastic waste on supermarket shelves. Plastic pack rings, also known as hi-cones or yokes, have been a standard packaging device for over 50 years but have become an environmental concern due to their contribution to ocean pollution and harm to marine life. Last year, Carlsberg announced plans to replace plastic rings with recyclable glue, highlighting the industry's growing efforts to find sustainable alternatives. Diageo is transitioning away from plastic packaging in multipacks of its Guinness, Harp, Rockshore, and Smithwick's beers, replacing it with fully recyclable and biodegradable cardboard packs. In a recent announcement, Coca-Cola revealed plans to abandon plastic shrink wrap packaging for multipack soft drink cans in western Europe, opting instead for 100% recyclable cardboard. The new cardboard multipacks will be rolled out for four, six, and eight packs of cans across all brands, including Coca-Cola, Diet Coke, Dr Pepper, Fanta, Lilt, and Sprite.

Autumn in the northern hemisphere is often marked by the appearance of one star in particular: Fomalhaut. As we approach September 23rd, now is a great time to start searching for this distinctive bluish-white star. The chart below shows the view at midnight on September 23rd (BST), looking south. With a clear horizon, Fomalhaut will appear as a solitary figure, its brightness standing out against the surrounding darkness. This isolation has earned it the nickname "the loneliest star". Despite being twice the size and mass of the sun, Fomalhaut outshines our star by a factor of 16, emitting a dazzling amount of light. Located just 25 light years away, it's a relatively close neighbor. Fomalhaut is the brightest star in the faint constellation of Piscis Austrinus, which can be challenging to spot from northern latitudes due to its faintness and low position in the sky. The star's Arabic name, "mouth of the whale", is a literal translation.

Thomas Cook customers in Tunisia were locked inside a resort in Hammamet by a hotel owner who was concerned that the struggling travel firm might not be able to pay its bills. The standoff occurred at the Orangers hotel, where guests were not allowed to leave until they paid a 6,000 Tunisian dinar (£1,680) fee. According to reports, buses sent to transport the holidaymakers to the airport at Enfidha were turned away by security. Maddie Clamp, 26, and her boyfriend Shaun Holmes, 30, from Derby, described being locked within their holiday complex as management tried to secure payment from their guests. "They wouldn't even let us out of the hotel," Holmes said. However, by Sunday, the standoff had been resolved and guests were allowed to leave. A local Thomas Cook representative worked late into the night and returned on Sunday morning to address guests' urgent queries. The company stated that any guests who had paid the hotel had been refunded. A Thomas Cook spokesperson said: "We are aware that a small number of customers were asked to pay for their hotel room before leaving Les Orangers in Tunisia. This has now been resolved and customers flew home as planned. We continue to support our customers in all our resorts." Lynn and Peter Taylor from Newcastle, who had traveled to Tunisia with Thomas Cook, reported that guests leaving the hotel had been asked for extra payment. "Those who were due to leave today had letters slipped under their door," said Lynn Taylor. "The hotel was asking for 6,000 TD. I think one old lady paid it. We didn't." The hotel refused to comment on its communication with Thomas Cook, only confirming that guests are now free to enter and leave the premises. Tunisia's tourism industry is still recovering from the devastating impact of two terror attacks in 2015, which severely damaged the sector and resulted in the mass killing of predominantly British tourists at the Hotel Rui Imperial Marhaba near Sousse. The UK was particularly affected, as a government travel warning was in place from June 2015 to July 2017, advising against travel to Tunisia. Thomas Cook was one of the first companies to resume flights to Tunisia, announcing its return in February 2018. The British consulate in Tunis is aware of the situation and is providing assistance as needed.

A public servant in the home affairs department has expressed concerns to Parliament that the department's whistleblowing scheme is ineffective, citing a failed investigation into a staffing incident involving a senior executive. The anonymous submission to the Senate committee on press freedom alleges that a public interest disclosure (PID) was made in 2017 regarding an issue with hiring practices involving a senior executive. However, instead of conducting an independent investigation, the report was sent back to the department for handling. The outcome of the investigation is unclear. The government has repeatedly emphasized the importance of the public interest disclosure process for reporting issues, rather than leaking information to the media. Home Affairs Secretary Michael Pezzullo has stated that the department will investigate and prosecute public servants who leak sensitive information to the public. According to Pezzullo, department officers are trained to report issues through three channels: internal disclosure, the ombudsman, or the Australian Commission for Law Enforcement Integrity (Aclei). The submission reveals that the public servant initially contacted Aclei and the ombudsman, but the matter was ultimately handled internally. The submission states that the PID report was made to the ombudsman, which referred the matter back to the department. An executive-level assistant director was assigned to investigate, but there was no communication with the whistleblower for four months. The submission questions the independence of the investigation, suggesting that it would be unlikely for an executive-level investigator to make adverse findings against a senior executive. The submission concludes that the department's handling of the matter was flawed and lacked an independent investigation. "When it comes to reports involving senior executives, it's crucial that there is a higher level of independent scrutiny and ongoing oversight of the ombudsman or a national integrity commission, especially if the ombudsman chooses not to investigate PID reports. A public servant with over 30 years of experience in the sector described the situation as 'worthy of an episode of ABC's Utopia', where the Australian Federal Police (AFP) is called in by the department head in home affairs to investigate leaks that harm the minister for home affairs, such as the au pairs saga. The Guardian has reached out to the home affairs department for a response."

Marks & Spencer is set to introduce a "buy now, pay later" service on its website next month, aiming to attract younger customers and boost sales ahead of the crucial Christmas period. The retailer has partnered with Clearpay to offer customers the option of paying for orders over £30 in interest-free instalments. Clearpay, an Australian firm, is one of the fintech companies that has gained popularity among millennials on tight budgets, along with its rival Klarna. Many of M&S's competitors, including H&M and Asos, already offer delayed payment services, and the struggling business is eager to attract a younger generation of shoppers, including families with young children. M&S says its customers are increasingly seeking ways to spread the cost of larger purchases, and the Clearpay service enables them to do so by spreading the total over four instalments paid back across six weeks. The maximum spend is £800, and customers can manage their payments through a phone app without needing to apply for credit. Unlike traditional credit products, fintech firms like Clearpay and Klarna make money by earning commission on the sales transaction, although some also offer interest-bearing products. Shoppers who use these plans tend to spend more frequently, making it an attractive proposition for retailers like M&S, where clothing sales are declining. Over 4,000 UK retailers, including Asos, JD Sports, and Boohoo, work with Klarna, which has more than 3 million British customers. Clearpay, which launched in the UK just three months ago, has already gained over 200,000 active customers. However, not everyone is a fan of this form of credit. Simon Wolfson, CEO of Next, has expressed concerns that it might be dangerous, saying that there is a difference between spreading the cost and just deferring it. "Sue Anderson, a representative from the debt charity Stepchange, expressed concern that these payment plans may inadvertently encourage individuals to spend money they don't have. 'These services are marketed to consumers as a convenient option to "try before you buy", but the unintended consequence is that people may take on debt they wouldn't have otherwise considered.'"

Two years ago, Thames Water unexpectedly and without warning declared our residential rental property a commercial property and transferred our account to Castle Water. We were only informed that Castle Water was our new provider, without being told the reason behind the change. Since our direct debit was automatically transferred, we continued to pay without questioning the change. It wasn't until I notified Castle Water of our upcoming move that we discovered they believed we were a commercial customer. We are a family of two adults and a baby. After being assured that the mistake would be corrected and that Thames Water would reclaim the money we'd paid, we received two bills from Thames Water totaling almost £1,000. We have yet to receive a refund from Castle Water, which means we would have to pay for our water twice. I also submitted a complaint to the Consumer Council for Water, but have yet to receive a response.

As one of many customers caught up in the acquisition of Thames Water's business accounts by Castle Water, I was not clearly informed of the reason for the transfer of accounts. However, after your intervention, Thames Water has acknowledged that an administrative error led to our property being listed as non-household rather than domestic, resulting in our account being transferred to Castle Water. Thames Water has apologized for the confusion and is working with Castle Water to ensure we are not left out of pocket.

Castle Water has since refunded us £818, based on their tariff, but the bill from Thames Water was £874. Thames Water is currently offering us an installment plan. The Consumer Council for Water reports that Castle Water has consistently exceeded the industry average for complaints over the past 18 months. We appreciate your letters, but due to the volume, we are unable to respond to each one individually. If you'd like to share your thoughts, you can email us at consumer.champions@theguardian.com or write to Consumer Champions, Money, The Guardian, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Please include your daytime phone number. Please note that all submissions are subject to our terms and conditions, which govern the publication of letters.

The festive food industry is facing a potential crisis due to Brexit-related labor shortages in the meat industry. According to the National Pig Association, some specialist processing plants that require additional seasonal labor for hand-finished products are already struggling to meet orders. The majority of meat processing plants are experiencing labor shortages equivalent to up to 15% of their required workforces, while seasonal specialists are facing shortages of up to 30%. The fall in the value of the pound since the 2016 referendum, combined with uncertainty about residential status, has contributed to the labor shortages.

Ed Barker, senior policy advisor of the NPA, reported that several processors who relied on regular semi-skilled laborers from Europe are struggling to fulfill orders ahead of Christmas. "It's been difficult for the past two years, but it seems particularly squeezed this year," Barker said. "Three years of uncertainty and the fall in the sterling to euro exchange rate has changed the mind of a lot of laborers who have decided to return home." The British Poultry Council stated that its members are about 20% short of regular staff, and seasonal specialists, such as turkey and goose producers, are under pressure due to difficulties in hiring up to 2,000 extra workers usually required ahead of Christmas.

The concerns about meat production come after it was revealed that thousands of tonnes of fruit and vegetables are being left to rot in UK fields due to a shortage of pickers and packers caused by continuing Brexit uncertainty. Last month, some fruit farmers reported having 30% fewer workers than required, highlighting the severity of the issue.

Luxury department store Fortnum & Mason has announced another year of impressive sales and profits, but its newly opened Hong Kong store has been affected by the ongoing pro-democracy protests. Despite this, CEO Ewan Venters remains optimistic, citing strong bookings for its restaurant, which offers stunning views of Hong Kong Harbour, with 4,000 reservations made for December alone. The store, which is the company's first standalone location outside the UK, has seen sales in the territory fall to half of what was expected, but Venters is confident that business will recover. The retailer, which was founded in 1707, is known for its high-end products such as smoked salmon and caviar, with customers spending up to HK$7,000 (approximately £694) on these items. When asked about the wisdom of opening a store in Hong Kong during a time of turmoil, Venters replied, "We're an English brand that goes out into the world to sell tea, biscuits, and jam. It's not our place to get overly political." In addition to its standalone store, Fortnum & Mason also has concessions in several other Asian department stores, including Lane Crawford in Hong Kong, Isetan Mitsukoshi in Japan, and Shinsegae in South Korea. The company's flagship store is located on Piccadilly in central London. Fortnum & Mason's profits rose 26% to £12m in the year ending July 2019, with total sales increasing 12% to £138m. The group's flagship shop on Piccadilly saw a 6% increase in sales, while online sales grew by 13%. The company has benefited from a trend towards upmarket tea consumption, with tea sales rising 11% due to the popularity of unusual flavors such as chocolate violet and pistachio and clotted cream. New products like sparkling tea, made from a blend of black, white, and green teas, have also boosted tea sales, offering an alternative to alcohol.

I am writing in response to your article 'One in five pupils granted more time to sit key exams' (22 November). If we are genuinely committed to inclusion and accessibility for all, we must reevaluate the excessive time spent testing children and young people to identify their 'abnormal' needs before taking written exams. Instead, we should recognize that it is natural for everyone to work at different speeds and provide each individual with the time they need to complete the task.

One possible solution could be to set an average time limit for each exam, with the option for students to request an additional 30% time if needed. This approach aligns with the principles of the Equality Act 2010, which requires educational institutions to promote equality of opportunity between individuals with and without protected characteristics.

I hope this suggestion sparks a productive debate. I look forward to reading the thoughts of other Guardian readers on this important topic. You can join the discussion by emailing guardian.letters@theguardian.com or sharing your photos with us for publication in our print edition.

Ikea's parent company, Inter Ikea Group, is planning to invest an additional €200 million (£171 million) in green energy and forest planting to help the world's largest furniture retailer become carbon neutral by 2030. The investment will be made in two phases, with the first phase of €100 million dedicated to new renewable energy projects, including heating, cooling, and electricity generation, in partnership with suppliers and in areas of the supply chain where converting to renewable energy is more challenging. The second phase will focus on removing and storing carbon through reforestation and responsible forest management, with consideration given to tropical and subtropical regions where there is a high demand for reforestation and forests grow faster.

Inter Ikea Group has already made significant investments in sustainability, with plans to spend at least €3 billion on such initiatives. Since 2009, the company has invested close to €2.5 billion in renewable energy, owning 534 wind turbines and 715,000 solar panels in 14 countries, as well as 920,000 solar panels on store rooftops. Additionally, the company has invested in over 26,000 hectares of forest land, mostly in the US and Lithuania, taking its total ownership of responsibly managed forests to 208,700 hectares (about 2,000 square kilometers) in five countries.

Ingka Group, which operates 374 Ikea stores in 30 countries, has also made efforts to reduce its environmental impact, including investing in a plastics recycling plant, textile and mattress recycling, and trialing the sale of used, patched-up furniture in the UK. "Ingka Group is on course to generate as much renewable energy as it consumes in its operations by next year, thanks to its investments. According to Lena Pripp-Kovac, chief sustainability officer of Inter Ikea Group, the company believes that reducing greenhouse gas emissions is crucial in limiting climate change to 1.5°C. However, she emphasized that removing existing carbon from the atmosphere is also essential. Pripp-Kovac highlighted the company's potential to make a positive impact through its integrated supply chain, global presence, and expertise in forestry and climate issues."

A power outage struck the ABC's Ultimo headquarters, causing the ABC News website, app, and in some cases, the homepage to display stories from 2011. On Wednesday morning, ABC readers were greeted with a retro formatting that showed Julia Gillard as the prime minister, Lady Gaga performing in Sydney, and the Australian dollar nearly at parity with the US. The ABC Breakfast program broadcast a still image of a chicken for 15 seconds, but it was unclear if this was due to the power outage. By 10am AEDT, the entire online news front page was down, but those who had visited earlier saw archived homepages. Some users were automatically redirected to a mobile version of the site, which showed up-to-date articles but with no images and 2011-era fonts. Others who weren't redirected or manually clicked to the desktop version could see a version of the site from the early 2010s. For example, the business front page had the headline "Carbon, mining taxes won't stop investment," while the entertainment page reported that Lady Gaga had surprised Sydney fans with two shows and asked "Oprah to host Oscars?" At 10am AEDT, the front page was entirely down, with an error message stating "WEBSITE OUTAGE. We are currently experiencing a technical outage, which means we are unable to provide our usual service." The Ultimo building was plunged into darkness, and ABC News Mornings host Joe O'Brien and his colleagues prepared their morning briefings in an eerie half-light. ABC Radio National host Matt Bevan shared a video of the ABC's emergency generator in action. By 11am, the front page was back, but in a new format that displayed as a giant live blog with stories as individual posts. An hour later, the website was back to normal. A statement from the ABC attributed the difficulties to power fluctuations from their supplier overnight, which affected some of their systems. The ABC's website and news app were impacted, and alternative programming was being broadcast on digital radio. Meanwhile, the ABC's TV broadcast, terrestrial radio, and online radio broadcasts continued uninterrupted. Although the front page of the ABC's website was inaccessible, up-to-date news articles remained available online through their URLs or Google search results, although they appeared in the 2011 format.

On Friday, approximately 200 employees gathered outside Google's San Francisco office, calling for the reinstatement of two suspended worker activists. By Monday, one of the suspended workers, Rebecca Rivers, had been fired, with reports suggesting that three other Google employees had also been let go. Rivers, a software engineer at Google who had been involved in internal protests against the company's work with US Customs and Border Protection, announced her termination on Twitter. According to an internal memo obtained by Bloomberg, three other Google employees were also fired on Monday, with the company's security and investigations team citing "clear and repeated violations of our data security policies" as the reason. Google confirmed the accuracy of the memo but declined to comment further. The firings sparked immediate allegations of retaliation from current and former Google employees. Meredith Whittaker, one of the organizers of the walkout, described Rivers' firing as "craven retaliation" on Twitter, while Stephanie Parker, a current YouTube employee, called the terminations "inhumane" and "illegal". Whittaker and another organizer, Claire Stapleton, had previously left Google after alleging that they had been retaliated against by management. At the rally on Friday, Rivers had expressed pride in her actions, stating that she believed everyone had the right to know what their work was used for. The public protest and firings are the latest signs of growing labor unrest at Google, which has seen an increase in employee activism over the past two years. Many employees have been demanding a say in how their work is used, as well as their rights as workers. Google employees have voiced their discontent with several company projects, including a contract to supply AI technology to the US Department of Defense's drone program, a censored search engine for China, and cloud services to the fossil fuel industry. A notable example of employee dissatisfaction was the walkout by approximately 20,000 employees over the company's handling of sexual harassment cases. Many employees have also spoken out about Google's extensive use of subcontracted workers, who often have fewer rights and benefits than regular employees. In a strongly-worded Medium post on Monday night, a group of worker-organizers expressed their outrage at the company's actions. They accused Google of illegal retaliation against employees who are exercising their right to organize, describing it as "classic union busting" and vowing to resist it.

The Fearless Girl statue has taken on many meanings for many people. The 4-foot bronze sculpture of a defiant young girl, hands on hips, facing down the status quo, has been both criticized as a cynical marketing stunt and celebrated as a symbol of new feminism. Now, she is at the center of a court battle to stop her from being replicated worldwide. The original Fearless Girl appeared overnight in March 2017, just before International Women's Day, in downtown New York, standing opposite the Charging Bull statue near Wall Street. Commissioned by State Street Global, an asset management company, the sculpture was intended to promote a fund investing in companies with diverse gender representation. It quickly became a sensation, drawing crowds of selfie-takers. Even Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren, a long-time critic of Wall Street and a leading contender for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, used the statue to promote her policies. Sculptor Kristen Visbal has since created multiple copies of Fearless Girl, which now stand in cities such as London and Oslo. However, on Monday, State Street took legal action to stop the Fearless Girl from spreading further, seeking to have a statue removed from Federation Square in Melbourne. In a lawsuit against Maurice Blackburn, the Australian personal injury firm that commissioned the Melbourne piece, State Street argues that the replicas violate its trademark and dilute its message. According to the New York Times, State Street's lawyer, David Studdy, claimed that Maurice Blackburn used the Fearless Girl campaign to promote itself. State Street has also sued Visbal, the sculptor, for making other copies, citing trademark violations. Visbal's lawyers argue that State Street's moves are designed to "rob her of making a living from her art." The statue has been a mixed blessing for State Street, raising its profile but also highlighting its own record on gender equality. In October 2017, State Street paid $5 million to settle charges that it had underpaid about 300 women in its employ. "According to a report by the Guardian, State Street had a history of rejecting gender equality proposals at several prominent companies, including Alphabet (the parent company of Google), American Express, and Bank of America, all of which are among the world's largest corporations."

Over 40,000 academic staff are expected to participate in eight days of strikes starting on Monday, protesting against pension, pay, and condition issues. The action will impact over a million students across 60 campuses. The University and College Union (UCU) has accused universities of using "strong-arm tactics" to undermine the strike. Social media has been filled with outrage over universities' attempts to deter students from joining picket lines and encouraging them to report striking lecturers.

Last February, the largest ever industrial action in the UK's universities took place, with lecturers and other staff members participating in a 14-day strike. The strike caused significant disruptions for students, with some calling for compensation.

We want to hear from you about your experiences and opinions regarding the ongoing strikes. If you're an academic staff member participating in the strike, what are the key reasons for your decision to do so? How do you feel about having to go on strike for the second time? We're also interested in hearing from international students about how you're being affected by the strikes. Additionally, we want to hear from students who have been impacted by the strikes: do you support your lecturers' actions? Are you planning to join them on the picket line? Do you think students should receive compensation?

You can share your responses with us anonymously, if you prefer, by filling out the encrypted form below. Only the Guardian will see your responses. Please leave your contact details, as one of our journalists may be in touch to discuss further. If you're having trouble using the form, click here.

This week, staff at 60 universities across the UK will participate in a strike led by the University and College Union (UCU), with the full backing of the National Union of Students (NUS). While the NUS supports the strike, not all students agree with the decision, with many expressing criticism towards the lecturers. Within hours of the strike announcement, a petition was launched to demand reimbursement for lost contact hours, with many students concerned about the potential impact on their end-of-term grades. Some students feel that they are paying tuition fees and therefore expect a full term of teaching, while others are frustrated about the lost time and the potential effect on their grades.

However, it's essential to recognize that the frustration is mutual between staff and students. Both parties feel that universities are becoming impersonal and poorly run, with staff being treated like employees in a business rather than educators. Instead of directing our anger towards the lecturers, we should focus on the institutions that are forcing them to strike. It's not as if tuition fees are solely spent on tutors' salaries; in fact, academics' pay has fallen by 17% in real terms since 2009.

Furthermore, more than half of academics are on temporary contracts, which adds to their daily stress and contributes to the "epidemic" of poor mental health among higher education staff, according to a recent report. The UCU also reports a 15% gender pay gap and a decline in pensions due to changes to the Universities Superannuation Scheme (USS). Under these conditions, it's unrealistic to expect students to receive the best education possible.

As NUS vice president Claire Sosienski-Smith noted, "Students won't be happy about missing lectures, but they're not happy about studying in institutions where their staff are underpaid and overworked." It's not accurate to assume that this strike will damage our university careers. Many lecturers are ensuring their students won't be abandoned, and some are even leaving pre-prepared work and practical tips to help students make the most of the lost time. "Lecturers demonstrate a genuine concern for the academic well-being of their students. It's a testament to their dedication that they undertake such a demanding role without adequate recognition. The success of this strike hinges on universities recognizing that students stand firmly behind their lecturers and acknowledge the need for change. As students, we have a crucial role to play in sustaining these strikes, maintaining pressure to achieve fairer working conditions. I intend to hold my vice-chancellor accountable by asking what measures they are taking to address the issue. - Joshua Curiel, 19-year-old student at the University of Kent"
