The Bank of England's summer party expenses have crept closer to £100,000 this year, despite the bank's promise to review the costly event. According to figures released by the central bank, the party planners racked up a bill of £96,188 for the event, which was held at the Bank's sports club in Roehampton, south-west London, and hosted nearly 2,500 staff and their families in July. The costs included £52,200 on food and soft drinks, £30,000 on family entertainment, and nearly £2,000 for equipment and £12,000 for "other" undisclosed expenses. The total cost of £96,188 is slightly higher than the £95,673 spent on the event in 2018, raising questions about the bank's commitment to reviewing its expenses. In May, the Bank's board members were questioned by MPs about their expenses, including the summer party bill. Dorothy Thompson, a Court director, defended the party, saying it was an annual event that cost £40 per head and did not include alcohol. However, she also acknowledged that the Bank was looking to cut costs and that the event was under review. The Bank has already planned to shut its 32-acre sports ground and lease it to a commercial operator to cut costs. As a result, the 2019 Governors' Day was likely the last to be held at the plush sports centre. The Bank's incoming governor, Andrew Bailey, who takes over in March, will need to find a new venue if the event continues in 2020. The Bank of England made significant changes to its employee benefits last year, including reducing meal and hotel allowances, following a controversy over a £390,000 travel bill incurred by two economics advisers over a period of two-and-a-half years. The advisers, Anil Kashyap and Donald Kohn, were found to have submitted questionable expenses, with Kashyap claiming £11,000 for a flight from Chicago to London and Kohn submitting expenses for an £8,000 flight from Washington to London, as well as £469 for taxis for a single meeting. The Bank of England released a statement defending its Governors' Day tradition, which is open to all employees and their families, saying it aims to recognize their hard work and dedication. When contacted for further comment, the Bank of England declined to provide additional information.

I had the pleasure of attending the BBC film directors' training course in 1974 alongside Diarmuid Lawrence, who left a lasting impression on me not only as a talented creative person but also as a kind and compassionate individual. During the course, I had the opportunity to work with him on an exercise based on a script I had written, and I was impressed by his exceptional acting skills - I often thought he would have made a successful career as an actor, perhaps even as a diplomat. One of our instructors, an older lecturer, made some outdated comments about how to light a woman to make her appear "soft and feminine" and how to emphasize a man's jawline to make him look "strong." A determined feminist on the course repeatedly challenged these comments, sparking a heated debate among some of the men, who grew frustrated and exclaimed, "Can't we just get on with it?" The atmosphere became tense until Diarmuid intervened, speaking in a calm and conciliatory tone that diffused the situation and restored harmony. I believe his remarkable people skills, demonstrated on that occasion, allowed him to elicit outstanding performances from a wide range of actors throughout his career, earning their respect and admiration.

Astronomers are puzzled by a series of mysterious radio wave bursts emanating from distant parts of the universe. For several years, scientists have been fascinated and perplexed by these sudden, low-frequency radiation events, which release more energy than the sun does in a day and vanish instantly. Known as Fast Radio Bursts (FRBs), these enigmatic signals appear at random and without warning, leaving astronomers unsure of when or where they will occur next. Over 60 FRBs have been recorded to date, with the only consensus being that they are unlikely to be extraterrestrial greetings. A breakthrough discovery was made a year ago when scientists identified a repeating radio signal and traced it to a dwarf galaxy 3 billion light-years from Earth. Further observations suggested that the burst was generated by extremely powerful magnetic fields, effectively ruling out the possibility of alien laser signals. A team of astronomers from several Canadian universities has now announced the discovery of a second repeating radio signal. The team's breakthrough came last summer, shortly after activating the Canadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment (CHIME) telescope in British Columbia. The findings were published in two papers in Nature and presented at a news conference at the American Astronomical Society meeting in Seattle on January 9.

The power struggle at NBCUniversal has begun. On Monday, the company announced a series of executive changes that could pave the way for the next generation of leaders at the media giant, which encompasses the NBC broadcast network, Universal Film Studios, and cable channels such as Bravo and MSNBC. The latter has experienced a surge in ratings during the Trump administration.

NBCUniversal CEO Stephen B. Burke has reorganized the management structure by appointing Jeff Shell to oversee Hollywood operations, including the international business and Telemundo, while Mark Lazarus will be in charge of the broadcast network, news division, cable networks, and sports group.

Bonnie Hammer, 68, who has led the company's successful cable portfolio for years, has been tasked with heading an advertising-supported streaming service, which is expected to launch early next year. This new service will compete with Disney's and WarnerMedia's upcoming stand-alone streaming products, as well as established players like Netflix and Hulu.

Industry insiders believe the moves are a strategic positioning by Burke to create a showdown between Lazarus and Shell for the top job. Effectively, Burke has created an East Coast-West Coast divide, with Lazarus controlling much of the company from NBC's New York and Stamford, Connecticut, offices, and Shell overseeing the Hollywood assets from Burbank, California.

In recent years, the scrutiny of Facebook's handling of consumer data has led the tech giant to repeatedly defend its efforts on transparency and privacy. However, a new study by the Pew Research Center reveals that nearly three-fourths of Facebook users are unaware that the company compiles and shares their personal traits and interests with advertisers on its platform. When users did discover this information on their "Ad Preferences" page, half of them felt uncomfortable with the company's collection of this data. The study, which surveyed 963 American adults with Facebook accounts, suggests that many consumers remain unaware of how much of their online behavior is tracked, where the data is compiled, and even that Facebook has a page that lists this information. Pew Research Center focused on Facebook, which also owns Instagram and WhatsApp, due to its significant role in the global media ecosystem. According to Lee Rainie, Pew's director of internet and technology research, Americans prioritize privacy as a fundamental value, but their online behavior suggests a disconnect. Rainie hypothesizes that this inconsistency may stem from a lack of understanding about how their personal information is harvested and analyzed. The finding that 74% of Facebook users were unaware of the company's data collection practices highlights the need to educate Americans about these systems.

The Federal Trade Commission is nearing the end of its investigation into whether Facebook has violated privacy rules, with the agency expected to impose substantial fines on the company, according to sources familiar with the inquiry. The five FTC commissioners met in mid-December to discuss the investigation, which is a rare occurrence in the early stages of an inquiry, indicating that the investigation is well advanced. The investigation, which began in late March, is ongoing, and while consumer-protection and enforcement staff have presented evidence of alleged privacy violations, a final report has not yet been submitted. The FTC commissioners will ultimately decide on any staff recommendations, including the amount of fines or penalties to be imposed, although they do not always agree with staff recommendations.

As Sunday gave way to Monday, a rare and spectacular sight unfolded in the night sky: a total lunar eclipse. For those with clear views, the moon transformed into a vibrant coppery red hue. This was the only lunar eclipse of 2019, and it occurred just before midnight Eastern time. Despite the chilly temperatures in parts of New York City, which might have kept some people indoors, the clouds had cleared, offering a perfect view of the eclipse after earlier cloudy obstructions. The eclipse occurred when Earth passed between the sun and the moon, casting a shadow over our planet's moon. In contrast, a solar eclipse occurs when the moon blocks the sun's light, causing daytime to turn into night in certain parts of the world. The lunar eclipse also coincided with a supermoon, a rare occurrence when the full moon is at its closest point to Earth, known as perigee. While the supermoon might be barely noticeable to the naked eye, it added an extra layer of excitement to the celestial display. Some even referred to the event as the "super blood wolf moon," a name that captured the moon's striking appearance during the eclipse.

Viacom, the former cable giant behind popular shows like "Jersey Shore" and children's programming like "Dora the Explorer," is acquiring PlutoTV, a streaming service, for $340 million, the companies announced on Tuesday. This marks Viacom's most significant foray into streaming, a strategy that has become increasingly popular among media companies as viewers increasingly opt out of traditional cable subscriptions. The rise of streaming services like Netflix and Hulu has accelerated the decline of the pay TV industry and upended the media landscape. In recent deals, Time Warner, once the largest media company in the US, was sold to AT&T for $85.4 billion, while Rupert Murdoch's entertainment empire was sold to Disney for $71.3 billion after a bidding war with Comcast. Both deals aimed to create entities capable of competing with Netflix and other tech companies by offering their own streaming services. AT&T and Disney plan to launch their services by the end of the year. Viacom's acquisition of PlutoTV, while smaller in scale, shares a similar motivation. Founded in 2013, PlutoTV is a free, advertising-supported service with around 12 million active viewers per month. NBCUniversal also recently announced plans to launch a streaming service largely reliant on advertising.

Before the rise of Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter, people relied on websites like Open Diary, Blogger, and LiveJournal to share their thoughts with the world. Over time, social media platforms became the go-to places for people to share articles reflecting their political views, post photos of loved ones, and express emotions such as frustration or excitement. Medium, an online publishing platform, has managed to thrive and innovate in the social media era, attracting 90 million unique monthly visitors who come to read open letters, petitions, and personal essays. However, Medium's content rarely generates the same level of intense reactions as it did on Thursday night. That's when Jeff Bezos, Amazon's billionaire CEO, took to the platform to accuse American Media Inc., the parent company of The National Enquirer, of "extortion and blackmail." The post's headline, "No thank you, Mr. Pecker," referenced David J. Pecker, the chairman of American Media.

San Francisco - Typically, technology companies don't turn a profit until they go public. Twitter, Snap, Spotify, and SurveyMonkey were all unprofitable when they listed on the stock market. As Uber prepares for its initial public offering (IPO), the question on everyone's mind is whether it can make money. This is particularly significant because Uber, the most prominent tech startup of its generation, will set the bar for other well-known tech companies like Slack and Lyft as they also make their way to the stock market this year. Unfortunately, Uber's profit prospects are not looking good. The company recently reported a net loss of $842 million in the fourth quarter of 2018, a significant increase of 88% from the previous year when excluding certain one-time items. The losses are attributed to Uber's increased spending as it attempts to outcompete its rivals, many of which have intensified their efforts to attract riders and drivers. In response, Uber has been offering bigger incentives and promotions to fend off competitors like DoorDash, Lyft, and other ride-hailing and food-delivery services.

Pittsburgh's The Post-Gazette sparked controversy last year when it published an editorial on Martin Luther King's Birthday, titled "Reason as Racism." Just over a year later, the newspaper has appointed Keith C. Burris, the editorial page director who wrote the contentious piece, as its new executive editor. Burris takes the helm at a tumultuous time for the publication, which has been experiencing tension between its workers' union, the Newspaper Guild of Pittsburgh, and its owner, Block Communications. The situation came to a head on February 9, when publisher John R. Block launched into a tirade in the newsroom, threatening employees' jobs while his young daughter sobbed and begged him to stop. Block Communications disputes the journalists' account of the events. As executive editor, Burris will continue to oversee the editorial pages of both The Post-Gazette and its sister publication, The Toledo Blade. In a message to employees, Burris asked for their support and pledged to work together to uphold the newspaper's legacy and navigate the challenges facing the industry. "I ask you to recognize my commitment and I implore you to work with me to preserve the Post-Gazette's proud heritage and move forward into a bright future," he wrote. "It won't be easy, as we face perilous times for journalism, but we owe the Block family a great debt for their support and trust in our mission."

The time has come to add one more small moon to Neptune's family of icy satellites. Astronomers using the Hubble Space Telescope have detected a previously unknown satellite orbiting the eighth planet in our solar system, bringing the total number of moons to 14. The discovery, published in Nature, serves as a reminder that there is still much to be discovered in our own backyard, with implications for our understanding of exoplanetary systems in our galaxy. According to Anne Verbiscer, a planetary scientist at the University of Virginia, who was not involved in the recent discovery, "people often assume we know everything about the moons of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune, but we don't. We still have a lot to find." This is particularly true for Uranus and Neptune, which are often referred to as the ice giants. While every other planet in our solar system has been extensively explored by multiple spacecraft, these two remain largely unexplored. Voyager 2 did fly by Neptune 30 years ago, capturing images that revealed rings, six new moons, and its striking blue color. However, the spacecraft was moving too quickly and was limited by technology from the 1970s.

"Every week, our team of technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times reviews the latest news, providing in-depth analysis and a dash of humor on the most significant developments in the tech industry. Interested in receiving this newsletter in your inbox? Simply sign up here. Hello, readers! I'm Nicole Perlroth, a cybersecurity reporter at The Times. Unfortunately, this week's news isn't all sunshine and rainbows. It's no surprise that President Trump's aggressive diplomatic approach has reinvigorated state-sponsored hackers in Iran and China. They're now targeting US companies and government agencies with renewed intensity, following a multi-year hiatus. This resurgence in activity comes on top of the ongoing threat from Russian hackers, who have already begun targeting European civil society groups ahead of May's elections. This is a glimpse into what's to come in 2020. With the US withdrawal from the nuclear deal with Iran, Iranian hackers are launching cyberattacks against American banks, businesses, and federal agencies. Notably, their tactics have become more sophisticated and effective, making them harder to track down."

The Federal Trade Commission has announced a $5.7 million settlement with Musical.ly, now known as TikTok, over allegations that the app illegally collected personal information about children. The FTC has imposed a record fine for a child privacy violation. The agency found that a significant proportion of the app's users were under the age of 13 and had shared sensitive personal information, including email addresses, names, and schools. The FTC noted that the app did not obtain parental consent before collecting data on users, which is a violation of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act. When some parents requested that the app delete videos and other data, the site refused to comply. Under COPPA, online services are required to obtain parental permission before collecting personal data from users under the age of 13. "This record penalty serves as a reminder to all online services and websites that target children: the FTC takes enforcement of COPPA very seriously and will not tolerate companies that disregard the law," said Joseph J. Simons, the agency's chairman.

Ten years ago, Google was the target of a shocking cyberattack by the Chinese military, one of the most notable incidents of its kind in the US. This week, Chronicle, a security startup owned by Alphabet, Google's parent company, is set to launch a new product called Backstory, which leverages the company's vast storage, indexing, and search capabilities to help other businesses investigate malicious attacks. The concept is straightforward: Backstory will enable companies to access and search vast amounts of data, going back years, to uncover the origins of a cyberattack. While Chronicle is not the only player in the big data threat intelligence market, many competitors charge high prices for their services, making it inaccessible to smaller businesses.

Slate, a popular online publication recognized for its unique analytical approach and numerous podcasts, has appointed a specialist in narrative journalism as its new editor-in-chief. On Wednesday, the company announced that Jared Hohlt, a veteran of New York magazine, will take on the role. Hohlt succeeds Julia Turner, who left Slate in October to become a deputy managing editor at The Los Angeles Times. Lowen Liu, Slate's former managing editor and deputy editor, has served as the publication's acting editor-in-chief since Turner's departure. Hohlt, 47, is set to start on April 1. During his 18-year tenure at New York magazine, he held various positions, including editorial director and top editor of the print edition. Under his leadership, the magazine won the general excellence award at the National Magazine Awards in 2016. Prior to his departure, Hohlt worked under editor-in-chief Adam Moss, who announced his resignation in January after 15 years at the helm. Interestingly, Hohlt began his career at Slate as an editorial assistant two decades ago, when one contributor insisted on using a typewriter. "Slate was a journalistic training ground for me," he recalled in an interview.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, there is no cure for autism spectrum disorder, but medications can help alleviate associated symptoms such as high energy levels and depression. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have found that up to a third of parents of children with autism have tried treatments not recommended by pediatricians, and up to 10% may be using potentially harmful methods. The two books listed on Amazon were published more than five years ago and have collectively received over 600 customer reviews. "Healing the Symptoms Known as Autism" suggests that autistic children drink and bathe in chlorine dioxide, also known as "Miracle Mineral Solution." However, the Food and Drug Administration has warned that this compound, used for industrial purposes, can cause severe health problems, including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and dehydration. In an open letter to Amazon's CEO Jeff Bezos, Representative Adam Schiff criticized the company's algorithms for failing to distinguish between quality information and misinformation, allowing harmful anti-vaccine messages to spread. Schiff urged Amazon to take responsibility and prevent contributing to the growing public health crisis.

The sun bears were engaging in a peculiar behavior - making faces at each other. This was an unexpected discovery. For years, comparative psychologists have studied the facial expressions of primates like orangutans and gorillas, which have evolved in complex societies to convey emotions like joy, anger, and others to their companions. However, no one had considered the possibility that solitary-living creatures like sun bears might also use facial expressions to communicate. Marina Davila-Ross, a primatologist at the University of Portsmouth in England, and her colleagues were conducting research on orangutans in Malaysia when they stumbled upon a group of sun bears in a nearby rehabilitation center. Intrigued by the possibility that facial communication might be more widespread in the animal kingdom than previously thought, they set up cameras to capture footage of the bears interacting with each other. According to a study published in Scientific Reports, the bears do use facial expressions to communicate, suggesting that the ability to do so may be more common than previously believed, and that social creatures are not the only ones capable of expressing themselves in this way.

Jeff Bezos, the founder and CEO of Amazon, and his wife MacKenzie Bezos announced on Twitter that they have finalized their divorce details. According to the agreement, Jeff Bezos will retain 75% of the couple's Amazon stock, as well as their ownership of The Washington Post and Blue Origin, his wife wrote. Additionally, Jeff Bezos will have sole voting authority over his wife's Amazon shares, as stated in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Following the divorce, MacKenzie Bezos will own approximately 4% of Amazon, a stake valued at nearly $36 billion. By keeping 75% of the couple's Amazon shares, which is equivalent to about 12% of the company, Jeff Bezos is likely to remain the world's richest person, with a remaining stake worth almost $108 billion. In comparison, Bill Gates, the second wealthiest individual, has a net worth of $102 billion, according to Bloomberg. Experts had predicted that, under Washington State law, MacKenzie Bezos was entitled to roughly half of the couple's assets, given that Amazon is based in the state and they have been raising their four children there. The couple also has investments and properties across the United States. The terms of their divorce settlement are not publicly disclosed, and it is possible that the agreement includes other forms of compensation for MacKenzie Bezos.

Throughout the year, as Earth orbits the sun, it encounters streams of cosmic debris. This can result in spectacular meteor showers that illuminate the night sky from dusk till dawn, and if you're lucky, you might be able to catch a glimpse of the celestial display. The next meteor shower you might be able to witness is the Lyrids, which is active from April 16 to 28. The shower peaks around Sunday night into Monday morning, or April 21-22, although the moon may interfere with viewing this year. Records from ancient Chinese astronomers date back over 2,700 years, documenting their observations of these bursts of light. The Lyrids meteorites streak across the sky at approximately 107,000 miles per hour, exploding about 55 miles up in the planet's atmosphere. The Lyrids shower originates from Comet Thatcher, which takes approximately 415 years to complete its orbit around the sun. Comet Thatcher's last visit to the sun was in 1861, and its next approach will be in 2276.

Meteor showers are often the result of icy comets' leftovers crashing into Earth's atmosphere. Comets are essentially dirty snowballs that leave behind a trail of rocks and ice as they travel through the solar system. This dusty trail lingers in space long after the comet has passed, and when Earth encounters these cascades of comet waste, the small particles of debris – ranging from grains of sand to larger fragments – pierce the sky at incredible speeds, creating a spectacular display of celestial fireworks.

San Francisco - The New York State attorney general's office is planning to launch an investigation into Facebook's unauthorized collection of over 1.5 million users' email address books, according to sources familiar with the matter. The inquiry revolves around a practice discovered in April, where Facebook harvested the email contact lists of a portion of new users who signed up for the platform after 2016, sources said. These lists were then used to enhance Facebook's ad-targeting algorithms and other social connections across the network. The investigation was officially confirmed by the attorney general's office late Thursday afternoon. "Facebook has consistently shown a disregard for consumers' privacy while profiting from exploiting their personal data," said New York Attorney General Letitia James in a statement. "It's time Facebook is held accountable for its handling of consumers' personal information."

While many parasites are notorious for their sinister effects, some species actually play a crucial role in their ecosystems. For example, a type of fungus called Cordyceps manipulates ants into committing suicide, while the Toxoplasma gondii parasite eliminates a mouse's fear of cats. The Sacculina carcini barnacle, on the other hand, takes a more extreme approach, castrating crabs and transforming them into "zombie" slaves that care for its young.

In a surprising twist, some parasites can even benefit their hosts. In eastern North America, wood-eating beetles are often infected with a parasitic worm that makes their insides resemble a plate of moving spaghetti. Despite this, the infected beetles tend to be larger and eat more than their uninfected counterparts, according to a recent study published in Biology Letters. This increased consumption may actually help the forest cycle nutrients more efficiently, benefiting the entire ecosystem.

The study's lead researcher, Andy Davis, an ecologist at the University of Georgia, notes that "everything is connected" in the natural world. "Here's a case where a small bug in the forest is doing something important, and then there's another bug that lives inside that bug that's doing something important too," he says.

James Bennet, editorial page editor of The New York Times, announced on Thursday that he would step back from any involvement in opinion coverage of the 2020 presidential election, following his brother Senator Michael Bennet's (D-Colo.) announcement of his candidacy for the Democratic nomination. This move, anticipated for some time, comes as James Bennet is considered a potential successor to Dean Baquet as executive editor of The Times. With over a decade of service in the Senate, Michael Bennet had previously expressed interest in a presidential bid. It's uncommon for the head of a newspaper's Opinion section to disengage from a topic that will likely dominate global news discourse for the next 18 months. James Bennet's self-imposed moratorium applies to all opinion pieces, including Op-Eds, columns, editorials, and articles related to presidential candidates or major campaign issues. The Times has appointed Kathleen Kingsbury and James Dao, Bennet's deputies, to share responsibilities for political coverage in their department. This arrangement is expected to remain in place for as long as Michael Bennet remains an active candidate in the race.

Throughout the year, as Earth orbits the sun, it encounters streams of cosmic debris. This debris can result in spectacular meteor showers that illuminate the night sky from dusk to dawn, offering a chance to catch a glimpse if you're lucky. The next notable shower is the Eta Aquariids, which is active from April 19 to May 28 and peaks around May 5-6. With the moon approaching new, clear skies could provide ideal viewing conditions. The Eta Aquariids are one of two meteor showers associated with Halley's comet, with its sister shower, the Orionids, peaking in October. The Eta Aquariids are notable for their high speed, reaching about 148,000 miles per hour, making them one of the fastest meteor showers. The display is more prominent in the Southern Hemisphere, where observers can expect to see 20-30 meteors per hour during the peak. In contrast, the Northern Hemisphere tends to see about half as many.

When you spot a meteor shower, you're typically witnessing the remnants of an icy comet colliding with Earth's atmosphere. Comets, often referred to as "dirty snowballs," leave behind a trail of rocky and icy debris as they travel through the solar system. This debris lingers in space long after the comet has passed, and when Earth encounters these cascades, the small particles – sometimes as small as grains of sand – enter the atmosphere at incredible speeds, producing a dazzling celestial display.

A new study warns that climate change and rising sea levels could eventually wipe out one of the world's last and largest tiger habitats. The report, released by the United Nations, highlights that nearly 500,000 land species are now at risk of extinction due to threats to their natural habitats. The Sundarbans, a 4,000-square-mile region in Bangladesh and India, is home to the world's largest mangrove forest and a diverse ecosystem that supports hundreds of animal species, including the endangered Bengal tiger. However, 70% of the region is only a few feet above sea level, making it vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. Researchers predict that the warming planet will be "enough to decimate" the few hundred Bengal tigers remaining in the region. By 2070, the study concludes that there will be no suitable tiger habitats remaining in the Bangladesh Sundarbans. The findings, which rely on climate scenarios developed by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, add to previous studies that have made similarly dire predictions for wildlife in the Sundarbans. In 2010, a study by the World Wide Fund for Nature projected that a sea level rise of 11 inches could reduce the number of tigers in the Sundarbans by 96% within a few decades. Climate change has already had a devastating impact on the world's endangered mammals, with a recent study finding that it has harmed almost half of them. The new report's lead author, Sharif A. Mukul, and his colleagues examined the risks to the tiger population beyond sea level rise, which accounted for only 5.4-11.3% of the projected habitat loss in 2050 and 2070. They found that other climate-related factors were more significant threats to the Sundarbans' tigers, which are one of the largest remaining populations of wild tigers in the world. Since the early 1900s, habitat loss, hunting, and the illegal trade of animal parts have contributed to the global tiger population decline from around 100,000 to fewer than 4,000. A recent study has discovered that the Bangladesh Sundarbans will likely experience a decline in its population due to an increase in extreme weather events and changes in vegetation. As the Sundarbans flood, the likelihood of conflicts between humans and tigers will rise, as the animals venture out of their natural habitat in search of new land. According to Dr. Mukul, an assistant professor of environmental management at Independent University, Bangladesh, "Many unforeseen consequences could arise. The situation could worsen significantly if a cyclone hits, a disease outbreak occurs, or a food shortage develops." Notably, a landmark report by the United Nations's scientific panel on climate change, released in October, warned that if greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise at their current rate, the Earth's atmosphere will warm by as much as 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit above preindustrial levels by 2040.

Imagine a dinosaur-like creature, and you probably wouldn't picture a bat. However, a team of paleontologists in China has made a groundbreaking discovery that may alter your imagination. The team announced on Wednesday the discovery of a dinosaur, Ambopteryx longibrachium, which had fleshy wings similar to those used by bats to fly. This remarkable creature lived approximately 163 million years ago. When Min Wang, a vertebrate paleontologist at the Chinese Academy of Sciences, first examined the fossil, he initially thought it was a bird. This is not surprising, as birds evolved from dinosaurs and share many characteristics. Dr. Wang's initial assumption was based on the fossil's relatively long forelimbs, a trait shared by modern birds. However, as his team carefully excavated the fossil over the course of about a year, distinctly dinosaurian features began to emerge. One notable characteristic was the presence of long fingers, a trait that is unique to dinosaurs and absent in birds.

About 50 years ago, the Apollo astronauts deployed short-lived seismometers on the lunar surface. Their findings revealed that the moon was surprisingly dynamic, with various types of quakes occurring. Some tremors were likely caused by Earth's gravitational pull, while others were triggered by meteorite impacts or the moon's surface expanding and contracting every two weeks due to temperature changes. Additionally, there were shallow moonquakes occurring just a few miles beneath the surface, which couldn't be fully explained. However, a recent study published in Nature Geoscience suggests that these shallow quakes were caused by a combination of escaping internal heat and Earth's gravitational pull, triggering movements along numerous young faults. This discovery implies that the moon is still tectonically active, raising concerns about the potential for shallow moonquakes at future lunar bases. It also sparks questions about the moon's evolution, particularly given its small size and the assumption that internal heat should have long since escaped into space. Despite its diminutive size, the moon's internal heat appears to still be driving geological activity, contradicting expectations.

Conde Nast has sold Golf Digest to Discovery Inc., the companies announced on Monday, as the publisher of The New Yorker, Vanity Fair, and Vogue continues to divest titles amid recent financial losses attributed to the decline of the magazine industry. The terms of the deal were not disclosed, but two sources familiar with the matter revealed that the sale price was $35 million. Discovery stated that it would retain Golf Digest's editorial team, including Editor-in-Chief Jerry Tarde, and continue to publish the monthly print magazine. Additionally, the company announced that Tarde would serve as the global head of strategy and content for Discovery Golf, a unit that encompasses the digital platform GolfTV, which live-streams professional golf tournaments globally. "As we look to the future, Discovery's global reach and ability to distribute content across all platforms and languages, combined with the PGA Tour's brand, will benefit golf and golfers worldwide," Tarde said in a statement.

If you've ever taken a large bite of wasabi, you're familiar with the intense, creeping sensation that spreads across your scalp. You're not alone in your discomfort - many animals share your aversion to the spicy condiment. The culprit behind wasabi's sinus-clearing properties is a chemical compound called allyl isothiocyanate, or AITC, which actively damages proteins within cells. Flies, flatworms, mice, and wolf spiders all avoid AITC, and according to Gary Lewin, a molecular physiologist at the Max Delbruck Center for Molecular Medicine in Berlin, "practically every animal you look at will shun AITC." However, there is one notable exception: the highveld mole rat, a rodent native to South Africa, is completely impervious to the substance. In a recent study published in Science, a team of scientists, including Dr. Lewin, demonstrated the rodent's remarkable resistance to AITC. According to Ewan St. John Smith, a neurobiologist at the University of Cambridge, who was not involved in the research, the findings "demonstrate the power of studying naturally occurring differences in pain sensitivity." The study's results may ultimately lead to more effective pain treatment in humans.

The House has recently passed a retirement legislation with a significant bipartisan majority, which includes a range of provisions that will impact various groups of American savers and retirees. While the bill makes several key changes, one notable provision would enable employers to offer complex annuity products as part of their retirement plans. Here's a breakdown of some of the other significant changes the bill would introduce:

* Allow workers to contribute to individual retirement accounts without age limits, rather than being restricted to age 70 1/2.
* Increase the age at which individuals must begin taking withdrawals from their Individual Retirement Accounts (IRAs) to 72, up from 70 1/2.
* Permit penalty-free withdrawals from retirement plans to cover expenses related to the birth or adoption of a child.

Jeffrey Goldberg, the editor-in-chief of The Atlantic, sparked a wave of criticism on Thursday when he admitted that it's challenging to assign cover stories to writers outside of white males. In an interview with Nieman Lab, a nonprofit journalism organization, Goldberg stated that writing a 10,000-word cover story is a daunting task, and that only a select group of white male journalists possess the skills to accomplish it. According to Nieman Lab, 11 out of The Atlantic's 15 most recent cover stories were written by men. Goldberg suggested that to increase diversity among contributors, The Atlantic should identify and mentor new writers, telling them they have the potential to write lengthy cover stories. However, he acknowledged that this approach may not always yield success. The editor's comments sparked widespread criticism, with many accusing him of undervaluing the abilities of writers from underrepresented groups. The article length he mentioned sparked a lively discussion on Twitter, with many journalists chiming in. Margaret Sullivan of The Washington Post joked that she aspires to write 1,200 words, but tops out at 850. Andi Zeisler, co-founder of the nonprofit feminist organization Bitch Media, quipped, "Has anyone informed Jeffrey Goldberg about women who write books?"

Mitchel R. Levitas, a renowned journalist who received the esteemed George Polk Award in his 20s for his investigative series on labor racketeering, passed away on Saturday at his home in New Marlborough, Massachusetts. He was 89 years old. The cause of death was Alzheimer's disease, complicated by pneumonia, according to his son Daniel. Levitas held prominent positions at The New York Times for nearly four decades, overseeing the paper's metropolitan coverage, editing sections such as The Week in Review, The New York Times Book Review, and the Op-Ed page, from 1976 to 1995. Born and raised in New York City, Levitas graduated from the city's public schools and colleges before joining The New York Times in 1965 as a writer and editor for The New York Times Magazine. He retired in 2002 after 37 years with the paper, having served as editorial director of book development, where he launched volumes on the best travel writing by Times reporters and anthologies of Times reportage on significant historical events. Levitas continued to work as a consultant for the book development office until 2014. Known to his colleagues as Mike, Levitas was a meticulous editor with a keen eye for detail. According to an article in The New York Times Book Review from 1975, Levitas, as an assistant metropolitan editor, was instrumental in assigning a reporter to investigate the authenticity of "The Last Testament of Lucky Luciano," a book billed as a personal memoir dictated by the notorious Mafia boss himself.

CBS's "Late Show with Stephen Colbert" is one of the most popular programs on the network. Despite weeks of negotiations, CBS and AT&T failed to reach a contract agreement by a Saturday deadline. As a result, CBS went dark for over 6.5 million AT&T customers early Saturday morning, affecting its satellite service DirecTV, landline-delivered U-verse, and live streaming product DirecTV Now. The blackout affected customers in at least 14 major markets, including New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, and San Francisco. The network, which is carried in about 119 million homes across the country, lost tens of millions of dollars in monthly revenue as a result. CBS and AT&T had been at odds over pricing and streaming rights, with CBS refusing to agree to terms that would "undervalue" its popular programming. AT&T, meanwhile, accused CBS of being a "repeat blackout offender" and demanded a more reasonable fee structure. CBS is seeking an increase in retransmission consent fees, which it last negotiated in 2012, when market conditions were different and pay-TV bills were lower. While CBS is still available for free over the air using an antenna, it also sells its rights to pay-TV operators like AT&T, which carry the network on their systems. "According to sources familiar with the matter, CBS had been receiving an average monthly payment of around $2 per AT&T subscriber, and is now seeking a fee in the range of $3. The sources, who spoke on the condition of anonymity due to the private nature of the contract negotiations, provided this information."

On July 21, 1969, at 2:56 a.m. Coordinated Universal Time, humans made history by setting foot on another planet for the first time. This groundbreaking moment marked a turning point, as millions of people around the world tuned in to watch the event live on television, with tens of millions more listening on the radio. As they gazed up at the moon, a symbol of the unattainable, now within reach, and at our own Earth, a small blue dot in the vast expanse of space, people shared a collective perspective. For most people alive today, the Apollo 11 mission is a distant memory, as it occurred before they were born. Even for those who recall the event, it's easy to forget that the Apollo program unfolded during a tumultuous period in American history, when many Americans felt that other pressing issues, such as poverty, education, and civil rights, should take precedence over space exploration. Despite the skepticism, the mission's success became synonymous with humanity's potential, inspiring the notion that if we could put a man on the moon, we could accomplish anything. To commemorate this complex history and The New York Times' role in covering it, the science desk has been publishing a series of articles, essays, photo galleries, and a poem throughout the month, reflecting on the legacy of Apollo 11 and the promise and challenges of a new era of space exploration.

San Francisco - Food delivery startup DoorDash announced on Thursday that it is acquiring Caviar, a rival service, for $410 million in a move that intensifies the already competitive landscape in food delivery. DoorDash is purchasing Caviar from Square, a payments company that has owned the service since 2014. Caviar operates in approximately 15 cities, primarily offering food from upscale restaurants in urban areas. According to Tony Xu, DoorDash's CEO, Caviar's selection of higher-end restaurants in cities complements DoorDash's offerings, which are more focused on chain restaurants in suburban areas. When Square's CEO Jack Dorsey called to discuss a potential deal, Xu described the conversation as brief. The food delivery market has been increasingly competitive, with DoorDash, Postmates, GrubHub, and Uber Eats vying for customers, drivers, and restaurant clients. The intense competition has been further fueled by the initial public offering of Uber in May and the potential IPO of Postmates. In February, Postmates filed confidentially with the Securities and Exchange Commission, but has not yet set a date for its listing.

Sponges, also known as poriferans, are soft, stationary, and characterized by their numerous holes. Comb jellies, or ctenophores, are gelatinous, feathery creatures with cilia that resemble combs. For the past decade, scientists have been engaged in a heated debate over which of these two groups is most closely related to the first animal to evolve. The latest analysis, published in Royal Society Open Science, suggests that sponges are the closest living relatives of the earliest animal, although this conclusion is likely to be disputed further. All animals, from sponges and comb jellies to humans and other mammals, share certain fundamental characteristics, including multicellularity, the presence of nuclei in their cells, and the ability to consume food rather than produce it. Additionally, all animals are descended from a common ancestor that lived in the oceans at least 550 million years ago and shared these characteristics. However, scientists are still unsure what this first animal looked like or how it lived. To gain insight into the origins of the animal kingdom, researchers study existing species to infer what the common ancestor might have been like. "By comparing modern animals, we can try to reconstruct what the ancestor was like," said Antonis Rokas, an evolutionary biologist at Vanderbilt University. "How complex was it? What kind of genes did it have, and what kinds of traits did it possess?"

When you spot a meteor shower, you're likely witnessing the remnants of a comet's icy trail as it enters Earth's atmosphere. Comets are essentially dirty snowballs that release a trail of rocks and ice as they travel through the solar system. This trail lingers in space long after the comet has passed, and when Earth encounters it, the small particles of debris - as small as grains of sand - burn up, creating a spectacular display of celestial fireworks. A general rule of thumb is that you're not seeing the Earth pass through the comet's most recent orbit, but rather the remnants of its previous passes. For example, during the Perseid meteor shower, you're seeing meteors that were ejected from Comet Swift-Tuttle's visit in 1862 or earlier, not from its most recent pass in 1992. This is because it takes time for debris from a comet's orbit to drift into a position where it intersects with Earth's orbit, according to Bill Cooke, an astronomer with NASA's Meteoroid Environment Office.

To get the best view of a meteor shower, find a location with a clear view of the entire night sky, ideally with dark skies, away from city lights and traffic. Look for a spot with a wide, unobstructed view to maximize your chances of spotting the show. Meteor showers are typically visible for a set period, but they peak in visibility from dusk to dawn on a specific few days, when Earth's orbit crosses through the thickest part of the cosmic stream. The peak times of meteor showers vary, with some lasting only a few hours and others several nights. The showers tend to be most visible after midnight and before dawn. For the best viewing experience, use your naked eye to spot the meteor shower." "When using binoculars or telescopes, you'll typically find that your field of view is restricted. It's recommended that you spend around 30 minutes in the dark to allow your eyes to adjust to the reduced light. However, stargazers should be aware that moonlight and inclement weather can sometimes obscure celestial events. If this happens, there are often alternative options available, such as NASA and Slooh's meteor livestreams."

In 1995, when WNYC, the New York public radio station, had a new boss, Rudolph W. Giuliani was the mayor, and the station had a monthly audience of approximately one million listeners and an operating budget of $8 million. Since then, New York Public Radio, WNYC's parent organization, has expanded into a prominent public media entity, boasting a budget of $97 million, nationally syndicated radio programs, and numerous popular podcasts, such as "2 Dope Queens" and "Trump, Inc." The organization claims that its various broadcast and online platforms now attract 24 million people. After nearly a quarter-century, New York Public Radio has welcomed a new leader. The nonprofit group announced on Wednesday that Goli Sheikholeslami, who has led Chicago Public Media and its radio station WBEZ since 2014, and has held executive positions at The Washington Post and Conde Nast, will become the organization's new chief executive. She is set to start her new role in New York in October.

Google has reached a settlement with the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) over complaints from multiple employees who claim the company has stifled dissent, including one who was allegedly fired for being an outspoken conservative. As part of the settlement, Google plans to educate employees about their rights under federal law, such as the freedom to discuss workplace conditions, and assure them that the company will not retaliate against them for exercising those rights. According to Google spokeswoman Jenn Kaiser, the company will post a notice to employees reminding them of their rights under the National Labor Relations Act and clarify that its workplace policies do not prohibit discussing workplace issues. The settlement still requires approval from an NLRB official, and a regional director has already indicated her approval, according to a document obtained by The New York Times.

It's possible that it seems like there are more bugs buzzing around lately, whether it's swarms of ladybugs in California or billions of hoverflies in England, simply because radar technology has become more efficient. On Monday, meteorologist Doug Kahn from the National Weather Service in Cleveland observed several blue masses moving and growing over Ohio on the radar. The undulating blobs on the radar weren't storm clouds or a weather system, but a massive swarm of dragonflies. "There are millions of them," Kahn explained, "which is why you can see so many of them on the radar." According to Kahn, the Weather Service uses a dual-polarization radar that can create an almost 3D image of what's in the atmosphere. This technology scans both horizontally and vertically to measure the dimensions of what's in the air, allowing meteorologists to identify what's in the atmosphere even before they can see it in person.

"Game of Thrones" has secured the most Emmy wins for a drama series in television history. It's unlikely anyone thought the show would quietly conclude its final season. The HBO fantasy epic dominated the Creative Arts Emmy Awards over the weekend, claiming a record 10 awards, the most for any series in the Primetime Emmys' opening ceremonies. HBO's limited series "Chernobyl" also had a successful night, taking home seven Creative Arts Emmys. Amazon's "The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel", which won Best Comedy last year, won six awards, including honors for guest acting by Jane Lynch and Luke Kirby. In the drama guest acting categories, Cherry Jones and Bradley Whitford took home awards for their roles in Hulu's "The Handmaid's Tale". The 71st Primetime Emmy Awards, which will be broadcast live on September 22, honored winners in nearly 100 categories over two ceremonies, recognizing achievements in technical areas, guest acting, and other categories that may not be as well-known to viewers.

A typical lightning strike packs a significant punch, but superbolts are a different story altogether. First detected in the 1970s by satellites designed to monitor nuclear explosions, these extreme lightning events are thousands of times more energetic than regular lightning. However, the chances of being struck by a superbolt are extremely low. To better understand where these powerful lightning strikes occur, scientists analyzed data from the World Wide Lightning Location Network's 80 sensors. Their findings, published in the Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres, revealed that superbolts primarily occur over open water from November to February, contradicting expectations that they would occur in known lightning hotspots or during typical lightning seasons.

Dr. Robert Holzworth, an atmospheric and space physicist at the University of Washington, and his team analyzed over 1.7 billion radio-frequency observations of lightning, focusing on the most robust detections from 2010 to 2018. They identified 8,171 superbolts with energies exceeding one million Joules, which accounts for only 0.0005 percent of the total lightning recorded by the network, which Dr. Holzworth leads. "It's a tiny fraction," Dr. Holzworth noted. Superbolts are so rare that even Dr. Holzworth, a renowned expert in the field, has never witnessed one firsthand.

Apple is taking its first steps into the film industry, announcing that it will release three movies in theaters this fall. The movies, which Apple acquired earlier this year, will be the company's first foray into the film business. Apple plans to expand its film efforts in 2020, when it will begin producing its own movies, some of which will be co-produced with independent studio A24. A24 is known for producing critically acclaimed films such as "Moonlight" and "Lady Bird". Apple and A24 formed a partnership last year to co-produce movies.

The first movie to be released is "Elephant Queen", a documentary about a 50-year-old elephant, narrated by actor Chiwetel Ejiofor. It will be shown in select cities on October 18 and later become available on Apple TV+ on November 1. The second movie, "Hala", is a coming-of-age drama about a Muslim teenager played by Geraldine Viswanathan. It will be released in select theaters on November 22 and then available on Apple TV+ in December. Apple acquired "Hala" after its debut at the Sundance Film Festival in February.

A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan rejected the argument on Monday. Judge J. Paul Oetken wrote in his decision, "The court acknowledges that the SALT cap is a unique provision, but the states have failed to demonstrate that it exceeds Congress's broad authority to impose taxes." The lawsuit was joined by three other states: New Jersey, Connecticut, and Maryland. The cap on state and local tax deductions, which was previously unlimited, was introduced as part of the 2017 tax law to offset the cost of trillions of dollars in tax cuts. According to the Joint Committee on Taxation, the cap and related provisions are expected to generate nearly $700 billion in revenue over the next decade. Independent analyses suggest that even in high-tax states like New York, most residents received a modest tax cut under the 2017 law. Other provisions of the law, such as reduced marginal tax rates, offset the loss of the deduction for many families. The state and local tax issue poses an awkward challenge for Democrats, who are seeking to restore a tax break that primarily benefited high-income earners. Prior to the cap's implementation, households earning $200,000 or more accounted for roughly half of the nearly $600 billion in state and local tax payments deducted on federal tax returns. However, Democrats argue that the SALT cap unfairly penalizes states with progressive tax policies, making state and local taxes more expensive for residents. This could hinder states' ability to raise taxes, particularly on wealthy residents, and increase pressure to cut spending. In their lawsuit, the four states claimed that the SALT cap constitutes a coercive effort by the federal government to influence certain states' tax policies.

Evolutionary biologist Julia Sigwart from Queens University Belfast in Northern Ireland has an intriguing explanation for why chitons roll into balls: "To get to the other side." It's a behavior that dates back to the time of trilobites, which became extinct around 500 million years ago. These ancient creatures would curl up into a ball for protection, and their modern-day equivalent, the chiton, has a similar ability. Despite its appearance, which resembles a flattened piece of shrimp nigiri, the chiton is a marine mollusk that clings to tidepool rocks rather than being served on a dinner plate. Like trilobites, several other animals, including three-banded armadillos, pill bugs, and hedgehogs, can also roll into balls. Many scientists believed that this behavior, known as conglobation, was a defense mechanism against predators. However, Dr. Sigwart, who has studied chitons, has questioned this assumption. If a predator can swallow an animal whole, she reasoned, rolling into a ball would not provide sufficient protection. In a series of lab experiments, Dr. Sigwart found that chitons roll into balls to help them reach new locations after losing their footing. Her research, published in Biology Letters, suggests that chitons are capable of making decisions and may be more intelligent than previously thought.

For many of us, our typing habits on smartphones are largely a matter of trial and error. Unlike typing on a typewriter or computer keyboard, where there are established techniques, there is no widely accepted "right" way to type on a smartphone. However, a recent study involving 37,000 participants suggests that a specific approach can lead to faster typing: using two thumbs and relying on autocorrect, while avoiding predictive text. According to Per Ola Kristensson, a professor of interactive systems engineering at the University of Cambridge and co-author of the study, this approach is key to typing quickly. The study, presented at a human-computer interaction conference in Taipei, focused on the Qwerty keyboard, which was originally designed to prevent mechanical typing jams in typewriters. Despite questions about its relevance and the emergence of alternative keyboard layouts, the Qwerty layout remains widely used.

James Murdoch, the former CEO of 21st Century Fox, has taken a minority stake in Vice Media, the entertainment brand catering to millennials. As part of Vice's acquisition of Refinery29, a women's lifestyle publisher, Murdoch, who is already a member of Vice's board, made the investment through his holding company, Lupa Systems. According to a source familiar with the matter, who wished to remain anonymous due to the deal's private nature, Murdoch's investment was first reported by The Financial Times. After leaving 21st Century Fox, which was founded by his father Rupert Murdoch, James Murdoch formed Lupa Systems. Last year, the Murdoch family sold the majority of Fox's assets to Disney for over $70 billion, with James personally netting around $2 billion. Since then, he has invested in a range of media businesses that differ significantly from those founded by his father. Notably, he has shown less interest in traditional news ventures, according to the source familiar with the matter.

Uber has made a significant investment in Cornershop, a grocery delivery startup, in a move to strengthen its food delivery business. The acquisition comes as the company seeks to diversify beyond its core ride-hailing service, following a rocky initial public offering in May. Despite slowing growth in its core business, Uber is focusing on expanding its food and freight delivery services, as well as entering new markets such as bicycle and scooter rentals. Cornershop, which operates in Chile, Mexico, Peru, and Canada, will now be integrated into Uber's platform, with plans to expand into additional markets, including the United States. "We're thrilled to partner with Cornershop and look forward to working together to bring grocery delivery to millions of consumers on the Uber platform," said Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber's CEO, in a statement.

Lyft has shifted its focus to profitability, with CEO Logan Green stating that the company has made progress on its path to profitability. Green revealed that Lyft would be profitable by late 2021, excluding certain costs. During the company's latest earnings call, executives emphasized their goal of achieving operating profitability. The focus on profit comes as Lyft's loss was driven by stock-based compensation costs and payroll tax expenses. Excluding these costs, Lyft's operating loss was $121.6 million for the quarter, which was less severe than Wall Street estimates. Lyft's stock rose nearly 1.5 percent in after-hours trading on Wednesday. CFO Brian Roberts credited the company's strong revenue performance, saying, "We crushed revenue expectations." Roberts also highlighted Lyft's commitment to achieving profitability by a specific date, which he believes is unique in the industry. Earlier this year, Lyft had predicted it would incur record losses as it prioritized growth, but the company has since changed its strategy in response to a shift in sentiment towards prominent tech startups.

The decision to leave the publication must have been a difficult one, given the challenging job market in the industry. Newspapers have struggled for over a decade, particularly in small towns and midsize cities, and the digital news outlets that emerged in their wake have also shown signs of distress. In a text message, Ms. McKinney stated, "I no longer believe that this company supports its writers," citing the deletion of a post acknowledging reader complaints about auto-playing ads as evidence. On Tuesday, investigative reporter Diana Moskovitz announced that she had given her two weeks' notice the previous week, stating on Twitter, "What happened today, and everything that led up to it, are among the reasons I decided to move on." G/O Media has maintained that Deadspin is free to cover topics that may seem unrelated to sports, as long as there is a sports-related angle. After the mass exodus on Wednesday, the company released a statement, saying, "They resigned and we're sorry they couldn't work within our broad coverage mandate. We're excited about Deadspin's future and will have important updates in the coming days." Deadspin has been without a full-time top editor since August, when Editor-in-Chief Megan Greenwell resigned due to undue interference from management. Greenwell is now a columnist at The New York Times. One of Deadspin's notable investigative reports was a 2013 story revealing that the feel-good story about Notre Dame star linebacker Manti Te'o was fabricated, including the claim that his long-distance girlfriend had died in a car accident. Deadspin was sold to Univision in 2016 after being acquired by Gawker Media, which was subsequently sold following a $140 million judgment against Gawker in an invasion-of-privacy lawsuit backed by Peter Thiel, a Silicon Valley billionaire.

In recent years, devastating hurricanes like Katrina, Harvey, Maria, and Dorian have claimed thousands of lives and inflicted billions of dollars in damage. However, tracking the frequency of these destructive storms is challenging due to the limited availability of records, which date back only about a century and a half. Researchers have made a groundbreaking discovery by compiling a 1,500-year history of hurricanes in the Bahamas, using sand and shell fragments extracted from submarine caverns known as blue holes. According to their findings, published in Paleoceanography and Paleoclimatology in October, hurricane activity has fluctuated significantly over time. Notably, recent hurricane activity in the Bahamas has been relatively low compared to historical highs, despite intense activity in other parts of the Atlantic. The scientists attribute these fluctuations to changes in atmospheric and oceanic circulation, as well as volcanic activity. Following the destruction caused by Hurricane Dorian, Lisa Kennedy, a geographer at Virginia Tech, describes this historical record as a "wake-up call." She notes that we are still in the early stages of understanding hurricane patterns and processes within the context of long-term history. Blue holes, formed when carbonate rock erodes and collapses, are revered by divers for their deep, clear waters and are also important repositories of scientific data. Hurricanes deposit coarse materials like sand, gravel, shells, and coral fragments into these holes, making them valuable keepers of the historical record.

Xerox has become synonymous with photocopying and printing, a reputation that HP has also built around its printers. Now, Xerox is seeking to combine the two companies. On Wednesday night, HP revealed that it had received a takeover offer from Xerox, following "occasional conversations about a potential business combination." According to the statement, HP will carefully consider its options, taking deliberate and disciplined action to ensure the best interests of all shareholders are served. A merger would bring together two former industry giants that have faced significant challenges in recent years, as the demand for printed documents and ink has declined.

Facebook is taking steps to simplify the process of transferring photos from its platform to rival online services, in response to European privacy laws and regulatory criticism that its dominance and control over user data stifle competition. The company announced on Monday that it will begin testing a "data portability" tool in Ireland, which will allow users to move photos and videos from Facebook to Google Photos. However, critics have argued that the initiative does not go far enough. Facebook's control over user data has been a key focus of ongoing antitrust investigations in Washington and Europe, as authorities claim that the company's vast collection of user information creates a competitive imbalance that rivals cannot match. The company has historically benefited from network effects, where the value of its services increases as more users join, but many users have felt unable to leave Facebook due to the difficulty of transferring their photos and videos to other platforms. To promote more competition, officials have debated how to enable companies to allow users to take their content and data to other services.

During the Cretaceous period, the tooth fairy would have been kept extremely busy by the dinosaurs. Unlike humans, who only lose one set of teeth over their lifetime, dinosaurs frequently shed tens or even hundreds of sets due to their unique dental habits. Herbivorous dinosaurs, which needed to chew through tough plant material to sustain their large bodies, often replaced their teeth frequently. However, researchers were surprised to discover that a carnivorous dinosaur, the only known cannibal, replaced its teeth even more frequently than some herbivores. The dinosaur's habit of chewing on the bones of its prey may have contributed to its rapid tooth replacement rate, scientists hypothesized. The findings were published recently in the journal PLoS One and focused on several meat-eating dinosaurs, with Majungasaurus crenatissimus emerging as the star of the study. This 20-foot-long apex predator, which lived on what is now Madagascar around 70 million years ago, left behind a remarkable fossil record, including several complete skeletons, hundreds of fragmentary skeletons, and tens of thousands of shed teeth. "This is quite unusual," said Michael D. D'Emic, a vertebrate paleontologist at Adelphi University in Garden City, New York, who led the study.

For centuries, scientists, including Darwin, struggled to understand the phenomenon: despite being extremely nutrient-poor, tropical water is crystal clear. Yet, coral reefs thrive, supporting a staggering quarter of all known species on Earth. How could this be? The answer to this paradox lies in part with sugar. We often assume the ocean tastes salty, but it's also home to microscopic morsels of sugars and carbohydrates, known as dissolved organic matter. This dissolved substance accounts for most of the ocean's organic material and is particularly abundant near coral reefs. "Think of all these sugars dissolved in the ocean," said Michelle Achlatis, a researcher at the California Academy of Sciences. "If no one can use them, they might as well not be there." This filter-feeding sponge, found on coral reefs in the Indian and Pacific Oceans, strains tiny plankton as it sits in the water, using its filtering cells to sip sugars from the seawater.

Initially, it's clear that this new job isn't the solution people had hoped for. Instead of providing a safer alternative to the mine, it offers a fundamentally different kind of work. While the mine was hazardous, at least it provided secure employment with benefits. In contrast, the warehouse job is insecure, with no benefits, no full-time contract, and no guarantee of a pension, sick pay, or holiday pay. To make matters worse, workers are paid at or below the minimum wage. In fact, a government inquiry into the warehouse's practices a few years ago uncovered disturbing examples of employees being penalized for taking breaks, including one woman who was so fearful of losing her job that she gave birth in the warehouse and left her baby in a bathroom.

Uber is reportedly in advanced talks to divest its food delivery business in India, a move aimed at reducing its losses. According to sources, the company is close to finalizing a deal to sell its Uber Eats service in India to Zomato, a local food delivery service. The sale, which could be announced as early as this week, would reportedly value the India business of Uber Eats at $400 million. Uber's CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, has been working to streamline the company's operations by shedding money-losing businesses, in an effort to prove to investors that the company can turn a profit. Investors have been pushing Uber to clean up its balance sheet since its initial public offering earlier this year, both publicly and privately.

A new state law in California, intended to improve working conditions for contractors at companies like Uber and Lyft, is having an unintended consequence: more than 200 bloggers in the state will lose their regular writing gigs. As a result of the law, Vox Media has announced that it will eliminate 200 freelance positions at its sports outlet, SB Nation, effective immediately. The affected writers are frequent contributors to 25 SB Nation blogs that focus on California teams, including Golden State of Mind, Conquest Chronicles, and True Blue LA. Many of these writers have been producing dozens of posts per year for little pay, according to a related lawsuit. The law, which takes effect on January 1, poses a significant challenge for SB Nation, as it restricts contractors from producing more than 35 written content submissions per year.

"I previously wrote about downloading specific files from Google Photos, but now I need to know how to upload a specific album to share with a family group. How do I go about doing this? To share a specific album with a family group, you'll need to first select and organize the photos you want to share into that album. If you have automatic backups enabled on your smartphone or computer, the photos are already uploaded to your Google Account's online storage space. Alternatively, you can manually upload selected photos you want to share online. If you have a folder of images on your computer that you want to upload to Google Photos, you can log in to the website at https://photos.google.com, drag the pictures onto the browser window, or click the Upload button at the top of the screen and navigate to the folder to add them."

The fate of ABC's "Roseanne" reboot remains uncertain, but it's already generating controversy. At a press event in Pasadena, California, on Monday, show star Roseanne Barr faced repeated questions about her support for President Trump, as well as that of her character, just two months before the show's revival. While Barr clarified that she wasn't an "apologist" for Trump, she argued that her character's stance in the reboot was a necessary reflection of the nation's deep divisions. "I've always sought to portray a genuine representation of our society," Barr said. "Half the country voted for him, half didn't. It's a realistic portrayal."

Actress and activist Rose McGowan is set to star in a documentary series, "Citizen Rose," which premieres on E! later this month. The series, which promises an unfiltered look into McGowan's life, will debut with a two-hour episode on January 30 and return with four additional installments in the spring. McGowan's involvement in the project began in September, just before the publication of a New York Times story that revealed her settlement agreement with Harvey Weinstein, whom she accused of sexual assault. According to Andrea Metz, an executive producer of the series, McGowan's pitch to Bunim/Murray Productions was convincing, with Metz recalling that McGowan kept saying, "It'll be worth it, I promise." Jonathan Murray, chairman of Bunim/Murray Productions, confirmed that filming began in September and will incorporate footage recorded by McGowan over the past three years. As the #MeToo movement gained momentum, McGowan became one of the most prominent voices advocating for women who have been victims of sexual harassment and abuse. She has also publicly condemned men accused of sexual misconduct and criticized those who have not been outspoken enough. McGowan's online following, known as the #RoseArmy, has grown significantly since the Weinstein scandal broke. In a recent Twitter rant, McGowan criticized what she saw as "Hollywood fakery" during the Golden Globes ceremony, where many women wore black and some wore Time's Up pins. Ms. McGowan expressed her desire to emulate Gertrude Stein by engaging in meaningful conversations with the world, but she wanted to do so in a more public setting rather than just her living room. E! has had a mixed track record with its topical programming, with shows like "I Am Cait" and "Mariah's World" experiencing lackluster ratings. Despite some celebrities being hesitant to label their projects as reality TV, Ms. McGowan is unapologetic about her show's genre, stating, "I'm okay with calling this reality TV because this is my story."

For nearly a decade, The Awl has been urging the world to "Be Less Stupid." The editors warned of a vast internet landscape, cautioning that readers should approach it with intelligence. By writing thoughtfully about unconventional topics - such as a locket designed to hold "mad money" and a frustratingly unsatisfying West Elm couch dubbed "the Peggy" - The Awl and its affiliated sites strived to uphold their motto. On Tuesday, however, the editors of The Awl and one of its sister sites, The Hairpin, announced that the curtain would soon come down. Statements on the sites indicated that editorial operations would cease at the end of January. The closures mark another setback for independent publishers, which have long faced challenges in competing with larger entities that can offer advertisers a broader audience. In an email, The Awl's publisher, Michael Macher, attributed the decision to close to a steady decline in direct sales. In a statement, The Awl reflected on its efforts to build a better internet, acknowledging that it did not always succeed but striving to do so with integrity. The statement also proudly declared that the site's greatest achievement was the quality and passion of its audience, which it believed was unparalleled.

"Despite significant hurdles and a lengthy timeline, most efforts to revive net neutrality are underway. However, in Montana, Governor Steve Bullock has taken a different approach. By signing an executive order, he has brought net neutrality rules to a wide swath of the state. The order prohibits internet service providers with state government contracts from blocking or charging extra for faster website delivery to any customer in the state. Many major landline and mobile broadband providers, including Charter, CenturyLink, AT&T, and Verizon, currently hold government contracts in Montana. The new requirements will apply to all new and renewed contracts signed after July 1, 2018."

"I'm new to Instagram. Besides the service suggesting Facebook friends who also have Instagram accounts, how do I discover new people to follow? To find new users, you can utilize Instagram's search function, similar to other social networks like Twitter and LinkedIn. Simply tap the magnifying glass icon in the Instagram toolbar to access the search page, where you can search for specific individuals, hashtags, or locations that match your keywords. The search results will also include top accounts. Hashtags are labels that start with the "#" symbol (e.g., #FlyEaglesFly). Users add them to captions to categorize their posts and make them easier to find. The hashtag page on Instagram displays all posts that use the same tag."

"A revealing expose of the underground drug market, Silk Road, has raised concerns that valuable content like this could vanish from the internet if the wealthy owners of Gawker and L.A. Weekly decide to remove it. To mitigate this risk, the Freedom of the Press Foundation has announced that it will begin archiving online content deemed vulnerable to deletion or manipulation, starting with the two publications. The organization, which advocates for and defends adversarial journalism, aims to safeguard publications from the 'billionaire problem' - the ability of wealthy individuals to acquire and silence news outlets."

A significant development unfolded on Thursday in the ongoing saga surrounding the future of the $37 billion Redstone media empire, as CBS Corporation and Viacom announced plans to revisit a potential merger, reviving a proposal that stalled just over a year ago. In a joint statement, CBS and Viacom revealed that their boards have established independent committees of directors to assess the feasibility of a combination, but cautioned that there is no guarantee that a deal will be reached or on what terms it might occur. The companies' decision to re-examine a potential merger comes as they acknowledge the need to grow in order to remain competitive in the rapidly evolving media landscape, where scale is increasingly paramount. This shift in strategy is likely driven by the recent consolidation trends in the industry, including Disney's agreement to acquire most of 21st Century Fox and AT&T's pursuit of Time Warner for $85.4 billion. Additionally, traditional media companies are facing increased competition from technology giants like Apple and Facebook, which have expanded into the entertainment sector.

HBO is venturing into the world of podcasts, announcing a partnership with the hosts of the popular "Pod Save America" podcast to produce a series of hour-long TV specials later this year. This move comes just a week after HBO premiered the first of four specials featuring Jessica Williams and Phoebe Robinson, the hosts of the "2 Dope Queens" podcast, which received positive reviews and included an interview with Jon Stewart.
