"Pod Save America," a podcast hosted by Jon Favreau, Jon Lovett, Dan Pfeiffer, and Tommy Vietor - all Obama White House alumni - has become a haven for liberal Americans since the start of the Trump era. Initially produced as a podcast called "Keepin' It 1600" for Bill Simmons's website, The Ringer, during the 2016 campaign, the hosts continued the show after the election due to its popularity. With Donald Trump's presidency disrupting the media landscape - as seen in Stephen Colbert's high ratings and MSNBC's surge in viewership - "Pod Save America" now averages around 1.5 million listeners per episode. HBO has partnered with Crooked Media, the media company founded by Favreau, Lovett, and Vietor, to produce the TV specials.

Security experts have uncovered evidence that the attack was planned as far back as late last year. The attack was specifically designed to disrupt the Pyeongchang Games or send a political message, and was directed at the Pyeongchang Organizing Committee. According to Cisco's Talos threat intelligence division, the malware's purpose was to destroy the host computer and leave it offline, with no intention of leaving the machine usable. However, the attackers stopped short of causing destruction, erasing only backup files on Windows machines and leaving the possibility open for responders to reboot and fix the damage. Talos researchers are puzzled by this decision, with Craig Williams, a senior technical leader, asking, "Why did they pull their punch?" and speculating that it may be a political message intended to convey that the attackers could have done more harm. Other internet security companies, such as CrowdStrike, have reached similar conclusions, with Adam Meyers, vice president of intelligence, revealing that the destructive payload was constructed on December 27 at 11:39 a.m. Coordinated Universal Time, equivalent to 6:39 a.m. Eastern Time, 2:39 p.m. in Moscow, and 8:39 p.m. in South Korea.

"Can I use Microsoft Office on a Chromebook? While Chromebooks run on Google's Chrome OS, which was designed for netbooks and lightweight laptops, you can't install traditional Windows or Mac versions of Microsoft Office on a Chromebook. However, Microsoft's Office apps for Android devices can now run on newer Chromebook models that support app downloads from the Google Play store. These apps are free for devices with screens under 10.1 inches, but you'll need a free Microsoft account to create and edit files. For Chromebooks and tablets with larger screens, you'll need a paid subscription to Microsoft's Office 365 service, which starts at around $7 per month."

ABC executives expressed concern before the ceremony, stating that Oscar winners shouldn't feel pressured to deliver fiery political speeches. Instead, they suggested keeping the tone lighthearted and enjoyable. The ceremony largely avoided discussing the industry's concerns about the Trump administration, a departure from the politics-heavy Golden Globes and Emmys. However, the show did highlight the #MeToo and Time's Up movements. TV executives often attribute poor ratings to a lackluster lineup of performers or movies. In contrast, "The Shape of Water" broke records with $57.4 million in ticket sales, making it the biggest best picture winner in five years since "Argo" won in 2013. Live award show ratings have been plummeting over the past six months. The Grammys saw a 25% decline in viewership in January, and the Screen Actors Guild Awards experienced a 30% drop. This trend is consistent across most live events, including the Super Bowl and the Olympics, which also saw significant declines in viewership this year.

Russ Solomon, who passed away on Sunday at the age of 92, left behind a legacy as the creator of Tower Records, a music emporium that was a beloved destination for many music enthusiasts. With its iconic yellow-and-red color scheme, "No Music, No Life" slogan, and expansive aisles stocked with LPs and CDs, Tower Records dominated the retail music industry before the digital era. At its peak, the chain had over 200 stores across 15 countries and annual sales exceeding $1 billion. However, debt and shifting consumer habits ultimately led to its closure in 2006. Solomon's journey began at his father's drugstore in Sacramento, where he sold used jukebox records as a teenager. From there, he built a retail empire that was renowned for its vast selection of music and the vibrant culture that surrounded it. Tower Records' employees were passionate music aficionados, and the stores, which stayed open till midnight, became gathering places for fans. The locations on Sunset Boulevard in Hollywood and Broadway in Greenwich Village became popular tourist attractions, and even attracted celebrity devotees like Bruce Springsteen and Bette Midler. However, Tower Records' most famous patron was Elton John, who would often visit the Hollywood store early in the morning. A 2015 documentary, "All Things Must Pass: The Rise and Fall of Tower Records," features footage of John browsing the aisles and purchasing vinyl records in the 1970s. Solomon's reliance on debt to fuel Tower's expansion ultimately became a burden on the company's finances, particularly by the early 2000s. The decline of the music industry, exacerbated by online piracy, also took a toll on Tower Records. The company suffered significant losses, including $10 million in 2000 and $90 million in 2001. In 2004, Tower Records' parent company filed for bankruptcy in the United States, and two years later, the company closed its 89 American stores after liquidation sales. Outside the first store in Sacramento, employees left a poignant message: "All things must pass." In October 2006, a Tower Records store near Lincoln Center in New York was bustling with shoppers seeking out final deals, as photographed by Michael Nagle for The New York Times.

According to Nielsen, physical album sales in the United States, which reached a high of 785 million in 2000, plummeted to 103 million in the most recent year, as music consumption shifted towards digital formats.

I'm looking for a lightweight laptop, but I still need to use CDs and DVDs, which seem to be a thing of the past. Is there a way to still use discs with these modern computers? 

When designing modern laptops, many manufacturers have eliminated disc drives, along with floppy drives, Ethernet jacks, and other outdated technology, as cloud servers and wireless networks have become the norm for data storage and internet connections. The quest for smaller, lighter laptops with ample space for rechargeable batteries has also led to the removal of these once-standard computer components. 

However, it's still possible to use discs with these laptops. You can opt for external hardware to do the job. Keep in mind that some newer laptop models may only have USB-C ports, so make sure you know what type of connectors are compatible with the laptop you're planning to buy. If your preferred disc drive model doesn't match your laptop's connector, you can always get an adapter.

In the decaying leaves of one of Singapore's last remaining intact forests, the peculiar heads of carnivorous creatures, each the size of an egg, emerge from the soggy floor. It appears as though they are belching, singing, or screaming the catchphrase "Feed me Seymour," a phrase reminiscent of their Hollywood cousin. This unusual pitcher plant, Nepenthes ampullaria, is native to Southeast Asia and the Malay Peninsula. The "Seymour" it's referencing is actually the worm larva of Xenoplatyura beaveri, a fungus gnat that develops inside the plant's mouth. When mature, the gnat resembles a mosquito with impressive biceps.

This unlikely duo has a peculiar relationship. The plant provides a safe haven for the gnat larva to eat and develop, while the larva, in turn, builds a web across the plant's lips, captures and devours other insects, and then deposits its ammonium-rich waste into the plant's pitcher. The plant, in turn, feeds on these nutrients. This unusual arrangement is an example of "mutualism," a concept explored in a recent study published in Biology Letters.

Researchers, including Weng Ngai Lam, a graduate student in botany at the National University of Singapore, have conducted laboratory experiments to simulate this insect-plant interaction in the wild. Their findings suggest that cohabitation may have benefits for these obscure organisms. The study of tiny pitcher plant communities like this one may uncover secrets about plant and insect life, revealing the intricate relationships that exist in the natural world.

The top menu bar of my Mac has become cluttered with icons that I rarely use and find distracting. Is there a way to get rid of them? Most of the icons on the right side of the Mac's menu bar, which Apple calls "status icons," can be removed, rearranged, or restored to suit your personal preferences. These icons are designed to provide quick access to settings like network, Bluetooth, and AirPlay, as well as third-party apps that may add their own mini-menus. Typically, Spotlight search, Siri, and the Mac's Notifications Center are located on the far right side of the menu bar. You can remove unwanted menu-bar icons in two ways. When you click on a status icon and open the app's preferences, you may find a checkbox to toggle off the menu-bar display. (You can always restore the icon in the program's preferences if you change your mind later.)

To use picture-in-picture video with Safari on a Mac, you'll need macOS Sierra or later. This feature allows you to play a video in a floating window while keeping other pages and programs open on your desktop. Picture-in-picture mode works in Safari for videos on websites that use HTML 5 playback, such as Vimeo and YouTube. Additionally, videos from Apple's iTunes Store and some other apps support this feature.

To access picture-in-picture mode, open a compatible video in Safari and click the icon in the playback controls toolbar that resembles two rectangles. This will pop out the video in a small, resizable window that you can move around the screen by dragging its corner. If you don't want to anchor the window to a screen corner, hold down the Command key while dragging the window to your preferred position.

When you hover your cursor over the video window, you'll see controls to pause or play the video, exit picture-in-picture mode, or close the window entirely. However, to fast-forward or rewind through the video, you'll need to use the playback controls on the video's page in the main Safari window.

The rise of streaming has fragmented the television audience, making it a rare occurrence for a show to attract more than 20 million viewers. However, live broadcasts of major sporting events and awards shows still manage to draw large crowds. The interview segment featuring Ms. Clifford proved to be a major draw, surpassing the viewership of this year's Grammys (19.8 million) and Golden Globes (19 million). The "60 Minutes" episode also outperformed the usual editions of NBC's "Sunday Night Football," which averaged 18 million viewers, and came close to matching the viewership of ABC's Academy Awards broadcast last month, which had 26.5 million viewers. The highly anticipated segment on Ms. Clifford sparked viewing parties across the country. The broadcast also outperformed recent "60 Minutes" breakout episodes, including the El Chapo-focused interview with Sean Penn, which drew 20.6 million viewers in January 2016, and Lesley Stahl's sit-down with Mr. Trump and his family, which drew 20 million viewers in November 2016 shortly after his presidential election win.

Nickelodeon's most successful producer over the past two decades, Dan Schneider, is ending his partnership with the cable channel. As a former child actor who appeared in "Head of the Class" and "Better Off Dead," Schneider has created numerous hit shows for Nickelodeon, including "iCarly," "Drake & Josh," and "Kenan & Kel." Dubbed the "Norman Lear of children's television" by The New York Times, Schneider's production company, Schneider's Bakery, is also behind Nickelodeon's current top-rated show, "Henry Danger." However, one of his shows, "Game Shakers," was recently discontinued. According to a joint statement released on Monday night, Nickelodeon and Schneider, 52, have agreed not to renew their current deal after "many conversations about future directions and opportunities." The statement explained that since several Schneider's Bakery projects are nearing completion, both parties have decided that this is a natural time to explore new opportunities and projects.

"I've installed ad-blocking software on my computer, but I still see ads on some pages, even though the site didn't ask me to turn off the blocker. Why is this? The reason is that browser utilities like AdBlock or AdBlock Plus may still display less-intrusive ads from companies that have been approved by the independent Acceptable Ads Committee. This is because AdBlock Plus, which started the Acceptable Ads initiative, makes money by allowing these ads to pass through its filters. The initiative aims to strike a balance between the needs of web users who don't want to be bombarded with aggressive ads and the needs of websites that rely on advertising revenue to support their content.

"Acceptable" ads are those that don't use animation and don't interrupt the reader's experience on the site. Even if your ad-blocker program is set to allow non-intrusive ads by default, you can disable this feature in the program's settings. However, if you frequently visit a site and find its advertising acceptable, you may want to consider allowing its ads through your filter or adding the site to the ad-blocking program's white list.

To "white-list" a site means to make an exception for it in your ad-blocking program, allowing advertising to appear. While some ads can be distracting, excessive, or even laden with malware, most sites run ads because they need the money to sustain themselves. Some sites have implemented ad-blocker detection tools and will prevent your browser from loading the page unless you white-list the site. Others may ask you to white-list them in exchange for displaying a minimal amount of advertising.

If you need to white-list a site, click the ad-blocker icon in the browser's toolbar and look for the option to pause or disable the current filtering. The program's toolbar menu may also display a list of sites you have white-listed, along with controls for fine-tuning your ad filters."

The Atlantic magazine has severed its ties with conservative writer Kevin D. Williamson, whose hiring in March sparked a heated online debate about what views are acceptable in mainstream publications. The controversy centered around Williamson's extreme stance on abortion, which he advocates should be punished as premeditated homicide, potentially with the death penalty. This hardline view was first expressed in a 2014 Twitter exchange and ultimately led to his departure from the magazine. After hiring Williamson, Editor-in-Chief Jeffrey Goldberg initially defended him, stating that he didn't want to judge individuals based on their worst tweets or isolated statements. However, Goldberg later reversed his stance, citing a podcast episode from the same month in which Williamson elaborated on his anti-abortion views, which he deemed more than just trollish.

A young sperm whale that washed up on a beach in Cape Palos, Spain, in February likely died due to its inability to digest the massive amount of plastic trash, fish netting, and garbage bags it had consumed. The 33-foot-long whale, which weighed only 13,000 pounds, was swept onto the rocky shore on February 27. Despite being still growing, the whale was unusually underweight, with a typical adult sperm whale reaching up to 120,000 pounds. A necropsy revealed that the whale's stomach and intestines were clogged with 64 pounds of trash, including plastic bags, ropes, netting, and a plastic drum, which it was unable to digest or pass through its system. This caused severe inflammation, leading to the whale's decline and eventual death. Sperm whales, which can dive to great depths to hunt squid, often linger near the surface, making them vulnerable to ingesting floating debris that may be mistaken for food. Unfortunately, pollution in the ocean has devastating effects on wildlife, particularly in areas where buoyant debris accumulates in "islands" of trash that float above or just below the surface. One such area, the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, is estimated to contain at least 87,000 tons of plastic. As plastic pollution continues to grow, some scientists believe it may have a greater impact on animal populations than climate change. In 2008, two whales were found on a beach in Northern California with bags and netting in their stomachs, likely discarded by fishermen. One whale's stomach had ruptured, and the other, which had consumed over 160 pounds of trash, likely starved to death as the garbage obstructed its stomach. The authorities in Murcia have released the results of a necropsy conducted by the El Valle Wildlife Recovery Center as part of a campaign to raise awareness about the impact of plastic and trash in the coastal region's waters. Volunteers are working to clean up local beaches and are urging the public to be more mindful of their plastic waste disposal. "It's crucial that we address this issue through both cleanup efforts and education, making sure our citizens are aware of the importance of protecting our environment," said Ms. Rosauro.

A recent study has revealed that sea turtles use the Earth's magnetic fields to navigate back to their birthplace, a journey that can span decades. By analyzing the genetics of loggerhead turtles, researchers discovered that the turtles swim in a large loop from their nesting grounds in North Carolina and Florida to North Africa, before returning to nest on beaches within a 40-50 mile radius of their birthplace. The study suggests that the turtles imprint the unique magnetic signature of their home beach, a process known as geomagnetic imprinting. According to Dr. Kenneth Lohmann, a professor at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, and senior author of the study, this knowledge is crucial for restoring sea turtle populations to areas where they once thrived before being hunted to extinction. He also notes that similar principles may be applicable for restoring salmon and other fish populations to their natural habitats, as many birds and fish also rely on magnetic fields for navigation.

Facebook has replaced its head of policy in the United States, Erin Egan, as the company faces intense scrutiny from federal regulators and lawmakers. Egan, who has served as head of policy for the past two years and is also Facebook's chief privacy officer, was responsible for lobbying and government relations. She will be replaced on an interim basis by Kevin Martin, who currently serves as Facebook's vice president of mobile and global access policy and is a former Republican chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. Although Egan is stepping down as head of policy, she will remain chief privacy officer and focus on developing global privacy policies. According to Andy Stone, a Facebook spokesperson, Egan will partner with product teams to rebuild trust in how the company handles user information.

I have about 40% of my storage space left on my Nook device, and I'm hesitant to delete my favorite books. However, I'm curious about what happens to my digital book collection once my device runs out of memory or becomes outdated. The answer lies in the fact that, like its Amazon Kindle competitor, the Barnes & Noble Nook line of tablets and e-readers stores digital book purchases online. Even if I delete or archive a book to free up space, I can always download and read it again from the cloud backup. Additionally, I can access my books in my web browser for a larger screen experience.

To remove books from my Nook, the process varies depending on the model. I can find specific instructions on the Barnes & Noble support pages. On my current Nook Tablet, I can access the Nook Library app, select the book I want to archive, and press my finger to select Remove. Note that choosing the Delete From Account option will permanently remove the book from my collection.

To archive multiple books at once, I can go to the Library's Grid view screen, tap the three-dot menu icon, and select Manage Storage. From there, I can remove books from my list. I can also view all my Nook books by choosing Archive from the same corner menu. Books that are no longer physically on my device will be marked with a cloud-download arrow on the cover.

Researchers at Cornell University and other institutions are exploring a novel approach to track gypsy moth spores through indirect genetic sampling, rather than traditional microscopic examination, in order to improve predictions of moth damage. According to a 2017 study published in Applied and Environmental Microbiology, a single cloud of spores can spread over 40 miles or more from its original source. The gypsy moth is the adult stage of a caterpillar species that poses a significant threat to tree canopies. Introduced from France in 1869, the gypsy moth's feeding habits are more destructive to trees than those of native tent caterpillars, which it resembles. A fungus that specifically targets gypsy moths was first detected in the Northeast in 1989, although efforts to introduce it as a biological control measure began as early as 1910. In 2000, a coordinated program was launched by 11 states and the US Forest Service to combat the gypsy moth infestation. While the program has not completely halted the spread of the moths, it has significantly slowed their advance. The Cornell researchers are hopeful that the natural fungal predator can be harnessed to control the gypsy moth population and reduce the reliance on insecticides.

Can you record a video of what's happening on your iPhone 7 screen? Yes, Apple provides a Screen Recording tool with its iOS 11 system, but you need to enable it first. To do this, go to your iPhone's home screen, open the Settings app, and then tap Control Center. Next, tap Customize Controls, scroll down to More Controls, and add Screen Recording by tapping the green plus (+) button. Once you've added it, a circular "record" button will appear on your Control Center screen when you swipe up from the bottom of the screen. To start recording, swipe up to open the Control Center and press the Screen Recording button. If you want to include audio with your screen recording, press the button until a menu pops up with the Microphone Audio option.

In a long-awaited announcement, Lachlan Murdoch, 46, has been named the new chief executive and chairman of the Murdoch family's television company, a role that had been expected. The appointment solidifies Lachlan's position as the successor to his father, Rupert Murdoch, 87, who will take on the title of co-chairman. The news release from 21st Century Fox, which is planning to sell a significant portion of its assets to Disney, did not mention Lachlan's younger brother, James Murdoch, 45, who currently leads the company. James is expected to venture out on his own, possibly starting a new venture that focuses on digital media investments. The management changes were announced as part of the proposed sale, which is pending shareholder and regulatory approval. However, Comcast is trying to disrupt the deal with a hostile bid. Regardless of the outcome, the sale will involve the transfer of 21st Century Fox's movie studio, its stake in Hulu and cable networks, and its interests in overseas TV providers.

A bitter feud between two major media companies shows no signs of abating. On Wednesday, CBS Corporation took a bold step by amending its lawsuit against its parent company, escalating the power struggle between its CEO, Leslie Moonves, and controlling shareholder Shari Redstone. The latest move is part of a series of efforts by CBS to block Shari Redstone, president of National Amusements, from merging the company with its corporate sibling, Viacom. The amendment comes after a heated meeting where CBS's board voted to reduce Ms. Redstone's influence over the company, a move National Amusements promptly deemed invalid. In the revised complaint filed in Delaware Chancery Court, CBS asserts the independence of its board and asks the court to determine which interpretation of the recent vote is legally valid. The amended lawsuit also accuses Ms. Redstone of attempting to coerce a merger between CBS and Viacom, which it claims would not be in the best interests of CBS and its shareholders. While Ms. Redstone has expressed support for a merger, she maintains she has no intention of forcing one.

Is there a quick and easy way to create a PDF file from the text of an online article, excluding advertisements, so I can read it offline or print it more conveniently from my computer without having to copy and paste the text? If your browser has a "reader mode" that temporarily removes ads and other distracting page elements, you can create simple PDF files without needing additional software. To do this, simply switch to reader mode when you find an article you want to save, then use the PDF-saving function in the Print box on your Windows PC or Mac to create a copy of the article in a new file. Note that some websites may not support reader modes, but many do. For articles that span multiple pages, look for a "read on one page" or "Read More" button that displays the full text on one screen.

HBO has announced plans to develop a pilot episode for one of its five "Game of Thrones" prequels, which delves into the origins of the White Walkers. The premium cable channel made the announcement on Friday, revealing that the pilot will take place thousands of years before the events of the original series. While a release date has not been confirmed, the network has provided some insight into the show's premise. According to HBO, the series will explore the world's descent from a golden age of heroes to its darkest hour, and will uncover the true origins of the White Walkers and other mysteries. George R.R. Martin, author of the "Game of Thrones" book series, collaborated with Jane Goldman on the story, while Goldman, who has worked on films like "Kingsman" and "X-Men: First Class," wrote the teleplay and will serve as showrunner for the pilot.

In ancient Mesoamerica, stretching from central Mexico to Central America, turquoise was a highly valued gemstone due to its vibrant blue and green hues. The Aztecs and Mixtecs utilized the mineral to craft armbands, nose plugs, and decorative handles for sacrificial knives, as well as intricate mosaics of warriors and fearsome statues of double-headed serpents. For over a century, archaeologists have puzzled over the origins of the turquoise used in these stunning pieces of art and jewelry. Despite finding little evidence of turquoise mining in Mesoamerica, some researchers have suggested that the turquoise artifacts in the region were the result of a long-distance trade exchange with ancient civilizations in the American Southwest, where turquoise mines have been discovered. However, a recent geochemical analysis of Aztec and Mixtec turquoise has revealed that the mineral did not originate in the American Southwest, but rather in Mesoamerica itself. This finding, published in the journal Science Advances, also challenges the notion that there was extensive cultural exchange between Mesoamerican and Southwest American societies before the Spanish invasion in the 1500s.

For years, I relied on Picasa to edit my photos and send them to be printed. It was an intuitive program to use. However, Google has discontinued support for Picasa. Are there any alternative programs that are just as easy to navigate? 

After retiring Picasa from further development in 2016, Google announced that the desktop photo-editing program would no longer be able to upload, download, or manage online albums. While similar programs exist, they may not offer the same level of editing tools and online album-sharing capabilities as the free Picasa software. To find a suitable replacement, make a list of the features you used most frequently and look for a program that matches those capabilities. 

Google Photos, which replaced Picasa in Google's free software lineup, might be the simplest option for your files, as your Picasa Web Albums are likely already stored there due to Google's transition from the old program to the new one. Simply log in at photos.google.com using the same Google Account name and password you used for Picasa. Google Photos allows you to back up your computer's pictures to online server space and order printed photo books. However, some users may find the photo-editing tools less comprehensive than those offered in Picasa.

Every week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the latest news, providing insightful analysis and a dash of humor on the most significant developments in the tech industry. Hi, readers! I'm Jack Nicas, a technology reporter based in San Francisco for The New York Times. We're introducing a new format for this newsletter: a different tech correspondent will deliver it each week. (I'm kicking things off, still recovering from my birthday celebrations in Mexico - thanks, editor!) As news reporters, not opinionated columnists like Farhad Manjoo or Kevin Roose, we'll strive to offer our perspectives and inject some humor into our coverage. This week, it would be insensitive to summarize the news without addressing the controversy surrounding the Trump administration's recently halted policy of separating immigrant children from their parents at the border. The story dominated the headlines, seeping into nearly every area of coverage, including tech. As we've seen over the past two years, tech companies have once again found themselves drawn into political debates they've long sought to avoid. This week, my colleague Sheera Frenkel reported that over 100 Microsoft employees signed a letter urging the company to halt business with Immigration and Customs Enforcement, the federal agency responsible for separating families at the border. Executives from Apple, Google, Facebook, and other tech giants also publicly condemned the policy.

Over the past four years, Facebook has made grand announcements about developing a fleet of solar-powered drones with massive wingspans, capable of beaming internet access to people worldwide who lack online connectivity. With a massive user base, Facebook needs innovative solutions to attract new users. However, on Wednesday, the ambitious project came to a halt. Facebook announced in a blog post that it would no longer build the drones, despite being committed to its original goal of expanding internet access. Instead, the company will rely on other companies to develop aircraft. A manufacturing plant in western England, where the drones were being produced, will be closed. Facebook's co-founder and CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, had envisioned solar-powered drones flying for months without landing, 60,000 feet above remote areas. The aircraft were massive, filling a warehouse, but weighed as much as a grand piano. After a successful test flight in 2016, Zuckerberg hailed the project as "something that's never been done before." Unfortunately, the drone initiative, known as Project Aquila, faced several setbacks, including a crash landing and broken wing. The project was part of Facebook's Internet.org initiative to expand internet access in underdeveloped areas, a controversial effort criticized by some as a ploy to attract new users.

Google Maps provides driving directions based on available highways and traffic conditions, but can you calculate the distance between two towns in a straight line, "as the crow flies"? Google's driving directions take into account roads, traffic, detours, and other factors that may deviate from the most direct route. While this is helpful for trip planning and navigation, Google Maps also offers a simple tool to measure distances between points in a straight line. To access this feature, right-click on the starting point or city you want to use in a desktop web browser, then select "Measure distance" from the menu. Next, click on the second point on the map to display the direct distance in miles and kilometers in a small box at the bottom of the window. You can add more points to measure by clicking elsewhere on the map, or delete an added point by clicking on it. You can also move measurement points by dragging them on the map. Once you've finished, click the X in the box at the bottom of the screen to complete the measurement.

Barnes & Noble announced on Tuesday that it had terminated its CEO, Demos Parneros, due to a violation of company policies, without specifying which policies were breached. The company emphasized that the decision was not related to any disagreement over financial reporting, policies, or practices, nor was it related to potential fraud. As a result of his termination, Parneros will not receive a severance package and has been removed from the company's board of directors. This marks the fourth time in five years that Barnes & Noble's CEO has departed. Parneros had held the CEO position for just over a year, having previously served as chief operating officer before being promoted to replace Ronald Boire, who had a similar brief tenure as CEO before being ousted in August 2016 due to concerns that he was not a good fit for the company.

Last week, Showtime generated significant buzz on social media by posting a teaser on YouTube, announcing the upcoming release of what it claims is "the most dangerous show in television history." On Monday, the network revealed more details: Sacha Baron Cohen is returning to television with a seven-episode series, "Who Is America?", which will premiere on Sunday. The series marks Baron Cohen's first starring role on TV since 2004, when HBO aired the final season of "Da Ali G Show". "Who Is America?" has been in development for over a year. The show's format appears to be consistent with Baron Cohen's previous work, which blurred the line between satire and reporting by featuring the star in disguise, interviewing unwitting subjects. On Sunday, Baron Cohen's Twitter account linked to a trailer that began with the phrase, "Imagine if Sacha Baron Cohen had been undercover, secretly filming a new show for a year." The trailer then showed a snippet of former Vice President Dick Cheney signing what Baron Cohen's new character referred to as his "waterboard kit". The video has been viewed over one million times.

Since its inception in 2012, Wing has faced challenges in perfecting its technology, to the point where it had to scrap its entire design and start anew. However, its recent advancements suggest that the team is now satisfied with its progress. Despite this, technical hurdles remain, such as delivering drones in urban areas, and regulatory challenges may prove even more significant. The Federal Aviation Administration is gradually authorizing drone delivery tests in the US, including a forthcoming pilot program with Wing in Virginia. In an effort to turn regulatory requirements into a business opportunity, Wing is developing software that enables unmanned aircraft to navigate the skies, essentially creating an automated air traffic control system for drones. Meanwhile, Alphabet's other new unit, Loon, is building high-altitude balloons to deliver internet connections to rural or disaster-stricken areas. These massive balloons, which operate in the stratosphere at an altitude of around 13 miles above ground, use wind currents to cluster around areas with poor connectivity. Loon collaborates with local telecommunications companies to enhance cell service on the ground, acting as a temporary, floating cell tower. Loon, which originated in 2011 within X, has since traveled over 18 million miles, providing internet connectivity from Brazil to New Zealand. Last year, Loon delivered connections to Peru following floods and Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria.

"I have hundreds of TIFF-formatted photos and I'm looking for an efficient way to convert them all to JPG at once. The good news is that you can convert a large collection of images from one file format to another in a single step, just like renaming multiple photos simultaneously. TIFF files, commonly used in print production, tend to be much larger than JPG files, which are more compressed and suitable for web use. Most image-editing software, such as those in Adobe's Photoshop family, offer commands to convert TIFF files to JPG, and the program's help guide should provide specific conversion instructions for your version. However, if you don't use photo-management software, there are still plenty of affordable utility programs available. You can find these programs on the Mac and Windows app stores, which offer a range of options for converting file formats, resizing, and optimizing images in bulk. When choosing a program, be sure to read the reviews and ensure it meets your specific needs."

Waymo, a subsidiary of Google focused on autonomous vehicles, is aiming to make errand-running a breeze. The company announced a partnership with five businesses, including Walmart, Avis, and AutoNation, to provide self-driving car rides in the Phoenix area. This collaboration suggests Waymo's ambition to integrate its technology into daily life by transporting people between their homes, stores, restaurants, and other nearby destinations. Under its agreement with Walmart, customers who purchase groceries online will be able to summon a Waymo vehicle to take them to a store to collect their orders. The new service, set to launch this week, is the latest move by Walmart to gain a competitive edge in the grocery market, following the introduction of its personal shopper program and expansion of its online grocery delivery service, both of which are part of its intense rivalry with Amazon.

"How does my phone know to rotate the screen? And why doesn't it work sometimes? The answer lies in the accelerometer, a sensor found in many devices, including phones, fitness trackers, and smartwatches. This sensor measures changes in velocity, allowing the Android or iOS software to determine how you're holding your phone and adjust the screen orientation accordingly. This ensures that when you switch from browsing the web to watching a wide-screen video, the screen automatically rotates. The accelerometer's motion-sensing capabilities also enable features like augmented-reality apps, games, and navigation tools that track your speed and direction."

Jake Tapper, the seasoned CNN anchor, was forced to interrupt a guest and turn to the camera with a shrug, saying, "I apologize, we have some breaking news," as he flashed a lopsided grin. The hour-long broadcast that followed was a whirlwind of unexpected developments, with journalists struggling to keep pace with the unfolding drama that seemed to rival the most outlandish plot twists from "House of Cards." On Tuesday, a stunning double whammy hit the news: Michael D. Cohen, President Trump's longtime lawyer, pleaded guilty in a Manhattan courtroom, while Paul Manafort, Trump's former campaign manager, was convicted of eight counts of fraud in a Virginia trial. The simultaneous bombshells came at a particularly inopportune time, as news divisions were already depleted by the usual August vacations. The scramble was evident: Preet Bharara, the former federal prosecutor, shared his thoughts with CNN via a scratchy phone line that kept dropping in and out. Meanwhile, Jeffrey Toobin, the network's senior legal analyst, was at his weekend home in Connecticut when producers suddenly called to say a camera crew was on its way to his living room, where he ended up being filmed.

Graham Brookie, director of the Digital Forensic Research Lab at the Atlantic Council, views the recent efforts by Facebook, Microsoft, and others to be more proactive as a positive trend, but notes that it's only part of the solution. "This is not a solution," Brookie emphasized, "because it doesn't address the root problem of vulnerabilities in democratic society that the internet has exposed." He believes that a true solution would require a societal reckoning, with the federal government taking a lead role, and citizens becoming more vigilant about online content and its impact on their political lives. However, even with these efforts, Brookie cautioned that the best we may be able to achieve is a perpetual cat-and-mouse game between good and bad actors online, with the goal of reducing damage rather than achieving a definitive solution.

As for the upcoming midterm elections, Brookie expressed uncertainty about the level of confidence that can be placed in their safety from hacking and propaganda operations. While Facebook and other tech companies are increasing their efforts to police their sites, some of the threats they've identified so far appear to be unrelated to the election. For example, the Iranian operation has been ongoing for years and seems to be aimed at influencing American policy rather than the election itself. In a recent call with reporters, Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg claimed that the company has made progress in keeping elections safe, citing lessons learned from international elections since 2016. "He noted that in recent elections, including the French, German, Alabama special, and Mexican elections, our systems have successfully detected a significant number of fake accounts that potentially sought to cause harm on the system."

Beijing - The escalating trade tensions between China and the United States have created a challenging environment for the world's second-largest economy. Chinese stock markets have experienced a significant downturn, and the currency has been volatile. However, Alibaba Group, the Chinese e-commerce giant, is bucking the trend, with sales surging by over 60% in the latest quarter compared to the same period last year. Despite this, the company's profits fell by more than 40% due to the increased valuation of Ant Financial, an Alibaba subsidiary. This is because Alibaba has awarded some employees with Ant shares, leading to a significant increase in compensation expenses. If not for this, the company's profits would have grown by over a third. As one of the world's largest and most influential digital retailers, Alibaba is now focusing on providing technology to enable commerce, both online and offline, as well as logistics and marketing services. The company's strong quarterly results suggest that its expansion efforts have not harmed its core business of selling ads to merchants on its platforms.

The 2018 Governors Awards, also known as the Honorary Oscars, will celebrate the careers of Steven Spielberg's publicist, the composer of the "Mission: Impossible" theme song, Cicely Tyson, and two powerhouse producers. According to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, Oscar statuettes will be awarded to Marvin Levy, who has spent five decades in film publicity, including four years working with Spielberg; Lalo Schifrin, who has written scores for over 100 films, including "Dirty Harry" and "The Cincinnati Kid", as well as the iconic "Mission: Impossible" theme; and Cicely Tyson, a renowned actress with 91 credits to her name, including "Fried Green Tomatoes", "Diary of a Mad Black Woman", and "Sounder", for which she was nominated for an Academy Award in 1973. Marvin Levy will make history as the first publicist to receive an Oscar. Additionally, the academy has decided to grant its Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award for producing for the first time in eight years. The award, a bust of Thalberg, who was the head of production at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in the 1920s and '30s, will be presented to Kathleen Kennedy and Frank Marshall, who have collaborated since 1991. Kathleen Kennedy, who runs Lucasfilm, the Disney-owned "Star Wars" studio, is an eight-time Oscar nominee for producing films like "The Color Purple" and "Lincoln" with Spielberg. Kennedy, who started her career as Spielberg's secretary, will be the first woman to receive the Thalberg Award, which was last given to Francis Ford Coppola in 2010.

When you drip water onto a hot pan, the droplets will behave like tiny, speeding hovercraft, sliding around on cushions of steam. This phenomenon is known as the Leidenfrost effect, which has been observed by cooks and scientists alike. German doctor and theologian Johann Gottlob Leidenfrost first described the effect in his book on the properties of water in 1756. However, French scientists have recently made a new discovery about the behavior of these skittering drops. When the droplets are small enough, about a millimeter in diameter, the heat from the pan causes them to tilt and rotate, which propels them to roll. This phenomenon was previously unknown because scientists had not attempted to pin a water droplet to a precisely flat surface before. Additionally, the clear color of water makes it difficult to see the liquid's movement. It was previously thought that the droplets moved due to air currents or sliding down a slope, but the new research shows that they can move independently. "It's surprisingly simple," said David Quere, a scientist at the Ecole Polytechnique and ESPCI Paris. "The drop is running away, and it has a little motor inside, which is surprising." Quere and his colleagues published their findings in the journal Nature Physics this week. To observe the Leidenfrost effect, droplets of water were placed on a very flat, very hot, nonabsorbent surface held in place by a needle. The surface must be at least 400 degrees Fahrenheit, well above the boiling point of water, for the effect to occur. Some recipes use this test to determine whether a pan is hot enough. Large drops, measuring over 1.5 millimeters in diameter, have a flattened shape, resembling puddles. Within each drop, two convective cells rotate in opposite directions, much like two wheels spinning towards each other, canceling out each other's motion. The flow within the drop was visualized using tracers mixed with the water. As the water evaporates, the droplet shrinks and becomes nearly spherical, allowing for only one convective cell to exist. When the needle is lifted, the smaller droplet speeds away in the direction of its convective spin. The researchers' next step is to guide the droplets through channels or temperature gradients. There are still fundamental phenomena to be explored, such as why the surface temperature must be significantly higher than the boiling point for the drops to levitate. Interestingly, there is currently no clear answer to this question.

Our galaxy, the Milky Way, is home to billions of planets, many of which remain unseen by human eyes - at least for now. Just three decades ago, we had no idea if there were planets beyond our own solar system. In 1995, astronomers made a groundbreaking discovery when they found that a star in the constellation Pegasus was wobbling due to the gravitational pull of an unseen planet, an exoplanet that was scorching hot and inhospitable to life. The wobble method of planet hunting relies on sensitive spectroscopes that can detect the subtle changes in starlight caused by an orbiting planet. As a planet orbits its star, the starlight we see shifts from blue to red and back again, a phenomenon that can be detected by these advanced instruments. The Kepler space telescope, launched in 2009, revolutionized the field of exoplanet hunting by discovering thousands of planets in a small patch of the Milky Way. Unlike earlier methods, Kepler didn't look for wobbles; instead, it searched for small dips in starlight caused by a planet passing in front of its star. Kepler's findings were astounding, revealing a diverse range of exoplanets, including systems with multiple planets, icy worlds, scorching hot planets, and even planets from other galaxies that had been absorbed by the Milky Way. In recent years, astronomers have made significant progress in directly imaging exoplanets, capturing blurry but tantalizing glimpses of alien landscapes. We've also discovered a free-floating planet not bound to any star, as well as signs of planets being born, including dark rings of dust around newly formed stars. The next generation of planet hunters is now on the horizon. On April 16, 2018, the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite, or TESS, will launch from Cape Canaveral and spend two years scanning the entire sky for minute dips in brightness caused by nearby alien worlds. TESS is equipped with four cameras that can cover a 96-degree swath of the sky, which it will divide into sections and study for 27 days at a time before moving on to the next. "In two years, we will have mapped the entire sky. TESS will follow an unconventional orbit, venturing as far as the moon every two weeks before returning to Earth and releasing a flood of data to enthusiastic astronomers. As a planet hunter, TESS's discoveries can be further studied by the next generation of telescopes on Earth and in space. If fortunate, TESS may uncover planets with lakes, oceans, and atmospheres rich in chemicals, allowing us to detect signs of habitability or even life. The gases on these planets could reveal whether they are capable of supporting life similar to our own. The Milky Way is estimated to harbor more planets than stars, with a vast diversity that remains largely unexplored. In our quest for life and meaning in the universe, our own planet remains the ultimate benchmark."

A growing theory among astronomers suggests that our solar system may be hiding a large, ninth planet that has yet to be discovered. New findings about a small, icy world beyond Pluto have strengthened this idea. On Monday, astronomers led by Scott S. Sheppard from the Carnegie Institution for Science in Washington revealed the orbital details of this new world, which they have nicknamed the Goblin. Dr. Sheppard and his team first spotted the world, officially designated as 2015 TG387, during a systematic search for new worlds in the outer solar system, including the hypothetical Planet Nine. However, it took three years of additional observations to fully understand the world's orbit. "It took us three years to realize that it has an interesting orbit," Dr. Sheppard explained. The astronomers have submitted a paper detailing their discovery to The Astronomical Journal. The newly discovered world, estimated to be around 200 miles wide, is currently about 7.4 billion miles from the sun, or roughly 2.5 times farther away than Pluto. However, this distance is relatively close to the world's closest approach to the sun.

To combat a deadly pestilence, ants have formed an alliance with bacteria that produce a chemical capable of neutralizing the parasite. A recent discovery by Dr. Currie and his team has revealed that this partnership between ants and antimicrobial bacteria has been in existence for tens of millions of years. The key evidence came from two 20-million-year-old ants found trapped in amber in the Dominican Republic. One of the fossilized ants had specialized pockets on its head, known as crypts, which are also seen in modern ants and are believed to house the fungus-protecting bacteria, actinobacteria. The other ant specimen was found with gas bubbles on its body, likely produced by the respiration of the actinobacteria. "It's as if the ants are mobile pharmaceutical factories," said Dr. Currie, a co-author of the study, which was published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. This finding suggests that, like ants were ahead of humans in cultivating crops, they also preceded humans by tens of millions of years in partnering with microbes to produce antibiotics. Dr. Hongjie Li, an evolutionary biologist in Dr. Currie's lab and the lead author of the study, discovered the bacteria in the amber ants while inspecting the specimens using a scanning electron microscope at the Smithsonian Institution. "It was a surprise to me," Dr. Li said. The team combined this finding with data on 69 other ant species to reconstruct the ant's evolutionary tree. The results indicated that ants established their partnership with bacteria tens of millions of years ago, shortly after they developed their fungus-farming abilities.

It's been almost 3,000 years since Aesop penned "The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse," a timeless fable about an urban rodent introducing his rural cousin to the city's superior culinary delights. A recent study suggests that Aesop's fictional account may have been rooted in reality, as researchers have found significant differences in the diets of urban and rural rodents. By analyzing the remains of brown rats that lived in and around Toronto between 1790 and 1890, scientists discovered that city rats enjoyed a more varied and stable diet compared to their rural counterparts. Just as in Aesop's classic tale, city rats thrived on the abundance of human waste, while country rats struggled to survive. According to Eric Guiry, an archaeologist at Trent University in Ontario and lead author of the study, published in Proceedings of the Royal Society B, city rats had a significantly higher proportion of meat in their diet. "The difference is evident in their bones," Guiry noted. Guiry and his co-author, Michael Buckley of the University of Manchester, are pioneers in the field of paleoproteomics, which uses ancient bone proteins to gain insights into an animal's behavior. Guiry's interest in applying this technique to rats was driven by a desire to learn more about human populations in the 1800s without having to analyze human remains. The research also has practical implications for cities seeking to better manage their rodent populations.

"Embark on a journey to the vibrant coral reefs of Southeast Asia or Australia, and you'll likely encounter a wrasse. But which of the hundreds of wass species will you meet? These fish come in an astonishing range of sizes, from just an inch to over eight feet in length. Their bodies can be sleek and slender, like a cigar, or robust and chunky, like a football. Some wrasses have subdued colors, while others are a riot of color, as if they're attending a rave. Each species has evolved its own unique feeding strategy: humphead wrasses crush shellfish, tubelip wrasses slurp corals, and cleaner wrasses act like underwater carwashes, devouring parasites and dead tissue from other sea creatures. This incredible diversity is a result of wrasse ancestors migrating from the ancient Tethys Sea to the region that now bridges the Pacific and Indian Oceans. There, in a vast and vibrant cradle of coral reefs, they settled and diversified over tens of millions of years. Their story is part of a larger pattern: the Central Indo-Pacific has become the hottest spot for biodiversity in the world's oceans because many ancestors of today's marine life colonized it so long ago, according to a recent study published in Proceedings of the Royal Society B."

In 2009, renowned physicist and author Stephen W. Hawking hosted a party for time travelers, although the invitations were not publicly released until after the event. The invitations were designed to be durable enough to withstand the test of time, with the intention of reaching future humans who might develop the ability to travel back to the party. However, it's possible that they may not or won't be effective, as a video from the event shows Dr. Hawking sitting alone, surrounded by champagne, snacks, and balloons. Now, you can own a piece of that unique history by purchasing one of the invitations, or make an offer on it. The invitation is one of nearly two dozen items from Dr. Hawking's estate that will be auctioned off next week. Starting October 31, Christie's will host an online auction featuring items belonging to Dr. Hawking and three other iconic scientists: Sir Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, and Albert Einstein.

A team of astronomers has achieved the seemingly impossible by measuring the total amount of light produced by all stars in the universe. The staggering figure is 4 trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion photons, equivalent to 4 x 10^84 in scientific notation, or a 4 followed by 84 zeros. This enormous number was reported in the journal Science by Marco Ajello, an astrophysicist at Clemson University, and his colleagues. While the figure may sound daunting, it's essential to put it into perspective. The universe is vast, and the amount of light produced by all stars is equivalent to the illumination of a 60-watt bulb seen from 2.5 miles away. The observable universe, which is a bubble 14 billion light-years in radius, contains at least two trillion galaxies and a trillion trillion stars. Most of these stars and galaxies are too distant and faint to be detected by any human-made telescope. However, Dr. Ajello and his colleagues emphasize that the energy radiated by these stars is still present, filling the universe with a "fog" of photons known as the extragalactic background light.

NASA's InSight lander on Mars has captured the sounds of wind blowing across its surface, a historic first for the red planet. What's remarkable is that the lander doesn't have a microphone - instead, its seismometers, designed to measure marsquakes, picked up vibrations in the air, which are essentially sound waves. The winds, which were blowing at a moderate 10-15 miles per hour, caused the lander's solar panels to vibrate, and the seismometers recorded these vibrations. According to Thomas Pike, a scientist from Imperial College London, the process is similar to how humans hear sound. The solar panels act like the eardrum, the spacecraft structure is like the inner ear, and the seismometers function like the cochlea, converting vibrations into nerve signals. The recorded vibrations have a frequency of up to 50 Hertz, which is audible to humans as a low rumble. NASA has also created a version of the recording that boosts the sounds by two octaves. Bruce Banerdt, the principal investigator of the mission, described the sounds as "unworldly," saying they evoke the feeling of wind or ocean waves, but with an otherworldly quality. A second instrument, an air pressure sensor, also detected sound vibrations, although at a much lower frequency that is only audible to certain animals, such as elephants and whales. Here is a recording of the air pressure sensor's readings, sped up by a factor of 100, which raises the pitch by over six octaves. The sounds are lower in frequency because the instruments are not sensitive to higher frequencies. On Mars, the air is incredibly thin, with a density only about 1% of Earth's, which makes it more conducive to low-frequency sounds. The two Viking landers that NASA sent to Mars in 1976 were equipped with seismometers that captured some wind noise, but the recordings were made at lower sampling rates and didn't pick up any sounds at audible frequencies. According to Dr. Banerdt, the Viking seismometer did detect movements of the spacecraft, but it would be a stretch to describe them as sounds. NASA attempted to send microphones to Mars on the Mars Polar Lander spacecraft in 1999, but it crashed during landing. The Phoenix Mars lander was also equipped with a microphone, but it was left turned off to avoid any potential problems during landing.

Kathie Lee Gifford, co-anchor of the popular fourth hour of NBC's "Today," tearfully informed viewers on Tuesday that she would be leaving the morning show in April. "I've been in this business for 30 years, and I've never had the pleasure of working with a more wonderful group of people who consistently give their all," Ms. Gifford said, her voice cracking as her co-host, Hoda Kotb, fought back tears beside her. For the past decade, Ms. Gifford and Ms. Kotb, often accompanied by their signature glasses of wine, have been a beloved fixture of NBC's morning lineup. NBC News President Noah Oppenheim announced that Ms. Gifford will remain with the show until April, marking her 11th anniversary of hosting alongside Ms. Kotb. Oppenheim also stated that the network will reveal succession plans before Ms. Gifford's departure and that Hoda Kotb will undoubtedly remain a part of the show's future.

Harvard University has declined to comment on the discussions within its executive committee regarding Dr. Fryer, as well as whether the group requested his resignation. Dr. Fryer's spokesman has stated that he will not issue a statement on the matter. Dr. Fryer, a 41-year-old economist, is one of the most renowned young economists in the country and is among the highest-paid professors at Harvard. He achieved tenure at the age of 30, a record for the youngest African-American professor at the university. In 2015, Dr. Fryer received the John Bates Clark Medal, which honors an American economist under the age of 40 for significant contributions to economic thought and knowledge. However, his position at Harvard may be in jeopardy due to the findings of ongoing investigations into his conduct. An investigator has already substantiated seven instances of unwelcome sexual comments made by Dr. Fryer towards women. An investigation into allegations of harassment and retaliation is still ongoing, in addition to an inquiry into Dr. Fryer's spending and the lab's finances. Dr. Fryer was already under investigation and barred from entering his lab when he was nominated for the executive committee, according to Dr. Blanchard. The members of the nominating committee were unaware of the investigations, which Dr. Fryer failed to disclose. Some members learned of the allegations when The Harvard Crimson first reported on the investigations. Despite this, the executive committee's leadership did not ask Dr. Fryer about the matter. Dr. Fryer was elected to the executive committee this fall, but the vote sparked controversy within the profession. The committee members posted a statement acknowledging the allegations but stated that they would wait for Harvard to conclude its investigations before deciding how to proceed.

Amazon is expanding its brick-and-mortar retail presence to New York City. Recently, barricades were erected outside a retail space in the upscale Time Warner Center in Manhattan, with a sign announcing the imminent arrival of an Amazon bookstore. On Thursday, Amazon spokesperson Deborah Bass confirmed that the company will occupy a space previously held by Armani Exchange. The Manhattan location, set to open in the spring, will be the eighth Amazon store to open or be announced. Currently, stores are already open in or near Portland, San Diego, and Seattle, with additional locations planned for Chicago and Dedham, Massachusetts, near Boston. The company has also updated its list to include future stores in Lynnfield, Massachusetts, and Paramus, New Jersey. The plans for an Amazon store at the Time Warner Center were first reported by The Wall Street Journal.

Dr. Rouse likened the discovery of the ruby sea dragon to finding a needle in a haystack, and they were thrilled to spot not one, but two of the elusive creatures. The footage they recorded was published in the journal Marine Biodiversity Records on Thursday. In 2015, Dr. Rouse and his colleagues identified the ruby sea dragon as a new species after conducting genetic analysis on a dead specimen provided by the Western Australian Museum. Initially, the specimen was misclassified as a weedy sea dragon by the marine research survey that recovered it, likely due to its vibrant red color and the absence of appendages, which were thought to have been lost during the trawling process. During their research, Dr. Rouse and his team also discovered an older specimen dating back to 1919. When they finally captured footage of the wild ruby sea dragon, they confirmed that the species did not possess the camouflage-like appendages. However, it's clear that the species didn't need them to evade detection for nearly a century.

William Hartmann, a physics professor at Michigan State University who specializes in acoustics and psychoacoustics, offered a simple explanation for experiences like Ms. Miyawaki's. According to Hartmann, there are two routes by which we perceive our own voice when speaking. The first path is the same one we use to perceive most other sounds, where sound waves travel through the outer, middle, and inner ear. However, because our vocal cords vibrate when we speak, a second internal path is created, where those vibrations are conducted through our bones and directly excite our inner ears. This internal path emphasizes lower frequencies, making our voice sound deeper and richer to ourselves, Hartmann explained. However, this explanation doesn't apply to everyone, including Walter, my classmate, and myself. John J. Rosowski, a professor and researcher at Harvard Medical School who specializes in the middle ear, provided additional insight. He suggested that individual variations in perception may arise from the nuanced ways sounds are perceived by the inner ear within the two pathways outlined by Hartmann. "There are multiple paths that these vibrations take to reach the skull," Rosowski noted, "including the vibrations of the skull itself, which can vary."

Later this year, Netflix will be gaining new and old episodes of Jerry Seinfeld's popular show "Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee", which has been a staple on Sony's streaming service Crackle since its debut in 2012. This move is a significant blow to Crackle, as it has been the home to the show for nearly a decade. In addition to the show, Seinfeld has signed a production deal with Netflix, which will see him perform two stand-up specials and develop both scripted and non-scripted content. In recent months, Netflix has been aggressively pursuing top comedic talent, including Chris Rock, Dave Chappelle, and Amy Schumer, all of whom are set to release stand-up specials on the platform. The company has reportedly been willing to spend big to secure these deals, with Chris Rock's upcoming stand-up shows costing a whopping $40 million. Details of Seinfeld's deal with Netflix were not disclosed. "Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee" has been a flagship show on Crackle for four and a half years, earning an Emmy nomination for best variety series last year. However, Seinfeld's relationship with Crackle has been strained since Sony's TV chairman Steve Mosko left the company last year, and the show has been on the market since at least October. Hulu was also in the running to acquire the show, but ultimately lost out to Netflix.

In an era of revivals and reboots, it's hardly surprising that NBC has announced plans to revive its beloved comedy "Will & Grace" for a 10-episode run during the 2017-18 TV season. The original cast members, including Eric McCormack, Debra Messing, Sean Hayes, and Megan Mullally, will reprise their roles, alongside director James Burrows and creators Max Mutchnick and David Kohan. The nostalgia trend in TV is currently in full swing, with many shows from the 1990s and early 2000s making a comeback. "Will & Grace" is just the latest to join the ranks, following in the footsteps of Netflix's "Fuller House" and "Gilmore Girls," as well as Fox's revival of "The X-Files," which was a ratings success last year. Another example is the upcoming return of "Twin Peaks" in May, featuring many of the original cast members. "Will & Grace," which originally aired from 1998 to 2006, was a huge hit and critical darling, earning Emmy awards for its lead cast members and winning the best comedy Emmy in its second season.

Asteroids are small rocks that orbit in the inner solar system, while meteors are the streaks of light that occur when space rocks enter the Earth's atmosphere, and meteorites are the remnants that survive the descent and land on the ground. It might seem logical to assume that meteorites that fall on Earth would be similar to asteroids that pass through our neighborhood, but surprisingly, scientists have found that's not the case. According to Philipp R. Heck, curator at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, "That's what everybody would have expected," but planetary scientists were surprised to discover that the most common types of meteorites on Earth are not common in space. In a recent study published in Nature Astronomy, an international team led by Dr. Heck has shed light on the mystery. The researchers found that mineralogical evidence in some meteorites pointed to a massive collision in the asteroid belt around 466 million years ago, long before dinosaurs roamed the Earth. Dr. Heck estimates that during this time, skywatchers would have seen about 100 times more shooting stars than we see today. To investigate meteorites that landed on Earth before this collision, Dr. Heck and his colleagues turned to ancient limestone from Russia, which is around a million years older. They extracted 46 minuscule crystals containing the mineral chromite from almost 600 pounds of rock. These crystals remain unchanged for hundreds of millions of years, allowing scientists to determine that 41 of them originated from space and were once part of specific types of asteroids. The mix of meteorites from this ancient period was strikingly different from what we see today, with more than a third belonging to a type called primitive achondrites, compared to less than half a percent today. Geology professor Tasha L. Dunn, who studies meteorites at Colby College in Maine, praised the research, saying, "It's really inventive, their approach." According to Dunn, the findings align with the growing understanding that the composition of meteorites is shaped by the history of asteroid collisions in the asteroid belt, rather than the proximity of asteroids to Earth's orbit. Pierre Vernazza, a researcher at the Laboratory of Astrophysics of Marseille, France, who first identified the discrepancy between asteroids and meteorites in 2008, believes the new paper opens up new avenues of research. For instance, many achondrite meteorites originated from Vesta, a large asteroid that was severely impacted about a billion years ago. However, not all achondrites share this origin. As Vernazza noted, "In the case of the other achondrites, we don't have a well-known source yet."

Donald J. Trump has been a ratings magnet for cable news, both during his presidential campaign and now from the White House. Despite expectations of a decline in viewership after a record-breaking election year, cable news ratings have instead been soaring in the first 11 days of President Trump's presidency. The biggest beneficiary of this trend has been Fox News, which has maintained its position as the top-rated cable news network for 15 consecutive years. In January, Fox News averaged 2.8 million viewers in prime time, a 17% increase from the same period in 2016. The network's success has been largely due to the popularity of its new 9 p.m. anchor, Tucker Carlson, who has seen a significant surge in ratings following the departure of Megyn Kelly to NBC.

Josh Miller, a former member of the White House Office of Digital Strategy under President Barack Obama, has joined Thrive Capital, a venture capital firm led by investor Joshua Kushner. Miller will start his new role on Monday and will focus on developing technology that addresses the needs of underprivileged Americans. He hopes to enlist the support of tech investors and founders to help those without internet access or digital literacy navigate job websites and avoid predatory payday lenders. Miller's appointment marks the latest addition to Kushner's network of Democrats, as many of the founders of his portfolio companies and his girlfriend, model Karlie Kloss, have publicly supported Hillary Clinton.

In the rugged Himalayas, the path to saving the snow leopard is fraught with challenges. With only around 4,000 remaining in the wild, according to the World Wildlife Fund, the endangered species is struggling to survive due to poaching, habitat destruction, and human conflicts. The main issue, says Madhu Chetri, a biologist at Inland Norway University of Applied Sciences, is when a snow leopard enters a livestock pen, where it may devour a few goats and sheep or, in extreme cases, massacre over 100 animals in a single enclosure. If the cat becomes trapped, a tragic outcome often follows. "The herders will usually kill it in retaliation," Chetri explains. To address these conflicts, Chetri and his team have been studying the dynamics between humans and snow leopards in Nepal's Central Himalayas. To achieve this, they spent over 150 days tracking snow leopard scat, analyzing the excrement to uncover clues about the cat's diet and feeding habits. This research could eventually inform conservation strategies aimed at reducing contact between snow leopards and farm animals. The team's findings were published in the journal PLOS One on Wednesday.

This Friday night, two celestial events will take place: a lunar eclipse and the passage of Comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova. While both events may sound impressive, they won't offer much excitement for casual stargazers. The lunar eclipse will be a penumbral event, meaning that only a portion of the Earth's shadow will cover the moon, resulting in a subtle darkening of its appearance. According to NASA research scientist Noah Petro, "These things are very subtle... If it's a cloudy night, you might not even notice it." The best time to observe the eclipse is around 7:44 p.m. Eastern time, when the moon's top will appear slightly gray. As for the comet, it will pass close to Earth, about seven million miles away, which is 30 times the distance between our planet and the moon. Unfortunately, its distance means it will be challenging to spot without binoculars or a telescope. If you do manage to get a closer look, the comet should appear as a green dot in the sky due to its chemical composition. The best time to try and spot it will be early Saturday morning, around 3 a.m. Eastern time, but don't expect to be blown away by the sight.

"I'm happy with Windows 7 and don't plan to upgrade to Windows 10. If I continue to use Windows 7 after Microsoft stops providing updates, will I encounter any issues? Microsoft stopped selling Windows 7 on October 30 and is now counting down to the end of its support for the operating system, which was first released in 2009. The company has published a timeline for the Windows 7 life cycle, which includes a transition from mainstream support (where new features are added through updates) to extended support (which primarily provides security patches). Extended support for Windows 7 is set to end on January 14, 2020. Although Microsoft will no longer provide updates, some third-party security software companies may continue to offer updates for Windows 7, potentially allowing you to keep using the system for a few more years with protection against malware. However, even with updates, security flaws in the older operating system may be difficult to fix. As long as you're satisfied with Windows 7 and your programs continue to function, you can likely continue using the system as usual. Nevertheless, as software companies release newer versions of their applications and web technologies evolve, you may notice that your Windows 7 computer becomes slower and more unpredictable over time."

Large technology companies, such as behemoths like Amazon, test new concepts by using their hometown as a living laboratory. According to Nick Wingfield, a tech reporter for The New York Times, this is precisely what Amazon has done in Seattle, where it was founded and is headquartered. Over the past few years, the e-commerce giant has conducted numerous retail experiments in Seattle, including a drive-up grocery store, a physical bookstore, and a roaming delivery truck called the Treasure Truck. These tests have solidified Seattle's reputation as a hub for retail innovation, which has in turn created jobs and driven demand for office space in the city. Seattle has a long history of nurturing successful retailers, including REI, Costco, and Nordstrom, all of which got their start in the city. Similarly, Starbucks, also based in Seattle, has tested its own retail pilots in the city, including the launch of its first high-end coffee bar, Roastery.

"What do you appreciate about your setup, and what could be improved? For me, it's a huge time-saver: I don't waste a second watching commercials. (This aspect of my TV habits is probably the most unusual - I rarely see ads.) TiVo's interface is still far superior to any cable company set-top box I've used. As for what could be better, the cable companies are notoriously bad, especially in New York City, where we're stuck with a de facto monopoly. (I'm supposed to have the option of Fios soon, but it feels like it's been taking forever to arrive.)

Beyond my job, what tech product am I currently obsessed with using in my daily life? I love gadgets, especially in the kitchen. (I could talk about my pressure cooker all day.) Recently, I got a Joule sous vide immersion circulator for my birthday. It's a small device that you submerge in water to heat it to a precise temperature and maintain it. This means you can cook a steak to exactly 130 degrees Fahrenheit, edge to edge, without overcooking it. (You seal the food in vacuum wrap or a Ziploc bag.)

What do I and my family do with it? Since our oven broke and it's taking forever to get it fixed, I've been using the Joule for everything: meats, poached eggs, and even desserts like dulce de leche. Right now, I'm slow-cooking a whole brisket with it for the next 72 hours. What's blown me away is how precise and hands-off it is, and how it transforms meat in an incredible way." "I was amazed to learn that this device can transform a chuck roast into a tender and juicy, medium-rare steak, just like a high-end steakhouse - and I first discovered this in a feature article in The New York Times!"

The New York Times is making significant changes to its top leadership, with the addition of a third woman in just three weeks. Alison Mitchell, who played a crucial role in overseeing the paper's daily news coverage during the presidential election, will take on the role of assistant editor on the masthead. Alongside Matthew Purdy, a deputy managing editor, she will be responsible for guiding the daily online and print coverage, including selecting articles for the front page. "This is a perfect combination of the right person, at the right time, in the right role," said Dean Baquet, executive editor of The Times, along with Joseph Kahn, managing editor, and Matthew Purdy, in a note to the newsroom. "And now, we're giving Alison the title she deserves." Throughout her career at The Times, Alison Mitchell has worn many hats, including reporter, covering City Hall, Congress, and two presidential campaigns, as well as serving as education editor, weekend editor, and national editor.

Following its initial public offering this month, Snap, the creator of the popular ephemeral messaging app Snapchat, has completed its funding round. The successful IPO has sparked questions about which other private tech companies may go public this year.
