One company that has long been rumored to be considering an IPO is Airbnb, a leading online marketplace that connects travelers with people who rent out their homes on a short-term basis. Unlike many other venture-backed tech startups, Airbnb is not burning through investor capital to fund its operations, as it is already profitable, according to sources familiar with its financials. Despite this, Airbnb's CEO, Brian Chesky, has stated that the company has no immediate plans for an IPO, saying that it will only consider going public when it is in the best interest of the company's mission. With over three million listings in more than 190 countries, Airbnb is expanding its offerings by acquiring and investing in new business lines, including payments, property management, and restaurant reservations.

Scientists have embarked on an innovative experiment to better understand why some marine mammals, like dolphins and whales, are prone to mass strandings. The study, published in The Journal of Experimental Biology, involved housing a group of retired Navy dolphins and a retired killer whale in a large tank with a trainer for six months. The goal was to observe and measure the energy expenditure of these marine mammals as they performed various behaviors, such as swimming through oversized hula hoops.

The researchers, led by Terrie M. Williams from the University of California, Santa Cruz, found that dolphins and whales use more energy when swimming quickly than when cruising at normal speeds. This may seem intuitive, but it challenges the common assumption that marine mammals, which are known for their impressive diving abilities, have evolved physiological adaptations to conserve energy and oxygen.

To conduct the study, the team worked with trainers to encourage the marine mammals to engage in different behaviors, such as resting, swimming in a straight line, or diving to swim through hoops. The animals' breathing, oxygen intake, heart rate, and swimming patterns were measured across various settings. The results showed that there was little difference in energy expenditure between resting and swimming at average speeds. However, as the animals swam faster, they had to exert more energy due to water resistance, which nearly doubled their normal energy use when swimming at their fastest pace.

The Wall Street Journal's editorial page, known for its conservative tone, took a particularly harsh stance in an online editorial published Tuesday night, one that would stand out even among its left-leaning peers. The editorial was a scathing critique of President Trump, labeling him "his own worst political enemy" and accusing him of undermining his presidency with a constant stream of exaggerated claims, unfounded accusations, implausible denials, and falsehoods. The editorial board specifically targeted Trump's unsubstantiated claims that former President Barack Obama had tapped his phones, describing his persistence in making these claims as akin to a drunk clinging to an empty gin bottle. Despite the lack of evidence supporting Trump's accusations, which has been denied by senior intelligence officials and lawmakers from both parties, the President continues to cling to them. While the paper's editorial and opinion writers have been critical of Trump in the past, the language of this editorial seemed intended to urge the President to focus on his goals rather than distractions. The timing of the editorial, which coincides with the Supreme Court confirmation hearings for Judge Neil M. Gorsuch and the House vote on the Republican healthcare bill, is likely no coincidence.

Researchers in the United States have developed a highly realistic model of the female reproductive system, which simulates a menstrual cycle and produces pregnancy hormones. The team, comprising experts from Northwestern University, the University of Illinois at Chicago, and Draper Laboratory, published their findings in Nature Communications on Tuesday. The innovative model, dubbed Evatar, is constructed using a combination of human and mouse tissue and can be employed to test medications, potentially benefiting women suffering from painful periods, infertility, and other conditions. According to the lead investigator, Teresa K. Woodruff, the model offers a groundbreaking approach to personalized medicine. "If I had access to your stem cells, I could create a personalized model of your body, complete with a heart, liver, lung, and ovary," she explained. "This would enable me to test 10 different drugs at 10 different doses, pinpointing the most effective treatment for conditions like Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, or diabetes." The three-dimensional model features all the key components of the female reproductive system, including ovaries, fallopian tubes, a uterus, and a cervix. Notably, a liver is also integrated into the system, as it plays a crucial role in metabolizing drugs. The model consists of separate cube compartments containing mouse and human tissues from each organ, which are connected within a square frame in the laboratory.

Jason Blum, the renowned producer behind successful horror films such as "Get Out" and "Split," has secured funding from ITV Studios in the UK to launch a standalone television production company. Blumhouse Television, which is already working on its first project, a mini-series called "Secure and Hold: The Last Days of Roger Ailes," for Showtime, will focus on creating "dark genre" content that explores themes that scare and unsettle audiences. In addition to the mini-series about Roger Ailes, who was ousted from Fox News last year following allegations of sexual harassment, Blumhouse Television will also produce a drama set in the same dystopian world as the "Purge" film franchise. The "Purge" trilogy, which was produced by Blum for a total cost of $21 million and grossed $320 million worldwide, will be followed by a fourth installment in the summer of 2018. The television spinoff, which will air on both Syfy and USA networks, is being produced in collaboration with Universal Cable Productions. The mini-series about Roger Ailes has not yet begun casting, but it is expected to premiere on Showtime by this time next year. The timing of the "Purge" series is unclear, as the storytelling needs to be integrated with the existing film franchise. It is unusual for a film series to spawn a television spinoff, as studios typically wait until the movies have concluded before adapting them for television.

Kent State and Cornell University have adopted a new culinary approach, trading in pizza for poke bowls. This academic year, they've introduced the first certified gluten-free dining halls on campus. According to Dr. Alessio Fasano, director of the Center for Celiac Research and Treatment in Boston, approximately 5-10% of college students have celiac disease or other gluten-related disorders. For these students, avoiding gluten is not a trendy diet choice, but a medical necessity. Even accidental exposure to gluten, such as a single bread crumb in communal cream cheese, can have severe consequences, including gastrointestinal issues that may lead to missed classes. A 2016 survey by the New England Celiac Organization found that college students with celiac disease and gluten sensitivity often face significant challenges in their social and academic lives. By offering a wider range of gluten-free options, Kent and Cornell aim to make their dining halls more inclusive and welcoming for students with food allergies, while also attracting students without dietary restrictions. Gone are the stale bread and crumbly baked goods; in their place, popular dishes like poke bowls, stir-fries, huevos rancheros, and apple pie cupcakes are now available at Cornell's Risley dining room, which has been certified gluten-free, peanut-free, and tree-nut free.

SAN FRANCISCO - Despite controversy surrounding Uber's corporate culture, the company is touting a different message to investors and employees: its business is thriving. According to figures released on Friday, the ride-hailing service saw a significant increase in gross bookings, reaching $20 billion in 2016, more than double the amount from the previous year. Net revenue, which takes into account the costs of paying drivers, reached $6.5 billion. However, despite its growing business, Uber is still not profitable. The company reported an adjusted net loss of $2.8 billion in 2016, excluding the cost of its Chinese subsidiary, Uber China. This loss is attributed to the significant investments made in developing its operations in China, which were ultimately sold to Didi Chuxing last year. The release of these financial figures, which were previously reported by Bloomberg and confirmed by Uber, marks the first time the company has publicly disclosed its financial data. While some information about its financial performance has leaked in the past, and the company typically shares quarterly updates with employees and select investors, this is the first time the figures have been made publicly available. The move comes as Uber grapples with ongoing questions about its workplace culture and negative consumer sentiment.

This week, we're exploring sound bars - compact, all-in-one speaker systems designed to be paired with a television. I must admit, I've always found sound bars to be a bit puzzling. To gain a better understanding, I turned to Chris Heinonen, the AV staff writer at The Wirecutter, a reputable website owned by The New York Times that reviews and recommends products. Sound bars can be quite expensive, even surpassing the cost of a TV. So, why would anyone need one? While "need" might be an exaggeration, sound bars have gained immense popularity because they effectively address two significant issues related to TV viewing and music listening. Unlike the older tube-style TVs, which had ample space for speakers, modern flat-panel displays are notoriously cramped, leaving little room for sound reproduction. As a result, smaller speakers struggle to produce high-quality sound. Furthermore, the limited space on the front of the TV forced manufacturers to relocate speakers to the bottom or back of the panel. Concurrently, people shifted from playing music on CDs to streaming it on their computers and phones. Sound bars, with their sleek, compact design, eliminate the need for additional cables or equipment, featuring built-in Bluetooth (or AirPlay) for seamless wireless music playback.

Chinese authorities are planning to question Apple about the video streaming services available on its app store in China, as part of their efforts to increase pressure on the American technology giant over the content it provides in the country. According to a report by China's official Xinhua News Agency, the authorities intend to summon Apple to urge the company to strengthen its checks on software applications available in the Apple Store. The timing of the summoning has not been disclosed. The inquiry appears to be focused on third-party apps available on the company's app store in China. The report also states that the authorities have instructed three Chinese websites to enhance their oversight of online information, livestreaming services, and online performances. Specifically, the authorities have told some broadcasters to cease offering live content that is prohibited by Chinese law, including pornography.

Airbnb has settled a lawsuit with the city of San Francisco, bringing an end to a dispute that could have hindered the company's plans to expand and go public. As part of the agreement, Airbnb has agreed to increase transparency about its hosts and help enforce existing registration laws in San Francisco. This settlement follows Airbnb's decision to drop a lawsuit in December over a New York law that fines individuals who illegally list their homes on short-term rental platforms. With this settlement, Airbnb has cleared up outstanding litigation in two of its largest US markets. The agreement removes a regulatory cloud over the company as it prepares for an initial public offering (IPO), although Airbnb still faces legal disputes in a few markets. Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky has stated that the company could be ready to go public within a year. According to Arun Sundararajan, a professor at New York University's Stern School of Business who studies the sharing economy, creating a stable environment with less regulatory uncertainty is beneficial for Airbnb as it prepares for its IPO over the next couple of years. Sundararajan notes that while regulations no longer pose an existential threat to the company, they still represent the biggest source of uncertainty about Airbnb's future revenue streams.

President Trump has made job creation, retention, and repatriation a core focus of his early presidency. He has employed various tactics to encourage cooperation from companies, including publicly calling them out on Twitter or through policy pressure. In recent months, several tech companies have seemingly responded to Trump's job-related rhetoric and actions. Asian companies such as Alibaba and SoftBank have pledged to create thousands of new jobs in the United States. In February, Intel, the world's leading computer chip manufacturer, announced a $7 billion investment to complete a factory in Arizona, which is expected to generate 3,000 new jobs.

As Tom Price, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, walked into a meeting at the West Virginia State Capitol in Charleston on Tuesday, a reporter from the Public News Service, Dan Heyman, trailed behind him in the hallway. Heyman was eager to ask about the healthcare legislation passed by the House last week to replace the Affordable Care Act. With his Android smartphone at the ready to record audio, Heyman reached past some of the staff and security members surrounding Price to ask his questions. According to an audio recording provided by Heyman, he asked if domestic violence would be considered a pre-existing condition under the new legislation, saying "Do you think that's right, or not?" twice, and then "You refuse to answer? Tell me no comment." Kellyanne Conway, a counselor to President Trump, was accompanying Price, and at one point in the recording, a man's voice is heard saying, "Do not get close to her. Back up." After persisting with his questions for nearly a minute, Heyman was pulled aside by West Virginia Capitol Police, handcuffed, and charged with a misdemeanor count of willful disruption of governmental processes. He spent eight hours in a local jail before being released after the news service posted a $5,000 bail. The arrest raised suspicions that officers were trying to silence Heyman's efforts to ask questions, although the criminal complaint claimed he "tried aggressively to breach the security of the Secret Service" and was "causing a disturbance by yelling questions." Heyman's lawyer, J. Timothy DiPiero, described the case as "highly unusual" and said, "I've never had a client get arrested for talking too loud or anything similar to that." The American Civil Liberties Union of West Virginia released a statement condemning Mr. Heyman's arrest, calling it a "blatant attempt to suppress an independent and free press." The organization demanded that the charges against him be dropped immediately, describing them as "outrageous." In a separate statement, Mr. Heyman expressed his doubts about whether the security officials intentionally tried to block him, but noted that their actions were consistent with a broader pattern of hostility towards the press.

San Francisco - In a move to accelerate the development of self-driving vehicles, two major players in the industry are joining forces. Waymo, the autonomous driving unit of Google's parent company, has partnered with ride-hailing startup Lyft, according to sources familiar with the agreement. The deal aims to bring autonomous vehicle technology to the mainstream through pilot projects and product development efforts. The partnership was confirmed by both Lyft and Waymo, with a Lyft spokesperson stating that collaborating with Waymo will accelerate their shared vision of improving lives through transportation.

The deal highlights the dynamic nature of relationships in the self-driving car sector, where numerous companies are forming alliances to gain an edge in the market. The partnership between Waymo and Lyft has significant implications for Uber, the world's largest ride-hailing company, which has faced recent challenges. Lyft is the second-largest ride-hailing service in the US, and the two companies are bitter rivals. Waymo is also competing with Uber in the development of autonomous car technology and is involved in a lawsuit over alleged trade secret theft.

Details about the deal between Waymo and Lyft remain scarce, with the companies declining to comment on specific products or timelines. The partnership offers Lyft a new entry point into the market, as the company has previously stated it will not develop its own self-driving car technology. "General Motors acquired Cruise Automation, a self-driving technology startup, for over $1 billion in cash and stock last year. Since then, Cruise has started testing GM vehicles on public roads in California."

MSNBC's "Morning Joe" hosts, Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski, claimed on Monday that White House counselor Kellyanne Conway had expressed strong criticism of President Trump in private conversations with them before his election. During Monday's broadcast, Brzezinski revealed that Conway would allegedly denounce Trump in private after promoting him on television. "She would say 'Blech, I need to take a shower' because she disliked the candidate so much," Brzezinski said, describing Conway's supposed attitude. Scarborough echoed Brzezinski's statements, saying that Conway had told them she only took the job for the paycheck and would soon be done defending Trump. "But first, I have to take a shower, because it feels so dirty to be saying what I'm saying," Brzezinski mockingly quoted Conway as saying. However, Conway responded to the hosts' claims on Tuesday, calling them "absurd" and "not true." Conway initially worked for a super PAC supporting Ted Cruz's presidential campaign, but joined the Trump campaign after Cruz dropped out. She became Trump's campaign manager in August and frequently appeared on TV in support of him. Brzezinski announced in February that she would no longer book Conway on the show, citing concerns that Conway would spread falsehoods. Last week, Brzezinski renewed her criticism, calling Conway "not credible" and criticizing CNN for featuring her. "Your hosts look pained when they interview her because they know they're just doing politics porn," Brzezinski said, addressing the rival network. Ms. Conway has faced intense criticism from the media since she defended the White House's claims about the size of President Trump's inauguration crowd by introducing the concept of "alternative facts" in January. A recent clip of Anderson Cooper, a CNN anchor, reacting with disdain to her comments during an interview drew widespread attention, prompting Ms. Conway to label the reaction "possibly sexist" and attribute it to an anti-Trump bias in the media. Despite having a cordial relationship with President Trump in the past, the hosts of "Morning Joe" have increasingly criticized him in recent months. In response, President Trump has stated that he no longer watches the network.

Fox News has filed a court motion urging a federal court to discipline a lawyer, Judd Burstein, who the network claims failed to verify basic facts in a lawsuit accusing Fox of using fake Twitter accounts to harass a former host. In a court document, lawyers representing Fox News and two of its top executives accused Burstein of making "outrageously and flagrantly" false claims on behalf of his client, former Fox News host Andrea Tantaros. Tantaros has alleged that Twitter posts from fake accounts, known as "sock-puppet" accounts, were part of a concerted effort to silence her after she reported sexual harassment by Roger E. Ailes, a network founder who resigned as chairman and CEO last summer. Ailes passed away this month. In the court filing, Fox News argued that Burstein failed to conduct basic research into one of the accounts he cited, which was posted under the name Daniel Wayne Block. According to the filing, "a simple phone call would have revealed that Mr. Block is alive and well and has no connection to Fox News, other than as a fan."

When it comes to granting smart gadgets access to your Wi-Fi network, it's essential to exercise caution. As researchers have discovered vulnerabilities in internet-connected devices, such as smart light bulbs, it's wise to be vigilant when connecting smart devices to your home network. The Internet of Things (IoT), which includes wirelessly linked gadgets like security cameras, thermostats, and baby monitors, has been a prime target for cybercriminals seeking to infiltrate or disrupt networks. For instance, a recent major cyberattack, facilitated by compromised devices, brought online traffic to a standstill. To gain a better understanding of how hackers can exploit smart devices, refer to a detailed post on the Heimdal Security blog. In many cases, weak security on both the network and devices themselves has created vulnerabilities for hackers to exploit. However, there are steps you can take to fortify your home network's defenses. To start, ensure your home network router is using a strong, unique password that differs from the default one it came with. Your router's manufacturer should provide instructions for changing the password. Additionally, change any default passwords on your smart devices and use distinct passwords for each one. Furthermore, install any available firmware updates or security patches provided by the device's manufacturer to stay protected.

We're utterly dependent on our cellphones, and they rely on battery power to function. So, how can we ensure they stay charged? Nick Guy, a senior staff writer at The Wirecutter, a product evaluation site affiliated with The New York Times, has investigated this very question. When I search for "wall charger" on Amazon, I'm met with an overwhelming 32,819 results. Can you help me make sense of it all? The sheer number of options can be daunting, but once you know what to look for, it's not so intimidating. Our top pick for a wall charger is Anker's PowerPort 4, which boasts four USB ports capable of providing up to 2.4 amps per port. Most devices can't draw more power than that, so this charger will charge most devices at their maximum speed, including larger phones and tablets. The only exceptions are newer devices that support USB-C PD and Qualcomm Quick Charge, but these technologies are still not widespread. I often carry my charger with me, and I've wondered if it would fit in my pocket or weigh down my bag. While the PowerPort 4 would fit in a bag, it might be a bit too large for a pocket. If portability is a priority, I recommend iClever's Dual USB Travel Wall Charger, which is compact and lightweight, measuring about an inch and a half square by just over an inch thick. Recently, I read a warning that public charging stations can be risky to use, as they might compromise your data. Is this a legitimate concern?

The Galapagos Islands' avifauna continues to play a significant role in our understanding of evolution. When Charles Darwin visited the islands, it was the diverse range of finch beaks that helped him comprehend how a single species could evolve into multiple forms. Now, the Galapagos cormorants, the only species of cormorant that has lost the ability to fly, have enabled scientists to pinpoint the genes responsible for this species' divergence from all other cormorants approximately two million years ago. These genes, present in birds, mammals, and most animals, including the commonly studied nematode C. elegans, are also found in some algae. Their effects vary, however. In humans and cormorants, the genes influence bone growth. In humans, mutations can lead to severe diseases, while in birds, they resulted in smaller wings and a weaker breastbone, making flight less effective. Alejandro Burga, a researcher in the lab of Leonid Kruglyak, chairman of human genetics at UCLA's medical school, analyzed the DNA of these and other cormorants with his colleagues. Burga noted that he and Dr. Kruglyak were discussing how to leverage the increasing power of modern genetics to investigate the process of speciation. "We have very little understanding of how these events occur in nature," he said.

Sinclair Broadcast Group, which has recently agreed to acquire Tribune Media and create a massive local television network with 223 stations, is in talks with a seasoned television executive to expand its programming offerings. According to sources familiar with the discussions, Steve Mosko, the former chairman of Sony Pictures Television, is in preliminary negotiations with Sinclair for a senior management position. The talks were first reported by The Financial Times. Mosko's television career began in the late 1970s at a Baltimore station owned by Julian Smith, the founder of Sinclair, and he has maintained close ties with the Smith family, who continue to control the company. Mosko is perhaps best known for revitalizing Sony's television division, which was struggling after a major downsizing in 2001. By the time he left the company last year, television was generating more revenue for Sony than its film division. During his tenure, Sony produced popular broadcast network shows such as "Kevin Can Wait," critically acclaimed series like "Better Call Saul," and syndicated game shows like "Jeopardy."

If you're seeking an app that tracks your medication schedule and provides reminders, the free Round Health iOS app is worth considering. This app recently received an update that allows it to record when you take your pills, enabling you to calculate the timing of your next dose. Additionally, it sends pop-up alerts to remind you to take your scheduled medication. Another popular option is the Medisafe app, available for both Android and iOS, which offers a free version with in-app purchases for additional features. MyTherapy Pill Reminder & Medication Tracker, available for both Android and iOS, provides a journal function and can generate PDF reports to share with your doctor. Before using any app to manage your personal health information, be sure to review its privacy policy and understand where your data is stored, especially if it syncs across devices. It's also essential to enable the security features on your phone, such as a passcode, to protect your data.

In southwestern Canada, it's likely that an old elk you come across is a female. While male elk, or bulls, rarely live past five years due to hunting, female elk, or cows, can live up to 20 years. Interestingly, cows over the age of 10 appear to be nearly invulnerable to hunters. A team of scientists sought to understand why senior cows are so adept at survival. Is it because these elk are naturally more cautious, which allows them to evade hunters more effectively? Or can cows learn to avoid hunters over their lifetime, even if they start out more daring? Research published in PLOS One suggests that both factors are at play. By tracking dozens of female elk over several years, the authors found that, overall, cautious cows were more likely to survive. However, they also discovered that individual cows could adapt their behavior and adopt stealthier strategies as they aged. As cows got older, they tended to move shorter distances and seek safer ground if they sensed a higher risk of encountering hunters.

Before President Trump implemented a travel ban on certain majority Muslim countries and announced the US withdrawal from the Paris climate accord, the atmosphere was more conducive to cooperation. Despite this, White House officials reported that there was no hesitation from executives or investors to participate in the Monday meeting, which focused on upgrading government technology. According to Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, a professor and associate dean at Yale School of Management, the tech executives and investors attending the event faced a dilemma. "This is a double-edged sword for the tech CEOs," he said, "as they don't want to be used as window dressing for photo opportunities. However, this is the most business-friendly administration since Eisenhower, and it is more open to on-the-spot influence than any other administration."

Three prominent journalists at CNN resigned on Monday after the network was forced to retract and apologize for a story on its website that linked a close ally of President Trump to a Russian investment fund. The article, which was removed from CNN.com last week, was deemed unreliable and CNN was unable to fully stand by its reporting. The resignations are a significant blow to the network's reputation at a sensitive time, as it has faced intense criticism from President Trump and his supporters, who have labeled its reporting as "fake news". Trump's closest advisors have also accused CNN of harboring a bias against the president. CNN's president, Jeffrey A. Zucker, was deeply upset by the reporting errors and led an internal inquiry that found the story was published despite concerns expressed by the network's standards team. The three resigning journalists - Thomas Frank, Lex Haris, and Eric Lichtblau - were key players in the story's publication. This is the latest in a series of embarrassing episodes for CNN, which has previously fired Kathy Griffin after she published a controversial photograph and cut ties with host Reza Aslan after he made vulgar comments about Trump on Twitter. By Monday night, critics of CNN had already seized on the news, with the right-wing website Breitbart News publishing a headline that read "Fake News Blues". CNN's investigative reporting has received widespread acclaim this year, with the network touting the hiring of prominent journalists as evidence of its dedication to in-depth reporting. CNN's tenacious reporting has consistently clashed with the Trump administration, with President Trump publicly criticizing CNN's CEO, Jeff Zucker, at a White House press conference. Recently, CNN reporter Jim Acosta sharply criticized Sean Spicer, the White House press secretary, for restricting television coverage of press briefings. In response, CNN sent a courtroom sketch artist to document Spicer's appearance at a briefing, further highlighting its commitment to transparency and accountability.

Google's autonomous vehicle subsidiary, Waymo, has significantly scaled back its patent claims against Uber in a high-stakes lawsuit over driverless technology. In a recent federal court filing, Waymo announced that it is dropping three of its four patent claims related to light detection and ranging sensor technology, or lidar, which is a crucial component in self-driving car technology. The lawsuit, which has been marked by intense rivalry between Waymo and Uber, highlights the intense competition for autonomous vehicle talent and technology. The case is particularly significant for Google, as it has spent years developing driverless car technology and is now struggling to monetize it. Many of Waymo's top engineers have left for rival companies, taking valuable knowledge of its technology with them. The dispute between Waymo and Uber began in February when Waymo filed a lawsuit alleging that Uber was using stolen intellectual property from one of Google's former project leaders in its driverless vehicles. The case has been marked by months of wrangling, culminating in Uber firing the former Google project leader, Anthony Levandowski. The trial is scheduled for October, with the central issue being whether Uber misappropriated Waymo's trade secrets.

NASA's Juno spacecraft has been making repeated passes just above the cloud tops of Jupiter, capturing stunning views of the planet. During its latest flyby, the spacecraft came within 5,600 miles of the Great Red Spot, a massive storm that has been swirling for at least 350 years. The mission's latest images were released on Wednesday, offering a unique glimpse of the storm's internal clouds. According to Amy A. Simon, a scientist at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center, the appearance of the Great Red Spot may have changed since the end of the Galileo orbiter mission over a decade ago. "The internal clouds appear less sheared apart in some areas compared to Galileo," Simon said. "We expected this based on recent Hubble imaging, but these new images provide a higher-resolution view of the clouds and reveal exactly how they've changed over the past decades." The released images may appear distorted, but this is due to the spacecraft's close proximity to the storm, which causes the horizon to appear foreshortened. According to Candice Hansen-Koharcheck, NASA's lead investigator for the JunoCam instrument, the hourglass shape is a result of this unique perspective.

The Yukon-Charley Rivers National Preserve in central Alaska spans 2.5 million acres, providing a protected habitat for majestic animals like wolves. However, wolves do not recognize human-drawn boundaries and can roam freely across the region. A recent study published in Wildlife Monographs suggests that efforts to control wolf populations outside the preserve have had negative effects on the wolves living within it. The study found that when the Alaskan authorities were culling wolf populations outside the preserve, the survival rates of wolves within the preserve were lower than usual. This highlights the importance of communication and cooperation between wildlife managers within and outside preserve boundaries, with potential implications for wildlife management programs globally. The Alaska Department of Fish and Game has invested millions of dollars since the 1990s in an intensive predator management program, initially using sterilization and later shooting and killing hundreds of wolves from helicopters. The program aimed to increase the population of the Fortymile caribou herd in the surrounding lands, but after decades of effort, the herd still only peaks at around 50,000 to 60,000, down from an estimated hundreds of thousands in the 1970s. Research has suggested that these efforts may not be effective in increasing caribou numbers in the area. Over 22 years of monitoring wolves in the preserve using radio collars, researchers led by John Burch, a National Park Service wildlife biologist, found that wolf survival rates decreased during lethal management outside the preserve. "Every single wolf pack left the preserve," Dr. Burch noted, as the state only targeted wolves outside the preserve, while many wolves that ventured outside the preserve were shot and killed.

As August arrives, a new generation of black-legged ticks that carry Lyme and other diseases begins to hatch. These ticks, which are looking for their first blood meal, can be found on forest floors, suburban estates, and urban parks across North America and Europe, where tick-borne disease is on the rise. Typically, they feed on white-footed mice and other small mammals that are notorious for harboring pathogens that can infect humans. However, a new study suggests that the surge in tick-borne disease may be linked to a decline in traditional mouse predators, which could otherwise keep mouse populations in check. If mice were scarcer, larval ticks might feed on other mammals and birds that don't carry diseases harmful to humans, or they might struggle to find their first meal. Ticks need three meals to reproduce, and humans are only at risk of contracting diseases from ticks that have previously fed on infected hosts.

To investigate this theory, lead researcher Tim R. Hofmeester, then a graduate student at Wageningen University in the Netherlands, set up cameras in 20 plots across the Dutch countryside to monitor the activity of foxes and stone martens, key predators of mice. The plots were located in both protected areas and areas where foxes are heavily hunted. Over a two-year period, Hofmeester also trapped hundreds of mice and voles in the same plots, counted the number of ticks on them, and tested the ticks for infection with Lyme and two other disease-causing bacteria. Additionally, he used a blanket to capture more ticks by dragging it across the ground.

Obesity is a pervasive issue in the United States, with the country having one of the highest rates of overweight individuals in the world. According to a recent study published in Psychological Science, the journal of the Association for Psychological Science, this phenomenon may have a surprising impact on how people perceive American identity. The study found that heavier Asian-Americans are more likely to be perceived as "American" than those of a normal weight, and that overweight Asian-American men are less likely to be viewed as being in the country illegally. The researchers discovered a paradoxical social benefit for Asian-Americans, where extra weight can actually lead to being seen as more American and less likely to face prejudice directed at those assumed to be foreign. According to Sapna Cheryan, an associate professor of psychology at the University of Washington and an author of the study, this finding suggests that there is a social benefit for Asian-Americans in being overweight, as it allows them to be perceived as more American and less likely to face prejudice.

Many professors who have shared their opinions on race and politics this year have become targets of both liberal and conservative groups. It seems that nothing is too obscure or academic to spark an attack campaign fueled by websites that monitor social media for controversial statements. The Professor Watch List, created by the conservative group Turning Point USA, is driving a new level of scrutiny of professors who allegedly discriminate against conservative students and promote left-wing ideologies in the classroom. Some websites even send out alerts to subscribers. The latest victims of these attacks include:

* Sarah E. Bond, a classics professor at the University of Iowa, who wrote an academic paper challenging the use of marble antiquities by white supremacist groups. After critical articles in Campus Reform and National Review, she faced threats and calls for her dismissal.
* Tommy Curry, a philosophy professor at Texas A & M, received death threats after a column in The American Conservative drew attention to a 2012 podcast in which he discussed violence against blacks by whites versus violence against whites by blacks. The column was headlined "When Is It O.K. to Kill Whites?"
* Johnny Eric Williams, a professor at Trinity College in Hartford, was placed on leave after sharing a provocative post from Medium arguing that bigots in danger should be left to die. He also posted his own Facebook messages with a hashtag referencing the post's anti-white headline: "Let Them [expletive] Die." The threats were so severe that the campus was closed for a day, and Dr. Williams and his family had to flee the state.

Over the past year, a wave of controversy has swept across campuses, targeting racist historical figures. Statues have been toppled, and buildings have been rebranded nationwide. Following student protests and internal reviews, at least five universities, including the University of Texas at Austin and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, have renamed buildings that previously honored Ku Klux Klan members. However, not all universities have taken similar action. For instance, students at the University of Alabama petitioned the president to rename Morgan Hall, which is named after John Tyler Morgan, the KKK's grand dragon and a senator, in honor of alumna Harper Lee. Buildings named for David Bibb Graves, a former governor of Alabama and grand cyclops of the KKK's Montgomery chapter, can be found at Auburn, the University of Alabama, and at least nine other universities, including two historically black schools, Alabama A&M and Alabama State University. Meanwhile, Middle Tennessee State University's board of regents voted to remove Nathan Bedford Forrest's name from Forrest Hall, believed to be the KKK's first grand wizard, after years of student protests.

"Cease immediately! Abandon the sponge and move away from the microwave. The soft cleaning tool is a microscopic world teeming with countless bacteria. While some may believe that microwaving a sponge kills its tiny inhabitants, this is only partially true. The weak bacteria may be eliminated, but the strongest, most pungent, and potentially harmful bacteria will survive. They will then multiply and occupy the vacant space left behind by the dead. And your sponge will become even smellier and more unpleasant, leading you to regret not simply discarding it, according to a recent study published in Scientific Reports.

Bacteria are ubiquitous, so it's no surprise that a kitchen sponge would be a breeding ground for them. However, previous research had underestimated the quantity and diversity of bacteria found in sponges. By analyzing DNA and RNA samples from 14 used sponges, microbiologist Markus Egert and his team at the University of Furtwangen in Germany identified 362 different species of bacteria living within them. The researchers were astonished to find that the microbes occupied such close quarters with incredible density: approximately 82 billion bacteria per cubic inch. "This density is similar to what you'd find in human stool samples," Dr. Egert noted. "There may be no other places on earth with such high bacterial densities."

A hacking incident occurred on Wednesday night, where a major company's social media account was compromised. This is not an isolated incident, as a single hacker, known as "Mr. Smith," has been tormenting HBO since the beginning of the month. Mr. Smith has been releasing proprietary information, including emails of an HBO executive and unaired episodes of shows like "Curb Your Enthusiasm," "Ballers," and "Insecure." It is unclear how widely these episodes have been circulated online. However, this is not the only instance of leaked content. Two unaired episodes of "Game of Thrones" were leaked online earlier this month, including one that was scheduled to air on Sunday. These leaks were not related to the wider breach. Additionally, Wednesday night's Twitter hacking did not appear to be linked to the Mr. Smith attack. OurMine, a group known for hacking major companies like YouTube, Marvel, and Netflix, is also being investigated for the hacking incident.

The ability to behave randomly can be a significant advantage. Imagine a mouse trying to evade a cat - by moving erratically and unpredictably, it increases its chances of survival. Similarly, in humans, this type of behavior is linked to creativity and cognitive complexity. However, understanding the human mind's capacity to produce randomness is a complex task. Recently, a team of researchers from Europe conducted a series of experiments to measure human random choice-making abilities. They found that, on average, people are best at producing random results around the age of 25. The team designed five tasks to test randomness, including simulating random coin flips, guessing the next card in a shuffled deck, and arranging a grid of black and white boxes to appear random. Over 3,400 participants from 4 to 91 years old took part in the experiment. The researchers used software to analyze participants' responses and identified the sequences that were hardest for the computer to predict as the most random. By analyzing participants' performance against various factors, including age, sex, and educational background, the researchers found a strong correlation with age. Performance improved from childhood to the mid-20s and remained relatively high until the 60s, after which it began to decline. However, Dr. Zenil noted that even in older adults, there may be trade-offs that compensate for decreased randomness, such as increased experience and knowledge.

Syd Silverman, the owner of Variety for three decades, passed away on August 27 in Boca Raton, Florida, at the age of 85. His son Michael confirmed the news. As the president of Daily Variety, which focused on Hollywood, and publisher of the New York-based weekly edition, which he also edited from 1973 to 1988, Silverman was instrumental in shaping the entertainment industry's language. Founded by his grandfather Sime, both publications were pillars of the industry, with Daily Variety's reporters chronicling the business from a Manhattan brownstone, where typewriters and manual typesetting were the norm. Over the course of his tenure, Variety's editorial content spanned the 20th century, from silent films to digital devices, as the industry underwent significant transformations driven by cable TV, video recorders, satellites, and multimedia streaming, as well as new business models like syndication contracts and independent studios.

Figuring out why humans cry can be overwhelming. We cry in response to a wide range of emotions, from the loss of loved ones and violence to heartbreak and even the joy of a sweet kiss or meaningful words. Sometimes we don't cry when we should, and other times we cry for no apparent reason. Amidst all this emotional complexity, it's refreshing to appreciate the straightforward explanation behind why onions make us tear up. Onions release a chemical called lachrymatory factor, or LF, which irritates our eyes when it reacts with other substances. Simply peeling an onion won't cause our eyes to water, but chopping, cutting, crushing, or smashing one will. This is because the onion's cells break open, allowing two previously separate substances to combine and form a potent chemical irritant. According to Josie Silvaroli, an undergraduate at Case Western Reserve University, this chemical reaction is similar to tear gas, as it releases a gas that hits the eyes and sensory nerves, causing them to tear up. The lachrymatory factor evolved as a defense mechanism to protect onions from microbes and animals, including humans. When an onion is damaged, it triggers this defense mechanism, releasing the chemical reaction as its cells break down.

In 2015, BMI, a music licensing agency, reached a record-breaking $1 billion in revenue for the first time. At the time, CEO Michael O'Neill predicted it would take three more years for the agency to generate $1 billion in royalties to its songwriters and music publishers after expenses. Fast-forward to the present, and BMI has announced a significant milestone: it generated $1.13 billion in revenue and distributed $1.02 billion in royalties to its members during its most recent fiscal year, which ended in June. With hundreds of thousands of members, including notable artists like Taylor Swift, Ed Sheeran, and Sting, BMI collects royalties whenever songs are played on the radio, streamed online, or piped into a restaurant. According to O'Neill, "Revenue is a great number, but distributions are what actually go into a songwriter's pocket." BMI and its rival Ascap have seen steady revenue growth over the past decade, driven by changes in technology and music consumption patterns. Ascap had previously reached $1 billion in revenue in 2015, beating BMI to the mark.

Fox News's influential prime-time lineup, which has enjoyed a loyal following in the Oval Office, is on the verge of a change. According to sources, Laura Ingraham, a conservative radio host and commentator who was an early supporter of President Trump, is in talks with the network to take over the 10 p.m. time slot. If the deal goes through, Sean Hannity, the network's boisterous host and informal presidential adviser, is likely to move to the coveted 9 p.m. slot, pitting him against MSNBC's Rachel Maddow, the current ratings leader. This shift would mark the latest in a series of changes to Fox News's prime-time schedule, which has been in flux since the departures of Megyn Kelly and Bill O'Reilly earlier this year. The network is also facing unprecedented competition from MSNBC, whose hosts have seen a surge in popularity among liberal viewers since the presidential election.

AMC has officially announced the appointment of David Madden, a former Fox executive, as its new head of original programming. Madden's departure from Fox was previously announced in late August, where he was set to leave his role as head of the network's in-house TV studio, with Michael Thorn taking over as his replacement. Madden had already been in advanced talks to join AMC, which was looking for a new head of original programming following Joel Stillerman's departure to head up programming at Hulu. In his new role, Madden will oversee a range of popular shows, including the hit series "The Walking Dead" and "Better Call Saul", which is up for several Emmy Awards on Sunday. He will also play a key role in AMC's in-house studio and will be responsible for programming at Sundance TV. During his time at Fox, Madden was involved in the development of shows such as "The Shield" and "The Americans", and his focus on grittier, more complex programming is reportedly a better fit for cable networks like AMC.

"Is it possible to bold or italicize text in Outlook for Android? Microsoft launched its Outlook for Android email app in 2015, prioritizing inbox management and scheduling. While the app can display formatting in received messages, composing messages on your device is limited to plain text only, excluding bold, italic, underline, and other styling options. When writing a message, you can access common commands like copying by long-pressing on the text. If you'd like to request additional commands, you can submit a suggestion to Microsoft directly from within the Outlook app."

Just days after announcing its sale, Rolling Stone faces a new challenge: ongoing litigation over a retracted article about a gang rape at the University of Virginia. On Tuesday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan ruled that a lower court had made an error in dismissing a defamation lawsuit filed by three former members of the fraternity featured in the 2014 article. The original ruling had dismissed the lawsuit, stating that the three men - George Elias IV, Ross Fowler, and Stephen Hadford - had not shown that the article was about them personally, aside from their affiliation with the fraternity. However, the appellate judges disagreed, ruling that the article could be seen as "of and concerning" Elias and Fowler, and sending the case back to the district court for further proceedings. While none of the men were named in the article, details like the setting of the alleged rape and descriptions of the men's interests could have led a reader familiar with the fraternity, Phi Kappa Psi, to identify Elias and Fowler, according to the lawsuit. The judges upheld the original dismissal in the case of Hadford, whose only identifying feature was his fondness for riding his bike around campus.

China's giant pandas are a beloved national symbol, and the only place outside of captivity where they can be found. After years of conservation efforts by the Chinese government, including the restoration of bamboo forests and the establishment of national reserves, the panda population has made a remarkable recovery. In September 2016, the pandas were officially removed from the endangered species list, with an estimated population of 1,864 - not including cubs. This is a significant increase from the low of around 1,200 in the 1980s. However, the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) warned that climate change and other factors could still devastate the pandas' habitat in the long term, making any population surge a temporary victory. The fragmentation of the panda population, which is now confined to just six mountain ranges and 30 isolated groups, is also a major concern. According to Dr. Ouyang and her colleagues, Chinese conservation efforts have had a positive impact on panda habitats in recent years, and planned changes are expected to reduce pressures on the pandas and their habitat in the short term. However, infrastructure development, tourism, and other human activities could undermine these improvements. The researchers recommend several steps to prevent the pandas from becoming endangered again, including improving connectivity between isolated panda populations by building habitat corridors and reducing habitat fragmentation. They also suggest establishing "ecological red lines" to physically separate panda habitats from human development, expanding panda preserves, and restricting tourism in national parks containing pandas.

Disney has been quietly transforming its retail store at the Northridge Fashion Center mall in Los Angeles, making significant changes since late July. Gone are the iconic Pixie Path aisles, ornate displays, green walls, and color-changing fiberglass trees, replaced by a massive movie theater-sized screen, a simplified floor plan, and white walls. The store now features a wider selection of fashion-conscious items for adults. So, what's behind the makeover? The Disney Store in Northridge was a prototype, and the company has been monitoring sales and customer feedback as it prepares to revamp its 340-store chain. According to Paul Gainer, executive vice president of Disney Stores Worldwide, the goal is to learn from the experience, especially during the holiday season. "We'll roll out the new look gradually," Gainer said in an interview. "So far, we're thrilled with the results." The redesign aims to bring a more theme-park-like experience to Disney's stores, with daily parades from Disneyland in California and Walt Disney World in Florida being streamed live to the colossal video screens. During these parades, store staff will set up mats for shoppers to sit on and roll out carts stocked with treats like cotton candy and light-up Mickey Mouse ears.

In the spotlight of Los Angeles, every Hollywood star has a Playboy Mansion story to share. While many are too racy to print, one tale stands out as a testament to the mansion's infamous reputation. Sharan Magnuson, a former Warner Bros. executive, has a story that many women can relate to. Magnuson arrived in Hollywood in 1980 to pursue an acting career and soon discovered a side of the Playboy Mansion that few people dared to discuss - at least, not if they wanted to be invited back. "At first, it was enchanting," Magnuson recalled in a phone interview on Thursday, just after Hugh Hefner's passing. "Glamorous, fun, and the mansion was immaculately maintained. The banquet spreads were exquisite, and you'd step outside to find flamingos and monkeys. Hef, who would descend from his quarters later, was always gracious and charming." However, not all of Hef's male guests shared his gentlemanly demeanor. In the mid-1980s, Magnuson, then known as Sharan Lea, and her girlfriend were invited to the mansion for a Sunday movie night. Although she was not naive and had a reputation for being part of a hard-partying crowd, she was still taken aback when a guy who had seemed friendly earlier cornered her outside, near the famous grotto with its three massive hot tubs and shelves stocked with large bottles of Johnson's Baby Oil. "He suddenly had nine hands," Magnuson said, recounting the incident. "He tried to get me into the cave, and when I refused, he physically restrained me. I felt violated."

"I'm receiving warnings that my iCloud storage is full, and Apple is encouraging me to upgrade to a larger plan. Are there alternative options that are more affordable and easier to use? I don't need to back up my entire computer, just a few random files. Apple provides every iCloud account with 5GB of free storage space to store documents, photos, videos, and device backups. You can access these files from iOS devices, Macs, and PCs with the iCloud software installed. Additionally, messages from iCloud mail accounts and older @me.com and @mac.com accounts are also stored within this space. If you receive warning messages, Apple recommends either purchasing more storage or deleting old files, messages, and device backups to free up space within your original 5GB. Buying more storage from Apple is straightforward, as you don't need to download or install any new software. If you've purchased media content or apps from iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store, Apple may already have your credit card on file. Prices start at 99 cents per month for 50GB of storage, $2.99 per month for 200GB, and $9.99 per month for 2TB of server space."

The news of Tom Petty's passing spread rapidly across the internet on Monday afternoon, with CBS News being the first to report it. The announcement sparked an outpouring of tributes and condolences from famous singers like John Mayer, Shania Twain, and Jon Bon Jovi, who all took to Twitter to pay their respects to the late musician. However, it soon became clear that the news was premature, and it wasn't until just before midnight that Petty's manager officially confirmed his death, which had occurred at 11:30pm. Initially, CBS News reported Petty's death on Twitter, accompanied by a bold "JUST IN" banner, and attributed the information to the Los Angeles Police Department. However, in an online article, the network only stated "CBS News has confirmed" without mentioning the LAPD. CBS later deleted the tweet.

Nine weeks ago, Anthony Scaramucci was still the White House communications director, flying high on Air Force One and shaping the president's public relations strategy. On Monday evening, he was a man with a sling on his arm, regaling reporters in the mirrored basement of a Midtown Manhattan steakhouse he co-owns with outlandish claims about the moon landing and Tang and Velcro (which aren't true). The trajectory of Anthony Scaramucci's career has been a long and unusual one, and lately, it's taken a dramatic downturn. After being fired by President Trump, served with divorce papers, and ridiculed on late-night TV for his potty-mouthed antics, Scaramucci is attempting a comeback with a new media venture he's calling The Scaramucci Post. So far, the project's details remain unclear. "It will start as an experiential online venture," Scaramucci explained during a launch party at the Hunt & Fish Club on West 44th Street, his lapel adorned with an American flag.

I'm considering purchasing a new iMac desktop computer and was wondering if they're as good as the older models. I currently use an old MacBook with AppleWorks, a word-processing program. Will a new Mac be able to convert my old files to a current word-processing program?

A new iMac is technically superior to an older model, thanks to its faster processor, sharper screen, and updated software. However, you may need to adjust to the new hardware and operating system if you haven't upgraded in a while. The Migration Assistant program can help you transfer your files from your old machine to the new one. Unfortunately, older software may not be compatible with modern Macs.

AppleWorks, a collection of office and art programs, was discontinued over 10 years ago and replaced by iWork, a suite of free programs that includes Pages, Numbers, and Keynote. These programs are compatible with Macs, iOS devices, and web browsers. When you buy a new Mac, you'll get the latest version of these programs. However, you may encounter issues opening older files with the new software. If you were using AppleWorks 6 and saved your files in that version, you can try opening them with the current iWork programs. Files created in AppleWorks 5 or earlier may not be compatible. To open an older AppleWorks file, try opening the Pages program, selecting File > Open, and choosing the AppleWorks file. If it opens, you can save it in the newer Pages format by selecting File > Save As.

"I'm deleting my Yahoo and Flickr accounts. I still have most of my original photos on my computer, but I need to retrieve a few that I can't find on my hard drive. Can I download the Flickr copies in their original resolution, or will they be lower in quality? You can download a copy of each photo in its original resolution, just like it was uploaded. To do this, log into your Flickr account, select a photo from your collection, and click the Download arrow icon in the lower-right corner of the viewer window. From the menu that pops up, choose Original to download the image in its highest resolution. Flickr automatically creates multiple resolutions of uploaded images for sharing purposes, including small squares and thumbnail previews, as well as medium and large sizes for friends and family. You can see the range of sizes available for a picture by clicking the Download arrow and choosing View All Sizes from the menu."

Beneath Yellowstone National Park lies a supervolcano, a colossal and powerful force that dwarfs ordinary volcanoes. It has the capacity to release over 1,000 cubic kilometers of rock and ash in a single event - a staggering 2,500 times more material than the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens, which claimed 57 lives. This could blanket most of the United States in a thick layer of ash, potentially plunging the Earth into a prolonged period of volcanic winter. Yellowstone's most recent supereruption occurred 631,000 years ago. However, it's not the only buried supervolcano on the planet. Scientists believe that a supereruption occurs every 100,000 years, prompting questions about when the next such event will occur. To better understand this phenomenon, scientists are studying Yellowstone's past to uncover the secrets behind these rare and violent events. The early findings, presented at a recent volcanology conference, have revealed a surprising discovery: the forces driving these events can move much faster than previously thought. The initial evidence suggests that Yellowstone's most recent supereruption was triggered by new magma entering the system just decades before the eruption. Previous estimates had assumed that the geological process leading up to the event took thousands of years to unfold.

In addition, a woman who works at the Weinstein Company described a chaotic work environment on Friday, with unanswered phones and some staff members in open rebellion. Nicole Quenqua, the company's former top spokeswoman, announced that she would no longer provide company statements to the press. Over the past week, the Weinstein Company has been at the center of a growing scandal involving Harvey Weinstein, his brother. Investigations by The New York Times and The New Yorker revealed decades-old allegations of sexual harassment and rape against Harvey Weinstein. Harvey Weinstein, who has denied any allegations of non-consensual sex, was fired by the Weinstein Company's board of directors, which includes his brother, on Sunday. Several other male board members have resigned, including billionaire investor Dirk Ziff, Milwaukee Bucks owner and Avenue Capital Group CEO Marc Lasry, Technicolor president and deputy CEO Tim Sarnoff, and accountant Richard Koenigsberg, who left the company on Thursday. With around 150 staff members in New York and Los Angeles, the Weinstein Company has significant assets potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars, including a TV unit with popular shows like "Project Runway" and a theatrical division with seven completed films, including "The Current War" starring Benedict Cumberbatch. Cumberbatch released a statement on Tuesday expressing his disgust and outrage at Harvey Weinstein's actions. As the entertainment industry distances itself from the company - Apple, for example, has scrapped plans for a series produced by the Weinstein Company, and other network partners are considering similar action - questions are mounting about whether the studio can continue to operate. Speculation about bankruptcy surfaced in Variety on Thursday, and on Friday, The Wall Street Journal reported that the Weinstein Company is exploring a sale or shutdown.

"Q: Can I upgrade my three-year-old MacBook Air, still running OS X 10.9.5 without any previous upgrades, to the latest operating system? A: Yes, you should be able to upgrade directly to macOS High Sierra, skipping the intermediate updates, as long as your MacBook Air meets the necessary hardware requirements. According to Apple, Macs running at least OS X 10.8 (Mountain Lion) can upgrade to High Sierra without having to install the in-between updates. Specifically, MacBook Air laptops from late 2010 onwards, as well as MacBook Pro laptops, Mac Mini, Mac Pro desktops released in mid-2010 or later, and iMacs and MacBooks released since late 2009, meet the hardware requirements for the High Sierra upgrade."

The fly agaric mushroom is a staple of fairy tales, with its vibrant, large fruiting bodies spreading abundantly across mossy forests in North America and Europe. Initially, they emerge from the soil as white, egg-like structures, as if abandoned by some enigmatic woodland creature. Reaching up to a foot in height, the mushroom's cap develops warts, and its color gradually shifts to a deep red hue. Eventually, the mushroom opens and flattens into a distinctive, polka-dot disc that would make a perfect plate for a mischievous gnome. In recent times, mushroom enthusiasts and nature lovers have been sharing their fly agaric finds on social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. One particularly striking post from Hungary featured a video and photo of a massive mushroom, nearly as large as a child. For many Eastern Europeans, mushroom hunting is a cherished tradition, while for some, it provides an additional source of income. For Csaba Reisz, a fertilizer salesman and soil nutrition consultant in southern Hungary, mushroom hunting serves as a welcome escape from the stresses of work. As he wrote in an email, "I find solace in a combination of mushroom hunting and photography – it helps me make everything right again."

For five years, Netflix has been streaming original series like the Emmy-winning "House of Cards" and "Master of None", leaving a question unanswered: how many people are actually watching? The answer remains a mystery outside of Netflix, as the company, along with Amazon and Hulu, has been secretive about its viewership numbers. This has been a source of frustration for industry professionals who would like to know the popularity of these shows. However, Nielsen, a 94-year-old company that has long dominated television ratings in the US, has recently announced a breakthrough in measuring Netflix viewership. While the specifics of Nielsen's data and its measurement methods remain unclear, as the company did not release the information publicly, this development marks a step towards establishing a reliable third-party ratings system for streaming services.

"Q: When I visit the Amazon website on my computer, I see a list of products I previously viewed. Is there a way to stop Amazon from tracking every product I click on? A: Amazon automatically saves the products you browse on the site and displays them on your account's homepage, in case you want to revisit and make a purchase later. If you find this feature unsettling or share a computer and prefer to keep your browsing history private, you can disable it. To do so, go to Amazon.com, log in to your account, and click on the 'Browsing History' link at the top of the page. Then, click on 'Manage History' at the top of the page to adjust your settings."

The general counsels of Facebook, Google, and Twitter will take the stage on November 1 to testify before congressional hearings on the role their technologies played in Russia's interference in the 2016 presidential elections. The internet companies are opting to send their top legal advisors instead of their CEOs, Mark Zuckerberg, Jack Dorsey, and Sundar Pichai, to avoid putting them in the spotlight and dealing with potentially damaging questions and a full-blown public relations crisis.

Here's a rundown of who will be appearing in the congressional hearings:

Colin Stretch, Facebook's 48-year-old general counsel, has been with the company since 2010 and has led several high-profile legal battles, including an internal review on foreign interference on the platform. He previously led negotiations with the Federal Trade Commission over charges of privacy violations and directed the company's legal victory over the Winklevoss twins, who claimed Mark Zuckerberg stole their idea for Facebook. Stretch received his undergraduate degree from Dartmouth and law degree from Harvard, and clerked for Supreme Court Justice Stephen Breyer.

Richard Walker, Google's 56-year-old general counsel, joined the company in 2006 after serving as deputy general counsel at eBay. During his time at Google, the company has been involved in several high-profile legal battles, including a landmark copyright case with Viacom and a lawsuit with Oracle over software copyrights. Walker is currently leading Google's efforts to challenge a $2.7 billion fine from the European Commission for antitrust violations. After receiving his undergraduate degree from Harvard and law degree from Stanford, Walker worked as an assistant United States attorney at the Department of Justice. "Acting General Counsel, Mr. Edgett, 39, is currently filling the role while Vijaya Gadde, Twitter's General Counsel, is on maternity leave. With over a decade of experience at Twitter, Mr. Edgett has been part of a legal team that has faced numerous challenges, including navigating complex policy and legal issues related to site security, hate speech, foreign government demands for information, and the use of the platform by terrorist groups. Prior to joining Twitter, Mr. Edgett worked at prominent law firms Latham & Watkins and Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld. He holds a law degree from Pepperdine University and a Bachelor's degree from the University of California, San Diego."

"How do I know when a Windows 10 update is a system upgrade rather than just a patch? I get notifications about patches all the time, so I'm not sure when this one is different. Can I tell if it's already installed itself?

A. Microsoft started releasing the Windows 10 Fall Creators Update last Tuesday, which is available through the Windows Update utility for compatible devices. To check if the update is available for your system, go to the Windows Update page and look for the 'Feature update to Windows 10, version 1709' option. If you're unsure, you can manually check for updates. To do this, click the Start button on your Windows 10 desktop, select Settings, and then navigate to Update & Security > Windows Update. Click the 'Check for updates' button to see a list of available updates for your device."

Amazon has announced that it received a total of 238 proposals from cities and regions across North America for its proposed second headquarters, with bids coming from all but seven American states and several Canadian provinces and territories. The company did not release a list of applicants, but a color-coded map on its website shows that proposals came from 54 states, provinces, districts, and territories, including Puerto Rico. The map reveals that the majority of applicants came from the United States, with only North Dakota, South Dakota, Wyoming, Montana, Vermont, Arkansas, and Hawaii declining to participate. In Canada, the Yukon Territory, Saskatchewan, and New Brunswick were among those that did not submit a bid, while in Mexico, only three states - Chihuahua, Hidalgo, and Queretaro - applied. Amazon has said it will announce its decision sometime next year.

The bidding process for Amazon's second headquarters, dubbed HQ2, has been marked by a frenzy of publicity stunts and incentives offered by cities and regions eager to lure the 50,000 high-paying jobs promised by the company. Some cities have gone to great lengths to woo Amazon, including the mayor of Washington, D.C., who made a viral video featuring a faux conversation with Alexa, Amazon's intelligent assistant. Other cities have offered more unusual incentives, such as Tucson's 21-foot-tall saguaro cactus and Calgary's offer to fight a bear to win Amazon's new headquarters. While the bidding process has generated significant free publicity for Amazon, it has also sparked criticism of the company's request for tax breaks and other incentives, which some have dubbed a form of corporate welfare. New Jersey has proposed providing $7 billion in state and city tax incentives to bring Amazon to Newark. Some job seekers deliberately focused on showcasing their decision not to apply for Amazon's second headquarters. A business organization in Little Rock, Arkansas, recently published a newspaper ad in The Washington Post (owned by Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos) and created an online video to inform Amazon that they didn't want the traffic congestion its new headquarters would bring to their town. Notably, Arkansas is the home state of Amazon's main competitor, Walmart.

Is there a simple way to determine if the cable TV service is out for everyone or just at my own home due to equipment issues, without having to make a phone call? If you have a working internet connection or access to one on a mobile device or work computer, and you have an online account with your cable provider, you may be able to check the status of your own equipment. To do this, log in to your account on your TV provider's website and navigate to the technical support section. The information you find will vary depending on your cable company, but many providers offer online tools to help troubleshoot issues and reduce the need for phone calls. For example, Spectrum allows you to select the affected service (such as TV or internet) and view the status of your service, as well as check for any notices of outages in your area.

Twitter's headquarters in San Francisco is facing scrutiny over its role in the 2016 presidential election, with the company being called to account for its alleged involvement in deception and chicanery. On Thursday, Twitter admitted that it had overstated its monthly user figures since 2014, after mistakenly including data from third-party applications in its count. The revelation came as the company reported a narrower net loss in the third quarter and a 14% increase in daily active users. However, the disclosure may further damage Twitter's reputation, which is already under scrutiny over its role in Russia's election meddling, its handling of abuse and harassment on the platform, and concerns about its slowing user growth worldwide. Twitter discovered that its measure of monthly active users had been improperly including figures from third-party applications that used Digits, a software-development program. Digits is part of the Fabric mobile application platform that Twitter sold to Alphabet, Google's parent company, earlier this year. The program allowed third-party applications to send authentication messages through Twitter's systems, but did not reflect activity on the Twitter platform. As a result, the company lowered its monthly active user count by 2 million for the first and second quarters of this year and by 1 million for the fourth quarter of 2016. Twitter was unable to reconcile the figures for periods before last year's fourth quarter due to its data-retention policies. The company reported a 4% increase in monthly active users from the same period last year, with 330 million users, up from 326 million in the second quarter. Twitter reported a net loss of $21.1 million for the quarter, compared to a $102.9 million loss for the same period last year. Revenue declined 4% to $590 million.

"I've recently purchased a new iPhone and have noticed that every time I pick it up or move it, the screen turns on automatically, rather than requiring me to press the power button. Is this a common issue with the phone? The iPhone 6s and later models come equipped with a feature called Raise to Wake, which detects when you're holding the device and automatically activates the screen. This can be a convenient feature, as it eliminates the need to search for the power buttons. However, if you're not used to this feature, it may seem unusual at first. When you lift the phone, the screen will wake up and display your lock screen, allowing you to view any notifications you've received without needing to unlock the device. This can be helpful, but some users may prefer to disable this feature for privacy reasons."

This week, lawmakers delivered a stern message to Facebook regarding how Russian agents exploited the social network to spread division during the 2016 election. However, on Wednesday, Facebook's top executives, including CEO Mark Zuckerberg and COO Sheryl Sandberg, sent a different message: one focused on profit. As Facebook concluded its attendance at Capitol Hill hearings on Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election, the company released its third-quarter financial results. According to the report, Facebook's revenue increased by 47% to $10.3 billion, with profits surging 79% to $4.7 billion, exceeding Wall Street expectations. The results highlighted Facebook's dominance in online advertising, an area the company has been criticized for in Washington this week. Lawmakers questioned Facebook, Google, and Twitter about how Russians may have misused their platforms, including online ads, to fuel discord and polarization in the American electorate. Some lawmakers were particularly frustrated by the absence of top executives from Facebook, Google, and Twitter at the hearings, as well as the lack of attendance by their top lawyers. Facebook's general counsel, Colin Stretch, answered questions on behalf of the company, while Google and Twitter sent their top lawyers to participate.

A Canadian filmmaker, Barry Avrich, has decided to revive his documentary about Harvey Weinstein, which he initially released online in 2011. Avrich claims that the original film, titled "Unauthorized: The Harvey Weinstein Project," was watered down, and he now feels a moral obligation to rework it in light of the sexual harassment and rape allegations against Weinstein. Speaking from Ottawa, Avrich stated that he wants to expand the documentary beyond its initial 11-minute conclusion, which focused on Weinstein's behavior as a sexual predator. However, Avrich must first resolve the issue with IFC Films, a division of AMC Networks, which acquired the distribution rights to his documentary in 2010. Avrich has long alleged that IFC subsequently requested edits to the film and ultimately decided against a theatrical release to appease Weinstein, who was a powerful figure in Hollywood at the time. IFC has consistently denied these claims, releasing a statement on Wednesday that said: "The film was made available on various platforms, including Netflix, iTunes, and our own streaming service. We believe we provided suitable distribution for the documentary, as we do for the six to eight documentaries we distribute annually. We asked the filmmaker to remove 30 seconds of footage that we deemed non-essential to the story."

"I've been frustrated with my iPhone since I upgraded the software. Whenever I'm in a taxi, it keeps thinking I'm driving and I have to constantly tap the 'I'm not driving' button. How do I tell my phone I don't drive?
