The recent iOS 11 update includes a new safety feature within the 'Do Not Disturb' function that silences notifications while driving. When enabled, this feature automatically kicks in when the iPhone connects to a car's dashboard via Bluetooth or detects movement and acceleration similar to what you'd experience in a car. It can even mistake the movement of a train or bus for driving. And, as I've discovered, taxi passengers may find their phones temporarily disabled unless they switch off the Do Not Disturb control."

Thousands of years ago, two microscopic spores gave birth to a massive fungus, which grew at an astonishing rate of up to three feet per year. As it expanded, it sent out dark, twisted tendrils called rhizomorphs to explore the underground darkness and forage for sustenance. Today, this enormous organism covers an area the size of three Central Parks beneath the Oregon soil, potentially weighing as much as 5,000 African elephants. Known scientifically as Armillaria ostoyae, this behemoth is affectionately referred to as The Humongous Fungus, and it's officially recognized as the largest known terrestrial organism on the planet by the United States Forest Service. However, its impressive size comes with a deadly drawback: it's a highly destructive forest pathogen. While none have reached the same colossal proportions, other Armillaria species are also prevalent in North America, Europe, and Asia, causing root rot disease in forests, parks, orchards, and vineyards. What sets these fungi apart is their ability to send out stringy rhizomorphs that target weak trees, colonize their roots, and ultimately kill and consume them. A team of international scientists, led by Hungarian researchers, has made a breakthrough in the fight against these fungal giants. In a recent study published in Nature Ecology and Evolution, they uncovered the genetic secrets behind Armillaria's remarkable ability to develop its unique rhizomorphs, grow to enormous sizes, and excel at killing host plants.

"My new iPhone doesn't have a globe key on the keyboard like I've seen on other people's Apple phones. Instead, I have a'smiling face' key. Why is this? The iPhone can display multiple keyboard layouts for dozens of languages, including the smiling face and other emoji pictographs. When you add a new international keyboard, the'smiling face' key that inserts emoji characters into text changes to the globe key. Press and hold the globe key to access a menu that displays your alternate keyboard choices, including emoji. If you want to use a keyboard designed for another language, you can add it in the iPhone's keyboard settings. To do this, go to the Settings app, select General, then Keyboard, and finally Add New Keyboard. On the Add New Keyboard screen, scroll through the list and select the language you want to use. Alternatively, if you're using the keyboard in an app, you can access the settings by pressing and holding the emoji key for a few seconds, which will bring up a menu with an option for Keyboard Settings."

When someone tells you to "wake up and smell the roses," they may be giving you misleading advice. Research suggests that our sense of smell can vary in sensitivity over the course of 24 hours, with our noses being most effective during the hours leading up to sleep. A recent study published in the journal Chemical Senses found that this fluctuation is linked to our internal circadian clocks. The study, led by sensory researcher Rachel Herz at Brown University, aimed to explore whether the senses of taste and smell in adolescents influence obesity. To conduct the experiment, 37 adolescents aged 12 to 15 spent nine days in a lab, following a strict schedule to regulate their sleep-wake cycles. This allowed researchers to focus on the circadian clock's impact on the body, including metabolism. While more research is needed to determine the applicability of these findings to adults, Dr. Herz notes that the composition of smell receptors in the nose appears to remain stable throughout adulthood, although there is evidence that the body's internal clock may undergo changes.

Apple has made a significant move in the TV industry, securing the rights to a highly anticipated new drama series starring Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston. The show, centered around a morning TV show, is a major coup for Apple, which has outbid other contenders like Netflix and Showtime for the two-season, 20-episode project. This marks Apple's second major TV acquisition, following its earlier deal to revive Steven Spielberg's "Amazing Stories" anthology series. However, the Witherspoon-Aniston project is a much more significant move, given the star power and success of its leads. Witherspoon is coming off the critically acclaimed HBO limited series "Big Little Lies," where she starred and served as an executive producer. The new project will also mark Aniston's return to television after her iconic role on "Friends."

In a recent news conference, a prominent figure stated, "Google has amassed more information on individual consumers than any entity in history. We should not blindly trust the claims of corporate giants that they prioritize our well-being. Instead, we must ensure they comply with the law, protect consumers, and be held accountable." This statement comes as public opinion about tech companies has shifted. As technology expands into more industries and profits soar at the largest tech companies, critics argue that these firms have become too powerful and require regulatory oversight.

The state's preliminary investigation has found that Google may be collecting more user data than it has publicly disclosed, and users may not have a genuine option to opt out of this data collection. Google claims to provide consumers with the ability to control their privacy settings and does not share personally identifiable information like names, email addresses, and billing information with third parties.

When asked how Google would respond to the subpoena, a company spokesperson, Patrick Lenihan, declined to comment, citing the fact that the company had not yet received the subpoena. However, he emphasized that Google has robust privacy protections in place for its users and operates in a competitive and dynamic environment.

In 2012, the Federal Trade Commission (F.T.C.) concluded an investigation into Google's business practices without filing charges. As part of the settlement, Google agreed to cease using photos or user reviews from third-party sites that had requested their content not be scraped by Google's computers.

Is it true that you can now block those pesky videos that automatically play on some websites in Safari? Yes, with the macOS High Sierra update, Apple has added features to its Safari browser that allow you to stop loud videos from suddenly blasting. You can also customize your preferences for individual websites that play videos you don't mind seeing immediately. To manage autoplay videos, you have two options. If you land on a site that starts playing a video, you can right-click (or hold down the Control key and click) in the Safari address bar and select "Settings for This Website" (or find the option under the Safari menu).

Time Inc., the publisher of renowned magazines such as Time, People, and Sports Illustrated, may be on the brink of a significant transformation. On Sunday, the company agreed to be acquired by Meredith, a Midwestern publisher that has long been courting Time Inc. The deal, valued at nearly $3 billion, is roughly equivalent to the company's annual revenue. Like many of its peers, Time Inc. has struggled to adapt to the industry's shift from print to digital media. A decade ago, management disagreements and cost-cutting measures led to the departure of key talent and left the company without a clear succession plan. Now, after nearly 100 years in business, Time Inc. must turn to its new owner, Meredith, to chart a course for its future - a future that may not rely on the iconic photography, swimsuit models, and ambitious journalism that have made Time Inc.'s titles household names.

"To experience the most breathtaking Christmas trees, you'll need to trade in your boots for scuba gear. Your current Christmas tree is lovely, but it's a far cry from the most stunning ones out there. These extraordinary 'trees' aren't plants at all, but rather the intricate homes built by Christmas tree worms on coral reefs around the world. These marine creatures construct their tubes using calcium carbonate secretions and emerge to feed, reproduce, and breathe using their branchial crowns. As you snorkel through the waters, keep an eye out for these vibrant, spiral-shaped cones that resemble miniature decorated firs. According to marine biologist Orly Perry, who's studied these 'trees' as part of her doctoral research, they're "really pretty, very colorful, very festive, and Christmassy." Most of these worm 'trees' grow no more than an inch from the tube's opening, but they make up for their small size with dazzling displays that resemble the work of a skilled candymaker. In the Gulf of Aqaba, near Eilat, Israel, Perry has observed many of these 'trees' displaying a kaleidoscope of colors, including purples, greens, and whites. However, they can also be found in a range of other colors, and some even sport a solid winter white hue. Unlike other creatures, Christmas tree worms don't burrow into the coral; instead, they latch onto dead spots or wounds and begin constructing their tubes. By synchronizing their tube growth with the coral's growth, the worms ensure that their homes remain stable and accessible. Once settled, these worms stay put for up to 30 or 40 years, unable to relocate. As Perry notes, "it's crucial to find the right place" to settle." The locations where these larvae settle are not arbitrary. They appear to have a specific preference for certain coral species, often opting for less aggressive ones. Some species within the Spirobranchus genus have a fondness for artificial surfaces, while others have been found to thrive on specific types of coral. In fact, Mrs. Perry discovered a potentially new species in the Gulf of Eilat that has a peculiar affinity for plastic buoys and metal surfaces on piers and staircases. It's possible that the larvae are drawn to these preferred habitats by signals emitted by older worms that have successfully colonized similar locations in the past. In these optimal environments, the worms are able to grow to their full size. According to Mrs. Perry, this phenomenon is reminiscent of human behavior: "If you're comfortable in a place, everything is happy, and that's true for these worms too. Their size is directly impacted by their habitat choice."

As the streaming wars intensify, Apple has made its third TV show acquisition in just two months. The latest addition is a space drama produced by Ronald D. Moore, the mastermind behind popular shows like "Battlestar Galactica" and "Outlander". Last month, Apple secured the highly coveted rights to a project starring Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston, set in the world of morning TV. In October, Apple revived Steven Spielberg's 1980s anthology series, "Amazing Stories", for its first acquisition. It's likely to be at least a year before any of these shows are available to viewers, and the distribution plan is still unclear. However, Apple's eagerness to add shows to its growing slate is a testament to the cutthroat competition for content in the industry. On Thursday, Disney announced its plans to acquire 21st Century Fox, a move aimed at boosting its own ambitious streaming ambitions. Meanwhile, Netflix, the current leader in the streaming space, has pledged to spend up to $8 billion on content next year. Apple, on the other hand, has a budget of around $1 billion for original programming.

The latest development in the corporate battle for dominance in New York's live music industry came on Monday, as the Bowery Ballroom and Mercury Lounge, two iconic indie clubs, partnered with concert giant Live Nation. The two companies announced the creation of Mercury East Presents, a new promotion and booking company that will bring together the Bowery and Mercury with Live Nation's Irving Plaza, Gramercy Theater, and Warsaw clubs, as well as its Ford Amphitheater at Coney Island Boardwalk. The partnership aims to share expertise and marketing strategies, reflecting the rapid consolidation of the local market. In recent years, Live Nation has expanded its presence in the city, acquiring the Governors Ball festival in 2016 and AEG, its rival, has also made significant moves, buying the Bowery Presents and partnering with the owners of Barclays Center to purchase and renovate Webster Hall.

Wearable devices can now track heart rate, body temperature, and other vital signs. For the first time, a flexible, wearable sensor can detect multiple chemicals in sweat, providing real-time data on conditions like dehydration and fatigue. According to Ali Javey, an electrical engineer at the University of California, Berkeley, and co-inventor of the device, this technology has the potential to alert patients to take action, such as drinking water or taking medication. The sensor was described in a recent publication in the journal Nature. Dr. Javey noted that while many studies have explored how and why sweat composition changes, it was previously challenging to measure this in patients. He highlighted the system's advantage as being both comfortable and easy to wear.

Joe Earley, who spent over two decades in senior leadership roles at the Fox Television Group before resigning in October, is making a return to his old stomping ground in a new capacity. As of Friday, Earley, 49, will be the president of the Jackal Group, a new television, film, and live theater company co-owned by Fox and Gail Berman, a veteran entertainment executive. Berman announced Earley's hiring in a statement, praising him as "an exceptional leader with a keen eye for great content." Earley's departure from Fox was notable, as he left his top television job without being promoted or pushed out. "My role had become increasingly focused on operations, and I wanted to be closer to the creative side of the business again," Earley explained in a phone interview. "It's a fortunate coincidence that the opportunity to work with Gail again was the perfect fit."

I'm not claustrophobic or fidgety, and I have a passion for music, although I'm not a musician. Despite having written about numerous neuroscience studies that utilize functional magnetic resonance imaging (F.M.R.I.), I had never witnessed a scan in person. This was my chance to change that. I asked Nancy Kanwisher, a professor of neuroscience at M.I.T., if she would allow me to participate in the experiment recently published in the journal Neuron. I requested that she take me through the process, showing me where the music-specific pathway is located in my brain. I assured her that the enclosed environment wouldn't cause me to panic and that I would remain still and focused, providing high-quality data. Dr. Kanwisher agreed, and I was escorted to the scanning room in the basement by Sam Norman-Haignere, a postdoctoral fellow, and Alex Kell, a graduate student. The scanning device uses radio waves and powerful magnetic fields to track blood flow in the brain, an indirect measure of neural activity. Before the scan, I was instructed to remove any metal objects, including my boots, belt, earrings, and anything else that might interfere with the magnetic coils. I expressed concern about my titanium dental implants, but was reassured that they would be safe.

Richard P. Von Herzen, a renowned explorer who uncovered the surprising truth that the deep sea's icy exterior concealed vast regions of simmering heat, passed away on January 28 in Portola Valley, California. He was 85 years old. His daughter, Lane Von Herzen, confirmed that the cause of death was vascular disease. For over five decades, Dr. Von Herzen worked at the country's premier ocean research institutions, including the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution on Cape Cod and the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla, California. His early career coincided with a major scientific controversy. In 1912, German geophysicist Alfred Wegener proposed that the continents slowly move, much like a giant jigsaw puzzle, with the shoulder of South America fitting neatly into the armpit of Africa. Wegener's idea sparked widespread ridicule and debate that persisted for decades. However, Dr. Von Herzen's research was part of a broader body of work that ultimately validated Wegener's theory. As a skilled inventor, Dr. Von Herzen developed the first modern instruments and methods for measuring temperatures in the deep sea, enabling him and his peers to make extensive readings of how heat from the Earth's molten core rises through the seafloor. His expeditions in the 1960s across the South Atlantic and Pacific Oceans revealed significant temperature flows at seabed mountain ranges and low flows at deep ocean trenches.

While your portfolio of American stocks may have struggled recently, your portfolio of foreign stocks has likely performed even worse for a longer period. This disparity can be attributed to the US economy's faster growth rate and a stronger dollar, which devalues assets priced in other currencies. However, this trend may soon reverse, and many experts are advising investors to prepare for a shift in leadership and a prolonged period of strength in foreign markets. "In the remainder of 2016, investors can expect numerous opportunities in foreign markets, surpassing those in the US," said Komal Sri-Kumar, president of Sri-Kumar Global Strategies. "Foreign markets have historically offered better valuations, and they're correcting more sharply now." Factors such as central banks' interest-rate policies could also improve the prospects for foreign stocks. The Federal Reserve recently raised interest rates for the first time since the financial crisis and signaled further hikes, but the market is skeptical about the domestic economy's ability to support such aggressive tightening. In contrast, other central banks are adopting a more accommodative stance.

Naked mole rats, previously thought to be immune to cancer, have been found to be susceptible to the disease. Researchers had never reported finding cancer in these long-living rodents, either in the wild or in zoos, and had even injected their cells with viruses that trigger tumors in mice without seeing any adverse effects. However, a recent study published in Veterinary Pathology has found two cases of cancer in naked mole rats housed in zoos. According to Martha Delaney, a veterinary pathologist at the University of Washington School of Medicine and lead author of the study, these cases do not rule out the possibility that naked mole rats may hold a clue to fighting cancer, but rather provide additional clues about what makes them less susceptible to cancer. "Now that we have two cases of cancer in naked mole rats, we can study the colonies from which they came to understand why they are more prone to cancer compared to other zoo and research colonies," Dr. Delaney explained. The discovery of cancer in naked mole rats is significant, as researchers have been studying the rodents for over a decade to understand why they are less prone to cancer. The first case of cancer was identified in a 22-year-old male naked mole rat from the Brookfield Zoo in Chicago, which was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma, a type of cancer that develops from the body's mucus-secreting glands.

David Litt, the former joke writer for President Obama, is joining Funny or Die, a humor website and studio, to poke fun at American politics. As the new head writer and producer of Funny or Die's Washington operation, Litt will bring his comedic expertise to the role. According to Mike Farah, Funny or Die's president of production, Litt is "funny, clearly much smarter than all of us, and bears a striking resemblance to David Spade in the movie 'Tommy Boy'." Litt, 29, previously served as a special assistant to President Obama and senior presidential speechwriter until his departure on January 23. One of his notable comedic achievements was writing the script for a memorable moment at last year's White House Correspondents' Association dinner, where President Obama was joined on stage by his "anger translator," played by comedian Keegan-Michael Key. The video of the performance has been viewed over 35 million times on Facebook.

A remarkable cheetah named Chewbaaka has enabled scientists to journey through the species' rich and complex history, uncovering clues about how they evolved into the world's fastest land animals. Rescued as a 10-day-old orphan in Namibia, Chewbaaka became an ambassador for the Cheetah Conservation Fund, earning his name from a variation of the "Star Wars" character's moniker. Although he passed away five years ago at the remarkable age of 16, twice the average lifespan of a wild cheetah, his genetic legacy lives on. Scientists drew his blood, which was combined with samples from six other cheetahs from Namibia and East Africa to sequence the species' complete genome. Cheetahs, with their striking coats and distinctive "teardrop" markings, are a favorite among tourists on photographic safaris. Their remarkable speed, reaching nearly 60 miles per hour, is attributed to their unique physiology, featuring elongated legs, an aerodynamic skull, powerful adrenal glands and heart muscles, and claws that grip the earth like football cleats. Unfortunately, cheetahs are critically endangered, with only around 10,000 individuals remaining, mostly in southern and eastern Africa. A recent genomic analysis has revealed concerning findings: the cheetah has less than 5% of the genomic diversity of other wild cats, a level lower than even inbred domestic dogs and cats, and the lowest among the 30 mammals whose genomes have been sequenced. Genetic diversity in an animal is determined by variations in enzyme genes inherited from its parents and is crucial for its healthy reproduction and immunity to disease.

Sarah Kershaw, a former journalist for The New York Times who covered real estate, the Pacific Northwest, and New York City schools, passed away on Monday at her home in Sosua, a beach town in the Dominican Republic. She was 49 years old at the time of her death. According to Osvaldo Bonilla, a prosecutor for the province of Puerto Plata, who is investigating her death, Sarah was found with a plastic bag tied over her head and pill bottles nearby. Officials are waiting for the results of toxicology tests before determining the cause of death. However, according to Mr. Bonilla, Sarah had told her friends that she intended to take her own life due to a debilitating illness. Contrary to an initial report by the Dominican National Police, Sarah was not strangled, Mr. Bonilla clarified. Her husband, William Paul Norton, was questioned but later released without being charged. Sarah began her career at The Times in 1995 as a news clerk, writing articles about New York City schools and New Jersey on a freelance basis, before leaving for Newsday. She returned to The Times in 2000 and covered local news before being promoted to bureau chief in Seattle. Later, she wrote for the Styles and Real Estate sections of the newspaper.

It was a problem that everyone knew could be solved, but had yet to be cracked. For over a century, engineers, inventors, and tinkerers had been working on various forms of "telemotion," "televista," "photo-telegraph," and "tele-vision" using established technologies and readily available equipment. As early as 1907, The New York Times featured an article on February 24, introducing the concept, which was still in its infancy. The article announced the successful transmission of photographs by wire, crediting Dr. Arthur Korn's "telephotograph" invention. According to the anonymous reporter, with a few improvements to the apparatus, "television" or "seeing by telegraph" was just a year or two away. The article was accompanied by portraits of five elegantly mustachioed men, all transmitted using the new technology. Additionally, there was a picture of Dr. Korn himself, sitting beside his "telephotographic apparatus," sporting a healthy mustache.

Fox News achieved the highest ratings for a Republican debate since December, with 16.9 million viewers tuning in on Thursday night. The debate marked the first time Donald J. Trump and Megyn Kelly shared the stage since August. Thursday's ratings ranked as the fourth-highest viewership for a debate to date. The numbers significantly surpassed the 12.5 million viewers who watched the late January debate on Fox News, which Mr. Trump had declined to participate in due to Ms. Kelly's involvement. The viewership total also eclipsed the largest audience since CNN's debate in December, which drew over 18 million viewers. Fox News holds the record for the most-watched primary debate, which was its August event that attracted 24 million viewers. Additionally, the Thursday debate set a new record for live streams, with 1.5 million concurrent streams, according to Omniture and Akamai.

The advertising industry's go-to buzzword is "branded content," which suggests that marketing messages can be delivered with finesse by disguising them as entertainment or journalism. However, this concept often fails to impress, as readers can spot awkward advertorials and corporate sponsors' logos plastered everywhere, even at high-profile events like South by Southwest. But Red Bull Music Academy is an exception. Despite being an energy drink company associated with extreme sports, it has managed to build credibility over the past 18 years by hosting a respected music festival that attracts renowned musicians like Brian Eno, La Monte Young, Ryuichi Sakamoto, and D'Angelo. This year, the academy will take place in Montreal, but for the fourth consecutive year, a Red Bull Music Academy festival of live events will be held in New York, featuring an impressive lineup from April 29 to May 22. The festival will include a night of avant-garde jazz with Kamasi Washington, Pharoah Sanders, and the Sun Ra Arkestra, as well as performances by Anohni, Diamanda Galas, Glenn Branca, Dizzee Rascal, and Eddie Palmieri, all of whom are giants in their respective genres.

Universal Studios Hollywood is set to unveil a massive expansion themed around the popular Harry Potter franchise next month, aiming to attract families and compete with nearby Disneyland. However, the park has just thrown a surprise curveball at its teenage fan base: a permanent "The Walking Dead" attraction is coming to the park. A new haunted house, designed in collaboration with the creative team behind the AMC horror series, will be located near the new Hogsmeade area and is set to open this summer. A promotional video for the attraction shows a building engulfed in flames and zombies attacking visitors through a chain-link fence. According to Larry Kurzweil, president of Universal Studios Hollywood, the goal is to create a cross-generational experience that will appeal to a wide range of audiences. This will be a unique, immersive attraction that takes visitors on a thrilling adventure. Fans of "The Walking Dead" have had limited opportunities to participate in simulated invasions and experiences, including temporary mazes during Halloween festivals at Universal parks and a one-time experience at Comic-Con International in San Diego in 2012.

Lloyd S. Shapley, a renowned mathematician and emeritus professor at U.C.L.A., passed away on Saturday in Tucson at the age of 92. His son, Peter, confirmed the news, stating that Shapley had broken his hip several weeks prior. Shapley was a pioneer in the field of game theory, which seeks to understand the strategic decisions made by competitors in various situations. He is credited with developing the "Shapley value," a concept that allows for the fair distribution of benefits among participants based on their relative contributions. Shapley was a close friend and mentor to John Forbes Nash Jr., a fellow mathematician and Nobel laureate who struggled with schizophrenia. The friendship between Shapley and Nash was documented in Sylvia Nasar's 1998 biography, "A Beautiful Mind," which was adapted into a film in 2001. Nasar, a former New York Times reporter, credited Shapley with suggesting the book's title, which was inspired by his remark that Nash was "obnoxious" but redeemed by his "keen, beautiful, logical mind."

Scientists anticipated that plants would increase their respiration by nearly five times as much, based on short-term temperature response measurements from this study and others. To investigate, researchers at two forest research sites in Minnesota tested the respiration rates of 10 tree species from boreal and temperate forests over a period of three to five years. The trees were subjected to two conditions: ambient temperature and a 6-degree warmer temperature, achieved using heating cables. To examine long-term temperature adaptation, the scientists compared three factors: carbon dioxide release in ambient conditions, carbon dioxide release in the warmer conditions, and carbon dioxide release during short-term exposure to the warmer temperature (minutes or hours). When analyzing the results, they found that trees acclimated to warmer temperatures increased their carbon dioxide release by a significantly smaller amount than trees exposed to the same short-term temperature increase.

Two weeks after a deadly shooting in a Pittsburgh suburb, local news anchor Wendy Bell wrote a Facebook post that initially focused on finding hope and spreading kindness. However, before moving on to the kindness aspect, she made racial comments that ultimately led to her termination on Wednesday. The shooting, which occurred on March 9 in Wilkinsburg, Pennsylvania, killed five people, including a pregnant woman, and remains unsolved, with no arrests made and no suspects publicly identified. In her March 21 Facebook post, which was later edited and deleted, Bell played detective, making some critics feel that her comments relied on harmful stereotypes. "You don't need to be a criminal profiler to imagine the mental picture of the killers who shattered so many hearts two weeks ago," she wrote. The post continued to describe the suspects as "young black men, likely in their teens or early 20s" who had been in the system before and were familiar with the police. Bell also mentioned a hardworking young black man she saw working at a restaurant, praising him in a way that some saw as condescending. "I wonder how long it had been since someone told him he was special," she wrote. Bell did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Station officials removed her from the air last week and distanced themselves from her remarks, with President and General Manager Charles W. Wolfertz calling her comments an "egregious lack of judgment" in a broadcast address. In a statement, WTAE-TV's parent company, Hearst, said her comments were "inconsistent with the company's ethics and journalistic standards." Ms. Bell, who has been a part of the station since 1998 and has earned 21 regional Emmy Awards, issued an apology on her Facebook page, which has since been removed. In her statement, she acknowledged that some of her words may have been hurtful and could be perceived as racist. She expressed regret for causing offense and apologized sincerely. One of her supporters defended her, saying, "She spoke the truth, and those responsible for her termination should be ashamed." This is not the first time Ms. Bell has faced criticism for her comments. In the past, she has been forced to apologize for remarks perceived as offensive to African-Americans, according to Media Matters, a liberal watchdog organization. In 2010, after a segment on sunscreen, Ms. Bell made a comment to her black co-anchor, saying, "I want whatever you're using." She later apologized, saying that her words didn't come out as intended and had unintentionally offended some people. She expressed her deep regret and hope that her apology would be accepted.

A judge's order has brought the debate over race in Hollywood into the legal arena. Music executive Gerald E. Heller has filed a lawsuit against the makers of "Straight Outta Compton", alleging defamation and infringement of his rights. Following a ruling by Judge Michael W. Fitzgerald of the United States District Court for the Central District of California, Heller may now have the opportunity to present his case in court. Heller, who was once a business partner of N.W.A., the rap group featured in the film, claims that Paul Giamatti's portrayal of him as a sleazy and exploitative music manager in the movie has damaged his reputation and livelihood.

Andrew Sullivan, a renowned political commentator who was at the forefront of blogging in its early days, has returned to prominence by joining New York Magazine as a contributing editor. In his new role, Sullivan will write in-depth features on politics and culture, as well as blog about the upcoming Democratic and Republican national conventions. However, he has stated that his focus will primarily be on long-form journalism, rather than regular blogging. Sullivan's new position began on Friday. Prior to this, his personal blog, The Daily Dish, was published at a rapid pace from 2000 onwards, and was later hosted by several prominent publications, including Time magazine, The Atlantic, and The Daily Beast. Sullivan eventually retired from blogging in 2015, citing exhaustion with the demands of digital life.

Exxon Mobil and the energy industry faced increased scrutiny on Wednesday with the release of a trove of decades-old documents revealing the industry's knowledge of climate change. The documents, published by the Center for International Environmental Law, suggest that the industry had a deep understanding of climate change as far back as 60 years ago. According to Carroll Muffett, the environmental law center's director, Exxon's predecessor, Humble Oil, was aware of rising CO2 levels and the potential for global warming as early as 1957. The American Petroleum Institute, energy companies, and other organizations had formed a group called the Smoke and Fumes Committee to monitor pollution research and use science to undermine environmental regulations. Muffett believes that this committee's actions would be echoed in later efforts to discredit climate science. The Center for International Environmental Law's work was first reported by Inside Climate News, which has previously published stories suggesting that Exxon Mobil understood the risks of climate change from its own research and used that knowledge to plan activities such as Arctic drilling. Exxon Mobil's own research also funded climate denial groups until the mid-2000s. The investigations have led to a surge in activism against the company and the energy industry, with the hashtag #exxonknew. Attorneys general, including Eric T. Schneiderman of New York, have demanded information from Exxon about its internal research and funding of climate denial. Inside Climate News announced that its article on Wednesday is the first in a series based on the environmental law center's work and documents. Exxon Mobil spokesman Alan Jeffers dismissed the new allegations as absurd. Exxon Mobil is pushing back against an investigation into its knowledge of climate change, claiming that the inquiry is not credible. The company is being investigated by four attorneys general, including Claude Earl Walker, the attorney general of the US Virgin Islands, who is working with a private law firm. Exxon Mobil filed a response in Texas, accusing Walker and his team of misusing their power and violating the company's constitutional rights. The company argues that it has no physical presence in the Virgin Islands and therefore is not subject to the jurisdiction of the island's courts.

Michael Strahan is making a switch from one morning show to another, leaving ABC's "Live with Kelly and Michael" to join "Good Morning America" in September. As co-anchor on "G.M.A.", Strahan will bring his expertise to the network's flagship morning program. Strahan took over as co-host of "Live" alongside Kelly Ripa in 2012, following Regis Philbin's departure, and has since provided a steady presence for the valuable ABC programming asset. Now, he may be tasked with helping to maintain "Good Morning America's" momentum, as the show still leads "Today" in overall viewership (averaging nearly five million) but trails in the key 25-to-54-year-old demographic.

In the live music industry, the most visible rivalry is often between promoters and venues vying for the biggest names in entertainment. However, behind the scenes, a constant battle is being waged over ticketing, with promoters, venues, and technology companies negotiating deals for ticket sales and the valuable customer data that comes with them. Last year, Pandora Media made a significant move by acquiring Ticketfly, an online ticketing service, for $450 million. This company competes with Ticketmaster to sign up clubs and theaters, and has partnerships with over 1,200 clients, including promoters and venues. Recently, Ticketfly has secured a deal to become the exclusive ticketing provider for the Bowery Ballroom and the Mercury Lounge, two of New York City's most beloved music venues. Both organizations, which have historically worked with Ticketmaster, announced that they would be switching to Ticketfly on Sunday. This deal holds symbolic significance for Ticketfly, as it marks a major coup for the company. The Bowery Ballroom, which Rolling Stone has named the best club in the country, attracts around 130,000 attendees annually, while the Mercury Lounge draws around 80,000. The agreement also expands Ticketfly's presence in New York City, where it already works with other popular venues such as Central Park SummerStage, Forest Hills Stadium, Brooklyn Bowl, Output, and Birdland. Notably, the deal was reached as the Bowery Presents, a promoter affiliated with the clubs, is in talks to be acquired by AEG Live, but this transaction is not expected to be affected by the Ticketfly agreement.

Rovio, the app developer behind Angry Birds, is encouraging moviegoers to take out their smartphones at the theater. To promote the upcoming release of "The Angry Birds Movie" in the US on Friday, Rovio is offering bonus content in its new mobile game, Angry Birds Action, to those who open the app during the movie's credits. This cross-platform marketing strategy is part of Rovio's efforts to revitalize its Angry Birds brand and transform the company into a global media powerhouse. The original Angry Birds game, released in 2009, became a massive hit, but sales have slowed in recent years, leading the company to diversify into consumer products and reduce its reliance on mobile games. Despite these efforts, Rovio reported a 13 million euro loss (around $15 million) in 2015. The company's desire to evolve beyond apps led to the development of "The Angry Birds Movie", according to Tuomo Korpinen, president of Rovio Animation and former DreamWorks Animation executive. "We needed to compete with the best in the industry, like Disney, Pixar, and DreamWorks," Korpinen said.

The Internet is following in the footsteps of the Weblog, Electronic Message, and World Wide Web. The New York Times announced on Tuesday that it will adopt the same lowercase naming convention as The Associated Press for the global network that has become an integral part of our daily lives. The network, which we access through our pockets and screens, keeps us engaged with various feeds, much like lab rats pressing a lever to receive a reward. The changes will take effect at both news outlets on June 1, which explains why "Internet" remains capitalized throughout this article. In a memo to the newsroom, Jill Taylor, who manages the copy desks at The Times, acknowledged that it may take some time to break the habit of capitalizing the word "Internet". The Times' decision follows The A.P.'s announcement in April, made during the American Copy Editors Society conference, where grammar enthusiasts, punctuation aficionados, and syntax aficionados gather to discuss the latest guidelines for American journalism.

Shanghai - It's been a tumultuous week for Disney's CEO, Robert A. Iger. Just six days ago, he was beaming with pride as he gave reporters a tour of the soon-to-open Shanghai Disneyland. However, his mood took a dramatic turn when a mass shooting occurred in Orlando, Florida, home to Walt Disney World. In response, Iger tightened security at the resort, released a statement expressing his "heartbreak" and pledged a $1 million donation to the shooting victims. Despite the tragic events, the Shanghai Disneyland show went on. On Tuesday night, Iger attended a festive event to celebrate the launch of an all-Mandarin version of Disney's "Lion King" stage musical. The evening was filled with laughter and champagne, with Iger surrounded by his enthusiastic lieutenants who had flown in for the party. The next morning, Iger looked relaxed as he stood on the "Tarzan" stage for a news conference attended by around 800 journalists from around the world. However, by Wednesday afternoon, more devastating news from Florida reached China: an alligator had dragged a toddler into a lake at a Disney World hotel, and the child was later presumed dead. Iger issued a statement from Shanghai, saying, "As a parent and grandparent, my heart goes out to the Graves family during this difficult time." It was probably for the best that the unveiling of the Shanghai Disneyland nightly fireworks show, "Ignite the Dream! A Nighttime Spectacular of Magic and Light," was canceled due to a rainstorm on Wednesday night.

Dweezil Zappa, a guitarist and son of the legendary rock composer Frank Zappa, has had to change the name of his project not once, but twice. Initially, he called it Zappa Plays Zappa, a tribute to his father's music, but he later renamed it Dweezil Zappa Plays Frank Zappa to avoid legal conflicts with his brother Ahmet, who controls the Zappa intellectual property through a family trust. However, after another legal dispute with his brother, Dweezil is rebranding the show once again. His upcoming tour, starting July 1 in El Prado, New Mexico, will be called "50 Years of Frank: Dweezil Zappa Plays Whatever the Heck He Wants -- The Cease and Desist Tour." The tour's name is a nod to the absurdity of the situation, and the 50-year anniversary of his father's debut album "Freak Out!" by the Mothers of Invention. The Zappa brothers, who were once musical partners, have been at odds since the passing of their mother, Gail, last year. The Zappa Family Trust now has two trustees, Ahmet and Diva Zappa, with Dweezil and his sister Moon as beneficiaries. Frank Zappa passed away in 1993.

On March 3, two armed men broke into the home of Berta Caceres, a renowned Honduran environmental activist, and took her life. For years, Ms. Caceres had passionately opposed the construction of the Agua Zarca Dam, which was slated to be built on the ancestral land of the indigenous Lenca people. According to a new report by Global Witness, a nonprofit organization dedicated to uncovering environmental abuses, Ms. Caceres was one of 185 environmental activists brutally murdered in 16 countries in the past year. This alarming figure represents a staggering 59% increase from the number of murders recorded in 2014, making it the highest recorded rate since Global Witness began tracking data in 2002. "The environment has become a new front in the fight for human rights," stated Billy Kyte, a campaign leader at Global Witness and the report's author.

Fourteen pigs, which had been retrofitted with lab-grown bone, were thriving. This was a welcome surprise, given their unusual implants. According to Dr. Gordana Vunjak-Novakovic, a professor of biomedical engineering at Columbia University, the pigs' recovery was remarkable. "The pigs woke up, and within half an hour, they were eating normally," she explained. "We expected them to be in pain, but instead, they're doing extremely well." Dr. Vunjak-Novakovic and her team have successfully created living bone from stem cells. To achieve this, they first created a 3D image of each pig's jaw using a CT scan. Next, they crafted a "scaffold" - a three-dimensional replica of the pig bone - from cow bone. The scaffold was then immersed in a nutrient solution with stem cells extracted from the pigs. The cells attached to the scaffold, forming a new bone identical to the original. The researchers then implanted the new bone into each pig. Their findings were published in Science Translational Medicine.

In 2014, a significant milestone was reached when the nation's student body, spanning from kindergarten to 12th grade, became majority-minority. This demographic shift is already being felt in colleges and universities across the country, and the Census Bureau predicts that the United States as a whole will follow suit by 2050. As I observe these changes, I am left wondering whether our college and university faculties are prepared to teach a diverse student body. Unfortunately, I believe they are not. Faculty members often receive little to no training on teaching, and even less on diversity and inclusion issues, which creates a concerning situation for future learning. For nearly two decades, I have been studying the innovative strategies used by minority-serving institutions (MSIs) to promote student success. In my most recent book, "Educating a Diverse Nation" (Harvard University Press), co-authored with Clifton Conrad, a professor at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, we detail the lessons from MSIs that all faculty members can apply to their teaching practices. These institutions assume students' potential for success, rather than viewing students of color through a deficit lens. They also teach in a way that focuses on students' needs, rather than the professor's convenience. Additionally, MSI faculty members collaborate to develop curricula and empower students, allow students to bring their full identity to the classroom, and provide culturally relevant assignments that connect to students' communities.

The issue of campus rape is finally receiving the attention it deserves. However, efforts to address the problem are fragmented and ineffective due to widespread confusion about the university's role in responding to sexual assault. Institutions of higher education cannot replace the criminal justice system, nor should they try to mimic the civil justice system. Instead, universities have unique interests that must be addressed. Their primary focus should be on providing a safe and inclusive learning environment, free from discrimination based on sex. This core mission should guide comprehensive institutional reform. For example, colleges have a responsibility to create an environment where all students can learn, which means preventing sexual assault and gender-based misconduct. The goal is not to place the burden of prevention on women by teaching them how to behave, but rather to eradicate gender violence and the racism and sexism that perpetuate it.

For those who prioritize teaching others over personal gain, the burden of college debt can seem overwhelming - and rightly so, as it is a significant obstacle. To build a well-educated and globally competitive workforce in America, we must make higher education affordable. The American Federation of Teachers has launched a series of student debt clinics to help its members alleviate the crushing debt accumulated by millions of American students and their families. These 90-minute sessions provide valuable information on enrolling in income-based student loan repayment programs and qualifying for Public Service Loan Forgiveness. For some participants, the clinics have been transformative. The A.F.T. is at the forefront of the fight against predatory lending practices, warning students and their families about the risks associated with for-profit educational providers, servicers, and lenders, while educating them on repayment options and empowering a new generation of advocates to combat the national student debt crisis. In October, a young adjunct professor from Miami attended a two-part A.F.T. debt clinic, feeling overwhelmed by her $168,000 student loan debt and monthly payments exceeding $2,000. As a single mother, she was desperate for relief. After the first day of the training, she applied for income-based repayment and was able to reduce her monthly payment to $700. By the second day, she had found the courage to share her story with the group, revealing that it was the first good night's sleep she'd had in three years. Today, she is a trainer herself, helping others navigate the process of debt relief.

The Supreme Court's potential decision to overturn its 2003 ruling in Grutter v. Bollinger would have far-reaching and devastating consequences. The experience in California over the past two decades serves as a stark warning. Prior to the statewide ban on affirmative action in 1997, the incoming classes of undergraduates at Berkeley and UCLA were roughly 8% African-American. In contrast, last year's incoming classes saw a significant decline, with only 4.3% of UCLA's students and 2.8% of Berkeley's students identifying as African-American. Meanwhile, the percentage of black college-age residents in California remained unchanged during this period. This stark reality demonstrates the impact of California's ban, which was the result of a ballot initiative. It is peculiar that, despite the ongoing debate over affirmative action, few dispute the importance of diversity in generating innovative ideas. Without a diverse student body and faculty, universities will struggle to achieve excellence in teaching, research, and intellectual discovery. Furthermore, without the ability to consider race in admissions, achieving diversity will become an unattainable goal for many institutions. While preserving the consideration of race in admissions is crucial, it is insufficient. I believe that the court and society must also confront the broader question: whether our institutions of higher education, which have long been a driving force for individual and communal advancement, will be enlisted in the pursuit of a racially integrated society that transcends our nation's legacy of slavery, Jim Crow, and segregation.

Scientists may have uncovered the secret to swordfish's impressive speed: a special performance-enhancing oil produced by the fish. A recent study by Dutch researchers found that swordfish have an oil-producing gland located at the base of their sword, which is connected to pores on their head through a network of capillaries. This unique oil is only secreted on the head of the fish, not its body. According to the study's lead author, John J. Videler, a professor of marine zoology at the University of Groningen in the Netherlands, this waterproof lubrication may provide a smooth, water-resistant covering for the fish's head, allowing it to achieve remarkable speeds.

The battle for control of Sumner M. Redstone's $40 billion media empire is likely to intensify in October, with a Delaware judge ruling that a lawsuit over the replacement of five Viacom directors will go to trial on October 17. The judge also instructed lawyers to discuss the possibility of an independent medical examination of Redstone, who is 93 and in poor health. With National Amusements, his holding company, controlling 80% of Viacom and CBS's voting shares, the stakes are high. In related developments, a Massachusetts judge has scheduled an October trial for a lawsuit questioning Redstone's mental competence to make business decisions, while a California judge has set a tentative hearing for October 18 to address the future of his business estate. The prospect of trials in multiple states could increase the incentive for the two sides to resolve their disputes outside of court. It remains unclear whether settlement talks are underway.

Frank Palopoli, a renowned chemist who led the team that developed Clomid, the world's most widely prescribed fertility medication for women, passed away on Saturday in Montgomery, Ohio. He was 94 years old at the time of his death, which was attributed to heart failure, according to his son Frank. Over a nearly 50-year period, millions of women have successfully become pregnant thanks to the relatively affordable drug clomiphene citrate, which was first marketed by the William S. Merrell Company under the brand name Clomid in 1967. The team, led by Mr. Palopoli and his organic chemistry researchers, synthesized and patented the pill, which is now widely available in generic and branded forms, including Serophene. Notably, among women whose only infertility issue is the failure of their ovaries to release egg cells during the menstrual cycle, approximately 80% of those who take Clomid will typically ovulate and be able to conceive naturally or through assisted reproductive technologies such as intrauterine insemination or in vitro fertilization.

A prime-time presidential forum on NBC, featuring Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump, attracted nearly 15 million viewers on Wednesday, surpassing many primary debates in terms of viewership, according to Nielsen statistics. This strong audience is a welcome sign for television executives, who are expecting record ratings for this fall's presidential debates. However, it may have been a setback for...

The live broadcast from the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum in Manhattan, aired on MSNBC and NBC affiliate channels, and featured some memorable moments, including Mr. Trump's praise for Russian President Vladimir V. Putin. Despite this, Mr. Lauer's perceived mistakes - including accusations of sloppiness and unfairness - dominated headlines on Thursday. Mrs. Clinton's team even sent out a fundraising email with the subject line "Matt Lauer," highlighting a moment during the forum when Mr. Lauer failed to correct a false claim made by Mr. Trump about his stance on the Iraq War.

As we experience the thrill of a roller coaster ride, we often anticipate certain physical reactions: a jolt in the stomach, a surge in our heart rate, and a tingling sensation in our fingertips. For some, this may be accompanied by other sensations: a sudden pain in the back, a kick in the lower abdomen, or an urgent need to use the restroom. These symptoms are reminiscent of those experienced by individuals who have passed a kidney stone, a condition that may surprisingly be triggered by certain roller coasters, according to a new study. To investigate this phenomenon, researchers created a silicone cast of the inside of a kidney and used it to study the effects of roller coasters on kidney stones. The study found that moderate-intensity, rattling roller coasters may be effective in dislodging small kidney stones in the outer ducts of the kidney and propelling them towards the ureter, the tube connecting the kidneys and bladder. The researchers' report, published in The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association, suggests that riding these roller coasters could be a potential treatment for patients with kidney stones that are five millimeters or less in diameter. "The idea is to dislodge these small stones before they grow into larger, more painful stones," said Dr. David Wartinger, a professor emeritus at Michigan State University and one of the study's authors. Dr. Wartinger was inspired to conduct the study after treating multiple patients who had passed kidney stones after visiting an amusement park. One patient in particular stood out, who passed kidney stones after each of three consecutive rides on the Big Thunder Mountain Railroad roller coaster at Disney World in Florida. Dr. Wartinger teamed up with Dr. Marc Mitchell, a urologist at the Doctors Clinic, to create a 3D-printed silicone cast of a patient's kidney. They filled their life-size model with kidney stones and urine and headed to Disney World, where they took 20 rides on Big Thunder Mountain, holding their model at kidney height and observing the movement of the kidney stones. A recent study found that the back of a roller coaster is a more effective spot to try and dislodge a small kidney stone, with a success rate of 64% compared to just 17% at the front. Each year, over 300,000 Americans seek emergency care for kidney stones, often due to severe pain caused by a large stone lodged in their ureter. However, it's unlikely that a roller coaster ride would provide relief for those with larger stones. According to Dr. James Borin, a urologist at New York University, this study is specifically designed for individuals with small kidney stones. For now, if you're aware of having a small kidney stone and are interested in trying the roller coaster method, it's recommended that you consult with your urologist. Who knows, you might be able to eliminate your kidney stone while also having a thrilling experience – a true case of "killing two birds with one stone."

The audience for Tuesday's vice-presidential debate between Mike Pence and Tim Kaine was significantly smaller than the viewership for last week's presidential debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton. According to Nielsen, approximately 37 million Americans watched the debate, a decline from the 84 million viewers who tuned in to the previous debate. Despite being seen as a relatively tame affair, the debate between Pence and Kaine turned out to be more lively than expected. However, it is now expected to be the lowest-rated vice-presidential debate since Dick Cheney and Joseph Lieberman faced off in 2000.

A recent experiment suggests that apes may be able to read human minds. Researchers from Kyoto University and Duke University conducted a study in which chimpanzees, bonobos, and orangutans were shown a video of an actor and a person dressed as King Kong hiding an object under several boxes. The actor then left, and King Kong ran off with the object. When the actor returned, the researchers tracked the apes' gaze to see where they would look. The results showed that the apes accurately predicted the actor's next move, expecting him to head to the last place he had seen the object. Despite knowing the object was no longer there, the apes seemed to understand that the actor would believe it was, and they appeared to be aware of the actor's false belief. In essence, the apes knew what the actor believed, and they knew that belief was incorrect.

The New York Times Company is adapting to the digital era by shifting its focus to lifestyle journalism, with online products such as Cooking, Watching, and Well. The company has now made another strategic move into service journalism with the acquisition of The Wirecutter, a product recommendation website, and its sister site, The Sweethome. The all-cash deal, worth over $30 million, was completed on Monday. According to a source familiar with the acquisition, who spoke on condition of anonymity, the deal is worth slightly more than $30 million. Mark Thompson, CEO of The New York Times Company, said in a statement, "The Wirecutter and The Sweethome's practical approach to product recommendations aligns with our newsroom's values and standards. Their guides, which focus on helping readers make informed purchasing decisions, are in line with our goal of creating products that are essential to our readers' daily lives." Founded in 2011 by technology journalist Brian Lam, a former editor of Gizmodo, The Wirecutter provides recommendations for gadgets and electronics, such as TVs and headphones. The Sweethome, which focuses on home products, was also part of the acquisition. The Wirecutter was initially published as part of The Awl network, founded by Choire Sicha and Alex Balk, both former Gawker Media employees, with the goal of providing in-depth product reviews rather than frequent updates.

Jann S. Wenner, the founder and owner of Rolling Stone, defended the magazine in a libel trial in federal court in Charlottesville, Virginia, saying that the publication was wrong to fully retract a discredited 2014 article about a gang rape at the University of Virginia. According to Wenner, much of the material in the article was accurate, and he argued that the magazine had followed the highest standards of journalism in investigating the allegations. Wenner claimed that the magazine did not confront the accused rapists, but instead focused on verifying the account of the woman at the center of the article, known as Jackie. He attributed some of the blame to Jackie, whose story began to unravel shortly after the article's publication two years ago. Wenner said that journalists are powerless to stop individuals who are determined to commit fraud, and he disagreed with the decision to retract the entire article in response to a critical report by The Columbia Journalism Review in 2015. While Wenner acknowledged that the magazine had retracted the specific allegations made by Jackie, he believed that the bulk of the article, which detailed ways to improve the University of Virginia's handling of sexual assault cases, was still valid.

After graduating, Christopher Gray's first job title was Chief Executive Officer. Growing up as the son of a single mother who lost her job during the recession, Gray knew he would need significant financial aid to fund his college education. After a seven-month long and arduous search for scholarships, Gray successfully raised $1.3 million by applying for and reusing essays on leadership and community service, while also avoiding scams. During his time as a student at Drexel University in Philadelphia, Gray turned his experience into a social enterprise, developing an app called Scholly that matches students with personalized lists of scholarships. Scholly quickly rose to the top of the iOS App Store after Gray pitched it on "Shark Tank." In just three years, Scholly has been downloaded over a million times and has helped students secure more than $50 million in scholarships. Now 25, Gray has been recognized as one of Forbes's "30 Under 30" and Oprah Winfrey's "SuperSoul 100." As someone from Birmingham, Alabama, Gray initially felt the need to leave his hometown to pursue a career in technology entrepreneurship. He wanted to break the cycle of poverty and create a better life for his younger brother and sister, who were 4 and 2 years old when he started college. Gray's success has been both surreal and emotional, as he has been able to achieve his goal of helping a large number of people. Initially, Gray's goal was not to become a billionaire, but rather to make a positive impact on his community. It was only when he realized the vast market for scholarships that he understood the potential for Scholly to become a successful business. During his time at Drexel, Gray was surrounded by students from diverse backgrounds, including those from affluent families who still required financial assistance to fund their education.

The iconic song "We Shall Overcome" may be heading to court, as a lawsuit challenges the validity of its copyright. The song, which has become a powerful symbol of the civil rights movement and has recently been revived at vigils across the country in response to gun violence, is at the center of a copyright dispute. This case joins others, such as the suits over "Happy Birthday to You" and Woody Guthrie's "This Land Is Your Land," in highlighting the ongoing struggle to balance the protection of intellectual property with public access to famous songs whose origins may be unclear. For "We Shall Overcome" and "This Land," the issue is particularly charged, as the songs are being used by protesters and activists on multiple sides of major issues. The lawsuit, filed in April by the We Shall Overcome Foundation and later joined by the producers of the 2013 film "Lee Daniels' The Butler," argues that the song, which originated from a 19th-century black spiritual and may have roots even further back, should be declared part of the public domain.

The State of New Jersey warns against consuming fish and shellfish from the Lower Passaic River and Newark Bay due to their exposure to toxic pollutants. The Diamond Alkali Superfund Site, where chemicals like DDT and Agent Orange were once manufactured, has contaminated the surrounding waterways, allowing toxic substances to seep into the bodies of aquatic animals. Miraculously, some of these animals have survived, including the Atlantic killifish, a small, silver fish that has adapted to thrive in this toxic environment. According to a recent study published in Science, the killifish's ability to survive in polluted waters is a remarkable example of evolution in action. Researchers first discovered the fish's tolerance to toxic waters in the late 1990s, and since then, they have found that distinct populations of killifish have independently developed similar genetic adaptations to survive in highly polluted areas along the Atlantic coastline. The new study reveals that evolution can occur independently in different populations, and that similar genetic changes can emerge in response to extreme environments. According to Diane Nacci, a biologist at the Environmental Protection Agency, the study provides a valuable example of how animals can adapt to rapidly changing environments. The researchers, led by Noah Reid, an evolutionary geneticist at the University of Connecticut, compared the genomes of 384 killifish from polluted and less-polluted areas, finding that a single genetic pathway was responsible for the pollution tolerance in all regions, although with slightly different patterns of genetic changes in each population.

As the winter chill sets in, it's a great time to imagine experiencing the thrilling phenomenon of diving with sardines in the Philippines. To do so, simply book a trip with one of the many local dive shops and get ready for an unforgettable adventure. The boat will take you just a few yards from the beach, and from there, you'll dive in and swim down a few feet to witness the breathtaking sight of "fish clouds" above you. For the best view, consider heading out early, but don't worry if you can't make it soon - the sardines are present every day. Unlike the famous sardines that migrate to South Africa's coastal waters by the billions during the summer, the Philippine sardines are a year-round attraction. The sardines' unique schooling behavior, known as a "bait ball," is thought to confuse predators and help the fish survive. However, it's not a foolproof strategy, as evidenced by a 2010 video captured by conservation biologist Simon Oliver, who observed a thresher shark using its long, sickle-shaped tail to stun and devour the sardines. The sardines' presence near Cebu's beaches remains somewhat of a mystery, as they were previously unknown in the area until recent years. According to Dr. Oliver, the science on the populations of these fish is lacking, and it's unclear why they've emerged in such numbers. While the sardines may not be permanent residents, Dr. Oliver believes they've found a niche in the area, much like any other species that adapts to its environment. It's possible that a small number of eggs drifted into the waters around Cebu and were able to thrive due to the presence of few predators, an abundance of plankton, and ideal water temperatures. The sardines seem to migrate between locations, such as between Pescador Island and the shores of Moalboal. If this favorable setup were to change, they may disappear for good.

Warner Bros. is bucking the trend of leadership changes in Hollywood, which often occur when profits are low. In contrast, Warner is on track to have one of its most profitable years ever, according to financial reports. The studio, which has consistently been one of the top two in the industry in terms of domestic ticket sales, has just released "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them" to massive success. So far this year, Warner has a market share of 18%, trailing only Walt Disney Studios, which has a 24% share, according to Box Office Mojo. While Warner has had some successful films, such as "Fantastic Beasts," "Mad Max: Fury Road," and "The Lego Movie," it has also produced a number of critically panned movies, including "Pan," "Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice," and "Suicide Squad." Warner's CEO, Kevin Tsujihara, has been patient with the studio's struggles, but recently reduced the role of Warner's former president, Toby Emmerich, in superhero film production, giving oversight to Jon Berg and Geoff Johns instead. The pipeline of upcoming films left behind by Emmerich includes potential hits like "The Lego Batman Movie," "King Arthur: Legend of the Sword," and "Ready Player One." Emmerich's departure has been expected, as he has been looking to pursue new opportunities and has told colleagues that he wants to focus on his entrepreneurial ventures. Meanwhile, Emmerich's New Line division has had a string of successes, including "The Conjuring 2," "Lights Out," "Central Intelligence," and "Creed." "Mr. Emmerich oversaw the production of Warner's high-profile 'Hobbit' film series."

Dr. Tarduno and his team recently published their research in the journal Scientific Reports. Despite the uncertainty surrounding the Cretaceous period, Dr. Tarduno suggests that the prevailing theory is that the Earth's atmosphere was filled with heat-trapping carbon dioxide, likely the result of intense volcanic activity. This greenhouse effect would have transformed the polar ecosystem, allowing species like Tingmiatornis arctica and its prey to thrive. The Turonian age, a period of intense warming, is believed to have occurred between 93.9 million and 89.8 million years ago. During this time, the Arctic is estimated to have reached temperatures of around 57 degrees Fahrenheit at its coldest. Dr. Tarduno, who has spent time exploring the snow-capped hills and glaciers of Nunavut, has discovered two wing bones belonging to Tingmiatornis arctica. He initially found the first humerus in 1999, which was relatively small and didn't raise much interest. However, the discovery of a second, larger bone a few years later piqued his interest. Although the second humerus didn't initially capture his attention, Dr. Tarduno and his team were distracted by a large turtle shell found on the same rock. "We took it back to camp and realized, 'Wait a minute, there's another incredible fossil on the other side,' " Dr. Tarduno recalled.

The world of "Game of Thrones" is coming to a theater near you. Later this month, the show's iconic characters, including dragons, dire wolves, White Walkers, and power-hungry factions, will take over 150 Imax theaters across the country. To celebrate, an exclusive trailer for the upcoming season will be shown, along with the final two episodes of the previous season. This marks a historic moment, as "Game of Thrones" will be the first television series to ever appear on Imax screens. The event will run from January 23rd to 29th, and tickets will go on sale soon. This move reflects the blurring of lines between media platforms, where content can be streamed across a variety of devices, from smartphones to movie theaters. It also highlights the efforts of media companies to turn their hit shows into massive events, as drawing large audiences becomes increasingly challenging. For Imax, this is part of a broader strategy to expand its programming beyond traditional films, as the North American box office struggles with declining sales. The company has already had talks with other entertainment companies about showing other TV series and has tested technologies for screening live sports and music concerts.

A spokesperson for Jay Z and his company provided insight into his thinking, stating that the shift to streaming offers a significant opportunity for increased entertainment consumption and a chance for artists to promote their music more effectively. The strategic goal of Panther, Jay Z's company, is to expand globally and scale up Aspiro's platform, technology, and services. Jay Z's interest in Aspiro may be driven by his desire to tap into the niche market of high-fidelity digital music. Aspiro's WiMP and Tidal services, available in a few European countries and the US, respectively, offer lossless audio formats that are significantly higher in quality than those of Spotify and most other streaming services. WiMP has 512,000 paying subscribers, according to Aspiro's latest quarterly report, while Tidal has not disclosed its customer numbers, although it charges $20 per month, twice the average rate of most streaming services. The number of companies offering high-quality digital audio has increased recently, including Tidal, WiMP, Deezer's Elite version, PonoPlayer, and Sony's high-resolution Walkman, priced over $1,000. However, analysts note that consumers have shown little interest in these products. For Jay Z, another potential motivation for buying a streaming service may be to expand the media portfolio of Roc Nation, which began as a music-focused joint venture with Live Nation Entertainment in 2008 and has since expanded to represent top athletes.

The Super Bowl XLIX advertising lesson is clear: ads featuring puppies continue to be a hit with viewers, while ads dealing with sensitive topics like a dead child are met with criticism. Budweiser took the lead in Super Bowl advertising with a heartwarming spot that showed its iconic Clydesdale horses rescuing a lost puppy and taking it home. The ad quickly racked up over 4.2 million online views by Monday morning and accounted for 12% of online activity surrounding the Super Bowl ads, according to measurement firm iSpot.tv. Budweiser's social media presence was also boosted, with over 234,000 mentions on social media, 45% of which were positive, according to Amobee. In stark contrast, Nationwide's much-talked-about commercial featuring a young boy who dies in a preventable accident was met with widespread criticism. The ad sparked over 238,000 social media mentions, with 64% of comments being negative, according to Amobee. Nationwide defended the ad, stating that its purpose was to start a conversation about safety and well-being, not to sell insurance. Another standout ad was Procter & Gamble's Always commercial, which asked what it means to "do something like a girl." The ad highlighted how girls often lose confidence after puberty and showed little girls answering the question with confidence and strength, while older children and adults answered with weakness. The Always spot captured 8.6% of online activity and 1.6 million viewers, according to iSpot.tv. NBC aired 48 minutes of commercials during Sunday's game, according to Kantar Media, with approximately seven minutes dedicated to promoting the network's own programming. The game featured ads from 15 first-time Super Bowl advertisers. Amobee awarded Skittles the "Rookie of the Year" title, as the brand generated over 85,000 social media mentions, more than triple the amount of some other newcomers. The brand's humorous commercial also received a boost when Seattle Seahawks running back Marshawn Lynch was spotted eating the rainbow-colored candy just before the game started.

The New School is taking a comprehensive approach to addressing climate change, which can involve seemingly small actions like streamlining clothing production to minimize waste and transportation, or designing urban environments that are more resilient to extreme weather events, according to the institution. The school will conduct an internal assessment to identify ways to reduce its carbon footprint, cut energy costs, and minimize paper usage and waste. Additionally, it plans to promote sustainable food services by partnering with local suppliers in the Hudson Valley. The school has collaborated with environmental activist Bill McKibben on its initiative. According to Tokumbo Shobowale, the New School's chief operating officer, climate change is a complex problem that requires a multifaceted approach. By incorporating climate change into the curriculum across all disciplines, the school aims to go beyond divestment, which initially received skepticism from some faculty members. "Many people thought this wouldn't make a significant impact on companies or their ability to explore oil and gas," Shobowale said about the divestment plan. However, he noted that divestment can serve as a teaching tool, as economics students are analyzing the practices of companies in the school's $340 million endowment to develop principles that add nuance to their investment decisions.

Richard Meryman, a former writer and editor at Life magazine, died on February 5 in Manhattan at the age of 88. His wife, Elizabeth, confirmed that the cause of death was pneumonia. Meryman's career was marked by a range of notable achievements, including his intimate portrait of reclusive artist Andrew Wyeth, his collaboration with Joan Rivers on a memoir about her quest for stardom, and his own wrenching emotional journey after the death of his first wife.

Meryman's entry into journalism was sparked by an adventure story he shared at his first job interview with Life magazine in 1949. At the time, he had just returned from a cross-country trip with two college friends, including future Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. The trip, which began in a 1935 Packard hearse, was derailed by a broken axle and ended with the trio hopping freight trains back home.

Meryman went on to become Life magazine's first human affairs editor, writing profiles of extraordinary people in everyday life. His subjects included a struggling family on Chicago's South Side and a single mother giving up her baby for adoption. Although the magazine's initial focus was on photojournalism, Meryman was one of the first writers to use a tape recorder, conducting interviews with notable figures such as Ingmar Bergman, Charlie Chaplin, Marilyn Horne, Paul McCartney, Laurence Olivier, and Elizabeth Taylor.

Meryman's most famous interview was with Marilyn Monroe, which appeared in Life magazine on August 3, 1962, just two days before her death at the age of 36. The eight-hour conversation, which took place at Monroe's home in Brentwood, California, was recorded on tape and later became the basis for the 1992 HBO program "Marilyn: The Last Interview."

E! has agreed to pay a significant amount to continue airing the popular reality show "Keeping Up With the Kardashians" for an additional three years. According to sources, the cable network has reached a deal with the Kardashian family to extend the show's run, although the exact terms of the agreement have not been disclosed. The New York Post reported that the deal would be worth over $100 million and span four years, but a spokesperson for NBCUniversal Cable has denied this claim, calling it "grossly inaccurate". Despite this, industry executives believe that the Kardashian family's negotiating power will likely result in a substantial paycheck, given their popularity and influence. Notably, E!'s prime-time ratings for the 18-49 age demographic declined by 10% in 2014, averaging 386,000 viewers per year, according to Nielsen data.
