When Mr. Pizzolo posted his comic series "Godkiller" on YouTube, he was surprised to discover a large and untapped audience. The series, which follows siblings in a post-apocalyptic world, gained 100,000 views without any promotional efforts. After being released on Netflix, Hulu, and PlayStation, it attracted tens of thousands more viewers. According to Mr. Pizzolo, it's essential to not only cater to the core comic book fanbase but also to introduce new people to the medium. The inaugural series on the YouTube channel will feature a mix of comics from Black Mask and other independent publishers, including "Liberator," which focuses on animal welfare activists, and "Five Ghosts," which follows an adventurer possessed by literary characters. The channel will include links to purchase the comics and related merchandise.

Black Mask Studios was founded in 2012 by Mr. Pizzolo, a filmmaker, Steve Niles, a writer of horror novels and comics, and Brett Gurewitz, a musician and founder of Epitaph Records. The company was born out of "Occupy Comics," a project aimed at raising funds for the Occupy Wall Street movement. This experience highlighted the challenges of publishing comics with a message. With the upcoming release of the animated version of "Godkiller" and "Liberator," Black Mask will have a broader platform to share its message. Before the International Comic Con in July, the company will release the first part of the animated "Godkiller." Kirkus Reviews has praised the comic's first volume, describing it as "wickedly delectable" and "an experience rather than a story." Black Mask is also developing three comic-based TV series: "Sinatoro," "The Disciples," and "Ballistic." Despite its small size, with only a handful of employees and freelancers, the company remains committed to its mission. "We leverage the existing infrastructure of my film company and Brett's various companies to support Black Mask," said Mr. Pizzolo. "As a company, Black Mask operates like a startup, with a scrappy and entrepreneurial spirit." One of the key differentiators for Black Mask is the active involvement of the founders in adaptations, including those for animation and television. As executive producers, we ensure that the creators of the comics are also involved throughout the process. "Historically, film and TV executives would often use comic books as a starting point and then depart from the original material," Mr. Pizzolo explained. "Now, we're seeing a trend towards more faithful adaptations, which is a direct result of our hands-on approach."

Jay Z has officially acquired an online streaming company that competes with Spotify and Apple. On Friday, the investment vehicle used by the rapper to make a $56 million bid for Aspiro, a Swedish technology company, announced that it had acquired enough shares to take over the company. Aspiro, a publicly traded company in Sweden, operates subscription streaming services under the brands WiMP and Tidal, which entered the US market last fall. Jay Z, whose real name is Shawn Carter, made his offer for Aspiro in late January through an entity he controls, Project Panther Bidco. Aspiro shareholders had until Wednesday to consider the offer, which required 90 percent approval for Project Panther to take over. The acquisition is now unconditional, and Project Panther will complete the purchase of the tendered shares, according to a statement. As a result, Aspiro will be delisted from the Nasdaq Stockholm stock exchange. While Jay Z has not revealed further plans for Aspiro, his interest in the company may be related to its high-definition audio capabilities.

It's been nearly 50 years since Dustin Hoffman's character was given the iconic "one word" advice about the future in "The Graduate". Perhaps it's time to revisit the script and update it for the modern era. Similarly, metamaterials have the potential to revolutionize entire industries. Over the past 15 years, scientists have made significant progress in creating materials that can manipulate light, radar, radio, sound, and seismic waves in ways that defy nature. The concept of metamaterials was first proposed by Russian physicist Victor Veselago in 1967 and later developed by physicist David R. Smith and his team in 1999. Initially, it was seen as a curiosity with potential applications in science fiction, such as invisibility cloaks. However, researchers have since gained a deeper understanding of the science and are now driving innovation in various fields, including radio antennas, radar, cosmetics, soundproofing, and earthquake-resistant construction. Most recently, aircraft manufacturer Airbus partnered with Canadian company Lamda Guard to test a metamaterial-based coating for cockpit windows, designed to protect pilots from laser pointer attacks.

HarperCollins unveiled the cover for Harper Lee's highly anticipated new novel, "Go Set a Watchman", on Wednesday, providing a glimpse into the book's themes and story. The cover art, a poignant image of a dark tree with sparse yellow leaves against a dusky blue sky, features a train approaching from the distance, mirroring the opening scene of the novel, which follows a grown-up Scout's train ride from New York to her childhood home in Maycomb, Alabama. The novel, set to be released on July 14 with a first printing of two million copies, has generated significant buzz, with preorders selling briskly through Amazon and Barnes & Noble since its announcement in early February. The book's release has also sparked controversy among literary scholars and those close to the reclusive author, with some questioning why Lee agreed to publish a novel she had set aside in the 1950s, while others claim she has enthusiastically endorsed the book's release. Set in the 1950s, 20 years after the events of "To Kill a Mockingbird", "Go Set a Watchman" follows Scout as she travels to Maycomb to visit her aging father, Atticus Finch. While the characters and setting may be familiar to fans of "To Kill a Mockingbird", the two novels have little overlap, according to Lee's publisher and literary agent. The cover, designed by Jarrod Taylor in the Harper Art Department at HarperCollins, reflects Scout's journey home, according to Michael Morrison, president and publisher of HarperCollins.

Jeremy Clarkson's time with the BBC has come to an end. The popular host of the entertainment show "Top Gear", which is centered around cars and British masculinity, will not have his contract renewed when it expires at the end of March, according to the BBC. This decision follows an incident in which Clarkson, 54, allegedly verbally and physically attacked a BBC producer, Oisin Tymon, after returning to a Yorkshire hotel following a late-night drinking session to find that there was no hot food available. Tymon received medical treatment for his injuries but has declined to press charges against Clarkson. After the BBC learned of the incident, which it initially described as a "fracas", Clarkson was suspended on March 10, leading to the postponement of the last three episodes of the current season of "Top Gear".

I gazed at the card, struggling to comprehend how this was even possible. Hadn't I signed up for a different deal? I must have agreed to a lower rate. It was 2000, and I was 24, earning less than $30,000 a year. The American Airlines Citibank Card was my first ever, and I was thrilled to have it. The card was sleek and silver, adorned with the old airline logo at the top. The marketing slogans echoed in my mind: "Get miles!" "Live like others in New York!" "Welcome, kid." The card seemed to foreshadow the financial journey ahead. However, I couldn't recall the credit limit; all I remembered was what I'd bought. I'd splurged on a stunning gold, strapless Nicole Miller dress for a glamorous friend's sister's wedding. I'd also purchased gold sandals and a filmy wrap to wear around my shoulders. To complete the look, I'd gotten a haircut inspired by Meg Ryan's character in "You've Got Mail." The total cost was around $1,000, far exceeding the budget my stepfather had helped me create (which I promptly ignored). Instead, I learned a valuable lesson about debt, confidence, and identity that still resonates with me to this day. Growing up, I was privileged. I attended Sidwell Friends, a prestigious private Quaker school in Washington, and later Williams College in Massachusetts, where my family covered the tuition. As a result, I was financially sheltered, as I didn't need to understand the intricacies of money. My parents allowed me to focus on academics and personal growth, and I was grateful for that.

HBO, a leading premium entertainment network, is deepening its partnership with Vice, a pioneering media company and news organization. The company announced on Thursday that it will air a daily half-hour Vice news program, which will run five days a week for 48 weeks per year. According to Richard Plepler, HBO's CEO, the newscast is set to debut this year. For Vice, which already produces a newsmagazine show for HBO, this deal marks a significant strengthening of its relationship with a respected and successful media brand, a partnership that earned Vice an Emmy award last year. In return, HBO will gain a substantial amount of new programming as it prepares to launch its standalone streaming service, HBO Now. "This is one of our largest investments in terms of airtime," said Michael Lombardo, HBO's president of programming. "I've been with HBO for a long time, and I can't think of another producer we've worked with who will have this much presence on our network."

A new study has discovered that Little Foot, an ancient hominid, may have coexisted with Lucy, another well-known human ancestor, around the same time period. The research, published in Nature, reveals that early hominids may have been more diverse than previously thought. Discovered in a South African cave in the early 1990s, Little Foot was initially estimated to be around 4 million years old, but subsequent estimates based on mineral analysis suggested a younger age of approximately 2.2 million years. For years, scientists were unable to agree on a precise age for Little Foot. However, an international team of researchers has now used a dating technique that measures aluminum and beryllium levels in the rock layer containing the fossil to conclude that Little Foot is approximately 3.67 million years old, about half a million years older than Lucy.

Davidson College students have a unique perk - their dirty laundry is washed, folded, and pressed for them, free of charge. This benefit has been a staple of the liberal arts school, located near Charlotte, North Carolina, for an impressive 95 years. The service was originally introduced in 1920, when the all-male student body was expected to dress formally, complete with dress pants, starched collars, and ties. According to Jan Blodgett, the college archivist, the laundry service has been a beloved tradition ever since. However, come next month, this perk will come to an end. While freshmen students appreciate the convenience, only about a third of seniors continue to take advantage of the service. The college attributes this decline to the abundance of laundry machines available on campus, which are also free to use. By discontinuing the laundry service, the college expects to save around $400,000 per year, which it plans to redirect towards educational initiatives.

James Oseland, former editor-in-chief of Saveur, had dinner with Maria Rodale, CEO of Rodale, at ABC Kitchen near Union Square. It was there that they encountered Alice Waters, a renowned chef and advocate for sustainable food. "I felt it was a remarkable sign," Oseland recalled during an interview at Rodale's Midtown Manhattan office last week. Rodale remembered Oseland exclaiming that it was "like receiving a blessing from the pope." Nearly eight months after Oseland's surprise departure from Saveur to join Rodale, the publisher is launching a new magazine, Organic Life. This rebranded publication, formerly Rodale's Organic Gardening, will focus on the organic lifestyle, encompassing food, wellness, and home, rather than just soil and plants. "The past five to 10 years have seen a significant shift, and yet there was no single, comprehensive media brand catering to the growing demand for this type of content," Oseland noted. "Organic Gardening was a beloved brand, and our goal is to build upon its success and make it even more comprehensive."

Celebrity talk show host Dr. Mehmet Oz is expected to respond strongly to criticism from doctors who have questioned his medical advice and his faculty position at Columbia University, according to a show spokesperson. Last week, 10 physicians sent an email to the university, accusing Dr. Oz, vice chairman of Columbia's surgery department, of lacking integrity by promoting unproven treatments and cures for personal gain. The doctors specifically targeted Dr. Oz's opposition to genetically modified food crops, which they deemed baseless and relentless. Dr. Oz will address the criticism on his syndicated daytime talk show, "The Dr. Oz Show," on Thursday, when he will question the credibility of the letter's authors, some of whom have ties to a pro-industry advocacy group that supports genetically modified foods. He will also reiterate his stance that genetically modified foods should be labeled, a position he has repeatedly expressed on his show. The segment is expected to be longer than usual, taking up a significant portion of the 60-minute program.

Richard Corliss, a renowned film critic who wrote for Time magazine for 35 years, passed away on Thursday in Manhattan at the age of 71. His wife, Mary, attributed his death to complications from a stroke, which he had been receiving hospice care for. Corliss was a prolific contributor to Time, penning profiles, essays on popular culture, and reviews of television and theater productions.

A self-proclaimed movie enthusiast who believed that every film was worth watching, Corliss would often say, "Everything is worth seeing." However, he was not afraid to take a contrarian view as a critic, and his reviews were not always glowing. He was particularly critical of films like Robert Altman's "M*A*S*H," James Cameron's "Titanic," Richard Attenborough's "A Chorus Line," and the British comedy "The Full Monty," which he deemed formulaic and emotionally manipulative. In his review of "Titanic," Corliss praised the film's special effects but panned its storytelling, and he famously predicted that the film would be a commercial failure, calling it "dead in the water."

Thomas R. Shepard Jr., the last publisher of Look magazine, has died at the age of 96 in Sarasota, Florida, on April 29. His son, Rocky, confirmed the cause of death as pneumonia. As publisher from 1965, Shepard oversaw the magazine's rapid decline from its peak, marked by record advertising revenue and circulation, to its eventual demise. A salesman with unwavering enthusiasm, Shepard was appointed publisher during the heyday of mass-circulation magazines, characterized by newsstand sales, lavish photography, and captivating articles. However, the rise of television and crippling postal rate increases soon took their toll, eroding profit margins and ultimately contributing to the magazine's downfall. By the late 1960s, Look, Life, and The Saturday Evening Post were struggling to remain relevant, with Look and The Post publishing biweekly issues. Despite being considered an also-ran to Life, Look was briefly the top-selling magazine, with a circulation of 8.5 million copies, before Life's dominance lasted for nearly four decades under the ownership of Henry Luce, who acquired the magazine in 1936 and transformed it into an all-photographic newsmagazine.

A recently discovered horned dinosaur, characterized by its unusual ornamentation, has been found to be a close relative of Triceratops. The dinosaur's nose horn was longer than that of Triceratops, and it had two small horns situated above its eyes. However, its most striking feature was a radiating frill, comprising large, pentagonal plates resembling a crown, situated atop its head. Researchers at the Royal Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology in Canada have named their discovery Regaliceratops peterhewsi. The team initially stumbled upon the fossilized remains protruding from a cliff along the Oldman River in southeastern Alberta about a decade ago. Like other horned dinosaurs, Regaliceratops likely evolved during the late Cretaceous period, which spanned from 65 million to 100 million years ago. The nearly complete skull of Regaliceratops has been described in the latest issue of the journal Current Biology.

The United States Fish and Wildlife Service announced on Friday that all chimpanzees will be classified as endangered under the Endangered Species Act. This decision follows a 2010 petition filed by Jane Goodall, The Humane Society of the United States, and other organizations to eliminate the distinction between captive and wild chimpanzees. Under the new classification, chimpanzees in captivity in the US will receive the same protections as their wild counterparts. The new regulations require permits for biomedical research, interstate trade, and the export and import of captive chimpanzees, issued by the Fish and Wildlife Service. The changes will take effect on September 14, after a 90-day grace period that begins on June 16. However, the regulations do not require permits for private ownership or use of chimpanzees in the entertainment industry, according to Dan Ashe, director of the US Fish and Wildlife Service. Ashe explained that the previous distinction sent a mixed message to the public, implying that chimpanzees were not in urgent need of conservation efforts.

To get the most value from their travel dollars, older Americans can follow these expert tips:

# Identify your top travel destinations and estimate your annual budget. As Anne Scully, president of McCabe World Travel, advises, "Decide where you want to spend your money and tackle the most challenging trip first." # Calculate the total cost of your trip before you leave, including all expenses, such as hotel fees and departure taxes. According to Scully, "Look at the final price" to ensure you're getting the best deal. Cruises and all-inclusive trips can simplify the process by providing a clear, upfront cost. # Take advantage of loyalty programs, two-for-one offers, and last-minute discounts, which may be more accessible to retirees than those with full-time employment. # Consider home exchanges, a cost-effective option that allows you to swap homes with another family without exchanging money. John Adams, a retired publisher, and his wife, Martha, have been using home exchanges since 2013. As Adams explains, "No money changes hands, and they'll take care of my house just as I'll take care of theirs." Some popular home exchange websites include www.myplaceforyours.com, www.homeexchange.com, and www.homeforexchange.com.

Campus-affiliated accounts can come with hidden fees that can quickly add up if students aren't mindful of their account usage. For instance, some campus debit cards charge extra fees when students use their PINs to make purchases, whereas traditional checking accounts typically don't. Additionally, some accounts may charge steep overdraft fees for debit transactions, as reported by the Center for Responsible Lending in a recent study. To avoid these fees, it's crucial for students to carefully review the terms of their account and use it in a way that minimizes expenses, advises Meredith Turner, chief governmental officer with the California State Student Association. "Always read the fine print," she emphasizes. While adjusting to campus life can be overwhelming, students should take a few minutes to familiarize themselves with their bank accounts' rules. "Take the time to set yourself up for financial success while in school," Turner suggests.

To avoid an account with excessive fees, students should ideally consider their financial aid options and manage their personal funds before arriving on campus, Turner advises. "If you already have a bank account, have your financial aid directly deposited into it," she recommends. According to estimates from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, more than half of new college students already have a bank account.

The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science has been awarded to the following laureates:

In 2004, Finn E. Kydland and Edward C. Prescott were recognized for their significant contributions to dynamic macroeconomics, particularly in the areas of time consistency in economic policy and the driving forces behind business cycles.

In 2002, Daniel Kahneman was honored for his groundbreaking work in integrating insights from psychological research into economic science, with a focus on human judgment and decision-making under uncertainty. Vernon L. Smith was also awarded the prize for establishing laboratory experiments as a valuable tool in empirical economic analysis, particularly in the study of alternative market mechanisms.

The 2001 prize was shared by George A. Akerlof, A. Michael Spence, and Joseph E. Stiglitz, who were recognized for their influential analyses of markets with asymmetric information.

In 2000, James J. Heckman was awarded the prize for his development of theory and methods for analyzing selective samples, while Daniel L. McFadden was recognized for his work on developing theory and methods for analyzing discrete choice.

Leonid V. Kantorovich and Tjalling C. Koopmans were jointly awarded the 1975 prize for their significant contributions to the theory of optimum allocation of resources.

The 1974 prize was shared by Gunnar Myrdal and Friedrich August von Hayek, who were recognized for their pioneering work in the theory of money and economic fluctuations, as well as their insightful analysis of the interdependence of economic, social, and institutional phenomena.

Wassily Leontief was awarded the 1972 prize for his development of the input-output method and its application to important economic problems.

John R. Hicks and Kenneth J. Arrow were jointly awarded the 1971 prize for their pioneering contributions to general economic equilibrium theory and welfare theory.

Simon Kuznets was awarded the 1970 prize for his empirically founded interpretation of economic growth, which has led to new and deepened insights into the economic and social structure and process of development.

Paul A. Samuelson was awarded the 1969 prize for his scientific work, which has developed static and dynamic economic theory and raised the level of analysis in economic science.

Ragnar Frisch and Jan Tinbergen were jointly awarded the 1969 prize for their development and application of dynamic models for the analysis of economic processes.

If you're ready to file your 2013 federal income tax return, you can do so starting now. Tax-filing season has officially begun, albeit later than expected, due to the delay caused by last year's government shutdown. However, taxpayers seeking help from the Internal Revenue Service may find this year particularly challenging. According to the National Taxpayer Advocate's annual report, the agency's reduced budget and staff will likely result in decreased service, significantly hampering its ability to provide top-quality assistance. In practice, this means longer wait times to have questions answered. For instance, in fiscal year 2013, the IRS received 109 million phone calls, but only 61 percent of callers reached a customer service representative, with an average wait time of nearly 18 minutes.

Mutual of Omaha declined to comment on ongoing legal matters, while John Hancock did not respond to a request for comment. According to Jesse Slome, spokesman for the American Association for Long-Term Care Insurance, women typically account for approximately two-thirds of long-term-care insurance claims paid annually. Last year, insurance companies paid out $7.5 billion in claims. As a result, women will now pay several hundred dollars more per year in long-term-care premiums compared to men, according to the association's 2014 report, which is based on data from insurers.

For a single 55-year-old man in good health buying a new policy, the average annual premium for a policy providing $164,000 in current benefits without inflation protection would be $925. In contrast, a woman of the same age and health would pay an average of $1,225 per year for the same policy, a difference of $300 or more than 30 percent. The difference in premiums is even greater if you opt for a policy that builds in 3% annual inflation protection, compounded annually. For this option, a 55-year-old healthy man would pay $1,765 per year, while a woman would pay $2,307.

The association found that a typical single woman will pay an average of 12% more than in 2013. The impact of gender pricing on couples who buy a policy together varies by insurer, with some companies pricing policies based on their rates for single men or women, while others offer a blended couples rate. Genworth noted that its gender-specific pricing only applies to single policies. Insurers typically offer significant couples discounts, and the average premium for couples with inflation protection has risen by about 3% from last year. When considering long-term care insurance, it's essential to explore ways to secure the lowest premium possible. According to Mr. Slome, consumers should shop around as premiums for similar coverage can differ significantly among insurance providers. Insurance broker Rose Clayton of Orange County, California, recommends that women keep the additional premium cost in perspective. While clients may initially be disappointed to learn that women pay a higher premium, Clayton notes that it's not a deal-breaker. Instead, it serves as a reminder to plan for their golden years. As Clayton pointed out, a visit to a nursing home or assisted living facility can starkly illustrate the impact of women's longer lifespan.

A federal appeals court handed a victory to banks and the Federal Reserve on Friday, overturning a lower court's decision. As a result, the amount banks can collect from retailers when consumers use debit cards will remain unchanged. For consumers, this means that for now, there won't be any significant changes. According to Adam Levitin, a professor of financial regulation and consumer protection at Georgetown Law, consumers shouldn't expect their fees to increase or their rewards to decrease. As part of the financial regulatory overhaul following the economic crisis, Congress aimed to cap the fees banks can charge retailers for debit card transactions. However, they left it to the Federal Reserve to write the rules. The Fed ultimately reduced the fees to 21 cents per transaction, starting October 1, 2011, down from an average of 44 cents. On Friday, the US Appeals Court for the District of Columbia overturned a district court judge's July ruling, which had favored retailers. The original rule had been challenged by retailers, who argued that the Fed had been too generous to banks. If the July ruling had stood, experts said, it was possible that swipe fees could have been reduced further.

As July arrives, many people look forward to warm weather activities like swimming, hiking, and enjoying watermelon. However, for couples who both work and have school-age children, summer can be a stressful time of juggling schedules and finding affordable childcare until the school year resumes. According to Pew Research Center, a staggering 60% of two-parent households with children under 18 feature both parents in the workforce. For these families, the traditional 10-week summer break is no relaxing vacation. As Ellen Galinsky, president of the Families and Work Institute, notes, "Summer is really tough because we often have these fantasies of summer as it's supposed to be: enjoying ice cream, watching the sunset, and spending quality time at home. But it's not that way." Not everyone has access to nearby family members who can provide childcare or the budget for a full-time nanny. As a result, many families rely on summer day camps. In fact, the number of summer day camps has increased by 40% over the past four years, according to the American Camp Association, which accredits both overnight and day camps.

US Secretary of Education Arne Duncan recently announced that states can delay using test results in teacher-performance ratings for another year, acknowledging the immense pressure on teachers due to new academic standards and rigorous standardized testing. In a blog post, Duncan wrote that testing issues are "sucking the oxygen out of the room" in many schools, and emphasized the need for teachers to adapt to new standards and tests that focus on more than just multiple-choice answers. Over the past four years, nearly 40 states have passed laws linking teacher evaluations to student performance on standardized tests, with many districts planning to use these evaluations to determine tenure, promotions, and firings. These laws were a condition of Education Department waivers from the No Child Left Behind law, which governs how states receive federal education funding. The test-based teacher evaluations were also a requirement for Race to the Top grants awarded by the Obama administration. Many teachers and parents argue that these laws force educators to narrow their curricula and spend too much time on test preparation. Meanwhile, schools are scrambling to adjust their curricula to align with the Common Core, new academic guidelines for math and reading from kindergarten to high school graduation. Adopted by over 40 states, the Common Core standards have become increasingly controversial.

2. The University of Tulsa Golden Hurricane, the University of Miami Hurricanes, and the Iowa State Cyclones are three examples of institutions with Native American-inspired mascots. 3. Texas A&M, New Mexico State, and Utah State, all land-grant universities, pay homage to their agricultural heritage through their mascots. 4. Central Michigan University, formerly known as the Chippewas, and the University of Illinois, formerly known as the Fighting Illini, have modified their mascots while retaining their tribal names. Florida State University, with its Seminole mascot, and the University of Utah, with its Ute mascot, have maintained both their names and mascots with the approval of their respective Native American tribes. All four institutions have been removed from the NCAA's list of schools with "hostile and abusive" Native American mascots. Even so, when Chief Osceola rides into Florida State University's Doak Campbell Stadium, planting a spear in the ground, fans often chant "scalp 'em." 5. Georgia Tech fans, dressed in school colors, suggested the team's name, the Yellow Jackets, and its mascot, Buzz, as well as its secondary mascot, a 1930 Ford Model A Sport coupe. The Ramblin' Wreck tradition originated from a yearly auto race that began in 1929 and eventually evolved into a parade of makeshift mechanical buggies. 6. In 1927, the University of Akron held a contest to find a team name and awarded $10 to the winner, who submitted the name "Zippers" – a reference to a pair of rubber galoshes made by B.F. Goodrich of Akron. The team name was later changed to the Zips in 1950, and three years later, the mascot, Zippy the kangaroo, was chosen for its speed, agility, and power. Zippy is unique among mascots, as she is a female.

The US Department of Education is investigating allegations that plans to close or reorganize public schools in Philadelphia, Detroit, and Newark disproportionately affect black and Hispanic students, as well as those with disabilities, a department official confirmed on Monday. Community activists from these cities, along with 15 others, will meet with Education Secretary Arne Duncan on Tuesday to urge a temporary halt to school-closing plans until alternative solutions can be found. Jitu Brown, a community organizer from Chicago's South Side, said the group will demand immediate action on the civil rights complaints and push for officials to stop school closings, privatization of public schools, "phaseouts" that lead to school closures, and the combination of public and charter schools. "Racism is a reality in the US," Brown said. "There are different rules for students in our community." According to Daren Briscoe, an Education Department spokesperson, the department lacks the authority to impose a moratorium on locally mandated school closings. The department's civil rights office has never substantiated a complaint related to such a program, he added.

In Tokyo, Japan's central banker, Masaaki Shirakawa, defended the country's recent monetary policy moves, saying they are not currency manipulation and are necessary to combat deflation. The Bank of Japan's governor made the statement on Thursday, following the release of new economic figures that showed an unexpected contraction in the fourth quarter. Shirakawa emphasized that the central bank's goal is to stabilize the economy, not influence currency values. The bank decided to maintain its benchmark interest rate at zero to 0.1 percent and hold off on expanding its asset-buying program. The news came as Japan's government released gross domestic product numbers showing the economy contracted at an annualized rate of 0.4 percent in the October-to-December quarter, marking the third consecutive quarter of decline. Despite this, economists expect Japan's economy to recover later this year, driven by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's plans for fresh fiscal stimulus and continued low interest rates.

When Diana Natalicio became the first female president of the University of Texas at El Paso in 1988, a local newspaper published an illustration of her as Wonder Woman. As she begins her 26th year at the helm, a tenure that is the longest among current Texas public university presidents, this depiction remains fitting. Under her leadership, the university's budget has expanded significantly, growing from approximately $65 million to around $400 million, and research expenditures have increased from $6 million to about $76 million. The number of graduate programs offered has also risen, from just one to 19, with more in development. Total enrollment has grown from fewer than 15,000 students to around 23,000. "I think the biggest difference between then and now is our self-confidence as an institution," said Natalicio, now 73. "We used to marginalize ourselves, thinking no one would pay attention to us because we were located in the Chihuahuan Desert." This month, the TIAA-CREF Institute, a research organization for colleges and universities, awarded Natalicio the Theodore M. Hesburgh Award for Leadership Excellence, named after the former University of Notre Dame president.

"Every city council member who takes their job seriously is searching for solutions to their financial struggles," said Mr. Sweet. "However, no one wants to discuss the issue, and no one wants to take the risk. But if Calpers can be forced to take a cut in Stockton, what's to stop another city from filing for bankruptcy and reducing its pension contribution by half?"

Mr. Sweet and other public finance lawyers believe that the outcome in Stockton could serve as a guide for Detroit, which is not currently in bankruptcy but has been placed under emergency management by the state of Michigan. Calpers, a $252 billion pension fund, administers pensions for California state employees and many municipal workers. The fund calculates the annual contribution amounts, bills the cities, collects the payments, invests the funds, and distributes benefits to retirees. When Calpers' investments lose money, as they did during the stock market crash, the cities' bills increase. In 2011, Stockton paid Calpers $20 million, roughly double the amount it spent on public libraries. The city's payments to Calpers are expected to nearly double over the next decade, making Calpers Stockton's largest creditor. Stockton claims it has no choice but to continue making payments, even as it cuts costs elsewhere, including payments to bondholders. The city argues that reducing the rate at which its workers build up their pensions would lead to a mass exodus, particularly among police officers who were recruited with promises of large, early pensions. Last year, Stockton requested a "hardship exemption" from Calpers, allowing it to slow down its contributions. However, Calpers denied the request, fearing that if Stockton fell behind, it might never catch up. "They're terrified," Mr. Sweet said. "Calpers claims that if they give Stockton a haircut, the entire system will collapse." The phrase "if it happens in Stockton, it's going to happen in San Bernardino, and if it happens in San Bernardino it's going to happen in Modesto, and if it happens in Modesto it's going to happen in Bakersfield, and if it happens in Bakersfield it's going to happen in Fresno" suggests that financial troubles tend to spread throughout the region.

San Bernardino, however, did not follow the same path as Stockton. After Stockton filed for Chapter 9 bankruptcy, San Bernardino did the same, but instead of continuing to make contributions to Calpers, it stopped making them. Calpers was prepared to take legal action, but the judge handling San Bernardino's case, Meredith M. Jury, put the issue on hold, stating that she would address the matter of pension contributions later in the bankruptcy proceedings. In contrast, Stockton continued to make its pension contributions during its bankruptcy, a decision praised by Calpers' spokesperson, Amy Norris, who described it as a "right business decision."

China has signed a free-trade agreement with Iceland, its first such deal with a European country, as Beijing seeks to expand its economic influence amidst growing concerns from its trading partners. The agreement, which aims to eliminate most tariffs over the next few years, was signed in Beijing during a state visit by Icelandic Prime Minister Johanna Sigurdardottir. The two economies, with Iceland's GDP of $14 billion and China's GDP of $7.3 trillion, are vastly mismatched, with trade between the countries being relatively small, totaling $402 million in 2011. While Iceland cannot offer significant new market growth, it could help China gain more influence in the Arctic region, which is becoming increasingly accessible due to global warming and polar ice retreat. China is seeking to join the Arctic Council, an intergovernmental body promoting cooperation in the region, as a permanent observer. Iceland, a member of the European Free Trade Association and the European Economic Area, will not grant China backdoor access to the European market through this trade deal. The country had been negotiating EU membership but suspended talks in January due to domestic opposition. If Iceland were to join the EU, it would have to terminate its bilateral trade deals, according to the EU trade commissioner's spokesman. The two governments also issued a joint statement calling for cooperation on human rights, gender equality, labor issues, Arctic affairs, geothermal development, culture, education, and tourism. With the Doha Round of talks under the World Trade Organization stalled, some nations are seeking partnerships at a lower level. Currently, two significant trade agreements are being discussed, both centered around the United States. The Trans-Pacific Partnership is being negotiated between Washington and several Asia-Pacific nations, while a comprehensive trade and investment agreement is being considered with the European Union. China is not a party to either of these agreements, leading some officials and trade experts to speculate that the proposals are intended to counterbalance China's growing influence in global commerce. This development comes at a time when China's intentions towards its North Atlantic ally are under scrutiny, following the construction of a large Chinese Embassy in Reykjavik and the puzzling effort of a Chinese billionaire to build a luxury hotel and golf course in a vast Icelandic wilderness area.

Finance ministers from the world's leading economies managed to avoid a public disagreement with Japan over its currency policies, while maintaining pressure on Germany to boost economic growth in Europe. After two days of talks outside London, the Group of 7 finance ministers appeared to accept Japan's explanation that its new monetary measures were aimed at stimulating its domestic economy, rather than manipulating the yen's value on global currency markets. The UK's Chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, stated that the G-7 ministers reaffirmed their earlier commitments on exchange rates and agreed to ensure that their policies align with domestic objectives. The talks were described as in-depth and positive by other officials. Last week, the US dollar broke the 100-yen mark for the first time in over four years. The two-day meeting in Buckinghamshire also focused on combating tax evasion and banking reform, with Osborne emphasizing the importance of completing work to prevent banks from becoming too big to fail. The officials also discussed the stalled efforts to create a European banking union.

Mr. Gee, who became the first public university president to earn over $1 million in 2007, had a base salary of $830,439 in the most recent year, the highest among the 212 chief executives included in the Chronicle report. He is renowned for his exceptional fundraising abilities, which have generated over $1.6 billion for the university since he took office, as well as his luxurious lifestyle, which includes a rent-free mansion with an elevator, pool, and tennis court, and private jet travel. According to Mr. Stripling, there has been a significant shift in the past few years, with the wealthy becoming even wealthier, and some compensation packages exceeding $1 million, even $2 million. Deferred compensation agreements can greatly increase pay, as seen in the case of Mr. Gogue, whose pay jumped from $720,000 to $2.5 million in a single year when he completed his five-year contract. However, Mr. Stripling noted that the biggest growth last year was in the $600,000 to $700,000 range, which included 28 chief executives, up from 13 the previous year. The Chronicle report revealed that the median total compensation for public research university presidents was $441,392, a 4.7% increase from the previous year's $421,395. The median base salary was $373,800, a 2% increase from $366,519 the previous year.

Air traffic controllers in France have scheduled a three-day strike, starting on Tuesday, to protest the European Commission's proposal to accelerate the integration of air traffic management systems across the continent. Meanwhile, their counterparts in several other European countries are expected to take limited labor action this week. France's civil aviation authority has made contingency plans, asking airlines serving Paris, Lyon, Nice, Marseille, Toulouse, and Bordeaux airports to reduce their flight schedules by 50% from Tuesday morning to late Thursday to minimize the impact of the strikes. Unions in over a dozen countries, including Belgium, Hungary, Italy, and Portugal, are likely to participate in work-to-rule and other symbolic actions on Wednesday, which may cause limited delays, according to Koen Reynaerts, a spokesperson for the European Transport Workers' Federation. The strikes aim to coincide with a speech by European Union Transportation Commissioner Siim Kallas on Tuesday, in which he is expected to announce planned changes to European legislation to transfer air traffic management responsibilities from member states to a central body in Brussels.

The great American mortgage sale, which has been characterized by ultralow borrowing costs, appears to be coming to a close. While home loan rates are unlikely to return to traditional levels, they will likely remain modest, having encouraged millions of homeowners to refinance and contributed to the housing market's revival. As the yields on 10-year government bonds rise in response to signs of economic improvement and the Federal Reserve's plan to reduce bond purchases, mortgage rates have quickly followed. On Thursday, rates on 30-year fixed mortgages reached 4.25 percent, up from 4.12 percent the day before, after Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke hinted that the central bank may begin to ease back on stimulus efforts later this year. Just a few months ago, the average interest rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage was 3.5 percent, near a historic low. In contrast, credit card borrowing costs are already at relatively high levels, and rates on short-term loans, such as car loans and home equity loans, are tied to short-term interest rates, which the Fed has indicated will not rise before 2015. For example, the rate on a five-year car loan is currently around 4 percent, similar to its level in mid-May. Similarly, a fixed-rate home equity loan carries a rate of 6.1 percent, not far from where it was a month ago. However, the fact that the Fed is keeping the short-term bank lending rate at close to zero means that savers will not see any improvement in the low interest rates paid on savings accounts, money market accounts, and short-term certificates of deposit, which are also tied to short-term rates.

HONG KONG - The Chinese central bank has sought to alleviate investor concerns about a prolonged credit crunch, announcing that it has been providing targeted support to bank liquidity. Chinese stock markets experienced wild fluctuations for the second day in a row on Tuesday, following several days of volatility. The People's Bank of China, which is working to curb excessive lending growth and mitigate financial risks, initially held back from intervening as interbank interest rates skyrocketed last week. However, it appears to have subsequently injected more funds into the market. The uncertainty surrounding the central bank's stance led to significant trading swings on Tuesday, with the main Chinese stock indexes plummeting to their lowest levels since 2009 before largely recovering by the end of the trading day. The Shanghai composite index, which plummeted 5.3% on Monday, fell over 5% in the early afternoon on Tuesday before recovering most of its losses to close down 0.2%. The index has declined nearly 20% since reaching a peak in early February. After the markets closed, the People's Bank of China issued a statement aimed at calming investors' nerves and maintaining pressure on banks deemed to be taking on excessive risk.

Global stock markets declined and oil prices surged above $100 a barrel on Wednesday, as concerns about the political crises in Egypt and Portugal added to traders' growing unease. The situation in Egypt was at the forefront of geopolitical concerns after President Mohamed Morsi refused to step down as demanded by the army, heightening the risk of violence and chaos. According to Damian Kennaby, director of research at IHS Cambridge Energy Research Associates in London, while Egypt is not a major oil producer, the uncertainty surrounding the situation is driving up oil prices. Egypt produced an average of 728,000 barrels of oil per day last year, compared to Libya's 1.5 million barrels, according to BP figures. As a result, American crude oil for August delivery was trading at $100.72 a barrel, a 1.12% increase and its first time above $100 in nine months.

The Bank of England has decided to maintain its benchmark interest rate at 0.5%, a record low, and has not altered its economic stimulus program, which remains set at 375 billion pounds (approximately $570 billion). This decision comes as Britain's economic recovery appears to be gaining momentum, with the government reporting a 0.6% growth in the second quarter and all major industries experiencing faster growth for the first time in three years. According to James Knightley, an economist at ING, "We're starting to see some real signs of momentum building. People feel more secure in their jobs, households feel richer as house prices rise, and there's a real improvement in sentiment." Following a close call with a triple-dip recession at the beginning of the year, Britain's economy has shown signs of improvement, with increasing home values, recovering consumer sentiment, and slightly increased lending to small- and medium-sized businesses. However, some economists caution that the recovery faces challenges, including inflation above the Bank of England's 2% target and concerns about slowing growth in Asia and uncertainty in the euro zone economies.

The International Monetary Fund has issued a warning in a report, stating that Greece may face a financial shortfall of 11 billion euros over the next two years due to a persistent recession and the government's slow progress on reforms. This concern comes as Greece received a 4 billion-euro ($5.3 billion) aid package from its creditors, comprising the IMF, the European Commission, and the European Central Bank, on Wednesday. The latest financing gap may necessitate Greece's creditors to consider providing debt relief and additional funding to enable the country to meet the requirements of its current 172 billion-euro bailout program, which is an extension of the 110 billion-euro bailout program provided in 2010, according to the IMF. The Fund also cautioned that investment and growth in Greece are unlikely to recover unless investors are convinced that Greece's creditors have a credible plan to address the country's debt crisis. This warning has sparked alarm among some IMF officials, including Paulo Nogueira Batista, who represents Brazil and 10 other countries on the IMF board. Batista abstained from voting on additional aid to Greece earlier this week and said that the IMF's latest report shows an increasing awareness of the risks of the program going off track. He also noted a sense of despair among IMF staff, who are urging the Greek and euro-area authorities to uphold their commitments.

Hong Kong - Despite China's slowing economy and a less rosy outlook for Asia, Sotheby's has chosen Hong Kong as the location for the sale of a rare multimillion-dollar diamond in October. The auction house announced on Monday that "The Premier Blue," a 7.59-carat diamond, will be auctioned off on October 7 as part of its regular bi-annual sale series. Measuring about the size of a shirt button, the stone boasts a vivid blue color and a round cut, making it exceptionally rare. According to Quek Chin Yeow, deputy chairman of Sotheby's in Asia, the company expects the stone to fetch around $19 million, a record per-carat price for any diamond.

The Chinese Communist Party's anti-corruption drive has expanded into the oil sector, a powerful and sensitive area. This week, the authorities announced that four executives of state-owned China National Petroleum Corporation are under investigation. According to the Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of China, three oil executives - Li Hualin, a deputy general manager of China National Petroleum; Ran Xinquan, a vice president of PetroChina; and Wang Daofu, the chief geologist of PetroChina - are suspected of serious disciplinary violations and are currently undergoing investigation by an anti-corruption agency. PetroChina also confirmed that the three executives were under investigation and had resigned due to personal reasons. A day earlier, authorities announced an investigation into Wang Yongchun, a deputy general manager of China National Petroleum, for suspected disciplinary violations, which are often considered to be corruption, embezzlement, or bribery. The investigations suggest that the Communist Party's efforts to combat corruption extend beyond the government to powerful state-dominated industries. Party leader Xi Jinping, who came to power in November, had promised to tackle official corruption and self-enrichment, which has become a major source of public discontent.

Moscow - After years of delay, the largest oil field outside the Middle East has finally started producing crude, providing a significant new source of energy to meet the world's growing demand. Although the initial flow from the Kashagan field in Kazakhstan was limited, a consortium of oil companies, including Exxon Mobil and ConocoPhillips, plans to significantly increase production over the next few years. According to Claudio Descalzi, chief operating officer for exploration and production at Eni, the Italian oil company involved in the project, "This is one of the most complex projects in the world." He described the moment as "historic," citing the high quality of the oil and its proximity to rapidly growing markets. The field was first discovered in 2000, and at the time, it was the largest new oil deposit since the Prudhoe Bay field was discovered in Alaska in 1968. Even today, it remains one of the largest, highlighting the challenges of finding new oil sources.

Madrid, Spain - The country is on track to meet its 2013 budget deficit target agreed upon with the European Union and is expected to emerge from recession by the end of the year, according to the economy minister. Luis de Guindos, the minister, also announced that the government will not require additional one-time austerity measures in the 2014 budget, which will be presented this month. The budget will be based on an improved forecast for 2014, with projected growth and unemployment rates that are more optimistic than previously expected. De Guindos noted that Spain's economy has been in a state of recession since the construction bubble burst in 2008, but he is optimistic that 2014 will mark the beginning of a recovery. The European Commission granted Spain more time to meet its budgetary targets in May, given the severity of the recession. De Guindos expects Spain's deficit to fall to 6.5% of gross domestic product in 2014, down from 7% in 2013 and the initial target of 4.5%.

The Social Security Administration's website indicates that it is currently processing some spousal retirement claims and paying them according to schedule. If you and your spouse reside in a state where same-sex marriage is recognized, and you meet specific requirements (see below), the application process should be straightforward. However, an unresolved question remains regarding couples who were legally married in one state but relocated to another state that does not recognize gay marriage, and whether they can receive the same benefits. This is because the Social Security Administration currently uses a "place of residence" standard to determine spousal benefits. According to Susan Sommer, senior counsel at Lambda Legal, the agency has instructed its staff to accept and hold such applications pending further legal clarification. "We're awaiting guidance, and we're hopeful," she said. The agency is also holding other types of applications, such as those for survivor benefits, pending further clarification. Notably, Lambda Legal's Mary Bonauto expressed encouragement regarding the case of 83-year-old Herb Burtis, a musician and voice teacher from Western Massachusetts. Burtis had applied for survivor benefits after his husband's death in 2008, as they had married in 2004 when Massachusetts legalized same-sex marriage. Although his initial claim was denied, he became a plaintiff in a lawsuit that successfully challenged the Defense of Marriage Act, and is now receiving the extra payment, as well as a lump-sum payment for the past five years. Bonauto stated that there is "every reason to expect" that the agency will eventually process and pay survivor benefits to other eligible same-sex applicants. If you're considering applying for benefits, here are some key questions to consider:

# How do I know if I'm eligible for benefits? You must meet specific criteria.''' To qualify for spousal retirement benefits, you typically need to be at least 62 years old and have been married for at least 12 months. For the survivor's benefit, you must be at least 60 years old and have been married for at least nine months. If you meet the age and duration requirements, Ms. Bonauto recommends applying for benefits, despite any uncertainties. You can apply for spousal retirement benefits online at www.ssa.gov. However, you will need to visit a local Social Security office to apply for survivor's benefits; be sure to schedule an appointment in advance. GLAD suggests bringing a copy of your marriage license, civil union certificate, or domestic partnership certificate, as well as a copy of your spouse's death certificate, to your office visit. If you have questions, you can contact the regional communications director for your state, whose contact information is listed on the Social Security website.

The 1% or top 0.1% income bracket is not a fixed figure, as millions of individuals and households move up or down the income scale annually based on their earnings, investments, and age. The fortunes of new tech graduates and retiring lawyers fluctuate, but those with considerable capital, essentially the already wealthy, have fared well during the economic recovery. According to economists, the 1% tends to be resilient, and this is particularly true during bad times. A study by Treasury economists found that a quarter to a third of individuals in the 1% in a given year remained in that bracket for the following five years. As a result, the profile of wealth in the United States has remained relatively unchanged before and after the recession. The typical high-net-worth individual is coastal, educated, older, white, and male, said Mr. Friedman. Warren E. Buffett, the investor and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, exemplifies this profile, with his net worth increasing by approximately $10 billion over the past year due to his cash reserves and appetite for acquisitions. The tech industry has created hundreds of new top earners, mostly men, although often younger. David Duffield of Workday and Elon Musk of Tesla, among others, have benefited from the tech boom. Meanwhile, fields like finance, medicine, and energy continue to generate significant wealth, with financiers and business owners dominating the ultra-high-net-worth category. Three interconnected economic phenomena - stocks, houses, and loans - have driven the boomerang effect among the country's top earners, economists said. The rich suffered significant losses when the markets plummeted in 2008 and 2009, but those who held on or invested after then have been rewarded, with every dollar invested in the Dow Jones in 2009 now worth approximately $1.40 after correcting for inflation. The recent market gains have boosted the earnings and net worth of Americans who own stocks, primarily through vehicles such as mutual funds. However, the wealthy have benefited significantly more. According to Edward Wolff, a New York University economist, the top 10% of households hold more than 80% of the value of stocks, either directly or through investments like mutual funds. In addition to capital gains from selling their shares, shareholders have also benefited from the surge in dividend payments. Many companies paid out large dividends, totaling around $260 billion, before taxes on unearned income increased in January. Another factor contributing to the wealth gap is housing. Wealthier Americans tend to have a smaller portion of their net worth tied up in their homes, so the nationwide decline in housing prices had a less significant impact on them. However, after prices dropped and credit markets relaxed, many of them were able to purchase homes as investments.

Lael Brainard, the United States' chief financial diplomat, is set to leave her post at the end of the week, according to a Treasury official. Some have speculated that the White House might appoint her to a position on the Federal Reserve's Board of Governors. As the Under Secretary for International Affairs since the beginning of the Obama administration, Ms. Brainard has played a key role in negotiations over China's economic rebalancing and Europe's sovereign debt crisis. In her capacity as a shuttle diplomat, she has attended numerous meetings with foreign finance ministers and central bankers, experience that could be valuable at the Fed. Global concerns persist that the tapering of the current asset-buying program could lead to rising interest rates and the bursting of "Bernanke bubbles" abroad. Ms. Brainard is also well acquainted with the White House's nominee for Fed Chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, with whom she has worked closely in recent years to address the fallout from the deepest downturn since the Great Depression.

The German economy outpaced all other Group of 7 nations in growth last year, according to official data released on Wednesday. However, the pressures of the euro crisis and a slowing global economy seem to be already affecting output. Germany's economy grew by 3 percent in 2011 compared to 2010, according to the Federal Statistical Office in Wiesbaden. Notably, most of this growth occurred in the first half of 2011, and the office estimates that the economy actually shrank by around 0.25 percent in the fourth quarter compared to the previous three months. Some economists now predict that Germany's economy will contract again in the first quarter of 2012, which would meet the typical definition of a recession as two consecutive quarters of declining output. Despite this, Germany's 2011 growth rate of 3 percent still outstripped Canada's growth rate of "a little over 2 percent" and the United States' growth rate of "1.7 percent or a little more", according to Ralph Solveen, an economist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt.

In Europe, stocks experienced a modest decline on Monday following confirmation that Spain had slipped back into recession in the first quarter of 2012. According to the National Statistics Institute in Madrid, Spain's economy contracted by 0.3 percent between January and March, mirroring the same rate of decline seen in the final quarter of 2011. A recession is typically defined as two consecutive quarters of economic decline. The Euro Stoxx 50 index, which tracks euro zone blue-chip stocks, fell 1.6 percent by the end of trading, while the FTSE 100 index in London dropped 0.7 percent. While the economic news from Spain was not as dire as expected, with a Reuters poll predicting a quarterly contraction of around 0.4 percent, the country's economy still shrank by 0.4 percent compared to the same period a year earlier.

L. Rafael Reif, a seasoned electrical engineer and MIT provost for the past seven years, has been appointed as the institution's next president. At 61, Mr. Reif will take office on July 2, succeeding Susan Hockfield, who announced her resignation in February. As provost, Mr. Reif spearheaded the development of MITx and edX, the institute's groundbreaking online initiatives, and expanded MIT's global presence through projects in Abu Dhabi, Singapore, and Russia. He also played a key role in nurturing the emergence of an innovation hub adjacent to MIT in Kendall Square. During the 2008 financial downturn, Mr. Reif oversaw a process that eliminated a $50 million structural deficit. A native of Venezuela, Mr. Reif has been a part of the MIT community since 1980, serving as head of the department of electrical engineering and computer science, the institute's largest department, before becoming provost. He is recognized for his research on semiconductors and has been a driving force behind MIT's innovation and growth.

To avert a potential trade war, Mexican tomato growers announced on Thursday that they are willing to accept significant price increases for their products entering the US market and establish a system to improve compliance and enforcement. This move comes as the US Commerce Department weighs the fate of a 16-year-old agreement between the US and some Mexican growers, which American tomato farmers claim keeps Mexican tomato prices artificially low, making it difficult for them to compete. To keep the agreement intact, the Mexican growers are proposing a 18-25% increase in the minimum price per pound of tomatoes sold in the US, depending on the type of tomato. Additionally, they have pledged to extend the agreement to all Mexican growers exporting to the US, currently around 85%, which will enhance compliance and enforcement, according to Martin Ley, a member of the Mexican delegation negotiating with US trade officials and vice president of Del Campo Supreme, a family business that exported $60 million in tomatoes to the US and Canada last year.

A recent survey reveals that financial struggles affect the academic performance of approximately one-third of all college students, and a similar number of students frequently skip purchasing required academic materials due to the costs. The burden of college expenses on families and former students is well-documented in an era of stagnant incomes and rising tuition and student debt. According to the National Survey of Student Engagement, financial concerns are a significant source of stress for undergraduates while they are still in school. The survey found that nearly three-fifths of students often worry about having enough money to cover everyday expenses, and students who work the most hours at part-time jobs tend to feel the most financial stress. Among those who work over 20 hours a week, about three-fifths reported that their jobs interfered with schoolwork. "For too many students, financial struggles are a major obstacle to achieving their academic goals," said Alexander C. McCormick, director of the survey, which polled 285,000 students at 577 four-year colleges and universities in the United States and Canada.

Recent surveys of consumer and business confidence have reached recession-era lows, sparking widespread uncertainty. In response, businesses have scaled back their spending on capital investments, such as computers, delivery trucks, and equipment, likely due to concerns over higher tax rates and the potential consequences of government cutbacks. With capital expenditures already weak, some economists believe that businesses will increase spending if Congress can provide clarity on fiscal policy, reducing the risk of severe tightening. According to Nigel Gault, chief US economist at IHS Global Insight, "Businesses must have a list of projects they'd like to pursue, but have been delaying due to uncertainty. Once they have a clearer understanding of the future, including tax rates, they'll be able to revive those plans and implement them." Improved access to credit can make capital expenditures more attractive and accessible. Commercial and industrial loans have been increasing in recent months, according to the Federal Reserve, and the National Federation of Independent Business reports that the share of small business owners struggling to meet their credit needs has been declining. Additionally, corporate profits reached a record high in the third quarter, adjusted for inflation, and companies have accumulated significant cash reserves that can be used to invest in equipment or hire staff if they feel confident about the recovery. In contrast, consumers are still not financially flush, particularly since their disposable income has been stagnant or declining in recent months. However, consumers have made significant progress in reducing their debt, either by paying it down or having it written off through default, and they are also feeling more affluent due to the stabilization of the housing market. The country has finally cleared the excess housing inventory from the bubble years, and housing prices and construction are now on the rise. The pace of household formation is increasing, as young adults are finally moving into their own homes, as well as other Americans who had previously lived with family or friends. According to Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics, "We're making steady progress, with more job opportunities emerging, particularly for younger households. Eventually, young people can only live with their parents for so long. There are strong forces driving them to leave, both from the parents' perspective and the young adults', and as soon as they have the opportunity, many will take it."

Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, speaking at a two-day labor-management conference in Denver on Tuesday, suggested that teachers' unions can play a crucial role in addressing the challenges facing public schools. However, this view was being challenged in several state capitals as the conference began. In recent weeks, Republicans in various states have proposed legislation that would restrict teachers' unions to only negotiating compensation, excluding them from all other policy discussions. In Tennessee and Wisconsin, Republicans have gone further, proposing to strip teachers' unions of their collective bargaining rights entirely. According to education historians, this is the most hostile political climate teachers' unions have faced since states began granting them legal bargaining rights decades ago. The conference, organized by the Department of Education, brought together school administrators and teachers' union leaders from 150 districts across the country to discuss ways to work collaboratively. To participate, each district's superintendent, school board president, and teachers' union leader had to sign a pledge committing to work together in good faith to improve student achievement.

In Frankfurt, German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schauble cautioned on Thursday that a Greek debt default could have severe and unpredictable consequences. However, his comments also left the door open for a less drastic solution, where Greece could be granted more time to settle its debts. "We have no precedent for what happens when a country within a currency union becomes insolvent," Schauble said in an interview published in the German newspaper Handelsblatt. European leaders have started openly discussing the possibility of extending the repayment period for Greek debt, despite fierce opposition from the European Central Bank. Schauble's comments were seen by some as a sign that he has moved closer to the central bank's stance.

The US trade deficit unexpectedly decreased in April, with the country selling a record-breaking $175.6 billion worth of goods and services abroad. According to the Commerce Department's report, released on Thursday, exports of goods totaled $126.4 billion and services $49.1 billion, while imports reached $219.2 billion, resulting in a trade deficit of $43.7 billion - the lowest since December. The revised March deficit was $46.8 billion, down from the initial estimate of $48.2 billion. Economists had predicted the deficit would widen to $48.8 billion. A weaker US dollar has made American goods more competitive overseas, while rising demand in developing countries has driven up export prices. The Commerce Department attributed the April increase in exports to higher sales of industrial supplies, capital goods, and consumer goods. The decline in imports was partly due to a decrease in automotive parts, vehicles, and industrial supplies, the department said.

European finance ministers announced on Saturday that they have made significant progress towards finding a comprehensive solution to the debt crisis during a two-day meeting of the Group of 20 industrial nations. Despite ongoing challenges that could exacerbate the crisis, officials have agreed to take all necessary measures to stabilize the financial system and contain the troubles. Although details were not provided, officials aim to introduce a comprehensive plan at a meeting on October 23 in Brussels. US Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner, who has urged the Europeans to take swift action to prevent the crisis from spreading globally, expressed encouragement at the pace and direction of their efforts, as well as commitments from France and Germany to find a solution. However, Geithner emphasized that the true impact of Europe's efforts will depend on the details, which are difficult to assess until the plan takes shape.

The University of Chicago's new Joe and Rika Mansueto Library is a futuristic building with a unique design, featuring no traditional book stacks. While many of its nearly one million items, including special collections, journals, dissertations, and documents, can be accessed online, the library has also invested in innovative technology. Unlike other academic libraries that are digitizing and moving their collections offsite, the Mansueto Library is one of the largest and latest to incorporate automated storage and retrieval systems. The library's volumes are stored in solid steel cases located about 50 feet below ground, and books can be retrieved through a complex system of cranes and elevators, reminiscent of the door-sorting machine from Pixar's "Monsters Inc."

The $81 million Mansueto Library has a capacity for 3.5 million volumes, freeing up space in the main library's cramped stacks that students typically browse. Interestingly, the Mansueto Library also features a lab that serves two purposes: digitization and conservation. The lab not only mends paper and rebinds the university's books, including some ancient papyrus volumes, but also cleans and prepares materials for scanning, which are then shared with partner Google Books.

Despite budget cuts of over $30 million for the next two years, the Brownsville Independent School District is working to maintain funding for its chess program. This year, the district has allocated $400,000 for chess, a significant investment that sets it apart from other school districts nationwide. According to Jay Harris, who oversees the program, Brownsville's commitment to chess is unparalleled. As a border city struggling with poverty, the district sees chess as a valuable tool for student success and a source of community pride. This year, around 4,000 students have signed up for the district's chess programs, which include regular tournaments. Harris notes that it's common to see 500 to 800 students attending these events.

James Anthony, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, is often surprised to discover that many other iPhone and iPod Touch developers share his programming background. Like him, they learned the ins and outs of Apple's hit mobile devices through Stanford's popular iPhone applications course, which debuted in fall 2008 to a packed lecture hall. However, while Anthony took the class as a senior at Stanford, many other Apple developers have learned through free video recordings of lectures on iTunes U, which often ranks as one of the most downloaded courses. According to Anthony, Stanford's online class is currently the primary way to learn about iPhone development. However, online students miss out on the benefits of in-person learning, such as attending office hours or receiving email responses from instructors. Unfortunately, this term's classes are not available online, although past sessions have typically been uploaded to iTunes U within two to three days. Stanford is unable to discuss Apple's new iPad, which is part of the spring syllabus, due to rights issues. However, a lecture from last winter's term by Apple software engineer Evan Doll provided valuable tips for iPad programming. Despite the limitations, classes from past years offer iPhone developers a rare opportunity to gain insight from Apple itself, which is notoriously secretive about its communications.

Ken Meyer and Carmine Fiore exchanged handshakes in the kitchen, while their daughters, Sabina Meyer and Stephanie Fiore, pondered logistical challenges at opposite ends of Room 227 on moving-in day at Queens College's sole dormitory. Stephanie Fiore, for instance, was struggling to find a place to store her extensive shoe collection, as her closet already seemed too small to accommodate all her clothing. Meanwhile, on the floor above, new roommates Letticia Camacho and Juliet Dolan giggled at the unusual coincidence of having brought items that shared a matching color scheme: turquoise-and-purple hangers, storage boxes, and sheets. On the fifth floor, Mohamed Sako left his dorm room door ajar and his stereo playing, with the lyrics to Nicki Minaj's "Your Love" drifting into the hallways: "You got spark, you, you got spunk." Living on campus is a privilege reserved for 500 of the approximately 20,000 students at Queens College, which is primarily a commuter college located in a corner of Flushing that is easily accessible by car and bus, but not by subway. The Summit, as the dorm is officially known, offers rooms with full kitchens, cable TV, wireless internet access, and private bathrooms. The dorm has a hotel-like atmosphere, with carpeted hallways, a glass-encased gym, and a lobby featuring flat-screen TVs. For its residents, it is a convenient and enviable living arrangement. For the college, it serves as a valuable recruitment tool.

As part of a project aimed at developing innovative methods for evaluating teachers, researchers have recruited 3,000 educators from seven school districts across the United States. These districts include Dallas, Denver, Charlotte, North Carolina, Hillsborough County, Florida, Memphis, New York, and Pittsburgh. To participate, the teachers agreed to be videotaped in their classrooms, with the understanding that only researchers would have access to the recordings, not school administrators. The participants are comprised of teachers from grades four to nine in regular public schools. To showcase the project for The New York Times, The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation requested that teachers in Charlotte and Memphis volunteer to record additional classes, with the understanding that these recordings would not be bound by the confidentiality provisions. One teacher who volunteered was Rachael Maher, a seventh-grade math teacher at Alexander Graham Middle School in Charlotte. For an hour, Ms. Maher taught her students the Pythagorean theorem while digital video equipment captured a panoramic view of the classroom. A few days later, two scorers from the Educational Testing Service, a nonprofit organization based in Princeton, New Jersey, reviewed the video footage to critique Ms. Maher's performance. Edith Aurora Graf and Leslie Thornley, the scorers, watched the video multiple times, much like coaches reviewing game footage. They noted Ms. Maher's rapport with her students, her pacing, and the way she transitioned from direct instruction to group work.
